It's actually possible to move too fast at this company,
column13: Navigating the great bureaucracy. Sometimes feels like we produce nothing but excel and PowerPoint pitches. It takes a lot of stakeholder management and working across and up the matrix to get anything done. In the midst of a pretty significant drive to change to a more entrepreneurial culture. An ambitious and worthy goal but a long way to go.
column14: We are much further away from empowerment and delegation of authority than we care to admit. Try allowing for open ratings of managers , incorporating a system similar to glass door where employees can submit public feedback on working for a manager. This would drive a huge culture change around empowerment and leadership.

column12: people are dedicated and passion about their work
column13: management does not provide the resources to do the job
column14: provide the resources to your team so they can do the job right

column12: they pay you what they say they will. that's about it
column13: literally everything. Put one screw in one hole all day. Smoking only across the street. Ridiculous job, really.

column12: Projects, capabilities, security, some work life balance
column13: lack of opportunity for growth

column5: Challenging Work Environment, Not Great Benefits
column12: GE is an established company with well-established product development plans. There was clear and concise information from management about the program goals at the front end of the project, but they were willing to adjust those goals depending on feedback from other groups. GE has a number of process and systems in place to promote and challenge their employees. The company is so large and diverse, there is never a lack of opportunity within the company.
column13: GE continually challenges its employees, which can lead to stressful work situations. The benefits were not great when I was there. New employees (regardless of previous work experience) were given 2 weeks of vacation. There was pressure on the employees to not take much vacation during the year but to save it for around the end of the year (most employees take off the last two weeks of the year). In addition, the healthcare contribution was significant for families and were high deductible plans.
column14: The company has a good vision and good overall technical and project management, but better benefits and work/life balance would be helpful for employee retention.

column12:
Decent pay
Decent benefits
Good work environment (not noisy, climate controlled, takes safety seriously)
column13:
WAY too many meetings/too much time spent on meetings. 
Seriously, most of us know our jobs really well. A quick 5-10 minute meeting in the morning is understandable. But two 15-20 minute meetings at shift start and shift end AND a State-of-the-unionesque all hands meeting on thursdays? Plus random extended meetings during the week? And the meetings are always about how we're not meeting our production quota? Maybe not spending 3 hours a week in meetings would help. 

WAY overzealous HR. Do not trust them. They smile in your face and pretend to be your best friend, but they will kick you to the curb in a heartbeat. Very SJW and PC. If anyone hears you make a non PC joke or something (which tends to happen in a factory!), you will get fired mercilessly with no chance to correct your behavior. 

Also, CONSTANT material problems. They're trying to be like toyota and do "Just in time" and "lean manufacturing". Look, that only works when you have a steady and constant supply of parts. When you are running almost every unit through the line without all the parts needed and then setting the units aside in a graveyard, you need to stop complaining that we aren't putting out enough units and then putting us on mandatory overtime.
column14:
Seriously, put the HR department on a tight leash. It's manufacturing, not a tea party. Guys talk. They make jokes. Deal with it. 

FIX THE MATERIAL SUPPLY.

column12: Exposure to many industries. Breadth of product offerings.
column13: Complexity, politics, tough for new arrivals.
column14: Break down the political camps.

column12: Great people, great work life balance(vacation, flexibility, maternity/paternity) and good pay. I personally had great career growth in my time there. Great leadership programs and training (if you get in/them).
column13:
My cons are specific to GE's current climate; currently it is a tough time and that trickles into everything you as an employee cares about. 

Career growth is difficult at this time, unless you are willing to give everything for the company and smooch smooch smooch, it is difficult because there are so many people being laid off that are trying to stay.
Compensation is being "hit" by the current environment; no raises, low to no bonuses, and even 401k hits.
Job stability.
 
Once GE rights the ship (because I know they will), my cons list goes down to just job stability.
column14: Keep being positive, but also honest in particular with those that are/will be affected by the current climate within the company. I am hoping and pulling for you to right the ship. You are a great company and needs to pull through for us who had the pleasure of working there, for the US, and for the customers.

column5: You will find a better opportunity elsewhere
column12: Benefits are just good enough.
column13: Poorly managed, metric obsessed & only care is to report 'green' artificially to get bonuses.

column12: It was gainful employment at the time
column13: They work you like a dog

column12: Don't know of any, unless you are an EE and really need a job with medical insurance, 401K etc...
column13: Incompetence on all levels i encountered. From team leads and team members up to 1-3 line management. Have not had to deal with anybody higher than that. A lot of politically correct nonsense, as in most big companies. Probably the worst HR I have ever had to deal with. Med. insurance premiums were taken out of my paycheck regularly, but when I needed to go to a doctor turned out HR messed up my paperwork, actually did not even send it to insurance company, so I had no coverage. Premiums deducted for nothing (as it turned out) were never reimbursed back to me. I left company on my own accord. Could not bear this total lack of understanding of what it takes to get the project done; and, consequentially, having to pay for management's mistakes by working overtime, that was not compensated in any way. Most of my colleagues, with few exceptions, were incompetent too, worked for meager salaries, cannot imagine them being hired by any really professional company. Six months after I left, got a call from collection agency, stating that GE submitted me to collection agency for "overpayment of salary". GE HR could not even get my last day at work correctly nor my mailing address. Took several weeks to straighten this mess out and for GE HR/payroll to admit their mistake. No bonuses, no overtime pay, short vacations, not so good med insurance or 401K. Salaries (for Software Engineers) are generally lower than industry average. That was my experience. Your mileage may vary

column12:
Unique work projects
Dynamic Environment
column13:
Low pay
Benefits not that great
Poor employee recognition
column14: Admire and appreciate employee that are deticated to your company

column12: The people are committed and were enjoyable to work with.
column13: As a former employee, I hope the company can turn financials around.
column14: None

column12: Telework, company paid mobile device and permissive time off.
column13: Pay is not consistent among employees. A lot of layoffs which creates heavier workload for others.

column12: GE is making decent revenue in this economy despite being labeled "a bank". For the most part, experienced professionals at GE are smart, hard working, process oriented and respectful. I work with bright people who really want to make a difference despite cost cutting. High integrity. Good work/life balance.
column13: Employee compensation and benefits nowhere near where they used to be. You DO NOT work for GE for the pay or benefits anymore. Those days are over. Only those in leadership training programs get the worthwhile promotions...regardless of their knowledge and accomplishments. Budgets have been cut so drastically, you'll be working with MS Office 2000 and IE 6. Projects for the past few years have been focused on cost cutting. Not really any good new projects.
column14: I used to be excited and proud working for GE. Now, after 10 years, I have become disheartened. You have allowed the stock price to cloud your judgment. You have slashed benefits, bonuses, salary increases, stock options, employee rewards, all in a desperate attempt to lower expenses to increase the stock price. The stock price is still down and employee morale is even lower. Over the past 3 years I have witnessed scores of talented people leave GE. I look around during all hands meetings and I see only average people. The good people are gone and you can't blame them.

column12:
GE has a great brand, sure, and I believed that a good bit of that was self-congratulatory hype but I don't think that's the case now. In all honesty, it's a huge enterprise but all of my colleagues and managers were bright people, doing their best. I never felt like the smartest person in the room, but I never worked with an idiot either.

I can't emphasize how important it is to have a company where people are taught management skills. This means that the worst manager can get called on the carpet and send to "work on his/her skills" - so the overall culture is one where baseline management skills are relatively high.

It's a culture of (genuine) integrity. You'll get tossed out for bad behavior. Everybody gets their hands dirty - super-senior leaders will double check the numbers.
column13: Really demanding. Expect to be on call a lot. I took my phone to funerals, weddings, never went on a vacation without my laptop.
column14: Is there anything left to say? I loved it, I hated it, it molded my work character.

column12: good time off & health benefits
column13: culture & upper management can be demanding

column5: GE is a strong company with strong management. You can be confident that GE will continue to stay strong.
column12: GE is an outstanding place to learn and grow. Excellent senior management. When we have access to them, we learn a tremendous amount. GE offers great training and a culture of training and growth. People really do love working for GE and that enthusiasm helps motivate employees. I also feel that good work and analysis is well rewarded at GE. If you go above and beyond, you will be recognized. However, if you just do the standard work and perform fairly, GE will keep you around but you will never advance. GE seems to keep people around for a long time despite strong or poor performance.
column13: Bureaucracy can at times be stifling and employees are not empowered to make decisions. It would help to have more transparency within the company. Employees don't often know what is going on. Some senior leaders are excellent with communication and even during hard times, they are honest and straightforward with employees. Other senior leaders need to learn these lessons as well. Another downside is that there is no known clear path to promotions. People really don't know what to do to get promoted. There is sometimes a black box for how decisions are made. Employees should have a better understand of this.
column14: Listen to your employees and value their opinions and feedback.

column5: Great place to work if you like a challenge and are willing to work hard!
column12: Great place to develop your skills and be challenged. The talent working there keeps you striving for better performance all the time. Don't be shy...ask for more challenge...you'll be surprised how much they will give to you. True meritocracy ... early career and new hires have great opportunities for advancement, the same as seasoned professionals. The training and benefits are world class. Check out ecomagination.ge.com and learn about how GE is changing the future. It's amazing. Lastly, the philanthropic arm is donating money and equipment to needy orgs in US and abroad. The company is one of the most respected in the world for a reason: great talent, opportunities, advancement, growth, challenge, rewards.
column13: Long hours, big company to navigate if you don't put in the effort to understand the organization
column14: Ensure managers can understand what's important to motivate and challenge and retain the Gen Y, Gen X and baby boomers. Sometimes the same...often different. Not being flexible in leadership style will cause talent to leave.

column5: Great place to start a career in finance
column12: I came to GE Energy right out of college and went through their FMP program. I HIGHLY recommend this program. It wasn't until I left GE that I realized how much I had actually learned. Not all my managers were 'good managers,' but I think that's a good lesson to learn when you're young. The program is highly competitive, pays well for a job right out of school, and certainly provides many opportunities. After this role, I took an FP&A job in one of the energy divisions. My work/life balance was great, I enjoyed my role, my manager was an amazing mentor, and I loved the people I worked with. Since leaving GE, I have been very impressed by how well respected GE's finance division is. Having that on my resume has been very beneficial in finding post GE jobs. To top it off, I made some incredible life long friends here.
column13: The pay at GE is not very competitive and this is ultimately why I left.
column14: FMP program is amazing! Keep good managers of the program, it makes a difference. Mine was amazing!

column5: 23 years at GE - 5 businesses in 4 locations in NE US
column12: Huge field of opportunities to grow; amazingly talented people. Competitive pay and benefits. Very strong values around integrity (ethics), from the top down.
column13: I worked for GE from 1989 to 2012. I was - and am - proud to have worked there. However, I saw two trends emerge around 2005 that bothered me - and it took me 7 years to decide to move on.
column14: Two trends that made it a different company than the one I joined in '89. 1) Selection of leaders became waaayyyyy more subjective and based on pedigree and personal relationships than on credibility with the workforce and good leadership skills. 2) The company's values shifted sharply to the left after Jeff I took over, and never moved back to the center, at least while I was there. I left in 2012. I'd still recommend the company to about anyone - just know that you're going to be in a culture that rewards liberal values.

column12: Stimulating work environment. Problem solving.
column13: Rotating shifts. Lots of hours.
column14: Soon weekly shift rotations will be illegal.

column12:
Nice people
Flexible place to work
Summer hours
column13:
Pay
Feels more like old school corporate rather than family

column5: Hard-edge culture that they are trying to fix
column12: It's a big company, so there are many different types of roles you can do at GE. It's in a number of different industrial businesses, so that provides variety. It's also global, so there are opportunities to work with people around the world and learn from them.
column13: The culture is very cut-throat. GE is trying to be more of a "we" culture, but many of the senior leaders got to where they are during a period when "looking-out-for-me" was how you did it, so it's a battle. I had peers (including Senior Executives and VPs) who stole my ideas, slides, etc. and used them as if they were their own. This was called "getting your lunch money stolen," so they even had a term for the phenomena. The culture is also insular: training (including company sponsored MBA programs) is done at GE-only facilities; I did attend one training session where outside businesses were discussed, but mostly the topics were GE-centered, so there was a limited opportunity to learn how others do it; best practice sharing was across GE...very little with others; non-GE-run training was discouraged. Also, the downside of being big is that it can take a lot of time to get things done, although they have worked pretty hard to move decisionmaking down closer to the customer.
column14: Keep focusing on making GE a "we" company, not a "me" company. Perhaps after a generation of "we" you'll be where you want to be.

column12: Not killing yourself and work indoors, old pay scale $37.71/hour, new hires top at $32/hour and no pension for new hires.
column13: Awful benefits and union contracts. Company has done some sketchy business practices

column12: It's basically a city job. Busy when there's work, dead when there isn't.
column13: Management and coworkers can tend to be rude and insult you under the guise of jokes.

column12:
good
good life and work balance depending on manager
unlimited vacation
column13:
hard to move up
some managers are still old fashioned 
lots of politics
column14: please have less on top

column12: Some work life balance, when not traveling.
column13: No work life balance during travel periods.

column12: Great team to work with
column13: General company direction not clear
column14: Great management

column12: You are surrounded by many intelligent people, managers are usually very experienced, and you learn a great deal vs. other companies. Development is top notch and second to none. I would say that I learned more at this company than where I am currently. I worked hard but learned a great deal.
column13: If you aren't on the fast track in certain key leadership programs or working in an area they need expertise (Tax, Legal, any government facing compliance role) you will be underpaid. Most employees will be paid less than market, and there is no incentive to stay with the company if you aren't in the select group they pick their leaders from and don't breathe and live the culture. Work life balance in finance was nonexistent. Unfortunately, the company for many is a resume builder.
column14: Management knows that the company's culture is so strong that they can retain most of their top leaders and develop up and coming leaders who will stay; the other employees who are not on that track will leave once they learn that they are not compensated fairly. In order to retain your employees, especially the younger generations, you will need to compensate them more. As the economy improves and younger workers show less and less company loyalty, relying on your culture won't cut it.

column12:
GE has a fantastic culture. Integrity in the workplace is a priority and you feel the difference. 
GE provides ample opportunities for training and exposure to some of the best leaders in industry. Great place to start your career.
column13: GE doesn't pay well. Their benefits are also no longer that great, although, they do still maintain a pension plan which is rare. You just have to work there for 20yrs to make it worth while.
column14:
The old saying still seems to hold true... "If you want a decent bump in salary at GE, quit and come back." I applied for my old job 3yrs after leaving the company and they were willing to give me $20K. I didn't take it because it was still low compared to another competing offering. 
Advice: People like working at GE. However, it's tough for employees to afford to stay. GE needs to consider the cost around keeping experienced folks vs the cost of hiring, training, and then continually losing the next decent employee to better paying companies.

column12: It is a large company. Offer good pay
column13: It is a large company and very political

column5: Great place for the right type of person. Definitely not for everyone.
column12: GE is a very diverse and dynamic organization. If you are the type of person who will actively manage their own career, opportunities abound. However, you must be willing to relocate to just about anywhere in the world to truly be successful. The employee experience really varies from one business to the next. Overall, the benefits and respect for employees is good. Of course, there are some businesses where this is not the case. The good thing is, every 2 years you are free to apply to any internal job your qualified for!
column13: You will get no career management from them. They pretend to be interested in managing the top talent, it simply isn't true. Moving around such a big company also has it's pitfalls. It is entirely possible to land in an unsuccessful business without even realizing it at first. Once there, it is hard to get out....
column14: They need to get back to managing for the long term success of the company and not just Quarterly numbers....

column12: Fantastic place to learn and think like an entrepreneur regardless of the job function. Everyone is expected to have well thought out their ideas and encouraged to speak-up. Leadership training is offered to those who have the "sponsorship" from one of the company officers. Therefore <10% people end-up in executive ranks. Functionally, those in Sales or Finance are valued the most. The rest end up being worker bees for their lives.
column13: Very intrinsically focused for a company that has better than average products. GE is good at acquiring businesses that have good products. However, GE is weak in Product Management. As a result, there is little improvement on products over next 5-10years even though a huge amount is spent on product development. Once competitors catch-up, GE starts lowering its price and hence takes a margin hit. This goes on until the product is unattractive and then GE divests the company.
column14: Cut down the multiple layers. Adding a layer to bring two or three businesses under one umbrella doesn't help. The synergies are not there and hence 1+1+1 is not greater than 3.

column5: Better stay away from GE at this time.
column12: Great people, large organization, some training opportunities, technical engagements.
column13: GE is going through a mess right now; financially/organizationally/leaders jumping ship. The job security is very volatile with leaders being clueless about software (though GE wants to be a software company). Regular layoffs & scramble to find a job inside GE (only will succeed in finding an internal if you know the "right" people not if you have the "right skills"). HR is only looking at every employee as a number, irrespective of ones' skills and achievements. The Detroit location is led by poor leadership and is being looked upon as a money saving opportunity (layoff people or move to a better tax discounted area). There is a lot of effort to ask people to move to Rhode Island or Miami. There was a round of layoff in MI in Nov, 2018 (around 300 people), the only reason given was "we are pulling out of Detroit" (Can you believe it - not due to cost pressures, not due to performance but due to location strategy change???). Local HR is unresponsive to say the least.
column14: Treat your people well and do not look at them as just numbers or cost saving opportunities. if you want to be a software company - people with skills are your asset. Unfortunately its not the same GE anymore!

column12: Teaming environment makes workers feel empowered when it works. Work is performed inside. Tools are provided. Flexible hours.
column13: Teaming environment is just a trick to avoid paying middle managers and keep workers fighting amongst themselves too much to organize. Pay is not on par with the responsibilities required—you are expected to be more than just a tech but the pay does not reflect this. Production goals are not based on technicians working a 40 hr week. Overtime is not required on paper but is required for teams to meet production goals—at the end of the day the only thing that truly matters is output numbers. Policies constantly change based on the current site consensus. Gatekeeping tactics are being implemented with the tech level requirements, as one group advances they change the requirements behind them making it harder to advance. Support staff are actively involved in decisions affecting technician pay without their own pay even being known. Techs are subject to termination if they don’t comply with certain time requirements yet support staff can blatantly disregard these with no repercussions.
column14: Keep support staff out of any discussions that concern technician pay. Tech pay should not be disclosed to support staff just as theirs is not disclosed. This creates a rift that no amount of teaming will fix. If we are truly all at the same level in a “flat” organization, then this unspoken hierarchy of white collar over blue collar has to go away.

column12: Very good Salaries and decent Benefits
column13:
Management Hubris
Too much focus on financials over market edge and vision
column14: Stop leading only by the numbers. Lead with a total vision in mind.

column5: Working in the World of GE.
column12: GE is a global network of professional opportunity. The company affords great benefits - including a flexible work schedule that enables one to truly work towards a healthy work/life balance. This has been key for me personally. I have been with GE for 6 years and was able to work from home for 4 of those.
column13: Can be highly political, very intense...if one does function well in a pressure cooker then this probably wouldn't be the best work environment for him/her. As mentioned above the having the flexibility to work from how was a great perk. However, the downside is that there is never really a day off...it's a highly competitive work environment and it can be somewhat relentless. It was not uncommon to have to address work issues and to work on holidays, weekends and vacations. No one in the business ever truly shuts down or turns off work.
column14: Leadership is key...it's important that the Senior Management truly lead and in doing so look to the resources that the staff/team has to offer.

column12:
- Diverse work in many businesses, is easier to translate skills from one to another
- Lots of on-line training courses available, if time to take them
- If you succeed as a manager in GE, can do well in most any company
column13:
-TOO lean in almost every business section. Push whos left to meet financial goals with less and less support. Normal managers work week is 55+hrs if you are to succeed, more normal 65+ hrs.
- Corporate Arrogance, some times forgets customer 
- Do more with less, makes cuts in name of six sigma until failure then takes years to correct.
- Lost focus on life/work balance, talk a good game but no actions around allowing more normal work week.
column14: Seems to have lost their way, GE has forgot it's core compantancies. Stock price has not increased in 8 years so leadership is not in touch with wall street or investors. Doing the right thing for the right reason is harder to find evidence of in most cases. Taking care of people are taking a back set to bottom-line financial plans, more concerned with double digit profit each quarter instead of focusing on long term performance. Seems to have a short term focus selling off non-profitable parts of the business at rock bottom instead of early in the down slide is more the normal in the past 3-4 years. I know we are smarter than that

column12: Benefits aren't too bad. They are however becoming increasingly worse. This is to be expected as most large companies continue screweing the workers that make the companies what they are.
column13: GE is way too political and too far in bed with the current administration running our government. The stock has tanked due to GE getting called to task on their shifty numbers padding to make the stockholders happy. The CEO has made too many wrong decisions and has relied too much on the Obama admin that he's become blinded and in-effective. The politics of this company is deplorable.
column14: Pay attention to the staff. Quit coming up with these endless useless "cover your ass" paperwork schemes in the guise of concern for worker safety. The permit-to-work program you adopted from the UK is a freaking joke, and is just another example of more beauracratic red-tape paperwork that only serves to hold up contractors and cost the comapny and contractors more money, and due to the heavy handedness of this red tape, you're sure to cause employess to take shortcuts which in turn will cause an injury. Too many unnecassary positions exist, and those people try to justify their existense by coming up with one program after another that either don't work, are cumbersome, or just plain duplicative in nature, and no-one has the balls to stand up and tell the initiator how stupid their idea is or how much money was wasted on that program.

column12: Products and peers. Flex schedule
column13: Pay and only promotes veterans

column12: Open Culture in management decisions
column13: Too many changes without transitions

column5: A high school kid could have done my job.
column12: Great health benefits.....until 2010 when they changed plans...and now they are similar to other large companies. Lots of available training and there is a huge knowledge base in your fellow employees. Opportunity to move within the company is pretty fluid.
column13: You are a small fish in a huge pond. My manager wouldn't know my name if it wasn't for my name tag. Design engineers are basically mini-managers of the drafters....who actually create all of the models, drawings, and BOM's. You will become an expert in powerpoint and quite frankly that is all you truely need to know to do my job. None of the "engineering" software programs communicate to each other. Therefore to complete seemingly simple tasks you have to use upwards of 4-5 programs to get the job done. They always say they are going to get rid of this long standing problem....but in turn they just create a new program, which just adds another to the list that you have to use to complete your work. Every year there is a massive reorganization of the COE and you get placed in new groups with new hardware and new projects. A lot of knowledge is lost with this constant reshuffling and months are lost trying to get up to speed on the new job.
column14: Fix the relationship between manufacturing and engineering. Decrease the frequency of reorganizations, this will create a better knowledge base.

column5: Fragmenting the business structure in Erie.
column12: Great job experience working with the few remaining senior engineers. Pay is good for the area.
column13:
There are a ton of job opportunities at GETS if you happen to live in Bangalore India. Retaining young talent at the Erie plant seems to no longer be a consideration. The current staff in Erie now devotes most I their time holding the hand of the team overseas because there is a "they cannot be allowed to fail" directive from engineering management. Senior engineers and senior mfg managers are retiring in droves and there is a huge gap in service experience looming in their absence. Rest assured though as these spots will all be filled overseas as this valuable knowledge that is being lost is obviously easily replaced, or so it seems.
Executives have split for Chicago to distance themselves from the union work force and a new mfg facility in Fort Worth TX has given them the leverage they need to slowly dismember the 506. 
Stressful place to be when you're wedged in the middle someplace.
column14: Place some value on the in house experience especially with the young talented engineers who are willing to stick around in a city like Erie Pa. Keep engineering in Erie. Then if the 506 leadership would pull their heads out of the sand and be a little more flexible GETS in Erie could once again be the place everyone wants to work.

column5: Relatively enjoyable career with some cons.
column12: Diverse portfolio allows for dynamic careers. Work-life balance has always been good for me. There is even significant paternity leave for fathers. I feel the amount of vacation and personal time off is overall generous (even after the permissive time off migration).
column13: Recent acquisitions have forced many layoffs of existing employees. With the threat of layoffs always hanging over our heads, and more work added to our plates due to layoffs, it just does not feel worth it to try and start a career here anymore.
column14: Quit thinking about how to make this quarter better, and start thinking of how to make the company better in the long run. If you take a few bruises to the stock price temporarily, long term gains could be higher. Every time executives speak to the public, their only concern is shareholder value. If you invest in making individual contributors fulfilled and less worried about their paycheck, then shareholder value could possibly fix itself.

column12: Flexible work hours (during non-close hours), trainings (non-work related), unlimited vacation (really depends on the manager or the team), relocation bonus
column13:
Management: Rude and clueless senior and executive management who do not care about their teams and will blame you for not have the job done even if things were out of your control. 

Work: Unrealistic work goals, redundant work processes, 15+ hour daily work weeks during close (Accounting/Finance groups), work on federal holidays and weekends, blame throwing on each other is part of the culture. Only certain teams are helpful while the rest feel like sharks in a tank. 

Benefits: Pay is extremely low compared to market average and raises are no more than 2%. Forget about being paid for further education or raises after achieving them. Medical is high deductible only and not affordable to most. Have to pay for monthly parking in the building. 

Career: GE Global ops started off with 1000+ employees in 2016 and now there less than 200 left in the center. You can imagine what the turn over rate is . Changing the teams is a strict process (18+ stay in current position required) with no possibilities for raises or promotions. GE's current reputation in the market has completely deteriorated so recruiters and companies know that you are desperate to get out. More importantly, the company overall is shrinking down at a massive rate and businesses are being closed down to cut down costs. Layoffs and firings are expected more in the upcoming year.
column14: Figure out the direction where the company is successful and then start caring about employees running it.

column12: There were none to list
column13: Everything about the job was horrible the people and the job we arrogant
column14: Start over

column5: Good Start for Exposure, Learning, Training but debatable as viable longer term career choice
column12: Leadership Development and training is excellent, with a wide variety of resources. Global exposure and solid operational mechanisms provide lots of internal infrastructure support. Variety of business experience exposure across various industries in finance, media, industrial, energy, medical, and transportation. Good benefits on par with large companies (401K, Health, Educational Reimbursement, etc.) and includes a pension.
column13: Tremendously political organization and substantial complexity...there is more rewards and focus on flooking good in style than on actual results. Struggles to really innovate and be nimble despite the depth of talent and financial resources. GE tends to take long term employees for granted in many ways, so beware that although it is a great place to start, it may not be such a great place to finish or stick around. Large amount of acquisitions in past several years has diluted the previous high performance GE culture substantially.
column14: Focus more on substance than style. Lots of mid and senior talent being lost because of substantial growth of politics within the new regime. Need to focus more on retention of people for the long term and true career talent management. Wall Street wants results and transparency and not a continued defense of the GE method being right. Down stock price for 5 years is telling it, more rapidity is needed to address.

column5: GE has provided me with unbelievable opportunities. I never would have imagined that I'd be doing the things I am doing.
column12: The obvious reasons to work at GE are its excellent history and reputation, wide breadth of industries, excellent training and many, many opportunities. There are endless types of jobs, locations and industries within GE. Less obvious reasons to work at GE are the excellent people. Not only is the GE leadership top notch, but the competency of the average employee is extremely high. Most people want to get the job done. People are very smart and very passionate about their jobs. The size and influence of GE is impressive. Whenever you encounter a problem in your job, you can tap the entire company's resources to help. Lastly, the global nature of many of GE's businesses make it an exciting place to work. I have friends and collegues all over the world and have had many opportunites to travel around the world.
column13: Work/life balance is not always the best at GE. Additionally, GE's strict penny pinching can get tiresome.
column14: None.

column5: Excellent leadership opportunities out of college, continued opportunities for those who "perform."
column12: You get the chance to work with some of the smartest people across industry. The management is top notch, and the grooming for the top performers keeps the pipeline full. It's not uncommon to see GE alumni in top executive jobs across the country. In my opinion, this is only because GE has an over supply of leaders, and unfortunately, there isn't enough room for all the talent that is brought up.
column13: Being a top performer generally entails more than 40 hour weeks. GE does like to run lean and efficiently, meaning the peak times will require you and your team to give a little more than your salary covers. Also, the new focus on specialization and expertise has narrowed the career paths somewhat. Cross-functional opportunities are much harder to find.
column14: Stop reorganizing the company. It's adding a lot of work which costs the company money.

column5: Very corporate environment but you can move up if you want to play that "game".
column12: If you like working in a corporate environment then maybe this is the place for you. You can advance but you need to be the type that enjoys corporate lingo and to be blunt it helps if you suck up to the right people.
column13: Extremely corporate environment. You feel very much like a cog in a wheel and that is how they like it. They try to keep the threat of layoffs hanging over you to keep you under control.
column14:
GE Security is GE's attempt at entering the highly technical business of security technology. The company is composed almost entirely of acquisitions. That is also how I came to be part of GE Security. 

However, GE applied their formula that has worked well for them in the past. That formula being to try and mass produce a technology with low skilled labor and to minimize the impact of a single engineer/scientist. Unfortunately, what they do not understand is that technologies in this sector are still burgeoning. They have to put more emphasis on R and D and put more value on the scientists and engineers that are researching the new technologies. If they keep acting like they are making locomotive engines and that they are working with a "mature" technology then they are in big trouble. Value your scientists and engineers.

column5: Great for managing your career path
column12:
- You do the work and company manages your career progression
- can work with multiple business without changing the company
- Provides exposure to various functional skill set early in the career
- Has great leadership programs at all level ( entry, mid level management etc)
- 60-80% people do not leave GE or come back. A great % of employee base has 10 , 20+ years with the company\
- It has a great culture ( integrity, people, extracurricular activities etc). GE almost has its on language. Both internal employees and customers can relate to the culture.
column13:
- Initial year in the company is difficult as its a huge company and finding your feet takes time. Everyone around you helps but just give your time.
- Pay scales may be low up front as GE gives you a brand name - but it catches up as you grow within GE
column14:
- Change is inevitable - make it simple for low level employees
- Please continue to keep GE as a powerhouse of mentoring great leaders from tech to finance.

column5: Great place to work and grow, Great for learning and leadership Training
column12: For gaining experience and leadership skills there is no company better. They invest a lot in the employees and they give plenty of opportunities to grow. They care about there employees and in situations where it maybe unsafe they will take every precaution to make sure it is safe.
column13: Its wont be the best paying job and its just as important to pick the right manager as it is to pick the right job. Once you have figured out the best way to do that you will go far. In GE during the first 5 years you will determine whether you love it or hate it.
column14: Be more competitive with your compensation. Finding, training, and growing great talent is a huge advantage that GE has over all other companies... Keeping them is the difficult part. If you are competitive with your compensation, salaries, you will keep the vast majority of your talent and it will pay off more then what was spent on salary in project execution.

column5: Great Place To Learn, Not so much for a Career
column12:
-If you are labeled as a top performer (I was), you are given many opportunities to attend various trainings and are given exposure to upper management
-Generally a very hard working and good workforce, good people to work with.
-Meritocracy (used to be more than now) where hard workers are rewarded for their efforts
-Job security, as long as you do your job you will have one because GE isn't going to go out of business anytime soon
column13:
-Bureaucracy. Not too long after Jack Welch left the company, the bureaucracy has grown like cancer. This is what you would expect from a culture that believes in Meritocracy, but the company is extremely slow to experience real "organic" growth, so this leaves limited positions for advancement. The bureaucracy hinders "outside of the box thinking" and leads the organization to seek after short term gains. 
-Leadership full of little "Napoloens" who rule their own domains with little concern for their employees or other domains
-Benefits are becoming less and less attractive. What used to be a generous stock, health care, and salary package has been whittled away to be average or below industry, even for top performers.
column14: Get rid of middle management. Look beyond the metrics. Grow the company (IP, products, industries), not just the bottom line. Reward the employees more fairly for the best years of their lives

column12:
They have great dedicated people that only God Knows why they stay
There are many opportunities within the OKC site since people have been leaving
If you have a sponsor there are opportunities within other GE divisions
If you like to get involved there are many groups and activities to be involved in like the Employee Activities Committee, United Way Campaign, Women's Network, Veteran’s Network, and Volunteer's Group
Since the acquisition most people are getting Green Belt trained (but not certified)
Great physical location in Oklahoma City
They have just installed Tornado shelters
Company provides coffee
column13:
Most managers are not in tune with their subordinates needs
Within Oklahoma City there is not much career growth
It is hard to get certified for your Green Belt because the data is not readily accessible
There is a lengthy workflow for everything
Most departments are busting at the seams with people
Thus, parking is a hassle
Some, not all, managers micromanage
Some, not all, managers do not promote career growth with their people
In some departments there are too many layers of managers
Each department is even more silo'ed in their group than before due to the workflow burden
Though the company provides coffee, it is a different grade of coffee between builds. (Engineering is known to have the best coffee, tea selection, and hot chocolate stash, WHY?)
There is constant blame games even within departments rather than let's fix it and be a team
Terms & Conditions are ridiculous on contracts for orders as well as to approved suppliers
GE Corporate has unrealistic profit objectives and holds the divisions responsible even if the company within are hitting their targets
column14: Learn the etiquette of managing people, be authentic NOT fake

column12: Decent pay & benefits
column13: Zero accountability for upper management be it for unprofessional behavior or failed results. Lack of direction from leadership. Due to the amount of reorganization & lay offs management & employees understand knowledge is power and will not share information or train new employees, creating great opportunities for suppliers & bad results for GE. Culture is broken, leadership talks about change & being open to change, but much stays the same at the top layers. The only changes that occur are in lower middle to low management staff. Layoffs occur monthly, constant staff changes makes it impossible to knowledge transfer or create a strategic plan to implement & execute so all work is transactional at best.
column14: If GE truly wants change: Define a strategy, communicate it & holds ALL folks accountable- measure supplier performance, measure executive performance via external audit companies/process. Hire new staff with external qualifications & knowledge. Get rid of “internal competition” which makes for more politics & kingdom building & the mentality of “this it is the way it has always been & is at GE”. Improve mediocre systems, policy & processes which hinder most collaborations between entities & departments (suppliers divide & conquer all day). Hold managers accoutable for succession & training of staff, so that a token few don’t hold the keys to the kingdom.

column5: It’s a very educational place to work lots of good job skills.
column12: There are a lot of different jobs your able to do. You are not stuck doing the same thing over and over each day. Also working there will teach you many different skills that you would have to learn from working at multiple companies.
column13: GE hires to many young kids straight out of collage and puts them in leadership positions. And they don’t listen and take advice from the workers who have been there for years and years who knows the ends and out.
column14: GE hires to many young kids straight out of collage and puts them in leadership positions. When they haven’t ever worked in a place like GE and when a problem arises they don’t listen to the employees who have been doing the job for 20 plus years who knows the ends and outs of the job. There more interested in trying to get themselves recognized which 90% of the time results in them spending tons of money and time on different ideas of how they think it should be done. And in the end they usually just have to go back and ask the machinists who run the machine how to fix it. This waste of money also cause us employees not to be able to get the tools re need to do our jobs correctly and on time

column5: Great people. Smart people. Poor long term management perspective. You drive your own growth.
column12: Smart people. Good theory taught. Poor execution.
column13: Poor management and career development. HR is poor.

column12: work-life balance, culture, healthcare benefits
column13: limited advancement, poor management, low 401k match

column5: Intelligent personnel, but a somewhat backstabbing environment. No real loyalty among employees and chain of command.
column12: Smart, driven and competent employees.
column13: Senior management doesn't have great leadership ability. Managers are out for themselves, without any real training or motivation to develop subordinates. GE advertises flexible work/life arrangements and programs, but when you approach HR about these programs, they basically try to steer you away from utilizing the same programs that they brag about so much.
column14: Consistent, specific feedback and regular performance counseling (whether that performance has been good, or bad!). Take care of your people and go to bat for them when interacting with more senior personnel. Do what you can to find out their own goals and help them to achieve them. I felt that most of the reviews I received at GE were considered a waste of time and more of an afterthought or annoying requirement by my chain of command, and I never got an real useful information in these reviews. Also, feedback should be formal and regular, not once a year.

column12: It is at least a job
column13: Stressfull. Treated badly. Belittled. Management seems glad to cause employees problems.
column14: Treat people with respect

column5: I saw the BEST and WORST of GE
column12: For the most part you are surrounded by smart and motivated people. If you have a track record of success, you will have the opportunity to move into different areas (i.e. finance to sales). GE’s reputation for having great training and leadership development carries a lot of weight with other companies. I genuinely liked most of the people I worked with and made many friends while working with GE.
column13: When times got rough, GE went back to its comfort zone. The “old boys” club is very much still in place. Generally speaking, GE still very much has a top down / command and control management approach. GE was trying to embrace innovation, but for the most part management does not really encourage it. The current year’s operating goals are priority one. Management and HR very much believe that GE is the greatest company in the world and that it is a privilege to work there. They take pride in paying employees below market. The most successful employees seem to have started with GE right out of college and have never experienced what it is like to work for another company.
column14: Listen to your customers and employees - act on what they are saying. Seek outside research and advice - do not just trust your gutt and do what you have always done. More coordination is needed between business segments in many areas.

column5: Big company with a lot of oppurtunities. You just need to be in the right business.
column12: it is a land of oppurtunity. There are offices everywhere so your career growth isn't restricted. If your willing to travel or are globally mobile, then you can do anything you want. Some of the people there are absolutely brilliant and very motivated
column13: Structured annual increases. Your hard work may get you an annual increase of 5% but really whats that when the guy next to you gets 2% and leaves at 4:58pm everyday regardless of things not being done. Also, after turning down a few job offers I am irritated at the percent raises on internal transfers. I would rather see what they're willing to pay for the job rather than basing my salary on my previous job.
column14: It would be great to see more direct communication from senior leaders. It's comical when you get thank you emails from senior leaders that were "sent on their behalf". Come on, really...

column5: GE Should Not Have to Be a Stepping Stone to another Job!
column12:
Benefits are good.
Fellow Employees are great.
Having GE on the resume is always a plus.
GE uses quality equipment and is very safety conscious.
column13:
GE has elevated bureaucracy to an art form!. 
Compensation: there is a cookie cutter approach to compensation (Pay for Performance doesn't work for every job) 
Employee Review System: too regimented with no real objective standards for measurement, forcing employees to use "GE Speak" - get rid of it.
column14:
Compensation: Pay on a competitive scale with ANNUAL increases (occasionally adjusted for inflation, C.O.L.), use bonuses to reward outstanding performance (using objectively quantifiable measures) and give your real "stars" stock GIFTS, not options. Treat your employees like you treat Senior Management - even the lowest paid employee should reap the benefits of the companies overall performance when times are good, even if the scale is different. If you're going to give bonuses and stock options to Management, then do the same to the rank and file. Don't think that management is solely responsible for a company's growth.
Employee Reviews: Get rid of the current approach to forcing employees into using "GE speak"! Allow employees to think and write their own reviews more creatively. Imagination at Work! Review your managers by getting feedback from the people that report to them.
Opinion Surveys: Use independent researchers and expand the opinion survey process - the current process doesn't dig deep enough!

column12: Unlimited vacation, able to work from home occasionally, good work atmosphere
column13: Pay inequality among employees and uncompetitive pay for area.

column12: The people, both leaders and technology experts, really make this a great place to learn and solve. People are willing to share and support each other, and I've made a lot of friends here. The technology and innovation are exciting and it all goes toward solving major issues in energy, healthcare and transportation around the world.
column13: It is a big, far-reaching company, so there are some extremes at the edges. Don't believe anyone who says "always" or "never" here... that probably only means that they have limited .experience or view of the variety at this dynamic company. There are more and more acquisitions that don't yet benefit from the rest of GE
column14: Share more about how GE is solving some of the world's toughest challenges....we are purpose-driven yet don't talk about it enough. Those of us who work here learn about the lives saved or the advances to create reliable, affordable and even sustainable energy....but that doesn't seem to be shared much.

column5: Corporate IT Strategic Vision is Inconsistent YoY
column12: Working with and leading very bright and talented individuals. Many opportunities for change in role provided you build relationships across the vast and different IT spaces and business units. Great training and professional development courses. Excellent experience to build exposure of complex enterprise architectures.
column13: Inconsistent strategy and vision of internal IT solutions. No emphasis placed on strategic decisions made from quantitative data in recent years, with large and grandiose statements being the norm often with no modeling for total cost of ownership. 18 month minimum in job before moving to a new position often leaves 90% completed product, tool or service rolled out with the original project owner or executive champion moving on with no direct link to future project success, failure, or TCO projection alignment.
column14: Drive IT strategy with cash flow and cost based approach; eliminating strategic vision statements with no imperial data to validate. Go back to multi-year valuations to provide data points on project, tool, and architecture success and continue to drive efficiencies of scale.

column12: All of my coworkers were incredibly kind and welcoming. I did not have a car of my own so they would often invite me to have lunch with them. They even took me out to dinner or invited me to their weekend events. Was given a lot of exposure to the project management side of tech, brought into almost every meeting that my manager thought I could benefit from.
column13: I came in to my team in the middle of a complete workflow overhaul. All the teams were transitioning from waterfall to agile development. Due to this, the vast majority of my tasks were house keeping based. None of my projects were incredibly interesting or even difficult. The only comp sci skill I actively flexed was reading SQL in order to devise non-automated test cases for their principle software suites.
column14: Not that my manager wasn't great, but I was told by other managers who had no interns that, had they known of the process, they would have definitely had interesting projects for their interns to do.

column12: Great people to work with and the company makes products that are important to the world
column13: Transportation leadership does not value their employees. They have some some pretty terrible things over the last few years. For example taking good hardworking folks from one location and telling them if they want to have a job they can move with no assistance or cost of living adjustment to a new city that is 30% more expensive. Some of these folks were leadership program graduates doing good things and cost less than the new hires they are getting in Chicago. They have treated people who have given up a lot for the company like they dont mean anything at all. One day you are working for a company for 10 years and the next day they tell you that you need to bid on the job you already have to see if you are still the right choice. I have seen families move to the new Chicago location as high performing employees to be told within a year that they are just not the right fit.
column14: Be honest with your employees - we are not stupid people. If you want to have a successful business then you should keep your employees accountable for the work they do and treat people like you would want to be treated.

column5: GE stock is dropping for a reason
column12:
After 22 years with this company, I can say GE had its drawbacks like any company would have, but overall a great place to grow career and meet amazing people. The last few years, especially after the Alstom purchase, it has been a disaster. I hope it can turn around.

I am pleased with my compensation, but the benefits have changed drastically over the last 8 years and are negating this pro.
column13:
I do not know a single person who is happy in Schenectady working for GE. Does HR understand an unhappy workforce leads to low productivity and impacts the stock? The "you are lucky you have a job attitude" does not = productive workforce. Health insurance is horrible and the last cost increase was more than my raise. My first raise in 2.5 years because they were suspended for Senior Bands . Pensions are at risk of being frozen for older employees and were already eliminated for new employees. Constant threat of layoffs is draining and demoralizing. 

I was pro GE for my entire career and always loyal to this company. I actually recruited friends to work for this company. I am now actively looking for another job and would never recommend anyone to work for GE the way it is today. I not only feel guilty for having friends come to GE, but now still having a job with GE, I will be competing with fellow employees who were laid off for other local jobs.

column12: Well known name, opens doors easily. Great benefits and PTO policy.
column13: Difficult to advance from inside.
column14: Always be honest and do what you say.

column5: Great Company, Great people - you've got to break through the glass ceiling in order to become a fat cat.
column12: Great benefits, reasonable life work balance, great people. My job is incredible. I truly enjoy the challenge and working in new product development. I think I have one of the best jobs on the market. However, the downsides sometimes make me want to leave.
column13: Career growth difficult in my business (Appliance sector). If I thought I was being faily compensated I would think I had the absolute perfect job. Very diverse business, however, too often promotion opportunities are based upon minority/woment rather than those who are most qualified for the promotion. There is a vast difference between the "executives" vs. "non-executive" salaries and benefit packages. The only folks that get any bonuses are the "execs" so don't expect anything less.
column14: Senior management at appliances well done, GE corp - tell the truth, always tell the truth. Your overall business strategy is not going well.

column5: General Electric Aviation is a dynamic place to work
column12: GE is only a handful of big corporations that still has a traditional pension plan with good benefits. It is the only company left from the original 10 NYSE start-up companies. General Electric is one of the more respected and recognize company in the USA and the world.
column13: Like most large companies, cost of health insurance and compensations have brought forth a reduction in work force either by layoffs or early retirement. Newly hire workers do not have the traditional pension plan anymore but allow increase in 401K and matching contributions.
column14: WIth the increase in older workers looking for retirement, it would be beneficial to the company if new workers are brought in earlier for training to capture the years of experience and to improve this transition. One more advice to GE Corporation, it would save the company BIG money if the "Union" workforce is to work a full 40 hours before overtime is paid out. This will eliminate absenteeism and increase productivity.

column12:
Good company for learning for freshers.
Extremely senior positions maybe good for experienced leaders however the bureaucracy may ease off whatever passion good hires have in 2-3 years of employment.
My recommendation would be to see this company as a 2-3 year investment and not more as diminishing returns would follow after a few successful years.
column13: Low salary and limited growth outside of leadership programs which are dogged by a bureaucratic selection process. HR has too much power and therefore high growth candidates must avoid this company for a long term career. The company would most like loose out to competition in the long run due to the above anomaly in growth culture.
column14:
Leadership needs to be nurtured in spirit instead of lip service.
Be more flexible and disruptive.
This company has huge financial resources and therefore it has the capability for taking hire risks for faster growth. Therefore, my advice is to increase commercial intensity, R&D and most importantly start valuing your human capital more. Give better remunerations at lower levels, allow people to grow their careers and act as a true leader for making exceptional careers.

Try to become the number one company to work for and success would follow. In case the attitude doesn't change, this company would very soon become irrelevant for the world economy. Wont survive more than 25-30 years as a meaningful MNC if the above problem is not solved.

column12: back in the day when Jack Welch was at the helm, GE was run like a well oiled machine. The stock split, GE was good. GE was diversified and the pension was funded.
column13:
Things changed when Jeff Immelt came and took charge and totally screwed up GE, he did not do what was best for the company, nor did the board of directors. They kept the problem going on for over 16 years. Replacing Immelt and not giving John Flannery enough time to fix a 16 year mess was wrong.
There is still a good ole boys network and not enough women are promoted. GE talks diversity but their actions don't always show that. Obviously the executives don't lead by example, they still spend money and cut everyone else from spending. It should be across the board. Expect to always worry about layoffs and to keep getting more and more work assigned to you as more people are cut.
column14: After 39 years, this is not the GE I started with. I was embarassed at the end to say I worked for this company. Would I suggest someone go work there, no, I would tell them if they want a work balance, look some where else as GE is not the only game in town. Listen to your employees, they know what needs to be done and they go above and beyond to make things better. Stop being top heavy in the organization as that is what got the business in trouble.

column12: Expertise could come from many areas
column13: Who can be expert in energy, finance, entertainment, and healthcare

column12: Great exposure, can learn a lot
column13: Low pay for the value provided

column5: Not the same company anymore ... lost basic roots of operational execution focus
column12: Very bright people, great career opportunities and challenging jobs. For employees starting their careers it has wonderful leadership programs at entry levels that help you develop your professional skillset. The company has some of the brightest folks and a strong management bench so early on in your career you can learn and grow.
column13: Work-life balance, highly political environment, internal promotions highly biased on network and not necessarily based on competence and skillset. GE is a demanding environment so work life balance is not part of the culture if you want to get ahead. After entry level jobs or leadership programs have been completed the career progression is heavily based on networking. People get promoted based on networking and behavior more then on their job performance, competence or skillset.
column14: Company culture has shifted dramatically towards behavioral traits and has lost its operating roots. People are valued more for how they behave then what they accomplish. It should allow for criticism of what is not working and listen to what employees are saying. The leadership traits and values focus too much on behavior and growth traits and not enough on basic job competence, execution and skillset. As for operational management the last couple years has been very short term focused and GE has lost most of it's longer term vision.

column5: Lots of dead weight and very political
column12: You don't see a lot of mass firings in the engineering department. They are happy to put you in a position to do a job that you may not be considered for in another company because of lack of experience or qualifications. Free parking, coffee and occasional lunches.
column13: Like others have said. They have trouble getting rid of dead weight and difficulty motivating the top talent to stay. Very much a sit down and shut up environment. Feedback is not encouraged. Everything is political. Requires a policy and procedure for everything. It is common to see people thrown under the bus. Getting basic tools to do your job is impossible. Lots of lip service to software development methodologies in use etc., but no execution to back it up. Turnover is high.
column14: If you want to attract the best and the brightest you need to create an environment that encourages it. When I was recruited into the company the HR person told me about how GE looked for people who can connect the dots etc.. The culture actively discourages this kind of thinking and many of your hires have trouble doing this. Ditch the ceremony and get to the essence and give your people the tools that they need to do their job...if people are not able to perform after you have given them the tools and environment you need to remove them from the team.

column12: FMP (Corporate) - Great leadership development program. GE has a particularly strong finance department with a top-notch focus on training/development for FMPs. Excellent networking opportunities. Great managers. Top performers are treated well and given preference when considering future job assignments, special projects and perks.
column13: Corporate culture is all about drinking the GE koolaid. Whenever the powers that be come up with a new initiative/buzzword, for instance the finance department pushed "simplification", the results are usually just lip service. The irony in spending countless hours on draft after draft after draft of beautifully formatted powerpoint pitches explaining the benefits of "simplification" seems to be lost on management.
column14: Mid-level management is great, GE really does have an eye for talent and promotes internal folks accordingly. My advice would be that GE is not the end all be all, acknowledging as much would help in fostering a more open-minded culture that could foster more "innovation" than just writing the word thousands of time in GE-approved templated powerpoints.

column5: Sadly, after a great career I’ve finally lost the ‘silver lining’ attitude.
column12: My immediate team is AWESOME! I wouldn’t trade these folks for anybody else. We work hard, support each other, deliver for our customers, and continue to learn and grow despite everything else happening around us.
column13:
HR, Digital (global functions and data), and senior leadership continue to disappoint. No clear direction, great leaders forced out due to ridiculous location strategy, no communication on next steps or what they are doing to fill the leadership gap. In the span of one month I will lose my leader and the next two leaders above that. Our team has been moved around internally four times in the past year and a half with leaders beyond my direct manager taking absolutely no interest in what we do and how we deliver for our customers. 

HR and HR for HR are a joke. Not at all responsive to employees questions and not at all proactive in reaching out to the employees they supposedly support to learn about what we do. HR is not an employee advocate. They are puppets. HR People Partner...please. Spare me. 

Compensation is far behind peer companies/jobs. Absolutely no faith that we are on the cutting edge of HR any longer. We got cocky, thought we were better than everyone else, and fell too far behind to catch up.
column14: Take a hard look at the impact of what you’re doing on employees. Your losing, or will be losing, good people because you’ve lost focus on the fact that it’s the employee that creates our success.

column12: Flexible work schedule at times
column13: No raise in 3 years. Mediocre health benefits.
column14: Not transparent like they claim

column5: From Employer of Choice to Middle of the Pack
column12: A variety of roles and career paths available. You have the opportunity to stretch yourself in jobs. Always something new to learn and a challenge to solve. A variety of business units to work in covering different industries.
column13: In 2010 GE will be switching its medical benefits in the United States that will drastically increase the medical costs to employees. Further all salaried employees have not received salary increases since 2008. I am not sure how the company thinks employees will be able to afford these additional costs without being compensated. GE is moving from employer of choice to middle of the pack. Years ago you could depend on GE to be stable and not worry about losing your job. You also had great medical and retirement benefits. Today you can get laid off at any time and your medical benefit costs will increase by 150% with 0% salary increase. Not to mention that the company has historically had lower than average salaries. I believe that in employees will have to seriously take this into consideration before joining the GE team in the future.
column14: Focus on your employees. If you make them successful the company will follow. Stop letting the government dictate the way we operate our business.

column5: Good for starting your career, better opportunities exist outside of company once you have GE on your resume
column12:
-Leadership Programs are designed to create future leaders/managers
-Great training and development opportunities
-Great work/life balance, ability to work from home
-Lots of visibility and exposure to leadership early in career
-Employees are very helpful and interested in growing new hires
-Managers are competent
-Size of company makes lots of opportunities available, employees can easily move between different GE business
-Good processes and best practice sharing
-Global exposure, even for interns and new hires
-Very intelligent employees
-Sense of pride in working for a company with so much history
-Clear vision and direction set by leaders
-Leaders are honest and open
column13:
-GE expects you to move every 2 years to move up
-Lots of bureaucracy and politics
-Extremely matrixed and confusing organizations, simple tasks require approvals and sign-offs from hundreds of people
-GE is sometimes like a cult
-Employees dont actually understand our products, competitors, etc (and mgmt likes it that way)
-Suck-ups that do B.S. work for leadership move up
-Few opportunities in major cities (NYC, LA, Chicago)
-Salary is below market, no overtime pay
-Lots of work done by offshore contractors, often results in low quality work due to short contracts focused only on quick development
-Too "number" focused, everything must have a financial benefit (increased satisfaction is never a reason to pursue an initiative)
-People are expendable
column14: Focus on people. Recent decisions (i.e. new benefits package) have made many employees frustrated.

column5: Huge company that is a little too diversified
column12: Incredible effort and resources spent to develop leadership, in those that are nominated through the “Session C” process (yearly employee performance reviews). Good opportunities if you work hard and get results.
column13: Way too internally focused on the short term numbers. Spend more time telling people above you what you did last period, and what you are planning to do next period than actually doing anything. Managers are not given the power to make decisions over what is their responsibility. Decisions only made after all other managers are in agreement, which requires multiple meetings over months and months.
column14: Stop talking about "Simplification" and actually make things simpler. Get rid of most of the “work flows” and allow your people to manage their responsibilities. Change the metrics so that we create long term value instead of making our quarterly numbers. We will never become a great company unless we look further than the end of the quarter.

column12: GE is a great company with a great history. The company truly believes in its HR policies. Things like EO, compliance, and ethical behavior are not just once-a-year training. The company does truly strive to be ethical and fair to employees.
column13:
GE is in the middle of a very painful transition on two fronts. First, the sales mentality that has pervaded for years has created a culture of 'No one fails.' This doesn't meant that no one fails - it means that we don't address failures and allow them to continue on by just rebranding them as some kind of alternative success.

Second, GE knows that it must become a digital company to stay relevant in the future and this transition has been very painful. Instead of bringing in new leaders to make us digital, GE has relied on their legacy managers to just try and to think and behave differently. Needless to say, the company has not changed enough in the right ways.
column14: The shift to becoming a digital company is not like a new product introduction. This is not some short term thing. It's a huge cultural shift that needs to be led by people who know software. It cannot be adapted by a leader that has been living in spreadsheets for the past 20 years.

column12: Really good money. Preference to promote from within. Pretty good benefits. Some training is done through a really well-done series of on-line courses, so you can do it on your own schedule. Communication from management is good; even when they decided to move our business out of state, they gave us over a year's notice.
column13:
1. Really squeezing employees to cut costs; very few people went home after 8 hours. Management really does not care about your workload, and will force as much down your throat as you will swallow.
2. If you are a small division, management frequently is not at your location, and everybody in the building works for someone who is offsite.
3. Bonuses are calculated based on the performance of business groups, not just your own location. So even if you do great and your company does great and meets all its goals, if your group does poorly, you get nothing.
4. As with any huge corporation, your division can be sold, moved, or otherwise changed, leaving you unemployed. No real loyalty to long-time employees.
5. I would recommend to a friend if their lifestyle could accommodate decent pay/benefits but long hours with little relief.
column14: Pay bonuses reflecting the goals of individual companies -- there's little incentive to bust your butt if there's a dead weight in your business group that's going to weigh everybody down.

column5: Like Grandpa Trying to "Be Hip" and Roll With The Tech Companies
column12:
- Flexibility to work remotely
- Many events with free food
- Can wear jeans to work
column13:
- Pay is at or marginally below market rate for positions
- At the mercy of "leaders" who want things done yesterday
- Very political organization
- Lack of work-life balance
- Archaic ways of doing things that are justified as being "just how things are done"
column14: The direction GE is moving towards of being like a "start-up" company with collaboration and lean only works in a culture that isn't laden with politics and bureaucracy. Just because you minimize the amount of levels between an executive and entry-level positions doesn't mean you're any closer to emulating a digital company in Silicon Valley. Your employees need to feel like they are working towards something meaningful and not like they are working to avoid losing their jobs or from being reamed out by their supervisor. If you're going to attract young talent in your effort to become a digital industrial company, you're going to need to do more. Millennials value work-life balance, crave opportunities to be innovative, and want to be on a "fun" campus. Let some of them take the driver's seat instead of letting the "traditional" GE leaders continue to steer the company.

column12: Great vacation and maternity leave.
column13: No opportunity for career growth for internal candidates.

column5: Good challenges, but has a tendency to jade you.
column12: GE will constantly provide you with great challenges which will push you to your limit every day. The management tends to be friendly, and most people there care about you as a person and employee.
column13: The bureaucracy of most large companies are bad, and GE is one of the largest. If you can't play the political game you are either shoehorned into a particular role or forgotten about. Old-world style managers will make their way upwards while very talented individuals will be used for their abilities, but will ultimately suffer in their personal lives as a result. You can make it big at GE--for a price.
column14: Keep listening to your employees. Get out of your bubbles, but don't go so far as to micromanage. The world isn't GE, you can't expect our customers to think as we do internally so be a little more realistic about what GE is and what we can provide as employees.

column12: Great trust and flexibility in allowing the Area Sales Manager own and manage their market. The years of developed experience is shared through strong support of one another. Manager's goals are closely aligned with those of the employees.
column13: Just as in any other sales organization, you are to be moving in multiple directions at once while many times feeling like one hand is tied behind your back.
