- Managers are very helpful (Director and CIO) since I reported first to Director, then to CIO
- They at least say that you should take risks and try new stuff
column13:
- Really BAD health plan with a VERY HIGH deductible, meaning you pay tens of thousands of dollars deductible before ins starts paying a penny
- To get promoted esp to Director/Leader level, you need be there 5+ years, so don't expect stellar growth like in silicon valley
- Inspite of all the talk about new tech, taking risks, IT is still a support function to business. At the end of the day, what the business head wants, goes. Very different from a software product company, where we techies rule.
column14: GE makes a ton of profit, how much will it really cost to provide a good health plan to employees?

column5: Great company to have on your resume
column12: High performance expected. This was my first job after graduating from college. The level of professionalism and performance expected from management creates a high level of production from employees.
column13: The bottom 10% rating system is not totally fair in a small group. When its time to downsize, the least effective performer, who could possibly by the last hired, could lose their job,
column14: Well trained managers can add significant value to young professionals if they are properly trained on how to lead. Not all management have the social skills to be able to successfully lead a non-technical group.

column12:
- GE is a great company. I started as an intern/coop, went into a leadership program, and rolled off full time. The Pros definitely outweigh the Cons.
- Transportation is a large business with a small business feel.
- They promote within. If they like you, you will succeed. 
- Training is world class and very abundant.
- Compensation and benefits are very good.
column13:
- The business will place you where they see fit. Sometimes hard to make a move.
- Managers are difficult to work with - it is never their fault and they will throw you under the bus the first chance they get.
- Lots of change all of the time. People are coming and going. Makes for lots of ambiguity. 
- Living in Erie, PA - small city, very poor. If you hunt, you will get along with everyone.

column5: It's a sinking ship and the rats are manning the helm... lower the life boats and save yourselves.
column12: Great pay. Always something that needs fixed so your day is never dull.
column13: Management loathes the union. No support from the company. Appears to be doing everything they can to move all of the work out to non union locations and sub contractors. Anytime a deal has been made to be more "cost effective", 6 months later the company cries poor with their pockets turned out and say we are no longer competitive.
column14: Where do I start? First, quit comparing our wages to the local wages when you compare yours to the national level. Second, quit crying poor when maintenance says they need tools and then allow your maintenance manager to build himself the dream office he always wanted! Third, it's time to get rid of Immelt, the stock has been in the crapper since he has taken over and do not see a change in sight. Finally, to all the management that get their jollies off when employees are laid off, just you wait, when you get your pink slips, I hope you have positioned yourselves for searching for employment and wages that are "more in line with the area". When my day comes, I will be sitting in my paid off home and driving my paid off vehicles while you cry the blues!

column12: A company that cares about training and leadership development. Very dynamic and fast-paced, with a culture where being nice is rewarded. Great place to learn about business management. Some of the main offices will feel very international as it is one of the most global companies.
column13: GE really struggled in 2017 and is especially struggling to integrate digital technology into the company. Being a data scientist at GE involves working through a lot of unclean and siloed databases and dealing with plenty of managers who fundamentally don't understand what you do.
column14: Don't be afraid to get into the technical weeds. The world is moving very fast and people who understand how to use technology are leading it. GE is not.

column5: Good place to start, need to accelerate career progression
column12: Benefits / Resume Builder / People / Hours / Relocation possibilities throughout the country/world. The company is well respected and has a large network of EX GE employees with whom to network. Tuition reimbursment is also a great benefit.
column13: Beauracracy / Mundane tasks / Non stop data asks / Advancement can be structured so as to not work in your benefit. If you do twice as much as someone else they can get promoted faster if they have been there longer. There can also be a lot of mundane data grabs or other task that get fed down the pipe.
column14: Senior Managment should take a careful look at the people. There is a lot of talent at GE but also a lot of dead weight.

column12: Great global presence. Boundaryless in every way. Excellent people to work with. Your career is based on your networking at GE as well as delivering.
column13: You'll witness several young, inexperienced people that don't deserve it move up quickly. Unless you are in a management program out of school, it will be more difficult to move up.
column14: Stop giving so much, so soon to IMLP's. You promote them way too fast and then they take their experience elsewhere. You need to focus on those who are dedicated to GE and have greater experience too. GE Capital was unfairly treated by GE Corporate resulting in the good talent leaving GE Capital. GE Capital is the train track that kept GE rolling.

column12: Excellent in house training. Great fitness facilities, decent benefits, long term career prospects. Constant innovation and change.
column13: recent remodel attempt to "googlize" a 130 year old company a complete failure. Staff that previously had some privacy in their cubicles now shunted off to open benches and cheap, Ikea-style open cubicles made out of metal and p article board. shoddy carpet squares in light colors instantly took on a dingy grey cast. Open "collaboration spaces" noisy and not conducive to the kind of work done at headquarters. It wasn't lost on people that the ones who got the worst set up were minorities and that creates a bad image. Not the impression you want to create at corporate headquarters.
column14: Recognize that remodel on the cheap makes sense if HQ is moving, but doesn't mean we like it.

column12:
-Career opportunities are virtually endless provided you have the flexibility
-The ability to work remote is phenomenal
-The access to interact with executive leadership is great
column13:
-Highly matrixed organization...hard to know who does what exactly
-You get too many teams working on the exact same solution
-Lack of stability at leadership positions
column14: Change is good, but there is a such thing as too much change at once. It does not allow anyone to feel like there is stable operations, so it feels like there is always a moving target for achieving your goals, not metrics, as you can manipulate metrics to be met, but overall goals of making a difference. It feels like we are dealing with the same issues year in and out, and can't truly resolve issues and grow because there is constant change.

column12:
* Good leadership development programs and entry level opportunities
* Exceptional Peer group - you will work with some of the brightest individuals in your field
* Solid reputation and strong focus on integrity
* Very attractive to recruiters if you eventually decide to leave
column13:
* Performance Mgt process at times misses the true under performers due to risk
* Stock has been flat for far too long - no longer a retention tool like in the past
* The requirement to relocate can place a burden on the employees - especially in today's environment where housing prices are no longer appreciating at record pace like in the past
column14: Meet your numbers, but don't do it at the cost of your future... Avoid being short sighted to please investors and truly determine what is required for long term growth...

column5: GE- a great place to work and even better if your good!
column12: Alot of opportunity if you are a hard worker. GE is place to be apart of a company with a world-class supply chain and manufacturing component. People who go above and beyond are rewarded and promoted. Most leader care about the people in their businesses and do whatever they can to make sure their teams are successful.
column13: ALot of people and if you do not have a strong personality, it is easy to get lost in the fold. Its usually difficult to start with GE from the outside, do the the highly matrixed organizations and leadership structures...but that also creates alot of growth potential.
column14: Keep the best interestest of your teams at hand...they are the heart and soul of the company.

column12: Large company, good benefits, fair compensation, aility to move around in same city and available to work in cross functional areas. You usually are working with excellent folks that are good at what they do.
column13: Large company, if you are not used to being accountable for perormance get used to it here, you are ranked according to what you deliver and compared to your peers on a annual basis. In lean times and in good times the bottom 10% are laid off. Part of a larger conglomarate (GE) and we are going to be sold or spun off in the next 1-5 years depending on the economy.
column14: Tell it like it is and get out of the way so the workers can get stuff done and stifle all rumors.

column5: Culture to bring my best 'self' to work...
column12: GE has evolved! It has grown from a 'corporate company' to a culture that encourages individual thinking. I have never worked at a company like GE where you are rewarded for your accomplishments and work. GE is evolving their culture to be a modern company and to build an environment where I can have a great work/life balance and therefore bring my best 'self' to work.
column13: The only con I can think of is that working in a large company you do have to figure who you are and where your career should go. It has to be a personal decision and push. GE will help but you have to be driven in a big company.
column14: Keep up the positive evolution we are seeing!

column12: It is a large company that can provide a lot of avenues to continue in your career, a large amount of experience handling a larger variety of issues than one would find at another company, and is highly recognized by other institutions. Also, there is a great possibility to move up within the company.
column13: It is a large company so sometimes communication is lacking on projects or issues.
column14: In thinking about our future, and advertising our company as an environmentally friendly, they could do much more on the local level beyond what they determine as financially reasonable. However, as a new employee I was respected by senior management. In my position, it was also nice to see such a high regard for employee safety and health from the senior managment.

column5: GE is a really great place to have your career.
column12: GE is a really great place to have your career. You will get a comprehensive view of what you would like to achieve as a business professional as you start working in GE and people around you will be extremely supportive on that.
column13: High reward sometimes come with high effort so it's up to yourself how you would like to balance your work and life, but the company fully support people to have a life if that's their priorities.
column14: Maybe it's important to have a vision of where GE will be in the next 10 years and drive the company to that direction progressively. Sometimes you need to get rid of the debt faster so that you could get up to speed quicker.

column5: Why would anyone consider switching to GE at this time???
column12: Unless you don't have a job and desperately need one or if they are making you an offer at least "6 sigmas" outside the market range, I don't see any pros!
column13:
Where do I even start?? To be clear, this is about GE Digital and not the overall GE. But seriously, this is a great vision screwed up with poor execution. But the main reason I wouldn't advise anyone to join GE Digital is that the folks who screwed up execution are still in the same position, continue making the same poor decisions but get rewarded with promotions or not getting "RIFed".

I have a neutral opinion of John Flannery as such but I fail to understand why he hasn't canned Bill Ruh as yet. My only guess would be that he is too busy trying to save the big mother ship and doesn't have any other option but to stick with Bill Ruh because he can't reveal the true strategy in an interview to any new CEO candidate!
column14: Clean up the cancer as soon as possible - Ruh and all his direct reports, as well as HR. Even if someone can say that the RIFs were necessary, the leadership truly failed by not evaluating the actual roles that needed to be eliminated as opposed to protecting favorites

column5: Great products, good people, and typical mgmt nonsence
column12:
GE makes some truly great products - especially in their Healthcare and Power & Water divisions
At the entry and mid-career level they pay well and have competitive benefits
column13:
Management has the same political BS that is evident in most large corporation.
GE is a highly distributed corporation and it is quite common to have a team spread out across the US or globally and even your own manager in another part of the world. It is tough to have a team concept or unity in this setting.
column14:
Optimize teams locally instead of proliferating the world-wide model
Treat all team members the same regardless of geographic location - items like bonuses should be equally distributed regardless if one is the in the home office or a remote office

column5: Cooperative, results-oriented atmosphere, almost everybody is willing to help.
column12: Helpful, small-company culture with big corporation support, pay, and benefits. Almost everyone is downright friendly and knows you just want to get the job done. Almost everything is here in one building so you can always get an answer for anything you need to do.
column13: HUGE corporate push to cut costs, so staffing is short and almost everyone is a little overloaded. Out-of-state corporate HQ approval occasionally needed (though it's not too hard to get). Fewer and fewer people around to remember old reasons why designs are like they are. A little bit of "not my job" starting to creep in due to silo'd management structure headquartered out of state. And company is moving out of state in mid-2015, so future only available if you can move.

column12: GE generally is a great company to work for. It gets the fundamentals right. Compliance is not just a fancy word. Everyone lives it. Besides, you get to work with really smart people. Culture and people are two top reasons I stick around.
column13:
GE is a big company. It is so big that there are rules and standards to everything. IT tools definitely is something the company struggles on. 

Decisions cannot make quickly as there are too many stakeholders internally. 

Young talented people cannot move up quickly, generally speaking... as there are so many policies and it needs to seem fair to everyone.
column14: GE is at challenging times now, but cost cutting target is not the only measurement here. We should still invest in developing people, and we should really support this financially too.

column12:
-Greatest opportunity for growth I have seen.
-Very Flexible schedule
-Unlimited time off for senior employees if you get your job done
-Great people to work with
column13:
-Leadership places politics over business needs (this may be changing)
-Mismanagement from leadership the last two years - No bottoms up voice
-Too focused on quarterly earnings and stock price instead of technology
column14: GE has the best technology resources in the world. Leadership needs to focus less on the quarter, and stretch to innovate. The Tesla business model is the way of the future, and the only way to make progress while gaining internal and external excitement. The stock price will increase, and so will profits if GE did this. It needs to be publicly transparent that this is happening for this to work.

column12:
In my experience GE is so large that it really isn't 1 company. I experience my field service district as if I work for a $15M business, not a $100MM.

I have a great manager who took over from a very long term great manager. As a result our district has high morale and excellent production.
column13: We will only be with GE another month or so as our division has been sold to raise cash to deal with corporate's giant mess. Apparently manufacturing, selling and servicing large electrical equipment is not part of GE's "core business". They are a software company in case you haven't heard. (Thomas Edison facepalm)
column14: Treat your people well and most will want to work hard.

column5: I knew it was a shinking ship and bailed....
column12: The colleagues that I worked with that were really interested in delivering value were great people. Unfortunately, they were the only sane people in an asylum run by the inmates and as such, the value that they worked to deliver would never see the light of day because of the risk-adverse culture and the bureaucratic cluster-bleep that has been fostered and rewarded for so long.
column13: Too many to list and I don't think it's any surprise that everyone else hasn't realized. GE is still operating with a management structure that was put in place in the 60's and hasn't really evolved since. Their management is essentially driving the company into the ground and as such, it cannot attract, hire, or retain high performing people to help the company be successful into the 21st century. GE hires and fires people so frequently and often and is so shortsighted and run by making quarter-to-quarter analyst expectations, there's absolutely no way they're going to be able to rebuild for the long-term as long as these short-term goals are driving their business decisions.
column14: Retire or leave immediately. GE should divest itself of all its subsidiary businesses and then fire all management immediately. The subsidiaries will become independent entities that are free from corporate and should be run like lean startups.

column5: GE is not what they say it is...you have to be on the inside to realize that...
column12: Not sure...management is more concerned with white people than any group. If you look to get into one of the training programs and you're not white...good luck! My home is in Boston, MA but they sent me to Atlanta, GA because I'm black. Meanwhile someone from Texas was sent to the Connecticut office.
column13: Selling your soul to the company. Not worth it at all...GE does not care about its employees. All they care about is working you out to death so they can make profits. Something funny happened when I interviewed at Fairfield, CT. Going to the cafeteria, the program manager walked with me outside but getting back she took me to the basement. That was a low point because she did not want people to see me with her....I'm black and very good looking guy. I pretended I didn't understand...Very racist company because the people are much older.
column14: They suck! They don't recognize talent when they see it. What they're concerned about is "are you white?" Even though they pretend to be a diverse team none of it is true. They are more about the white blonde sorority girls. When I visited the company that's all there were.

column12: Great people to work with, The company has good benefits, The company has abundant resources you may be able to levberage, Because the company has multiple businesses and locations, there are multiple career opportunities
column13: There can be alot of management and leadership turnover and at times it may be difficult to develop and maintain productive business relationships because the managers you proved yourself to have moved on. Large companies can also become internally focused and competitive. The challenges are probably different than in smaller companies.
column14: Develop processes and opportunities that leverage employees experience and strengths but also may help build new skills. Get to know your employees and understand how they can best help the organization. Perform regular reviews with employees and ask them what opportunities they see for improvement.

column5: Great Place to start your career
column12: GE and Transportation in particular are a great place to start your career out of college. Their developmental programs are top notch and serve as a real world masters program. Transportation gives people early in their career an incredible amount of responsibility which provides a great opportunity to grow and develop.
column13: GE is big and bureaucratic that can be frustrating to motivated employees who experience constant roadblocks in order to accomplish their goals and objectives. Too often you have to fight to overcome the inertia of the company to accomplish things.
column14: Trust your employees to do the right thing. Although compliance is extremely important, you should trust your employees to do the right thing and not put up artificial checks and balances. Empower us!

column5: GE used to be a GREAT company. It is not a mediocre company.
column12: There are many super-talented, experienced, creative and impressive people working in GE. Unfortunately, those people rarely advance to become senior leaders within the company, but they are wonderful people to work with. The GE culture is tough, demanding and aggressive. I say those things all in a positive light, as my own personal style closely matches the "GE persona."
column13:
For the past several years, most senior managers are not leaders, visionaries, and can easily pitch out buzzwords and speak about "driving growth" "innovation" and "collaboration."

In reality, most senior managers care exclusively about managing their own resumes to land their next gig either in GE or elsewhere. If you want to be inspired and learn from senior leaders, get a good book or watch an inspiring TED Talk. You won't find it here.
column14: Stop promoting people who are nothing but "taking heads" who simply repeat empty, meaningless buzzwords that they don't understand themselves. There is a tremendous pool of talented employees within the ranks with more active braincells than most of the folks sitting in corner offices. What a shame.

column12: Large company, well known, amazing people (coworkers and management), lots of growth potential, excellent leadership development, a procedure exists for everything, CEO values permeate the entire company
column13: Work-life balance can be difficult, benefits do not take additional education into consideration and lag behind industry after new-hire, sometimes the procedures are too restricting or not well defined, "support the customer" seems to mean do whatever they ask instead of aiding them in understanding the rippling effects
column14: Overall good job so keep it up. It's good that you are highly visible, but most of the time we see/hear you it's because of a problem you want fixed, sometimes the working level needs you to provide additional push on customer. Employee annual review seems like a bloated process but it works pretty well.

column12: Overall I really enjoyed working at GE it was a solid job in a great company. The financial backing for projects was un-measurable. It was like no where I had ever worked before.
column13: At times I found the focus to be a little lacking, when a company has so much money to throw at a projects is seems the do so until something sticks. There was also a very high competitiveness to become a life long 'company man' and work your way up the management chain. Rather than striving towards innovation, this seemed to be the main concern of a lot of people there.
column14: Put more of the focus on innovation and less on trying to climb the ladder to the next rung.

column12: GE is a very innovative company that focuses heavily on talent growth within. I have received many job offers outside the company with just having GE listed on my resume. Although I don't plan on leaving anytime soon.
column13:
the atmosphere and culture is very performance based so you have to be laser focused on completing these goals. With that the culture is come and go as long as your manager agrees. This could cause issues with employees who lack initiative.

The compensation isn't the greatest when compared to other tech companies, but it provides my family with a comfortable life.
column14: Continue to focus on talent growth within the organization including your own. Continue to take a head-in and hands-off approach and lean on your teams to achieve their commitments.

column12: There is a significant culture shift happening within GE in a good way- everything from talent acquisition to performance management is being looked at in new and engaging ways! The focus has shifted from being perfect every time to delivering an intended direction, gaining buy in and iterating. The GE Beliefs are also allowing more empowerment of employees and small teams and there is more opportunity for flexible work schedules.
column13: Carving a clear career path can be challenging, in terms of obtaining information on realistic possibilities as there are so many avenues in a global organization of our size. I know that the teams are working to provide employees more guidance on this area in the future.
column14: Keep promoting the culture shift! Outcomes over process...

column5: Stay away from GE- Toxic, unethical and stressful!
column12: You can learn all about power plants, if that is your interest.
column13:
- I joined GE from Honeywell, at the time of joining I was told that I have unlimited vacation time and I gladly joined as I was getting these benefits already at Honeywell along with free food. After 6 months I am being told that I have 22 days vacation time! I feel like being cheated, the company that can not stand by its words speaks volumes about its ethics. 
- It's stressful to work at GE with no benefits as such, to a point that I suffered from stress induced acute anxiety at work and have to be on medications. Even for attending my daughter's event for an hour I was pointed out and told to take PTO while many just loiter at work place for hours or WFH while they work at other places on that day. I complained to the HR but all they did was pacification and no action on my request to change my boss/ relocate to another team. 
- It's a dog eat dog world in here, no concept of collaboration what so ever. New hires like me we told specifically not to collaborate even when we the bandwidth.
column14: Clean up your company, it's dirtier than you can imagine!

column5: Get what you need and get out
column12: GE will pay for your mba with no contract. i believe they will also pay for your undergrad if you can get into GE prior to getting your bachelors. You will also get to know a lot about processes. GE is a process driven company and you the process you learn here can be taken into any business inside or outside of GE and be used. I know I will use the skills i learned here to start my own business and work within a business to bussiness selling environment. There is also a hundered different places to move.
column13: Too big and you can get lost in the mix
column14: get your head out of the clouds and listen to you employees

column5: Jeff Immelt was a breath of fresh air after Jack Welsh.
column12:
Opportunity for different interesting assignments.
Pay and medical are better than most large companies.
Employee morale was improved after Jack Welsh left as CEO.
The variety of different equipment worked with and the different students I was able to train kept my employment interesting.
I trained Navy Petty Officers on AEGIS, Shield of the Fleet on several different systems.
Also, NASA radar technicians on MOTR, Multiple Object Tracking Radar after the tragic Challenger Space Shuttle accident.
My previous RCA employment was counted as seniority towards retirement when a contract was acquired.
As a retiree, I am grateful that I stayed the course and made it,
column13:
Neutron Jack came in and wiped out 35%. of the staff.
Remainder had to become overachievers.
column14: Use the accumulated knowedge of long time emplyees.

column5: So proud to work for GE.. but not anymore
column12:
Extremely smart, hardworking people
Process oriented, driven culture
Great benefits
Treated employees fairly
Cared about its people
Big company with lots of opportunity
column13: Today, I would not work for GE. Integrity used to be paramount, now GE is selling out. NBC will no longer report a fair and balanced view of the government since Jeff Immelt is now on Pres. Obama's advisory board. There is not a shred of journalistic integrity left! I was once so proud to work for a great company like GE; now I'm embarrassed.
column14: Jack Welch - please come back! Jeff Immelt has ruined GE's reputation and shattered the very foundation on which the company was built. The CEO has clearly been "bought."

column12: Lots of smart people; generally a very professional atmosphere; opportunities for advancement, if you're willing to play the game.
column13: Very aggressive and overbearing work schedule, work-life balance suffers. Their commitment to 'Lean' methodologies is almost a joke; you must get certified to help your career, but projects are done for the sake of doing projects, not really to help; every project I saw enacted actually made things worse. People are transient - you're expected to move around and change jobs every 2 years or so, or else you're seen as there being something wrong with you. People will implement some new process to make a name for themselves, and then move on and let someone else clean up the mess.
column14: Consider the emphasis placed on Lean projects and how they're evaluated. Let people develop competency and stay put for a while if desired without being stigmatized. Especially for middle leadership - take responsibility for actions; if you implement some new program or process, stick around to make sure it works or fix it.

column12:
-It is a leadership factory. They really believe in investing in people. I joined 15 years back as a smart analyst and they made a leader out of me.
-People are great. For a company of this size, not a lot of politics. People may leave GE because their career aspirations are not met. But I have met no one who has bad things to say about the culture.
column13: GE Capital is shrinking. Hence opportunities for vertical mobility are practically non-existent. That is why i am looking out.
column14: It is a great company. Just keep fighting the bureaucracy that inevitably creeps in. Too many people stopping line managers from doing their work. Send real business focused people to enabling functions like compliance and sourcing who are holding up speed.

column12: Its a nice campus, very nice people, work is work - not much different from other large company but i would say that GE has its own way of doing things so it takes time to get adjusted.
column13: Work life balance is tough, alot of changes within the business and its constantly moving from one thing to another. Management changes out and people move around alot so its difficult to get focus experts on things.
column14: Streamline changes so people can adjust quickly to the new structures. Offer more training opportunities and introduce a 6 month "swap" program where two employees could cross train each other so people outside of programs could get an opportunity to try a different focus and branch out to new areas to see if they like it.

column5: Like poor little sheep, they've lost their way.....baaaa, baaa, baaa
column12: Vast resources. Smart, capable people.
column13:
Organizationally, it's a tangled ball of string - more so than at any time in the past 20 or 25 years. 
The "GE Store" has done little to break down inter-divisional walls.
Poor strategic decisions have resulted in poorly positioned businesses, burdened by huge weights (Alstom).
"Digital-Industrial" was/is the right idea, but inorganic expansion and spending on, and rebranding to this concept seems to have been executed by drunken sailors, blindly driven by group-think. GE may get there, but it won't be efficient - may not be effective, and certainly is not in time to lead the world as GE should have done.
column14: SEBs and EBs should act less like lemmings, and Question Authority more often

column5: Good place to start your career
column12:
-Great salary for entry engineer
-Great exposure to many fields of engineering/business. The locomotive product has so many integrates several different fields of engineering from structures to combustion to controls to circuit design.
-Exposure to projects that really "matter"- Many of your assignments have a high impact on the business.You wont be wasting time on small time projects. Anything assigned to you is likely a very involved / crucial project.
column13:
-Work life balance can be really bad depending on the area you work in - they are very understaffed but refuse to hire more engineers to compensate, and end up working people weekends/very long hours to execute deliverables.
-Upper management is very far removed from common sense - they are all seek the lowest common denominator to get the profit, even if that means cutting corners everywhere else
-Workplace environment is really poor. Several buildings are very old with no new renovations. Parking lots are often dirt (or mud), pavement is old (except for the executive parking lot of course), buildings lack any sort of temperature control, facilities are just generally dim and antiquated.

column12: Honestly there was enough work to keep me busy part time but not too much to feel overwhelming. Everyone was very understand that you're still in school and have exams, projects, etc. All in all very nice place to work.
column13: A lot of time is spent in your own cube doing your own thing. It's a very typical office job, albeit not a bad one but just not what some people are looking for. The office is also much older, mostly higher ups so you won't find many people to connect with although those who you do connect with are rather important.
column14: Not much I would change it really was a great experience even the cons I have are more personal preference than anything that needs changing.

column5: Extremely strong potential...now time to deliver.
column12: GE Security shows an amazing amount of promise. It has strong acquisitions in video (VisioWave), access (Casi-Rusco), and fire (Edwards), and is finally making great strides to incorporate them all into an integrated security platform. If realized correctly, this surely will be a big player in the security industry. Dean Seavers shows great vision in leading the company in a growth-oriented direction. The company prides itself on compliance on all legal levels both in the US and worldwide.
column13: General Electric is a company full of processes to ensure quality control and compliance at all levels. While most of these are extremely valuable and must be maintained, at times the bureaucratic nature of the organization prevents it from making quick navigational strides in order to compete with the smaller, leaner security players in the market.
column14: Continue to focus on integration, as this is the direction the market is taking, and spend less time on so-called "boxed solutions". While distribution will continue to be a strong market, the bigger wins can be realized with the larger, integrated projects.

column12:
You work with very smart people
Louisville is a great place to live/work/raise a family
You have the opportunity to change jobs within the larger GE family
GE is very respected in business community
column13:
Employee engagement is not taken seriously
Financial measurements rule exclusively 
If you make your numbers but don't take care of your team there are no penalties
Leaders are stretched so thin they aren't being setup to be successful
column14:
Upgrade the facilities - especially those used by many like Monogram Hall and GCC - they are an embarassment. It will increase morale.
Measure how many employee touch points leaders have every quarter - not just electronic ones - hold them accountable for building relationships with their employees. If they do it right, it will drive the bottom line.

column5: Not nearly as good as it looks from the outside.
column12:
It's a big company and it looks good on your resume. 
Lots of cool projects to work on.
column13:
Lots of politics. Lots of hierarchy. They do a terrible job retaining top talent. They layed off a bunch of really bright employees and kept the yes folks. It's no wonder the business has to grow overseas. The engineering is okay. The science is really subpar. The creative folks are not encouraged to be creative. GE's greatest strengths are its name and its marketing, because people still view it as the great American company. It's become a me-too company. Lots of acquisitions. Organic growth is non-existent. The So-called global research centers are a technological farce at best these days. 

Lots of projects, but they get canned all the time. The R&D is terrible because it's at the mercy of the businesses.
column14: Retain better talent. You're letting go of some of your top employees either through attrition, poor reward systems or layoffs and keeping the yes folks. The stock price is slowly going back up but that's due to international growth.

column12:
It's GE.
You're challenged to do your very best as you work with people who are tops in their respective fields. Great opportunities for professional growth.
GE has its own culture which takes some time to learn and to thrive in. But..."If you can make it there you'll make it anywhere."
column13: Transportation is short staffed. People work very hard, often too much. It's easy to lose a grip on work-life balance. You can give everything to GE and they'll take it...so you have to make sure you reserve something for yourself and your family.
column14: Take as much interest in employees as you take in earnings results. Remember that leading people is the most important part of leading the business.

column12: GE has a lot of top-notch talent, especially engineers. You can learn a lot, regardless of your career level. People that really wish to be managers can advance if they take the opportunities available.
column13: The upper management has a major issue of not listening to their subordinates. A great example is the implementation of PLM in GE Power & Water (formerly GE Energy). The engineers & supply managers that had to use it identified many issues with the brand brought in (Enovia), yet upper mgmt. pushed it through without allowing for correction. A loss of productivity over 40% was encountered due to a system that was not ready & did not fit the needs of the business -- the headaches entirely belonged to engineering to correct or work around.
column14: GE Management really needs to listen & act upon the concerns of engineers. It is the reason I left. What good is it being an engineer responsible for developing new technologies & furthering improvements if mgmt. just does what they feel like instead of analyzing the data in front of them & working with the engineers to improve things?

column5: Good Company but very bureaucratic and slow in decision making
column12:
- A lot of driven colleagues. So I enjoyed the interaction
- brand recognition across industries that GE plays in
- Good reputation
column13:
- Over hyped middle management and very slow, risk averse decision making
- Very political in middle management and sr management
- good old girls (yes they exist) and good old boys (not so many anymore) club. People are promoted based on first impressions and gossips rather than objective results
column14:
Poor nurturing of the talent base that GE is able to hire. I have come to believe that most strong leaders will leave GE at some point because the GE culture promotes those who suck up and step on people below. 

Remove the good old girls, good old APAF, AAF, HF and good old boys culture. If people are being promoted because they are active in some non work related organization, then you don't get the best people leading. And if that's the case, then good people will and should leave. Leaving GE with mediocre talent who have a lot of friends in GE.

column12:
Opportunities to learn as much as you can about businesses, six sigma, as well as networking across businesses. If you are willing to move, job opportunities grow exponentially.
Extremely ethical and train employees regularly in proper
column13:
Pay is not always highest, but at the lower end of the industry standard pay scale. 
In my particular business, there were a lot of hoops to go through to get management approval for new product ideas. Seemed like we spent a lot of time justifying our existence.
column14: Sometimes it is better to get out of your own way. Trust that your employees are working towards goals that will help grow the company, brand and/or business. You are great at hiring smart people, let them be smart.

column12: This company had an incredibly robust compliance program. It makes employees very comfortable to work in an ethical environment. Also very big on community service and volunteerism. You don't hear much about these two attributes but really make GE a nice place to work. Sure there is hard work and even some office politics ( although not as much as I have seen in other companies) but working in an ethical place that values employee involvement to help others is really a nice environment.
column13: This is not the place for people who don't want to give 100% to the job. Internal competitiveness is strong. You can't hide or coast.
column14: Keep paying and promoting for performance. That is the way to attract and keep the best people.

column12: Good rotations across businesses. Solid manufacturing and business training. Not as good at sourcing. Excellent opportunity to attain a Masters in Supply Chain from Penn State however there is a 4 year retention agreement requirement. Decent benefits.
column13: The program manager for Energy does play favorites when it comes to deciding OMLP's position and location preferences. The Program Manager is very impersonal. His scope is very large with over 50 direct reports yields minimal if any one on one time or feedback on performance. Cost cutting is a constant struggle that can negatively impact the experience. Salary is non-competitive when compared with Oil & Gas companies, decently paid compared with other energy industries. There is a lot of "who you know" when it comes to getting the next position or getting things signed off on. Highly political environment. Frustrating getting through unnecessary red tape. Some positions lack oversight and accountability. Despite the reputation of Six Sigma at GE, there is a lack of worthwhile and meaningful projects yielding realistic results.

column5: Great for investors, worst place on earth for employees
column12: When business is good, leadership training is second to none. Great name recognition. Diversified products. Always make their quarterly numbers, at any cost. Lots of opportunity to move into new industries and roles when business is good.
column13: Company, Sr. Leadership, Management ONLY care about the quarterly numbers. Employees are the last concern. Had a 15% reduction in force then the next week posted record profits. Business Unit leader got a big pat on the back from CEO while about 100 people filed for unemployment. No rules or even guidelines for hiring managers to place employees in layoff pool into open jobs. Pay is below average for most roles. HR Mgr told me when I was hired that "GE doesn't have to pay as much as other companied because we are GE". Health Ins surprisingly expensive for a company with 300+k employees and coverage not great.
column14: If you are going to treat the workforce as expendable, at least be honest about it and quit the BS lip service. Try to think further out than 13 weeks. Make decisions based on the long term benefit to the company not just what will help you career today.

column5: Lots of opportunities in a big company
column12: GE is a large company, and along with that comes a certain amount of security. There are a lot of opportunities to go just about anywhere in the world and work in a whole variety of jobs. Really flexible work environment and relatively good benefits.
column13: Much of the innovation in a large company comes from acquisitions of one type or another. Therefore, much of the work is managerial or regulatory, rather than detailed design work. There are not a lot of opportunities to change the way things work because they are dictated from other parts of the organization. If you want to be a manager, this can be an ideal environment, and GE prides itself in this. If you want to be a technical designer, it is more difficult.
column14: Be willing to take risks to tackle tough challenges. Decisiveness is absolutely essential as so much is lost in changing direction or gathering just a little bit more data. Empower and trust employees - if you let them perform to their potential, they will do great things.

column5: Overall GE is a good company.
column12: GE has excellent training programs, and integrity is an important part of the culture. The people are fantastically smart! Lots of opportunity to move through different roles and businesses if you are willing to relocate.
column13: A company of this immense size has a hard time getting out of its own way. The focus on process (6 Sigma) is often misapplied to services portions of the business. Engineers are revered - others, not so much. HR functions as kingmakers and are to be feared.
column14: Focus more on better quality and innovation on the product side of the business to better keep up with the competition, but stop trying to force the services side into an ill-fitting 6 sigma formula.

column12: As all he big companies, you belong to a big structure where you don't need to figure out everything yourself. They will train you, feed you, and provide processes for almost everything. And it's a very diverse environment where you can be exposed to all kinds of people.
column13: My business unit was later split from GE to form a JV with another company. It's very common for GE. And sometimes it's good, sometimes not so much. In the middle of this transition, my feeling is: employees really don't have a say. The decision-makers who are deciding your future are mostly out of this. Their interests are untouched.
column14: When doing JV, please consider giving more options to employees - options that do make a sense.

column5: Excellent Company (but so large it's difficult to manage)
column12: Excellent company with a literal ton of opportunities to move into different roles in the company. Lots of opportunities for cross training and networking with different businesses. Salaries and benefits are competitive to comparable businesses. One the forefront of the Industrial Internet.
column13: Company is very large and there is a lot of internal knowledge that one must learn before becoming effective at one's job. The new hire training is abysmal and nearly non-existent. All training is done by the new hire asking questions and learning by failing. It makes for a very stressful first year.
column14: Hire a team responsible for redesigning the training program. Diligently push the business into the Information Technology sector.

column12: The Commercial teams at GE Appliances give their summer interns their own projects and a lot of autonomy. Busy work doesn't count here. Interns are encouraged to attend and participate in big meetings and even company-wide outings and volunteer events.
column13: The on-boarding process isn't great. Interns jump right in - which can be exciting and scary. Interns are the first ones left in the dust when things get too busy. If projects aren't assigned or meetings aren't scheduled, it's easy to become idle. Also, depending on what team of which you're a part, the technical side of the actual appliances can be daunting and hard to learn.
column14: Continue to include interns in things from which they can learn - projects, meetings, one-on-ones, innovations, brainstorms, etc.

column5: Great place to learn and grow
column12: It is the most admired company in the world. It also fits in well with my lifestyle because I can work hard and indepedently when I want to. Besides the competitive salary, GE has good benefits.
column13: You can get lost in the crowd since it is such a big company. I don't know how far up the ladder some one can go as of yet. Some of the downsides may be the higher ups do not have enought time to talk to people for long. This may cause miscommunication and lost time in the long run
column14: Would suggest the company in general think long term, instead of short term quarterly profits.

column5: An excellent place to be in the current economy...
column12: GE as a whole offers a wider possibility of internal career advancement than any other company with which I am familiar. Internal hirings are common and often strongly preferred. The culture both demands success and provides employees with all the tools necessary to achieve success.
column13: GE has a rigorous way of doing things that is very unique to GE. The manner in which issues are communicated across the business is sometimes a bit awkward in comparison to other companies with which I have worked. As a "lean" organization, technology for business applications is largely outdated as sometimes not viewed as a necessity.
column14: Invest in centralized technological tools and applications to increase efficiency across the organization.

column12: I worked at GE for a summer, as an intern with absolutely no outside work experience. That said, GE treated me well and like I was a valued member of their community. As an intern, we got to meet many of the upper management and C-level employees. They also treated us to different events to help network and meet more people. This was a great place to intern, I really felt like I was part of a family and a valuable member that contributed to projects.
column13: From my perspective, GE really caters to the IMLP/other professional development programs, so if you are not in one of those, it can be difficult to get noticed, especialy as a young employee.
column14: Keep doing what you're doing

column12: GE is a good, caring company that tries to do things the right way. A lot of very talented people. Great learning environment. And today, with the need to revamp the world's energy delivery systems, it's an important place to work.
column13: The matrix structure just does not work for all parts of the business. Organizational structures and processes that were designed for industrial businesses are not very effective for areas where agility and creativity are key (e.g., software), so there's a lot of frustration with the pace at which things get done.
column14: Lose the matrix. It may be great for manufacturing stuff, but it doesn't work well for everything. Businesses like software require different processes and different culture.

column5: Great place to take on responsibility in a tough industry
column12: Lots of opportunity to take on responsibility and own a part, product or process. Good salary and working in GE provides a lot of interaction with other businesses and a very competent collection of people. Many opportunities to connect globally. Good set of tools and the business is investing heavily in the future. Business outlook is positive.
column13: Transportation is a tough industry - unrealistic to expect a lot of cuddling and praise. GE has a strong performance culture so may be difficult to adapt if you are coming from a "business as usual" culture.
column14: Seek simplicity to get the most from employees. Recognize that people are battling every day to make the company successful - find opportunities to celebrate small victories.

column5: Lots of talent, a good company to work for and to have on your resume
column12:
- a truly global company
- lots of great talent and very smart team - way above average and almost no low performers
- lots of opportunities to learn and acquire new skills
- pretty good pay
- lots of work responsibilitties and you're able to work on huge projects
column13:
- poor medical benefits
- lots of red tape
- a very hierarchical structure
- senior leadership only expects to hear good news, few are brave to say how things really are
- unclear strategies from the very top
column14:
- encourage open communication and "force" people to talk about problems: managers are needed to fix problems and build upon success
- cultivate a culture that appreciates people's work and acknowledges their successes

column12: GE is a great place to work and you will be surrounded by many peers who are among the elite A-type personality performers. There are tons of opportunities within GE and with it being such a worldy company, the opportunities afforded are almost limitless.
column13: The culture can be a very "sink or swim" mentality, so coming in from the outside can be tough as there is not much guidance or instruction given. They expect you to figure it out. Also, in order to really move up in one's career path, you really need to be open to moving around in terms of location in order to open up your available opportunities.

column12: Great place for executive management to learn and grow professionally. Lots of changes that enable leaders to stay sharp. Terrific company with deep expertise and technical acumen. And business leaders 4-levels deep think and operate like general managers, which makes GE a great place for leadership development.
column13: Too many changes can distract from long term goals. Lots of internal politics can sometimes lead to a culture of one-upmanship and backstabbing. Sometimes see people getting promoted purely on who they know, however HR is very strong in the company and tries to make things better.
column14: Listen to your lower level employees. Give them sufficient freedom to act. Limit the level of politicization at work.

column12: GE has an ambitious task as it bridges the gap from a traditional industrial company to a more forward looking digital strategy. This makes for exciting and challenging problems in the analytics space, with visible real-world impact. Right now they are also moving away from the Jack Welch mentality and are very people and family focused.
column13: There is a little of what I would call "Big Business Malaise" in certain parts of the organization and many people move horizontally in their careers. There is also a slightly unhealthy cost obsession where cost is measured completely independently of impact.
column14: The current direction with the digital strategy is the way to go. The recent changes in Benefits make GE an attractive company that will attract good talent.

column5: Difficult place to work. Too much is expected of employees.
column12: Good benefits. Salaried employees get flexible "permissive" time off as opposed to a defined number of days. This is considered a benefit but it has disadvantages.
column13: This is in reference to the headquarters office in Chicago, which is a very difficult, un-supportive environment. Employees are expected to take on a lot of responsibility but are given very little support or leeway to solve issues. Finger pointing is common. You will work your butt off at GE Transportation but it will never be enough, and they will laser-focus on your faults and ignore your strengths.
column14: Employees are human beings. There are only eight work hours in a day, five weekdays in a week, 365 days a year. Try to plan around this and not take advantage of hard-working employees who already give you much more than the average US worker gives to their employers. Realize that you are just as flawed as any other individual. Just because you are in upper management doesn't make you perfect. You might be immune (unlike us lowly employees) but you are not perfect!

column5: High-potential people working hard for their goal; hoping others' goals are aligned. They often aren't.
column12: Great breadth of variability in experience. Two people with the same title and positions will rarely have the same job. New ideas of thought or process are welcomed especially if it includes the word "simplification".
column13: Long term goals are often pushed aside for short-term needs. Continual cost cutting efforts drain morale. Messaging from executives often contradicts actions taken at local level. Most "improvements" or benefits are either a transfer of work or cost savings initiative they hope won't be noticed by the average employee. Anyone who questions the move will be asked to "wear the bigger GE hat".
column14: Mean it when you say, "our employees are our best asset".

column5: Opportunities to move around in large corp.
column12: Good for experience in the large corporation realm. GE tends to like mobility so perfect if you only want to gain experience in various products. You also will have opportunities to recommend many improvements. GE has the money to spend to try new equipment and processes.
column13: GE has cut many of the former benefits. Newcomers will have fewer and fewer benefits, from pensions to healthcare in retirement to vacation time. Their IT department is poor, so you can expect to be using old and clunky software, generally not the latest/greatest.
column14: Value those who stay to learn expertise, not just those who move around. Need medical for retirees.

column12: Plenty of opportunities for the ambitious professional. Overall, a good compensation package. Lots of locations and businesses to choose from. Great development for young leaders, from top development programs to a wide variety of training.
column13: Mileage may vary depending on business, site, function, product line ... Lots of leadership changes can mean instability for professionals, with constant barriers put up ... budget cuts, travel freezes, etc.
column14:
Simplification effort is great ... focus a little more on removing the internal barriers erected around cost control. Being leaner in that level of control will pay for itself. 

Don't push out top talent because it makes a layoff easier ... long term product health depends on the expertise developed over time.

column12: GE produces leaders. The best thing you can ever get out of GE is the training they offer. GE is dedicated to making the best leaders possible. I would strongly recommend their leadership programs from FMP, OMLP to IMLP. All great starting places for recent college grads.
column13: People are addicted to their work. Everyone is very hard working but unfortunately, not the place for people who enjoy work/life balance.
column14: GE tries to go into every business that is profitable at that time. It is a conglomerate of many industries, from NBC media to Financial services to making turbine engines and so on. I think GE needs to stick to few core businesses that are highly profitable and concentrate on expanding them.

column12:
The GE name on your resume.
Own a product or process from beginning to end.
column13: Lots of politics.Absolutely no training provided. Past due jobs get assigned to you. Random assignments thrown at you and are asked to figure it out at your own. No structure to the learning process. This way learning is severely affected. No guidance or support or mentoring provided to new employees. Multiple people watching over your shoulder and you are doing the job all by yourself. Constant pressuring to complete jobs by deadline (even past due jobs), doesn't matter even if there is a learning curve. People in charge don't want to listen or hear what the actual problems / issues are. They just want the job done. Extremely bureaucratic and chaotic. Disorderly and lots of confusion. Highly understaffed.
column14: Acknowledge the fact that people at the bottom of the career ladder do make a difference. Their effort does make a contribution to the company bottom line. A slight praise or a 'Thank you' could probably help in renewed motivation to keep performing.

column5: GE invests heavily in the training and growth of their employees
column12: The most competent, motivated, and skilled workforce I have ever worked with. The most valuable resource at GE is by far the people, I know of many employees that have left to work elsewhere and they either become leaders in their new companies or come back to GE because the love the culture here so much.
column13: Highly technical and competitive, you must be willing to work hard and learn everyday. The culture here is focused on continued everyday improvement of yourself and your co-workers. Be prepared for honest developmental feedback and be prepared to actually execute on your personal development plans, including furthering your strengths, but also working on your weaknesses.

column12: If you enjoy a larger company atmosphere, GE has great programs for employees and enough opportunity to move around and gain great experience. They were quite progressive in their views on working remotely, but I've heard that may have changed in the last year.
column13: Long working hours, but typically quite flexible. Many matrix reporting relationships to manage. A LOT of systems and nuances to work with due to the organizational structure - this can be very frustrating when trying to simplify and lean what is in your area of influence.
column14: Standardize across the company, not just within small areas - it has to be proliferated across the organization for the smaller office to feel that things are getting better.

column12: GE O&G business has products lines from upstream to downstream and is a huge company. There are a lot of opportunities to learn about the various products and excel. The ratings below are for GE O&G and does not reflect GE at large.
column13: As the O&G business is based on acquisitions, there isn't much transparency between the individual business and there are a lot of silos
column14: Cross pollinate individuals between the GE O&G business and also other GE businesses to instill culture. These individuals need to come from various levels senior leaders, managers, tech leaders, manufacturing managers to individual contributors. Immerse this individuals in a few months of training to understand the O&G customers and the products that GE supplies.

column5: A+ all around: job, team, company
column12: GE values their employees and focuses on employee development! They reward good work and provide opportunities to excel and to succeed. The team I work with is phenomenal and I'm working on leading edge technology. After years of working for horrible bosses and mediocre companies, I've finally found my sweet spot!
column13: Only con is GE has decided to sell my company GE Capital---but, even still, executive management has been transparent and has shown such commitment in keep employees and assisting others in making the necessary transition! Still the best company I've ever worked for and hope I never have to leave.
column14: Continue to value your greatest assets...employees! You're doing an excellent job!

column5: GE puts their employees to work
column12: Great benefits. Good environment to learn and grow. If you are will to relocate, opportunities are endless at GE.
column13: Looong hours. They give everyone a laptop to make sure you can work late nights. This is an environment where management will feed you projects and keep feeding them to you until you scream. It's all about doing more with less (people). Resource constrained, stretch opportunities are all key words used to describe your life at GE. Never enough people for a project, and management is always looking for team members to stretch beyond their over-burdened role into new areas.
column14: Long days and little reward leaves the worker bees a bit short on morale.

column5: Great place to start your career. Tradeoffs - pay and extreme workload demands.
column12: Personal growth and development. No shortage of opportunities to "stretch" yourself. The organization is so leanly staffed, that you get an opportunity to participate in everything.
column13: It's a machine. Extremely short-term, financial focus. The work/life balance seem to only apply to select groups, for PR purposes. In reality, too much "life" focus will leave you behind, or out. Haven't seen less than 50 hrs/week in years. "pay at the 50% of market,"
column14: Reconsider a 4% "effect on payroll," per year. In the US, food and energy prices are up over 10% and 30% this year alone, respectively. Putting us way behind the marketplace.

column5: If you don't have any room in your brain to learn, don't bother to apply for a salary band career at GE.
column12: Every 18 months to two years, the opportunity to seek a new role becomes available; if you do not like your job or boss, you have the ability to control your own future to a point. Good benefits, good periodic rewards as days out at events paid.
column13: There is much work, considerable pressure to learn quickly and produce.Others will help you if you ask, though.
column14: Development must have a flexible schedule; it isn't the same as production. We try to meet dates to please our bosses, but their bosses have ambition.

column12: If lucky enough to get in before the benefit was stopped being offered - pension benefits. Most benefits same as anywhere else. Nothing unique.
column13: The company is targeting layoffs at those with 15+ years of service - save salary and accumulated benefits. Medical cost is extremely high. Unlimited vacation - hard to get 3 weeks off and unlimited means no vacation payout under layoff benefits. Work environment has been in turmoil for at least 4-5 years with management scrambling to save their own jobs by bad mouthing or tripping up other departments. Work production slow due to constant layoff fear. It's very disappointing to see a once successful company fall so far.
column14: Cutting benefits or senior employees is not always the answer as the hubs established are lacking knowledgeable people to guide those that are being hired right out of school or have little work experience. Managers need to play nice in the sandbox to forge ahead. Stop the layoff madness and change the constant fear and dread looming around this - do this and employees will start to flourish with creative solutions and new customer ideas - the taking a chance on proposing new solutions/ideas might actually start again.

column12: Great flexibility with understanding my schedule as a college student. i am most happy with the fact that they are willing to be a more helpful than not type of company. the company has been around for many many years and they will continue to be a leader in the industry of technology and innovation
column13: none so far, i must say that they have been good at allwoing me to take on the level of responsibility of the usual engineers. i have no complaints at all. the only downside would have to be the current strength of the company which is weak.
column14: at time not very responsive to employees. but that is fine, i prefer a hands off style of leadership

column5: Good place to work, if you've got the time.
column12: There are lots of opportunities to be promoted and you learn a lot of valuable skills while working on the manufacturing floor.
column13: Most positions in manufacturing require a lot more hours than the 40 hours that your salary compensates you for and only Operations Leaders receive overtime pay, because there OT is mandatory. Great place to start at, if all you want to do is work a bunch and save money before family life begins.
column14: Stop cutting costs by overworking your salaried employees and begin addressing the very real, and costly issue, of getting an average of only 4 hours of actual labor from the hourly workers on the floor during an 8 hour shift.

column7: Financial Management Program and Financial Analyst
column12: Their entry-level training programs are a great way to start off a career if your primary objectives are gaining a strong foundation (albeit a GE-focused one). The industries they work in are on the forefront of the global economy (Energy, Healthcare, Finance, etc.).
column13: The "merit-based" culture sounds fantastic in theory, but not as much in practice at the General. It creates a culture of finger-pointing and blame-avoidance rather than teamwork and working towards common goals. Also, the health insurance went from great to significantly below average over the course of about a year. The costs were shifted to employees (although it's tough to blame them, seeing as how their costs were ballooning). If you want to succeed there, you have to make work your life. I have not seen any higher-level folks (nor seen anyone advance) unless they spend countless hours working at the office and out of the office.
column14: Focus more on long-term goals rather than quarterly results. Create a culture of successful employees by helping them to find the right fit.

column12: I have been working at GE in San Ramon for over a year and have witnessed unprecedented growth. While most of the product work is in the build phase, one can see the imminent monetization phase materializing pretty soon. It will the place the company in an unimaginable growth trajectory. You would want to be a part of this explosion - work on state of the art technology, solve problems at an amazing scale and get rewarded. Great benefits to go with it
column13: No upside for the employee in growth
column14: The company should follow the west coast trend and allow employees who contribute to this growth, benefit from it - introduce RSUs.

column12: As a large corporation, there are many opportunities for lateral movement, especially for younger workers seeking to enrich their careers if there is a willingness to relocate & take on more responsibility.
column13: Overall, upper management is too layered and far-removed from their customers. Many of us took issue with their stated devotion to customers, when quite the opposite was true. This was discouraging as corners were cut in the quality department in order to provide the goods, which often were sub-standard. That's not to say that the general employee base was responsible, but decisions made at the top often disregarded the downstream product quality. Operating from a manufacturing-based philosophy left the projects-based businesses GE acquired with a negative: the proverbial square peg in the round hole. Some of their processes did not function well in the world of reality. However, there was no sense of wanting to streamline/replace with proven cost and time-effective practices. Similar to working for a government entity. Work-life balance was almost nonexistent, depending on your position. Weekly subjection to pc fluff; HR & finance call the shots.

column5: Great place to start your career!
column12: Management training, clarity of performance measures linked to company goals, talent of fellow employees, clear performance measurement systems, great opportunities to move around the globe. Diversity of industries and businesses. Great processes in place for best practice sharing and learning between businesses. Lots of good mentoring possiblities. Company has alway had a strond focus on community service and the environment.
column13: Lack of work life balance. Focus on performance can sometimes blind leaders to good people who have potential to be developed. If you do not start on one of the leadership programs you can be easily passed over for promotion, training and recognition.
column14: Is promotion really based on attitiude as well??

column12: Well known global company that is very competitive in all the markets they service. Fast pace environment with little down time. Very Fair Review Process. Promote advancement in education, provide excellent training opportunities, get to work with very knowledgable people and can gain large amounts of experience very quickly. As a new employee you are challanged quickly
column13: Very large Company and there is little access to management more than one level up. Have to be mobile to move up the salary scale. If not top talent employee in the ranking system it is easy to fall behind on salary compared to outside employement opportunities
column14: Take the time to find out internal employees career goals and work on helping them acheive them

column12:
Great growth opportunities in expanding business segments when coming off internal leadership programs
Interesting products and technology- engineers will have a field day
Great perks for top performing teams and senior management
Competitive salary and bonuses
Always attempt to retain top level talent
Good launch pad to another company when working for a limited period of time
column13:
Corporate politics tough for employees not properly trained; must be aggressive to seek promotions
Always driving to metrics affecting the bottom line without properly identifying root cause of problems
Stretch employee headcounts thin to cut costs
Many employees really are simple numbers to senior management
Leadership programs essentially function as internal MBA for GE; however are not viewed in same light elsewhere
column14: Work vigorously to attempt to show gratitude towards lower-level employees more often

column5: Suddenly disappointed & sadly disenchanted after 20+ years of steadfast loyalty to every aspect of GE.
column12:
Historically- Very sound leadership in middle & upper management positions. 
The opportunity to enroll in leadership coursework that is unsurpassed in American Business.
Quality products with a loyal customer base in multiple markets.
column13: Headquarters for Energy in Atlanta has become oversensitive to promoting women, increasing minority headcount and generally ultra focused on cultural diversity. It is actually difficult to find people working there that know what energy business products and services we provide. Those without 10+ years seem to be in a world of their own and more concerned with social & business networking than serving our customers and working past 5 PM.
column14: Difficult times call for difficult decisions. Yet, Energy Services employees did nothing but succeed in 2008 and will do so again in 2009. Freeze the salaries of those who took bad risks in GE Money & elsewhere. Reward those who are directly contributing to growth while making great profits with real products & services in other segments of our company.

column5: Attempts to create work life balance, but way too much bureaucracy and superiors with turned up noses.
column12: The pay was excellent, and GE is a real mover and shaker in the world today, so there is a sense of accomplishment that comes with working for them. Benefits were also excellent and there was room for growth as long as you were willing to be loyal to the company for many years and work your way up the ladder.
column13: Extremely full of bureaucracy, very poor work life balance, at least in the IT group I worked in. 7 am to 7 pm days were normal for everyone on my team. I also felt very micro-managed by all superiors with meetings taking up at least 60-75% of each work day.
column14: My team leader never wore jeans on casual Friday, because the team lead never wore jeans, no one else did. The atmosphere was always tense, businesslike, and unfriendly while I was in the office. It would be nice to see a lot more interest in individuals, alongside the interest in team productivity, by upper management.

column12:
Great leadership experience
Lots of responsibility.
Ability to move from role to role and continue to grow. 
Company culture focused on meritocracy
Work with other very talented people.
column13:
Expect that could make more at different company. 
Once you reach certain level, can be hard to take the next step. 
Sometimes too much focus on cost out.
column14: I hear over and over again when people leave that the management was blindsided by it. Senior leaders say that they blame the bosses when a talented person leaves, but it's usually a too little, too late situation. Management needs to make sure that they reward high performing employees with additional responsibility and opportunity.

column5: Great compensation, hard to work here.
column12:
A lot of opportunities if you are a good work politician - also depending on department, direct supervisor, etc. (of course).
Expect to work hard, and compete with top notch talent (and know that "so so" performance will never cut it). Yes, I see this as a plus.
column13:
Dis-organized, too many changes, no direct or clear job responsibilities, nor even a title in some cases.
It has been said many, many times, there is an official policy at GE (for any given solution), and there is also always an underground reality of how things get done. No one will ever speak of the reality on a conference call or in an email or pitch, but you will have to know it to get anything done, you may have to support it and be part of it.
Senior staff at GE sees a scrubbed view of the solutions it employs.
column14: Get input from the business as well as people "in the trenches" (so to speak) about how solutions are REALLY performing (instead of relying upon trumped up performance metrics).

column5: I have worked for many companies over an 18 year span. GE is by far the best run company that I have ever worked for!!
column12: they understand why they are in business and that people make the difference. they invest more in their people than any other company.
column13: If you are not an "A" player, you need to work somewhere else as you will not have many opportunities
column14: Stay focused on building people. Continue to build focus on customer over shareholder value.. By focusing on customers, you will be able to keep your offerings in-line with what the market demands.. Shareholder value is an indirect indicator that the company is adding value.

column5: Fun workplace to be an engineer
column12: Great people to work with, fun product to work on, very dynamic workplace, lot of new products and opportunities for all engineering types. The products are diverse and ultimately system packages or products. Hands on product and manufacturing. Pretty good ability for employees to grow. The area has a low cost of living and most common shopping is close.
column13: Organizational processes are poor, push to market and bottom line drive many decisions. Union relations can make work fun and interesting. Roles and responsibilities not clear in new product launches.
column14: Align business to support NPI's better. Reward and take care of your hard working employees. Keep investing in R&D.

column5: Dynamic and demanding, full of opportunities
