column12: GE is a great company for people, who want to challenge themselves and grow professionally. The level of employees there is very high: smart, professional and hard working. The company is so large that there a lot of career opportunities in several different industries.
column13: GE is known for being very numbers focused and it's true. Seems like everything is measured and without solid financial support, it's hard to get a project improved...which means that they struggle with taking risks. They also have the forced employee ranking system, where only 10 top employees can get excellent rating and nice salary increases...which leaves many great employees discouraged.
column14: Remove the forced employee ranking system!

column12: Good benefits,salary, overall a good place to work as long as you are not in management and don't care about job security.
column13: First level managers were good to excellent. Next level up were generally useless. That level of management usually were hired from outside GE or from another division and had little or no market or product knowledge and were strickly spreadsheet jockies. One more level up and the arrogance was extreme. I had four very good managers over 10 years that were very long time GE employees. They all only lasted a few months to a few years in that position before leaving GE entirely. None would say so but we all knew they left because of the people they reported to. They were constantly reorganizing, shutting down divisions, moving functions from one locations to another, and moving mfg out of the country.
column14: Hire managers that know the products and markets they are managing instead of spreadsheet jockies that don't give a damn about the people they manage.

column12:
It is large enough that you can network with literally thousands of people. I'm a firm believer that a company's worth is measured by the quality of the people who work there, and GE inherited (through several acquisitions) some truly dedicated professionals.

There are always opportunities to advance, since (in my tenure) there was a lot of turnover.
column13:
For such a large company, I was surprised by the absence of processes when I joined. I have worked for family-owned businesses that took better care to provide computer backups, for one example. 

Promotions often seemed overly influenced by the "diversity" of the candidates (as opposed to their qualifications). I was verbally discouraged by one HR manager from applying for a job because I did not have the pair of chromosomes they wanted.
column14: Centralizing in Florida has sucked the energy out of the other centers of excellence, which were driving policy and innovation for the company long before Bradenton joined. Those acquired companies in the distant outposts feel less investment in GE's success because the division has become too "top-down" from HQ.

column5: Terrific resume value --- great to start your career not for mid career switches unless you are senior enough !
column12: GE's resume value is terrific. Extremely well managed and fair in almost every respect. I learnt so much about how to think, analyze, communicate, collaborate and deliver results. It was amazing to see how well managed the company is and how connected all the divisions are. You truly feel connected to the entire organziation. There are lots of best practice exchange meetings and you get to meet and see people from across the company. Extremely disciplined in all respects - everyone is focussed on the goals and timelines. The company geniunely invests in development of its employees globally. There are a multitude of career opportunities and there is real interest in finding the next role for you based on your skills, performance, development needs and one can easily move across functions - operations, finance, sales, marketing etc.
column13: Great place to start your career or move to early on in your career. The company places a lot of value on GE experience. You lose out to people who have graduated from one of GE's famous programs - FMP, IMLP, TLP, Audit Staff etc. There is too much focus on internal stuff and not enough on external customer oriented impact. Not great for work - life balance especially if you are on the management track. While the career development process is fair I found that relationships are important but then they are important everywhere ! You have go with the company speak - any deviation from company speak is viewed upon as negative instead of positive feedback. Great place to be in your 20's and if you are in your late 30's make sure that the position is visible and offers you an executive band track (EB in GE speak). If you are not EB you are NOT on the management track and your growth will be restricted though the company will take adequate care of you.
column14:
Actively pursue people who are different (not the typical white midwest type - no offence meant) and make them feel comfortable.
Reward external impact (with customers) as much as internal impact

column5: Great place to work, but don't stay forever.
column12: Top Notch leadership programs. Great pay but would probably get paid more for same job some place else. Lots of networking opportunities through the various affinity groups within company. Chance to travel internationally.
column13: Work long hours, especially if you are at the top. In spite of lots of talk about work/life balance, it is difficult to achieve it. Performance review is so long and complex you have to go to meetings in order to make sure you grasp the concept and do it right.
column14: Don't be stingy with the money. Make the effort to truly understand a business that's newly acquired. Stop thinking on a quarterly basis. Admit mistakes.

column12: Fair treatment to employees. Advancement opportunities are always available if you work hard and prove yourself. The work environment is very good and the company is accepting when you need time off for personal reasons.
column13: Politics can be extreme in a business the size of GE. Sometimes, due to the size of the company, projects that could typically get completed in a few months in a smaller company take much longer at GE.
column14: I think that the management at GE does a fairly good job. It would be nice to have our leaders join us in the field once in a while to get a true feel for what is happening in the workplace.

column5: So far, GE Software has given me unbelievable support, recognition and opportunities for growth.
column12:
- Market-competitive compensation
- Smart, team-oriented and supportive colleagues
- Commitment to excellence and to GE Values
column13:
- Commute to San Ramon is unpleasant, for most tech professionals
- Open work space approach works well for developers and engineers, but is disastrous for Marketing, HR, Finance. Difficult to impossible to hold effective meetings (even by phone) or to do any sort of critical or abstract thinking
column14:
- Consider the best of Silicon Valley approaches to improve location challenge
1) Satellite offices
2) Work from home flexibility
3) Company shuttles

- Ditto with open work space challenge -- build offices for your top talent.

column12:
Your pay is an important part of your employment with GE. In addition to your competitive starting salary, the company recognize and rewards individual performance. 

GE benefits are aligned to local market practice and often include pension/retirement plans and healthcare coverage. Some locations offer subsidized services such as sports facilities, medical/dental care and car-parking, and in a number of countries, you may have the chance to participate in a Share save programs.
column13: Since GE is a Matrix company, the working environment in GE is highly taxing, for these reason GE employees have to spread their knowledge and ideas to enable them fit for the role in which they are or will be shown the way out.

column12: GE is a fantastic company to work for if you're looking for incredible opportunities and are willing to work hard. Fantastic experience, tons of responsibility, smart people. I've been with GE for eight years and have moved across the nation, worked deals across the world, and been given enormous growth opportunities.
column13: Not much to say here... other than if you're looking for a comfortable job where you can clock in and clock out, then this is not the company for you. Be prepared to do what it takes to get the job done - yes - that means nights and weekends :)
column14: Have more corporate offices on the west coast!

column12: If you really push yourself at GE more and more opportunities will become available. GE is an innovator using cutting edge processes and provide a vast amount of experience that wouldn't normally be available to you else where.
column13: Management seems very disconnected from the supporting salary roles and hourly employees. Unless you came from a GE sponsored program (Edison, OMLP, or CAS) your growth is very limited regardless of experience or work ethic. With-in GE if you want to climb the latter you need to mess up or under perform. People consistently fall up hill. If you are good at your job and excel, that's where you will stay since they don't want to lose you from that position. GE as an industrial giant is slowly collapsing from its former glory.
column14: Focus on leading your teams rather than a face to the next level up managers. Don't blindly waste money on insignificant facility upgrades, when the budget can be better utilized on resources and equipment that will improve job efficiency and effectiveness.

column5: Great career growth with good mentors, nice challenges, and a wide variety of businesses.
column12: I have always worked with good people who have high integrity. The work has been very interesting and I have had access to great development opportunities.
column13: Benefits seem competitive, and in many areas pay is too, but not everywhere. It's a complex matrix that can be slow to respond and frustrating to manage through. Employees don't feel a close connection to each other at the major locations, but it's the opposite at smaller ones.
column14: Worry as much about the strong performers as you do about the poor ones and that will help. Make sure you find one on one time for the people one below one.

column5: Interesting and challenging projects, but lots of bureaucracy and red tape to get things done
column12: Big, challenging projects; Opportunities to travel/see the world to install/repair products and educate customers; Work flexibility, depending on role and manager; Plenty of training and opportunity for advancement if you are identified as a high performer
column13: No real organizational structure, nobody tends to know who/what department should be making decisions or taking ownership; internal IT applications/infrastructure are outdated and frequently inhibit working efficiently.
column14: Clearly identify your organizational structure and define the roles each department plays. Make sure that ownership and the strategy behind it is communicated to your employees; the employees need to know who is going to make decisions.

column12: General maintenance exposes an employee to a variety of experience. Since I have been at GE, I have worked on stamping equipment, injection molding equipment, overhead conveyors, assembly lines and automated fabrication equipment. Also, you do work outside your trade, expanding your skill set. Competitive pay and benefits comparable with other employers in area.
column13: GE is in the process of selling the appliance division. Future pay, benefits, and work conditions are uncertain.
column14: Happy employees are productive and show up for work on time. People are happy when they earn enough to be able to afford what they need and still be able to have some of what they want.

column12: Pay and benefits above average, especially vacation accruals. Opportunities to transfer to a variety of positions to diversify your skills. Tuition reimbursement. Global business which is more stable than most.
column13: Old company built on command and control business management style of last century (and earlier). Senior Management wants to change to a team and empowerment culture, but is yet to be felt downstream. For hourly, there are often roadblocks to transferring to other positions due to "business needs" or efficiency, and often politically driven. For Salaried, moving every 2-3 years is expected, if not required, to advance.
column14: Accelerate teaming culture from top to bottom to unlock the creative ideas of the work force that have been bottled up.

column5: Good global company, strong integrity culture
column12: Global company with strong businesses (Aviation, Healthcare, Power, Renewables, Oil & Gas). Talent is generally very good and the culture of integrity is strong which helps in doing business around the world.
column13: Current transition of management (CEO, CFO, Senior leadership), changes in Board of Directors and structure of the company creates a lot of uncertainty. Ongoing restructuring & cost out actions necessary but painful
column14: Stay focused on defining a sustainable portfolio of core businesses and don't overreact to the analyst & press reviews. Need a 10 year view and solid execution, not a 1 year promise that requires unsustainable actions to hit short term targets

column5: GE is a great company to jumpstart your career
column12: Bredth of opportunities across a wide range of industries. Great people to work with and are NICE people, which is apparently a rare occurance (especially within the finance field). People who are mid level managers to senior managers are very smart, quick witted, and definitely a breed of their own. Seems like you need to be very competent to stay within GE, but will be rewarded hansomly if you can stick it through. Lots of opportunity for growth, and a very lean firm structure considering the 300,000+ employees it hires.
column13: Bureaucratic, lots of red tape, but still working to improve it.
column14: Be available for more mentoring

column5: Huge potential to grow within the company!
column12: Huge potential to grow within the company! The runway in GE is fairly long, and growth opportunities are definitely there if you go through the FMP program. The FMP program provides fundamental skills and technical knowledge to be highly successful in your next career step by combining real hands on training and classroom sessions. 2/3 of GE’s CFOs have graduated from this prestigious program.
column13: The program is extremely prestigious internally at GE. However, externally the FMP program is virtually unknown. Outside of the northeast area, the FMP program is non-existent and will not provide the same level of opportunities you have within GE. That being said, there is a feeling of being “trapped” at GE unless your willing to shift into the slower track externally. However, the GE name does say a lot on your resume.
column14: The FMP recruiting events are a bit misleading. The program is presented as an alternative to Investment Banking but in reality its an alternative to joining an Auditing firm, with very few IB type rotations.

column5: If you are going to work for GE, look at Energy
column12: One of the best reasons to work for Energy would have to be the opportunity to move within the company, given good performance reviews and fulfillment of certain time restrictions.
column13: After a while, your role seems to morph into what could be two full time jobs, 40 hour weeks dont seem to give you enough time to resolve complex issues, especially when you are on conference calls for 4 hours a day...
column14: We pay too much for contracted services that in some cases are shaky/unreliable at best, at the end of the day they ultimately dont own the processes they are supporting, so there is little incentive.

column5: Career Opportunities Abound for the well networked & fwd thinking employee.
column12:
Career opportunities, diversity of the workforce, global teams.
An employee can move form Aircraft engines to credit cards to water desalination if they so desire, this is the value of a conglomerate. Then they can move from India to the USA to Singapore.
The career training is second-to-none IMHO.
column13: By design some bureaucracy naturally exists in a company this size, so if the expectation is that all decisions and processes are nimble, one need to gauge their expectations accordingly.
column14: Beware of folks on your teams that can give you false impressions/hopes...publicly ask questions a few levels deep during decision making moments...this will drive more direct and efficient behavior

column5: GE brings good things to their stakeholders? In the past Jeff immelt always made the best of bad situations.
column12: Mgmt training ground & exposure to multiple industries.
column13: Far more conservative of late (understandably) so less fun, less funding for new challenges, and more nail biting.
column14: Stop redirecting needed capital from growth businesses to GE Capital. The Green Initiatives PR campaign was good but for some reason was silenced. Where is the upbeat PR that contastantly talked of bringing good things to life? Now that the USA has its new president, what is GE doing to profit from more spending in infrastructure, alternative energies, and even cheap financial companies assets for sale?

column12:
* One of the most enduring and successful companies in the world
* An extraordinary commitment to integrity
* In the early stages of a major transformation from a solid, but stodgy giant to an agile innovator who embraces the opportunities that come with a volatile and uncertain world
* Overwhelming commitment to Customer-Driven planning and execution
* Possibly the deepest commitment to employee development of any major employer
column13:
* Some vestiges of old-school change aversion and Not Invented Here syndrome remain
* Need to step up communication by a lot to be in sync with rapid change scenarios
* Corporate still clings to Central Command and Control mentality
column14:
Communicate Much Much More in Advance as well as changes occur
Decentralize

column5: Great place to launch a career
column12: Clearly, one the best reasons to work for General Electric is the fact that it is such a well-known company with a history of excellence. GE is one of the most recognized names in industry and looks great on any resume. Additionally, the leadership programs that GE offers are first rate. As a member of the IMLP program I was given constant exposure to the leadership team at the company. Also, as an IMLP I had my choice of some of the most interesting projects and would be sought out by project leaders.
column13:
- Hard to meet everyone as company is so large
- Relocation Stipend could be better
column14: Continue with constant communication

column12: Large organization with opportunities to move. Good place to hide for a career as long as you have decent performance appraisals.
column13: Politically correct environment which is heavy on bureaucracy and work flows. Constant talk of "simplification" but have not seen anything other than lip service. Abundant job hopping, especially in management ...which is encouraged for growth (best route within the company) but horrible for business continuity. Matrix Organization intended to cause creative stress, but should be renamed to Siloed Fiefdom Organization to reflect reality. Also, bonus structure tied to unrealistic goals (20% increase in revenue for 2013? Really? Pure fantasy. For the record, we are down to plan by about 10%.... well outside of the bonus range unless you are in the Executive Band [EB]).
column14: Follow through... make the process more simple, but restructure matrix so one manager has some control and is able to set direction instead of hoping the collective does not have key individuals worried more about their career advancement as opposed to the organizational needs,

column5: GE still a great place to spend a career
column12: Great people who pull together. A much, much, better company to work for than when run by Jack Welch, who ran a sadistic frat house. Terrific opportunities now for diverse candidates. Company is making tough choices to remain relevant. A good place to work. You live and die by the numbers and accomplishing your commitments.
column13: Benefits, being rolled back at every opportunity. Previously GE was the gold standard. Pensions are no longer provided, retirement health care, LTC insurance, other insurances, vacations for executive level have all been cut back or eliminated. Culture is such that working on vacations is not unusual... Like many companies.

column12: Benefits have always been a strong point but have begun to diminish over the past 3 years. Pay is very good and competitive. Movement within the organization between businesses is attractive in that you can work in multiple industries within the same company. In many instances the caliber of talent that you work with is very high, but not in all instances.
column13: Inconsistent performance expectations across team members. GE often calls itself a "meritocracy" but this is not true. All too often recognition and advancement are given on poorly defined criteria. Leadership is incredibly inconsistent in messaging.. the organization feels like it is unstable with a continuing pattern of cost cutting, poorly defined performance recognition. Over the past 2 years the stability of the business has become questionable and strategy is unclear.
column14: Return to valuing the team members that deliver, recognize them, seek them out, leverage and reward performance. Define the strategy to the employees to demonstrate that there is a future other than continued cost cutting.

column12: Great benefits and leadership training. They have great leadership programs that give you a jump start. If you are considered at the top, then you are weened to grow.
column13: Overworked and sometimes leadership is based on who you know and not what you know. If you are not seen as top talent within the company, then you will not move up. People will only promote growing you and your career if you are deemed the best which does not necessarily mean its based upon performance but rather who you have networked with.
column14: Give credit where credit is due. Do not based decisions around politics but rather based on performance.

column5: Great for experience but not long term
column12: Very large international network that makes it very challenging from a information security standpoint. You will get lots of experience and challenges thrown at you on a daily basis that you will not see anywhere else because of the vast scale of the network.
column13: Work for GE not as a contractor if you can. Contractor positions can be shaky but GE positions are very stable. Communication is very poor and there is a lot of political garbage that goes on between the corporate security team and the rest of the teams. This is because they have a leader who is more interested in his next book than actually establishing good relationships between teams. This makes for very poor information sharing and make it very difficult to do your job.
column14: Get rid of the people with the "I'm a star" attitudes. Encourage information sharing. GE has money to spend on technology and needs to spend it. Stop being so cheap and give your security people the tools to do their jobs.

column5: Highly Competent People, Gap between Leaders and Employees
column12: Strong ethics background. People are very capable and competent. Follow leadership direction. Huge strength in organization and backing. Excellent training and development. Working on organization simplification, again. Don't track vacation, personal time, or sick time.
column13: Quarterly driven, rather than focus on long term sustaining strategy. Lost discipline with Lean and Six Sigma, and Quality programs. Arrogance displayed with customers and suppliers. Employees are disposable. Complicated Matrix Organization. Functionally driven. No root-cause analysis for fact based decisions. Problems are unacceptable if not presented with immediate solution. Tough to leave if you are well compensated compared to external market. Benefits package has deteriorated, including medical and retirement. Metrics driven and must work lots of hours, with high stress.
column14: Be willing to surface problems and learn from mistakes. Look at the gap with the GE Employee Opinion Survey and resolve the difference between Executives and Senior Professional employees. Stop spinning the numbers.

column12: Large company with unlimited career paths. Company values employees that strive to advance their career and also those that want to stay put and become an expert.
column13:
Very vonurable to market fluctuations resulting in neverending job insecurity. 
Performance measurement is not consistent from building to building or even manager to manager.
column14: Need to standardize performance evaluation so everybody is measured on the same scale. Also new contribution evaluations are too course snd do not allow for destinction from a bottom 10% employee all the way up to a 90%. Everybody is in the same bucket. Need to better recognize skilled employees so the feel valued and that their contributions make a difference.

column12: GE has a great culture and can build some of the best managerial talent around. They will expect you to take on tough projects and deliver results. Meeting and exceeding metrics is the best way to get noticed.
column13: Sometimes you may be on an island to deliver results. Everyone is working on their thing and even in a collaborative team, you may struggle to get full team engagement.
column14: Engage high potential entry level employees and discuss opportunities for growth early and often. It's a big company, and often times employees have felt forgotten. That being said, go out of your way mainly for those who continue to seek challenges.

column12: It looks good on your resume when you break free...
column13: Poor management, no work-life balance. This place is the reason for the saying "it's a man's world". I was one of the few women and experienced a lot of sexism... a colleague expected me to throw away his leftover lunch for him, I was criticized for being a mother and "deciding to work instead of provide care" for my child, and TOLD BY MY BOSS TO NOT GET PREGNANT. Then, some time later when I told him I was pregnant with my second child ( I had my first child before I worked for this place), I was SCOLDED for being pregnant and then given a poor review right after I returned from maternity leave. I was an easy scapegoat for my manager's requirement to give someone a poor rating. He claimed poor attendance because I was on maternity leave and how I had frequent appointments to see my doctor (I was a high-risk patient and had to see my OB once per week). I resigned shortly after. Stay away from this life-sucking place.
column14: Realize it's not 1940 anymore and get over yourselves. Women, who are also mothers, CAN do the same work as a man.

column5: GE - Good for Career, if you can live through it.
column12:
Great for the next job - having GE on the resume is a huge door-opener. There's a certain credibility that comes from working for the company - in large part, because employers can be reasonably sure of your capabilities. For example, if you were in one of the 'program' jobs, such as IMLP or FMP, there's a cadre of people who have completed the same program that gives a benchmark for your performance. It's like attending an Ivy League school vs. State U. ... Ivy League is known everywhere, but State U. is less well-known except in the geographic region. If you want to see the world, Join GE. 
The old adage about moving around has really been replaced; there's more emphasis on learning & mastering the job now, instead of learning every job in the company by relocation/reassigning you every 12-18 months. That's a huge improvement.
column13:
Given the flat organization structure, you can be a the same level for many years. You'll get pay increases, but not necessarily a title change. Their performance review process is too rigorous - there's just no getting around the "bottom 5%" situation with them. If you're graded as "least effective", you should get back in the job market, fast.
You're expected to stay in a role for 18-24 months, and that is rigorously enforced. Even if you're the best candidate for an opening, if you haven't hit that milestone, you can forget about changing jobs. (Caveat - unless you're considered" Top Talent" in the annual Performance Management derby).
Annual reviews are done, and a huge amount of time goes into this - almost bringing other work to a halt. However, your pay increases aren't necessarily annual - for Top Talent, it is 12 months, if you're considered "Highly Valued" - the middle 85% or so of employees, it is between 15-20 months. If you're "Least Effective" there is no raise.
GE provides great benefits, but the tradeoff is that you will work very, very hard and very long hours. Have a kid, plan to be back on line within days, even if you are taking maternity leave. There's not a lot of empathy about dealing with family matters. The expectation is that you are available 24/7, even in non-customer-facing roles.
column14:
Drop that stupid rule about getting rid of the bottom 5% each year. You create unnessary churn in the workforce - if you're going to insist people stay in a job for 18-24 months before changing their role, then you should give a person the same length of time to improve performance.
Recognize the need for telecommuting and other alternative work arrangements, especially given how electronically connected the company has made all employees.

column12: challenging, fair, interesting, professional, lot of possibilities, multinational workenvironment, possibility to work at the same company, but with always changing positions - if you want to change, you can work in different countries, with different cultures, safe place to work, reliable employer, fun teams
column13: in very few cases people get positions that is very questionable, sometimes company politics can be frustrating, work can be overwhelming, you need to be able to say no, otherwise you can get lost in the workload, sometimes seems bureaucratic, IT support line is useless in most cases with respect to the few good IT professionls
column14: less politics, would be nice sometimes to have more straight communication

column5: Engineering work at GE Energy Services Measurement and Control Solutions
column12:
Employee integrity - focus on safety, quality, timeliness, cost
Great products, challenging projects, flexible work time.
recreational opportunities, location: 20 minutes away from Lake Tahoe
column13: matrix management: it is hard to know what your priorities are and how to please multiple bosses. some times it is hard to know what the right thing to do is due to conflicting goals.
column14: encourage employees to stay in job long enough to gain depth and experience. switching jobs every two years in order to get a better raise does not lead to depth. Read the book Silos, Politics and turf wars.

column5: Intelligent community with tons of networking and advancement opportunities
column12: Globally respected conglomerate with opportunities to advance both professionally and personally. You have a wealth of learning tools and very smart collegues who are more than willing to show you the ropes. If you play your cards right, you can have a long lasting career with this company.
column13: Salary by far is the downside to working for GE. Get in, get the knowledge, meet the people. But, similar to other business models, if you advance from within the company there is only a minor salary increase, versus if you come from outside, the offer is definitely sweeter. Great company overall.

column5: Good stepping stone for entry levels
column12:
-Thorough processes ranging from procurement, engineering, production
-Great stepping stone to top tier of other companies
-Occasional work from home
-Expected to work overtime (no pay) based on others' mistakes
-Erie's lower cost of living is attractive
-Business casual attire
column13:
-Too many software systems act as obstacles to getting work done
-Working with the Union. Lack of motivation or interest to solve problems.
-Feudal system for career advancement. Your boss would have to be promoted and recommend you for his position. From Entry level engineer to Sub-section manager usually takes at least 10 years
-Company events cater to interns / coops to entice them to stay at Erie. However, Erie is not an exciting town for any entry levels. New employees require social events clubs.
-Compensation is OK. Health benefits are poor. 401k is OK
-Overseas contractors have more leeway when causing mistakes / problems due to their much lower compensation
-Winter is brutal
column14:
-Do not expect quality work or communication from overseas contractors
-Systems need simplification
-Better pool of employee candidates are avail if location is moved to a big city

column5: Great place to launch a career
column12: Great leadership development programs, a lot of opportunities for training, looks great on your resume if you decide to pursue graduate school or a new position elsewhere, decent work-life balance
column13: LImited upward mobility at younger ages, found many instances of people being promoted to manager because it is seen as the next step versus truly being ready to manage, experienced some leaders who were all about working your hours versus working smarter and alloing flexibility
column14: Embrace allowing people autonomy and flexibility in their work and work schedules and you will find a much happier workforce, make this a great place to not only launch a career but want to stay

column12:
- You'll work with very bright people and have an opportunity to learn everyday. 

- Their is almost always an opportunity to step into a different role.
column13:
- Bureaucracy can still be a hindrance although improvements are being made. 

- It does seem that politics still win over good work when it's time to give promotions.
column14: Reward your top talent with compensation and don't always use attrition to reduce headcount. We don't need to go back to the Welch days of cutting the bottom 10% but we shouldn't continue to allow good talent to leave so easily while lower performing employees are just happy to keep collecting a pay check for little effort..

column5: A good company that can be better
column12: The company has its reputation that serves as leverage between you and the customers. They make great end-products which is something that the workers are proud of. The company is big enough to allow people move from one department to another, or from one location to another. The organizational structure brings workers closer to the chain of command than you expect in bigger companies.
column13: Typical of a big company, it is big and departments don't communicate. This leads to policies that make it harder to perform your daily duties. It's all about numbers, and the average worker means nothing to the company. You'll get minimal to no training opportunities working there. The technicians even have to purchase their own tools used to work. Some people have been there for 5 years without a single meaningful raise. Opportunity for growth is therefore slim.
column14: Listen to your employees. Implement a reward system that tracks and recognizes hardworking staff. nothing compares to a meritorious organization that culminates into a high performance work practice organization.

column12: Excellent pay and benefits, working for a well respected brand and company. Training opportunities are top notch.
column13: Leadership culture focused on short term results. Executives operate in stove-pipe mentality - very little collaborative/cooperative effort. Arguments between executives over who will be assigned credit for perceived cost savings and idea generation. Stuff that drives you crazy. Very little room for promotion unless you are a real go-getter and are contributing to the success of an executive level player.
column14: The company is working on a huge shift of culture where performance is defined by outcomes. This is great. Continue this. Get mid level leaders aligned, get some outward focus and context.

column12: The checks clear the bank. They do interesting work and have interesting products and have access to some of the best customers in the world. Mostly it's good people trying to get by in a total F up company.
column13: It's corporate madness. They constantly play games with not just employees but customers alike. It's hard to believe that Edison's company has turned into such an evil corporation. They are constantly changing up things, doing this and that and never really focusing on providing a core product or service. Always gaming the system instead of just doing good work. You would swear these people in management would trip over a dollar to pick up dime. It is just that perverse. They pay well but then you are expected to work 45 to 55 hours per week. You are considered a slacker with hose ours. Some are know to work 80 to 120 hours a week. Some people live at that place. In most cased you are doing the job of one and 1/2 people at least.
column14: Shoot yourself in the head and do the world a favor.

column12: The best reason to work for GE would be to become part of the company that brews the next generation of leaders. The company focuses on leadership development and there are plenty of opportunities there. Everyone in the company works really hard and they drive you further as well. The interesting thing is that there is a culture of helping each other inside of GE, so it's collaborative competitive.
column13: GE's compensation is not up to par with their competitors. On top of that, demanding hours and shitty locations is just typical of GE.
column14: If you want to absolutely attract the best talent, you have to be competitive in all things offered.

column5: GE: Great place to worked, great place to have worked.
column12: Diverse businesses to work for and learn. Good benefits. Smart people to work with.
column13: Salaries are not as high as similar jobs elsewhere. Often high expectations for performance.
column14: Consider the businesses you are in today and how to unlock the most shareholder value out of these businesses. Some belong in the fold and others do not. GE's historic core competency of turning around businesses has not been present through Healthcare, Insurance, Money, etc. We are on a track of buying businesses in good times (buy high) and selling in bad times (sell low). Not a recipe for success.

column5: Lots of great people, almost too many
column12: Working with great people in a very important field for the world right now. Exciting assignments and have a lot of options for growth.
column13: It's huge. There are tons of people and a lot of learning how to do your job is learning who to know. People also move around so often that it can be difficult to keep up.
column14: Communicate the reasons for decisions that impact the jobs and projects employees are working on. When something doesn't receive funding and those working on it think it's a mistake it can cause bitterness. If everyone understands why, then everyone's on the same page.

column12: Great benefits at a low cost to employee, Worldwide name recognition, Very diversified company
column13: Too much overkill...ie., too much time wasted on some overkill positions from people trying to justify their positions and existence within the company, "Permit to Work", "JSA's", "RWA's", "SRA's", "Scorecards", "NPF Scores" on and on and on. To conduct a 10 minute job, this administrative overhead takes that 10 minute job and turns it into a 2 hour job, thereby costing the company money as contractors sit around waiting to get started to do the task they were hired to do. Management actually stated outloud "I Just Don't Know How Anything Gets Done Without All These Meetings"!! Read that again, that's not a typo. That's our actual mentality, and they wonder why people won't stay. Their attitude is that you shouldn't have a family or life outside of GE, that you should willingly devote your extra time on your low salary for the good of "The Business".
column14: Streamline, simplify, keep it simple

column5: A good company that will grow your skills- but it is a demanding culture that some will love and some won't
column12:
GE Transportation is an industry leader, has an increasing global presence, offers sophisticated and challenging work, and is run by a strong upper management team to whom integrity is
important.
column13: GE Transportation is fast paced but also extremely demanding with a sometimes harsh culture. The environment is cordial but this is not a place with frequent happy hours and social functions.
column14: It would be nice if management better balanced the demand for execution with compassion for employees. It is a very professional environment but one that could use a bit more of a human touch.

column5: Great Pay, Great Company, but Tough & Competitve Atmosphere
column12: Co-op's are responsible for important projects, and are relied upon by technology team. Most entry level co-ops are considered as a new full time engineer and are given resposnibilities based on that status. HR managers are flexible with un-paid time off/vacation.
column13: Managers are very demanding. Somewhat of a lack of communication between marketing and engineering team. Also, a loss of feedback from upper level managers is somewhat consistent. Work load and expectations can be very stressful at times.
column14: Management needs to communicate more with technology team about specific projects and why these are valuable to the industry.

column12: Incredibly motivated and passionate group of employees. GE has a talented workforce, opportunity for advancement for those who desire it, and consistent development opportunities.
column13: The geographic location can be challenging, if it is not something you are interested in. Erie PA is not exactly a metropolis and the weather can leave something to be desired.
column14: I would recommend that Management continue doing what it's doing. It does a good job to bring in the best talent, the company seems to operate like a true meritocracy (which is respected by most employees), and it does the best job it can to manage the firm in a consistently challenging global environment.

column12:
Frequent travel, chance to see the world... All expenses covered at all times by the company (food, dry cleaning, car, other transport expenses etc..)

Chance to climb the corporate ladder very quickly. You can become a C level executive in 4 years.

Different project in every 4 months.
column13:
Spending budget often gets cut if it is trending higher than expected. No business class tickets for any distance. (it was used to allowed if you fly across certain regions, now you need to take coach class even to fly from NY to Melbourne-Australia)

Office locations are mostly away from city centers. 

Salaries are based on your home location (read passport). Which means, if you're not coming from a country like US/EU etc your salary will be a lot lower than your peers.

There is a lot of conflict of interest in the promotion cycles and a lot of politics. Senior Managers can create success story for the group that they support.
column14:
Prevent conflict of interest in promotion cycles.

Be fair and do not group employees by their passports.

column5: Good place to work on a career, but somewhat lacking in the personal side of the job.
column12: Awesome, diverse group of businesses translates into incredible career opportunities. The performance review process is very transparent, and this is a very fair way to determine career advancement.
column13: They are very cost conscious, so if you are into lavish and excessive events you won't find them here. The office locations are mostly outside of the glamorous big cities, but within commuting distance. Work here is more about business than having fun.
column14: Pay slightly more attention to the feelings of the employees and what they need to be happy, versus only caring about job deliverables.

column12:
-options are wind energy, gas or steam turbines, generators, nuclear
-opportunities abroad
-opportunites in different businesses
-employee discounts at many places
-prestige when finding other jobs because everyone recognizes GE
-Edison engineering development program is what all the leadership development programs at other companies is based off of.
-get to work with competent colleagues
column13:
-lots of bureaucracy, esp starting out you need to get request access to basic things everyone knows you need but you still need to get approval for.
-some politics
-casual overtime is expected in certain departments
-stock is currently down to the point where they are not hiring anyway
column14: you don't need to go to every meeting scheduled for the day

column5: OK if you want to either move bilaterally or stay in the same position
column12:
Good pay
Great time off
Reasonable accommodations for work environment 
Recognition
column13:
Redundant
Boring
Horrible customers
Bad employees make great money because they're ruthless
column14: Overall, great place to begin working out of college if you're in need of a place to make some money, however my managers were not college educated and I am...I felt like my background was not appreciated. I enjoyed customer service but felt like it didn't matter how well I treated my customers if the person beside me got a bonus too and was rude but made her numbers. Needs to be a way to treat people fairly but recognize good service.

column5: Happy with challenges, team & industry impact, often frustrated with bureaucracy and size.
column12: GE is a leader in every industry we pursue. I have found tremendous opportunities to make an impact within the GE company, thereby influencing an entire industry segment. I have been given tremendous flexibility on my job scope, work-life balance and have been compensated very well.
column13: It can be easy to get lost in such a large organization, and the pathway to promotion is not always clear. Compensation is generally lower than smaller companies with equivalent job titles for most employees. Health benefits were recently dramatically reduced.
column14: Further simplification of the business is key to employee morale.

column5: I like when I am asked what I do for work because I'm proud to tell people I work at GE.
column12: Given the wide range of business at GE and the many global locations the is plenty of room for Growth, opportunities, advancement, and variety. GE holds their employees to high integrity standads
column13: Bureaucratic, too many layers that think they need to be involved that don't add value.
column14: Embrace and live the new culture. Cut the wasteful discussions, meetings, and project reviews and get stuff done faster. Uninstall PowerPoint from every PC. Stop talking about stuff and just do it.

column12: Great exposure to high-visibility, strategic deals. Developed a diverse commercial skill set through writing and negotiating contracts and proposals for deals ranging from $1-$250M.
column13: I spent 2 years completing the GE Commercial Leadership Program, which in retrospect could have been condensed into 1 year. The rotations were hit or miss so very important to find a mentor in the business when you first arrive.
column14: Need to refocus on the qualities that made GE a competitive, engaging place to work. The stated values of the company do not align with the culture. I do not feel that working at GE is a true "meritocracy".

column12: Amazing company to work for. Thoughtful colleagues with lots of smarts and big hearts. You will learn a ton by working anywhere in GE. You will be proud to wear the logo and proud to tell people where you work Don't settle for less.
column13: The size can be intimidating at times. You need to make a big company feel small by getting intimate within your business unit - but without becoming a completely separate culture.
column14: I retired early only because I was able to do so but keep up the good work. I would advise my children to work for GE if they had the opportunity.

column5: Great company going through painful transition
column12: Great development opportunities. Plenty of opportunity to move between divisions, allowing you to learn across multiple industries. Really smart people work here. Permissive work leave and flexible work arrangements in some cases.
column13: Change fatigue. Rash decision being made to move the stock price at the expense of people. The Alstom acquisition has proven to be a big mistake in terms of quality, operational excellence, and the fact that it is a terrible cultural fit.
column14: Always put culture and employee first and they will innovate and take care of customers. Cut your losses on Alstom.

column5: Great place to start a career and be competitive...move when good opportunity arrives.
column12: Great training place for anyone who is passionate for business. There are a lot great and competent people who works in GE C&I, you definitely can learn a lot from various projects and assignments. Taking constructive feedbacks and react to those negatives quickly are important in the company, they will help you to move up in the organization. Networking is one of the best tools to get promoted to your next job.
column13: Tough business, cash focused, short-term focused, low salary, Industrial business model does not mix well with consumer product business.
column14: Invest more in growth markets. Take more investment bets.

column5: Solid company but stay on your toes
column12: GE pushes employees to continually improve - which is great when it comes to having exceptional peers to work with. If you like to constantly be challenged with hard work, changes, new ideas, and the political game, GE is the right place to be.
column13: To much change. Change for the better is good - but this is not always the case. Management can also have unrealistic expectations, so be prepared to handle perception.
column14: Partner with your employees - start motivating people. Often management is more about tracking, babysitting, and metrics at GE, and less about helping employees do the right thing.

column5: Good chance to grow and learn for young/new careers
column12: Stable company with a lot of choices for a next job type and location. Good work-life balance. Culturally very strong with safety and compliance. Huge company with huge resources - a chance to see complex processes, systems, and organizations work together.
column13: Salary and benefits are below what could be found at other companies in my field. A large company like this means that depending on the job and manager, you could get lost in the shuffle and miss an opportunity - new opportunities are dependent on who knows you (you are often sought for a specific job, instead of applying to a listing cold).

column5: I have not actually started yet but the pre-start date experience has been nothing less than exceptional.
column12: The staff at GE has been very helpful in the transition phase that I am in. Everyone I have spoken with has been very pleasant and knowledgable about the things I was a bit unclear about. They have all offered to help as much as possible, even after work hours.
column13: The only con I have thus far is the lack of assistance in locating housing. In other companies I have received offers from they have a service that helps new applicant find housing in surrounding areas. It would be great if GE added this service.

column12: Good pay for the industry. Good benefits. Great opportunity to make more money by working extra Saturdays and selling water filters and service contracts.
column13: Everything from the choice of what area to work to when you get to take vacation is based off seniority. Not when you come to the company but when you come to the area. You have to work lots of Saturdays during the summer.
column14: Base the rights for when to take vacation off of performance instead of seniority. This will encourage new techs to work hard and motivate the senior techs to maintain a high level of performance.

column12:
You will work with some very smart people. There is not a lot of dead weight to be found.
The company has its processes down pat, so you don't waste a ton of time on non-work / administrative issues.
If you are willing to be mobile, there is lots of opportunity. Training is top notch and easy to get.
column13: You'll work the equivalent of three jobs in most other companies. Your nights, weekends and holidays will get overrun. The tragedy is, everyone gives up their life to the company, so unless you have zero shame you won't feel right taking time for yourself.
column14: The science is clear...we humans can only focus on 2-3 big things in a day. It is not unusual to load up an employee with 15 projects and then ask them to "stretch" to add more. Recognize that while there is a line out the door of young, eager college grads ready to work for your company, your seasoned employees are leaving for higher pay and lighter workloads.

column12:
-Competitive pay specially when working at leadership level and above
-Their views of Safety are always innovating
-All kinds of training are available for your growth as an employee 
-Monetary recognition are very usual when working on projects with Managers or/and Engineering
column13:
-New employees do not have an orientation class. For the size of the company GE new hires should have a idea of how they can check their hours, sing up for benefits, and do basic functions of their every day tasks.
-due to de size of the company it can take awhile before things get done. They must be approved by a few people before anything happens.
-This might only apply to the location I work at. When I first got hired I noticed the lack of discipline of employees. They would have to actually smack the Manager in order to get a disciplinary action taken against them. There was no control on what an employee would get done daily. Instead it was put on the area if goals were not met.

column5: GE, a great place to get experience and begin a career... go get more money else where though!
column12: I got over 10 years worth of work experience in 5... You make it what it is though.
column13:
I got over 10 years worth of work experience in 5... i paid for it in work life balance

Pay stinks....
column14:
Advice to C level management... The perception of delivery should not drive promotions. I had too many mid level managers that appeared to do well at their individual contributor roles, and made terrible people leaders... 

GE has great works, and great C level management... everything in between is up for debate.

column5: Good place to start a career.
column12: The leadership programs provide young professionals with the necessary skills to become successful. Because many of the programs are rotational, it's a good opportunity to see many different sides of the overall GE business. Be warned that most programs do not share rotations outside each specific GE business. For instance, if you're and Edison at GE Aviation, you won't be able to do a rotation at GE Healthcare without pulling some serious strings.
column13: Certain divisions are understaffed, especially when a product is being completed and rushed out the door. This results in employees working very long hours.
column14: Sometimes employees are not recognized appropriately for hard work.

column5: Great company, great job, LONG hours
column12:
- Leadership development programs are incredible
- Work with very diverse teams, some of the smartest people I have and ever will meet
- Ability to work in several different business models under one GE umbrella
column13:
- LONG hours in finance roles
- Expectations are difficult to meet, the bar is always one level higher than current performance
- The goal of CFO jobs is primarily to meet the operating plan numbers... using whatever levers necessary
column14: - Work on striving to change the mindset of senior leaders... motivation should come from making the total company more profitable, rather than working for internal ambitions (your own promotion, your P&L numbers, etc.).

column5: Continuous learning environment. If you can deliver consistently, sky is the limit.
column12:
Working with some of the best and smartest people in the world.
The companies size allows them to take risks on people and put them in "bigger" jobs than they'd find elsewhere.
Daily challenges and learning opportunities.
Great employee feedback process
column13:
Hours at times can be extreme
Sink or swim environment
Large company, comes with some bureaucracy
Some leaders seem to have survived regardless of performance (Minimal and often the exception to the rule)
Salary can be lower than individuals market value early in career.
column14: Continue to invest in new products and people. Technology is our key to winning.

column12: GE is committed to developing leadership. In order to take on big projects, a team needs to take risks to differentiate from the competition, and GE encourages this type of leadership challenge for all its technologists.
column13: It is a big company so filling out the online forms to get a job done can be tedious. Overall, it is a good system and we try to improve efficiency of the system all the time. Which is good overall but leads to constant change (that leads to employee complaints).
column14: Keep up the good work trying to steer the big ship by always re-evaluating our systems for constant improvement.

column12: Benefits excellent. Time off policy very good. Able to research and apply for positions throughout the company in all divisions and subsidiaries. Leadership training very good. GE employees are looked at by other companies and recruiters.
column13:
Very high expectations so be ready to put in some long days. In some areas there is management overkill.
Too much training overlap in some GE business.
column14: Stay in tune with your co-workers. Remember they work for GE, not you.

column5: Good company that loves to reorganize itself frequently.
column12: GE acquired the company I previously worked for, so there was an adjustment period. The insurance benefits have changed some, and I think are basically average - which is to say better than some companies, worse than some others. But there are other good benefits - like a pension, plenty of Sick, Vacation, Personal and paid vacation time, and flexibility when needed - at least in the GE business where I am.
column13: GE loves to reorganize - It has been 8 years since the acquisition and I have seen 5 reorgs in my business. Reorgs are unsettling for staff, and every time a new leader is introduced, they reorg us to their liking. There has also always been a sense that senior leadership is disconnected and really doesn't even know what they are reorging. Leaders move around from GE business to GE business every few years. Also, it is difficult to move up in the company past a certain point. It seems you have to start out of college in one of the programs, and/or join the Corporate Audit staff, to gain the visibility needed to move up. That can be frustrating for people who joined from an acquisition, and who bought into the GE culture and message very early on. The other thing which tends to add to staff morale issues is how frequently we are pushed to do more with less. Teams are combined and peoples jobs are more than doubled, with no salary increases, meager merit increases, and little acknowledgement. It's demotivating.
column14: Employee engagement and recognition is huge. It's not enough to get on an All-Hands call and tell everyone thanks. And it's worse to get on an All-Hands call and repeatedly praise the same people, frequently sales people, without praising or recognizing the staff that actually keeps your day to day business running. Of course new sales are to be commended, but the work that staff does every day to keep current customer happy and loyal is just as important. The sales cycle can be very long - so repeat revenue from existing customers is also very important. Also, compensate your staff. And when there is a huge disparity between peers, make a salary adjustment to get people's salaries in line. When someone stays with a company for a long time they are often paid less than someone new being hired into the position. What does it say to people who have had loyalty and dedication to a company when a peer leaves the company and comes back 2 years later making much more. It is demotivating and says that GE does not value its tenured staff.

column5: GE On Top of their Game....
column12: Strong Leadership and growth Opportunities accompanied by above industry benefits and salary. GE is investing heavily in the digital business and the incredible talent at GE can create a new age of useful, relevant, and actionable data.
column13: There are really no cons at working at GE with the exception of perhaps a struggle to find work/life balance. That however is mostly self inflicted.
column14: The best advice I'd have for management is to be aware of internal power struggles that sometimes occur over growth areas in the company. This can lead to poor cross functional collaboration and can quickly become an issue.

column5: Good industry position and great place to work
column12: There are many interesting projects and the industry business is stable and durable. Good pay and benefits. There are also lots of chances to work with different group of the people and be able to learn lots of skills such as interactively cooperating with others and understanding others' various technologies.
column13:
The company is in the trend to contract the work outside to save the cost temporarily, which may be costly in the long run but the current managers only worry about their available budget.
Big company problem and there are always some non-respectful talking persons, instead of workers, which is annoying and hurts others's feeling.

column12: GE is great company. The people there all supply a lot of mentorship, and are smart. The work is challenging, and as an intern, you usually get real work. It is a pipeline for the future jobs, which is helpful. Plus a lot of interns to hang out with. Young company. Pretty good work life.
column13: The feel of the company, can be slow sometimes, but they also build really complicated expensive machines. The decisions are made from afar, there is red-tape. A few interns got stuck in really bad roles, usually if you are a returner you can have more say in your position.
column14: Speed up the work cycle

column5: Poor Work/Life Balance for Field Personnel
column12: Job security. Takes risks on younger talent. No real nitpicking about travel and expenses. Freedom to make things happen and execute without much, if any higher approval.
column13: No real motivation to finish projects early or under budget. If you finish early you don't get extra time home, you just get on the next one faster. Going above and beyond or finishing early/under budget does not favor any kind of bonus, as there are no bonuses. Vacation time is extremely hard to use.
column14: Clear map of career path. Not everything "has to be done on X timeline", you can always push things a week or two.

column5: Great company under Jack Welch.... Now running on 1 sigma performance.
column12: GE is a performance-centric company. Everything is measurable and measured. So, whether or not one is doing a good job is never a question. As a result, employees who are competitive and wants to grow are inspired. You meet many smart, competent, competitive, type-A people in GE.
column13: Lower pay scale than competitors. Must accept military style commands. If one wants to get promoted, one must move everywhere. It can happen anytimee.
column14: Expand to newer technologies faster... drop the capital business. Focus on long term business growth rather than short-term stock performance.

column5: Great company respected across all diciplines
column12: Great company that looks great on your resume. The have a corporate culture that is lived and understood by every employee. They offer pleanty of training which is something you can learn from and experience you can walk away with.
column13: Extremely large company where it is easy to get lost in the enormity of the organization. Managers are hit or miss as with any organization. If you are a temperary employee you can find yourself on your own much of the time with little guidance and support.
column14: GE is a leader in every sense of what a company should aspire to be. No reccomendations

column5: GE is a great place for interns
column12: I interned for GE as an INROADs intern. I was in a remote site so it limited my interaction with other interns but there were still many opportunities to connect with other interns. GE hosted many cyber events to share internship experiences and career advancement opportunities. GE takes care of its employees with a fair compensation plan and actual pension plan.
column13: My site was small so there were limited opportunities for advancement. The company is also huge so you may feel a little bit lost amongst it all.
column14: Keep up the good work but focus more on team morale given the uncertain economy

column5: Need more focus on employees and long term vision
column12: Everyone knows GE as a company, and it typically carries a strong reputation. I've gained some good experiences, and I've worked with some good people. Flexible working has been nice. There usually is not any scrutiny around working from home vs. in the office.
column13: Everyone is expected to be "on" all the time. So, make sure to bring your phone and laptop even if you are on an international vacation. Decisions are made with "making the quarter" in mind with no long term strategy, which results in quick processes that break later. Employee advocacy is low. Employees are not considered when tough business decisions are made, and front line leaders and HR are left to help employees through these decisions afterwards.
column14: Not everything is about the financials and numbers. There are people that drive our business who deserve to be heard and their opinions considered. It's okay to take a hit on the short term to create a lasting long-term strategy.

column5: Good place to work and gain experience
column12: GE is a big company with many different divisions, so you can gain exposure to many areas of expertise. Many of the people are very smart, work hard, and are friendly. If you need help with something, people are usually willing to stop what they are doing to help you.
column13: While the company has many divisions, it is not very easy to move between those divisions; it's almost as complicated as finding a whole new job. Promotions are scarce, and the managerial track is more highly valued and compensated than the technical track.
column14: Focus more on empowering the individual contributor.

column12: The pay is well above average. An entry level production employee will start out around $14/ hr and can easily work up to close to $20/ hr
column13: Management is under staffed here at Bucyrus lamp plant in Ohio. The engineers are used as maintenance supervisors and don't have enough time to do actual engineering work.
column14: My advice to management is to spend more time and money to train the hourly employees. Utilize the experienced employees extensive knowledge of the machines to train the younger ones. Provide regular training for the skilled trades so they can remain current with technology

column12: Great people, great culture, incredibly busy office but fantastic place to work. there is a lot of camaraderie among employees and people tend to work together and not apart.
column13: Some managers tend to pander to upper management a little too much, which gains them favors. Unfortunately, others who are really dedicated to their personal product are discouraged by the favoritism and leave.
column14: Look at the value in each of your employees. There is some amazing talent right under your nose, but you will lose it if you don't look past those who would use their higher level positions to take credit for the work being done by others.

column12: You can make your career as you want it to be at GE. New graduates are having better chances to become leaders faster than hired professionals. New grad network at GE is solid and very helpful!
column13: Nothing I can say is bad about working here. People are focus on being politically correct all the time, try to be nice to anyone, and try to be helpful to anyone, and I see these across the team I work with. Sure there are tough and stubborn personalities who occasionally will use their positions to get what they want, but that happens every where, right?

column12: GE Trans is filled with high energy people that have incredible passion for strong performance, continuous learning, and career advancement. The company is one of the smaller GE industrial business units, but tends to operate on a faster tempo with a much leaner workforce.
column13: The learning curve is high and fast. Consistent performance with speed and quality is expected. Ability to manage high stress, perform under short deadlines, and prioritize work-life balance is critical to prevent burnout.
column14: Salary needs to be improved below the executive level. This is the majority workforce that makes GE deliver world-class products and services.

column5: Great pay for the area, management OK
column12:
Good pay (has since been reduced for new hires), great benefits. Unionized, so there's more employee protection. 
Frequent overtime opportunities for hourly workers.
column13:
Tone of the workplace depends on both the manager of the area, and the coworkers. Some areas have lots of drama, some don't. 
There's a strong Hourly vs. Salary mindset.
Management from different departments have in the past created rules for the workplace that impact morale negatively.
column14: Get more employee input about the details of a work area and job before inputting changes, to make sure they're useful and don't make aspects of the work more difficult.

column12: Empowerment in your position, was not reserved for training period. Management was hands on and motivated greater aspiration than current position. It was a team atmosphere, we fail together and we succeed together.
column13: Because they projected and encouraged great aspirations from the janitorial to the CEO, there was great tune-over in management, because of promotions in stead of pay raises. As soon you are settled into how one manager operates, another is on the way.
column14: Encourage depth and not just width. Pay raises instead of moving

column12: Competitive pay for the area. Good benefits: plenty of vacation days, personal days, sick days. Gym membership reimbursement. Free ebook library. $6k or more for tuition reimbursement per year. Decent healthcare coverage. Transportation business is in great shape and GE, in general, is placing more and more emphasis on the software engineering group.
column13: It can always be a challenge to stand out in a big company, but if you promote yourself you can get ahead. It is always proportional to the effort you put in.

column5: Great company pushing through tough times
column12: Truly impactful products and solutions (I work in the Power org). Providing new and/or cleaner energy to the world is a critical need. The company has a high level of integrity and a lot of smart people.
column13: Typical large company issues - bureaucracy, overlapping organizations, etc. combined with a very tough position on costs, cash, stock price, etc. The organization and the people are under stress, which can bring out the best, and the worst, in all.
column14: Flannery is a good guy trying to do the right thing. I believe he is on a mission. Continue to drive out complexity and centralized organizations.

column12: Good salary, 7% 401k, insurance, etc. Remote work is embraced, and the company offers room for advancement. If you do your job well, they treat you well. If you run into an issue, someone in another business has likely seen that too, and can offer help. There are so many smart people working at GE.
column13: Leadership program graduates get preference, stock price is faltering, who knows who will be the CEO in the future. Businesses getting sold can lead to turmoil.
column14: Don't give Leadership program graduates preferential treatment when they haven't shown results.

column5: Good experience to have on your resume
column12: Great for the resume...people love GE. GE Consumer & Industrial is not a company that people generally want to go to because it is not in a 'sexy' industry. This can be good for those who do chose to work there because they are often times given more responsibility because of the leanness of the organization
column13: The downsides are the poor working facilities and general low morale due to the state of the appliance industry. Not much rehab has been done to Appliance Park and it definitely shows. This type of work environment affects the morale because it indicates that the company is not making it a priority to invest in the well-being of its employees.
column14: Communicate more with employees. Also salary increases should be more frequent and be higher. Oftentimes the salary increase doesn't even meet the cost of inflation. In addition, recognize best employees with awards to show that their work is appreciated.

column5: GE - Is A good place to work
column12: GE is a learning environment. They encourage people to explore and gain knowledge. GE Has Great benifits. GE wants to promote people who are smart and work hard. You get to meet a lot of different people and learn about a lot of differnt access to information.
column13: Sometimes you feel like just a number. There are a lot of other people in the same place as you are. But there are ways to differenciate yourself. That will help you get a head.
column14: Trust your employees. They want to do good work.

column12: Experience, Leadership, Reputation, Opportunity, Growth, Rewarding and Inspirational
column13: Performance Appraisals can sometimes mean that a employee may not receive a favorable performance review eventhough he/she is an exceptional employee. Unfortunately, or fortunately depand on where you stand most everyone is expceptional, the best of the best or they probably would'nt be working for GE so it makes it tough to reward everyone on a system that bases performance reviews on a Top 3rd, Middle and teh Bottom 10%. Regardless of the Bottom 10% actual performance.
column14: Be fair in a difficult system. Coach all employees. Mentor new employees

column12: Lots of opportunities to learn how to become an effective manager and influential leader. Freedom to steer your own career. Learning opportunities and entry-level and experienced leadership programs are world-class.
column13: Compensation is not tied to to geography putting people living in high-wage parts of the country at a steep disadvantage to their peers. Raises are very small each year in order to keep up with inflation rather than actual value to the company. This is usually the opposite at upper bands.
column14: Develop a distinguishable pay scale and equity bonuses like other peer companies so employees feel an incentive to go above and beyond.

column12: GE has difference industry including Capital, Aviation, Energy, Transportation, Lighting , Healthcare. If you join the leadership program, you would have a chance to rotate in difference industry. Even not in program, GE normally gives employee opportunity to move into internal business for growth every two years. There are lots of smart people there. Good environment to learn esp for fresh graduates from university
column13: company is too big and job can be very specific scope. GE has some roles only GE has.And the salary increase for employees is not much. But GE pays much more for the same job if recruit from external

column5: A good place to work, if you enjoy hard work, politics and learning new things
column12: Training, Size, Network, Opportunities to move up and do cool work
column13: Politics, Cost Cutting & Acquisitions-focused culture (still), Revolving door leadership
column14: When GE businesses are underperforming, don't just let current and prior management lay people off to solve the problem...you should fire or replace the management teams of those underperforming businesses. Joe and Sally Cubicle aren't the ones responsible for the lack of business success. Be more critical when people blame "the market" for business performance...you're paying execs way too much to just let them blame external factors.

column12: Opportunity to learn and grow in roles where other companies would want you to have years of experience. This comes at a price of devoting your life to the company and you are the only one that can control work-life balance.
column13: Managing work and life. Expectations are that you will be available to work at any time, any place and do an excellent job.
column14: Ignore the stock price and the market. Continue to set a vision on GE as a whole, communicate the plan and get everyone on board and moving in the same direction.

column5: Good place to work if you can handle the bureaucracy.
column12: The culture is very relaxed, the business is very profitable, and the people are generally all around good and smart people. Work/Life balance usually has a pretty high priority.
column13: The salaries are just average, annual raises are typically small (average less than 3%), lots of bureaucracy within the GE matrix organization. Upper management sometimes also has a habit of selling products that don't exist, which creates a strain on the engineering teams.
column14: It would be better if the upper management rewarded employees for hard work. Especially when a particular business (such as Bently Nevada) is very profitable.

column12: Great company to learn and grow your career. GE is a Fortune 6 company and builds infrastructures of the world. You will be working on really interesting problems in the industrial space. You will meet the best and the brightest. You will be given the support you will need to succeed.
column13: Has over 300,000 employees and it feel like it. There is a large amount of bureaucracy. Almost 50% of your work time is spent working thru GE processes.
column14: Work more like a start up. Take chances. Thin out rigor and internal processes which are "thick and heavy".

column12:
As a corporation, GE treats its employees very well. 
Benefits are good.
Training is kind of bogus. Very corporate, not that useful. 
They really want their employees to succeed and support that where they can, however, it's manager by manager, as it is in all places.
People seem very happy here. On occasions people work evenings and weekends, but there is generally good work life balance.
column13: There are not a lot of different positions at the center. It's mostly engineers and UX people.
column14: Center could be more organized. People are moved around from project to project without being asked on a frequent basis.

column12:
