- great emphasis on building leadership skills
- invests in their employees
- fast paced environment
- always trying to be ahead of its competitors
- good reputation
- overall good work environment to work in
- work life balance is great
- always learning
column13:
- very very minimal salary increases each year (if any)
- no bonuses or extra compensation for a certain career band and below
- small salary increase for promotions to the next role
- many people jump outside the company to get the salary bump they are looking for, then eventually come back to the company
column14: Be open with employees wanting to switch to other businesses.

column12:
-Great working environment.
-Every team that I've been on has had a very flexible manager, they understand that there are things that we need to do outside of work.
-The ability to work from home is a plus, I look forward to working from the office though.
-Absolutely great benefits
-There are a ton of groups that you can join to development your career.
-Great diversity
-There are also a lot of development programs here.
-You get what you put in.
column13:
-Some people really do not like the open office space.
-Yes we receive a reduced parking rate at the garage, but it is still relatively high.

column5: Young GE professional in Erie, PA
column12: I like the fact that they are many young people that work here. Someone that is right out of college will make friends very easily. Also, the leadership programs are a great way for professional development. You get to see several sides of the business and learn 4 different roles in a 2-year period. You start off at a higher than average salary if you're on a program, and you have more opportunities for advancement and raises in the future. I would recommend that anyone coming out of school take a good look at a GE leadership program.
column13: GE expects you to get your job done. If you don't show results in your work you're going to be in the "needs improvement" bunch when they rank employees. Then you'll have to start showing results quickly, or you're out of a job. Depending on the job, you might have to work 50 or even 60 hours a week to get everything done. Many, if not all of the jobs are high stress. If you work on an off shift you might not get to see much of your family. In general, it is a demanding and sometimes stressful place to work, but the rewards make up for it.
column14: I think that Senior Management at all of the GE businesses are very skilled and knowledgeable. They make GE the great company that it is. The only thing I would recommend is that the presidents of each business stay in their role for longer than they currently do. They will be more likely to make a positive impact if they were around for 4 or 5 years. Other than that, I think that GE has a great management team.

column5: My experience at GE has been very challegning and work life balance is an issue.
column12: GE is so large and well respected that even if you decide it's not for you and you leave after a few years, others will be impressed with your experience there based on the reputation of the company. There are many, many jobs available within the company so you could potentially make it your place to grow throughout your career.
column13: Though the company claims to promote work life balance, it's understood that you're expected not to be a "9-5'er". Any significant advancement requires working a lot of unpaid overtime. Only those who devote almost all of their waking hours to the company have real chances of "success".
column14: I think managers could do a much better job of managing resources, meaning trianing employees properly instead of the sink or swin methodology and not having one person do the job of 3.

column5: Excellent experience, earlier on in one's career, working with extraordinaey people.
column12: A flexible approach to career advancement and leadership development. Ability to move between many businesses and multiple experiences. Opportunity to "fail smart" and take risks.
column13: Although things are changing, you will work very hard, sometimes very long, and in a good deal of ambiguity.those who are not decisive, inclusive, and lacking a good mix of thoughtful and provocative thinking will struggle to succeed.
column14: Engage the sr. leadership more often, and utilize social media more effectively to connect employees. Take the gloves off when it comes to attacking opportunities to lead the charge among competitors.

column5: Performance Driven Work Culture with Resources to Back it
column12: Company provides resources needed to accomplish your goals. Great Benefits; especially, the medical plan. If you are good, there is opportunity to grow and ability to transfer within the business.
column13: The goals are very aggressive and they push some people to the edge. I am observing a counter productive results when individuals work 50+ hours thinking that they will put in more hours and get closer to the goal. In reality, it prevents them from concentrating and they stall entire teams. Team dynamics suffer.
column14: Provide goals to individuals that can accomplish them or provide more realistic goals

column12: Collaborative culture, innovative spirit, access to leadership training, access to Lean Training, access to Six Sigma Training, access to many industries under one moniker, etc.
column13: At times, leadership does not practice Gemba. At times, you may see departments working in silos when a cross functional project is taking place. You see these challenges in many large organizations such as GE.
column14: Practice Gemba with the shop floor, with the buyer floor, with the warehouse floor, with lower leadership, and ask questions. All with the intent to practice continuous improvement, plus score points with the entire team along the way.

column12: I was a Co-op and worked at two facilities. Billerica, MA was an amazing experience with people always willing to help and teach you. There was no busy work and all of them relevant to current projects going on. The environment is very fast-paced, but you get to experience a lot with the project. As an intern/co-op, there are many opportunities and you can try out different divisions within GE.
column13: The other facility, in Houston, was terrible.The manager at one point even told me "I honestly do not have work for you." Some people were lazy and were not very receptive to helping.

column12: I have enjoyed working with GE previously and felt so proud that such company like GE would provide me the pride and efficiency in working that i am aiming for. No wonder that GE is one of most lead in every aspect of our daily life thank you for this great company and thank you for the great chance that would be given by time GE hires me.
column13: few are the downside that i might think of right now but i believe in general this is the company i would always have its products in my daily life.
column14: Keep up the good work

column5: GE is #1 for leaders for a reason
column12: Easy going environment at a great facility where completing your projects and networking is of utmost importance, and other 'business' things like 'face time' etc. are not as crucial here as they are at other firms. Everyone has a laptop, everyone has a VPN token - get the job done and you'll be golden.
column13: Unfortunately, the downsides are somewhat linked to the up side. People enjoy their barriers of communication through email, im, phone - or heaven forbid you see them face to face. Lots of meetings (Which can be seen as a plus or minus)
column14: Keep up the great work.

column5: great place to learn and develop your career
column12: GE does and excellent job investing in training for their employees. The work content is great and you're given a lot of responsibilities early on. This is a great place to start, and if you want to, finish, your career.
column13: Pay is too low to keep the best talent. There are not bonus so its a low risk, low reward career choice. There are definitely ways to accelerate your career, especially in finance by joining the corporate audit staff, but ultimately the company overvalues this. Also, in the finance function you feel very disconnected to the customer.

column12: GE has been smart enough to stay around for a long time because management is pragmatic and tries to stay grounded in real numbers and safe bets.
column13: Risk taking is not always rewarded, even when successful. GE tends to take safe bet and looks for innovative ideas that they can buy through aquisitions rather than branching out and trying new things themselves.
column14: Find a way to communicate your vision for the future of the business than by telling us the revenue you want to achieve. Having an end goal is great, but you need to tell us how you want us to get there.

column12: Easy job fun a times low stress most of the time. Benefits are ok however the pension is now gone and we just have a 401k.
column13: No advancement. They clamed from the beginning that advancement would be easy for the test enginneers. Them they changed our job title to test technican and took a week of vacation that was promised after our first year away from us. Everyone that's salary non exempt ban has to fight each other for the highest raise, which range from 0-2.75% annually. Myself and fellow test department have been repeatedly denied other jobs we've applied to and have been very qualified for. The hourly guys seem pretty happy but most make less than $20 an hr and may not be qualified for other roles.
column14: Start going through with what you say and at least give the guys a chance to more up in the company rather than highering people from the Erie plant or outside of GE.

column5: Big Company, Big Opportunities, Easy to get lost
column12: Company is large, but don't let that discourage you from applying. Knowing someone internally will always help move your resume upward on the stack. People within GE rely heavily on connections (internally and externally).
column13: Can't really think of any. The company does a good job of keeping everyone informed and aware of company goals and accomplishments.
column14: Keep focus on the end goal of leaving the Capital/Money business and moving more into the infrastructure, technologies industries. At it's core, GE is really a software company backing the many products that it develops (trains, airplane engines, gas turbines, etc.).

column12: I have been with GE for 18 years, and the best part of working for GE is the training and growth opportunities that they provide...if you are a hard worker, and strive to excel in everything you do, this is the place for you!!!
column13: As I said in the pros section, GE expects a lot from you, and you will work extremely hard to achiever your goals, so if you want just an ordinary job just to get by, this isn't the place for you.

column12:
Great company to learn how business is done in corporate america, opportunities for growth for young professionals.
Very community oriented with diversity of employees.
Opportunity to work with highly qualified team of professionals.
Great flexible work life balance, results oriented culture
column13:
Limited Senior Level opportunities.
On boarding process lacks structure.
Company acquisitions not always best for communities and personnel from former companies.
column14: I think there is a disconnection from Corporate and high level management and senior-mid level management that causes a lot of friction and makes company very internally focused. Try to really sell the GE store concept internally and not externally only.

column12: The company is trying to go from a 4.5 billion dollar industry to a 10 billion dollar industry by 2010 so there are more and more opportunities to shine in that environment.
column13: It's a get it done or go home type of atmosphere. So you need to make contacts fast so that you can produce on all your goals and more than your manager sets up for you.
column14: My manager was very hands off and tried to burn me behind my back so my advice would be that if you're not around me ask the people who are about me.

column5: Great for those who grow up in the system, not for newcomers with advanced careers
column12: GE has a great professional network and outstanding training, with ready access to internal training programs as well as willingness on the part of management to promote participation in external programs. Career development is encouraged and most of the leadership is "home grown" from within GE. The opportunities to work anywhere in the world are endless, and often times GE will accommodate the employees desire to relocate by finding a suitable position for the employee (for example, if a spouse is being transferred, GE will find a way to retain the employee within the GE network of businesses.) Also, there are many opportunities to try out different roles at different businesses within GE, not just movement within your own business unit.
column13: For my particular business unit, senior management does not seem connected to employees or engaged at all in the everyday challenges the business is facing. There does not seem to be clear direction from senior management on strategic or tactical issues, nor does there appear to be any clear understanding of our competition. While they may have the vision, they are not communicating that vision with employees. Also, many of the employees are on cruise control and not interested in either changing the status quo or growing the business in any appreciable way. There doesn't seem to be any repercussions for employees who have little external/customer focus.
column14: Benefits severely lag the industry in terms of vacation time, at least relative to those in the finance industry. Most financial firms offer a bank of days that employees can use as they wish; like many other industrial firms, GE gives all employees two weeks of vacation and a disproportionate amount of "sick days." Senior management should also listen more closely to what employees who have worked outside of GE are saying about the industry/market/competition; it seems like the GE mentality is to maintain the status quo.

column5: If you want to work very hard and advance quickly professionally (but not in salary), this is a great opportunity.
column12: GE holds the FMPs in high regard. Almost all senior leaders are FMP grads and will want to help you succeed. The path to high levels of management is laid out, and is attainable, but you must literally give your life to GE to get it.
column13: People at GE do not know how to relax. They are very concerned with the numbers of hours they work, often staying at the office doing literally nothing so that people can see that they are there late. They love to brag about how many hours they work. A disturbing majority of the Finance employees have either never been married, or are married to someone in GE.
column14: Don't take yourself so seriously. There are only two people at GE who anyone outside of GE has ever heard of.

column5: GE is the big business depicted in the classic movies
column12:
The company is the only company that openly admits to employee online monitoring! 

I think that says a lot for their integrity! (A++)

They maintain a amazing company educational cours4e library of several thousand personal. technical. and up to date business courses free for employees. And still offer tuition reimbursement incentives for educational facilities you may enroll in locally.. (Colleges, tech schools, etc)

There is an annual program for the performance review process that is basically making you keep your resume up to date, and the emphasis is to use the new "buzz words" corporate feels is right for the times - after you take an in house class about them..

Their retirement plan is incredible, and remains the best I have ever seen for a big business, especially as so many other places phased them out. the heart of it is 100% company funded!

I was in a target department during a RIF that was unfortunate to be involved in, but I also feel it was a wise bjusin3ess decision! I stayed my remaining 2 weeks making sure my project transitioned seamlessly for our customers. I am sure most people, including myself, would have simply left the same day at other companies!
column13:
The biggest downside is management always in a state of concern that they could be sacrificed to provide "the scape goat" needed to satisfy stockholder concerns over company profits and or projections. 

Watch a couple of the movies from the 50's where there are a dozen "yes men" always following the CEO around; or even realize most f the comments made by Jay Leno about GE (partners with NBC) are not fictional one liners - they are real! 

Even 30 Rock is a reflection of GE conglomerate day to day issues - but with a bit too much embellishment!

Of course, they are well compensated for their stress and most stay loyal for their entire career, so is this really a con? I would return in a heartbeat!
column14:
To management I can only recommend weeding out the active "yes men"! Don't fire them, just get back to basics on their own merits! Many of their predecessors have been guilty of this for over half a century, but I feel GE would be much stronger as a business in these troubled times, with the workforce becoming more loyal and projective as a result! 

But overall, GE's management does a fantastic job!

Note: The CEO at GE receives a salary and compensation that appears excessive to the media and the public often misled by uninformed reporters. But he really is a great deal for GE in the big picture, and worth the price!

column5: A good place to work .... for a few years, may be
column12: GE Energy has friendly co-workers, healthy work atmosphere and flexible hours. There is excellent technology being produced and engineers in particular, get to work on competitive products. A lot of knowledge exists in design reports and there is a lot one can learn from.
column13: GE Energy's higher management lacks strategy especially concerning its workforce. There is little recognition for the work that employees produce working in high pressure environments, most typically about 50 hours a week. Pay raises are meager to non-existent. Growth is super slow. Work can get monotonous very quickly and the senior management does not seem to care about its employees saturating. Conservative and rotten HR policies make for a nightmare, and it is easy to lose motivation.
column14: Value your employees. Address their pressing concerns quickly and rapidly. GE is where it is more because of the employees at the lowest rung than because of executives who make big bucks.

column12:
People, first and foremost. Every person I have worked with has been willing to help on whatever I ask. The people are smart, courteous, and professional. GE is good at identifying talented individuals and training them for the next level. They have internal professional development courses from the individual contributor level all the way to CEO. Their leadership programs are second to none.

The work I do is challenging and mentally rewarding. I feel that my contributions truly make a difference to my team and my organization. Management is always supportive of me expanding my role.

If you are willing to put in the work, you can move up in this company; it is a true meritocracy. Also, there are 300k+ people working around the world in businesses ranging from lighting to jet engines. Chances are that if you want to do something, it is being done in GE.
column13:
Compensation. If you are truly excellent at what you do, chances are you can get paid more to do it somewhere else. I weigh that against stability and future advancement opportunities. Travel has been cut substantially to contribute to shareholder value. Positions are also being eliminated to simplify the company. 

There is a perception that the company is old, outdated, and slow. People often talk about it like a huge ship: stable, but slow to react to change. This is true, but changing slowly as the company looks to lean processes.
column14:
Your employee review system is great. You know who your top contributors are, so pay them accordingly. The attrition rate is particularly high for people out of training programs. They acquire skills and leave the company for more money after a few years.

The company values are right on, and I am glad that compensation is based on values and performance.

column5: Solid company. Pros and cons just what you'd expect from such a giant company
column12: Very solid company with well defined culture, values, and practices. GE Power & Water has been a leader in power gen products for years, and the company fights hard to stay there. They are not resting on their accomplishments though, and there are a lot of opportunities for exciting new work. At a company this size your experience will vary from location to location, program to program, manager to manager, but in general most people here are professional, courteous, and enthusiastic about their job. There is a lot of flexibility in schedules and work scope for engineers, and I haven't experienced too much micro-managing of my time.
column13:
Not everyone is working hard, and those people can get away with it because of the large nature of the organization. The end result is that others have to pick up the slack. In the worst cases, those not carrying their weight are older "tenured" employees who have a lot of influence, but are slowing down progress with their lazy attention to detail and mistakes. I'd assume this can happen at any very large organization, however. 

Another issue is the uncertainty of the pay structure, raises, bonuses, and promotions. There is no clear definition for when or how any of those are setup and decided. Speaking with a few people, there is a general feeling that raises and promotions are at best based on some level of favoritism, and at worst arbitrary. These forms of compensation clearly depend on how well your manager fights for you in closed-door leadership meetings, and not necessarily on performance. So depending on your manager and program, you may get promoted regularly and fairly...or you may work hard and sit in an entry level position for 8 years. But, as said, while the raises may not be well defined, base pay seems to be in line with the industry and the area.
column14: Be more transparent about compensation structure. Do not let a person sit in an entry level position for 7+ years without promoting them or significantly recognizing them. Not only does it discourage that person, seeing it also discourages the rest of us who worry about uncertain raises. In the long run, if people aren't worth promoting after 3-4 years, they should be "strongly encouraged" to change job functions or just outright fired.

column12: Work schedule and atmosphere is top notch. You work with true leaders and innovators. I have only been in the current position for a short time but you really get to enjoy the people you work with.
column13: Communication is lacking at times. In the upper echelon of things communication breaks down and gets convoluted. "A lot of chiefs and not enough Indians" mentality.
column14: Communicate better between departments. This is said with a small amount of emphasis, most of the time management is very in tune and knowledgeable about what all their people are doing.

column5: A treat to be building tomorrow's industrial products.
column12: Providing innovative solutions for our worlds future energy and industrial needs is self-rewarding. GE is always industry competitive with advantages in capital management, engineering, and cutting edge technological advances in their products offerings.
column13: Rack and stack performance review structure is outdated. True professionals will be self-driven to succeed while also building other leaders along the way.
column14: Look for some of your future leaders outside of the leadership programs. Building a great leader comes from a wealth of business experiences, both good and bad. A silver spoon doesn't create a humble, knowledgeable leader that others will follow.

column12: Good 401 K match program. Decent vacation and paid personal time policy. Corporate has invested heavily in equipment and facility upgrades in recent years.
column13: 2-tier wage scale implemented in 2012 has downgraded this plant to "very average" for any skilled machinist considering employment here. No pension for new hires. Average benefits for a company of this size. Unskilled management team mostly transplanted from other GE divisions unfamiliar with machining and heavy manufacturing operations. High HR turnover has led to inconsistent HR policies and high frustration level among hourly employees. Plant is currently downsizing due to business conditions, leading to 100 announced permanent layoffs in the past 2 months, with more to come.
column14: Listen to the experienced hourly employees. Stop trying to run a GE machining facility like a GE lighting plant. Find a way to mediate the 40% pay difference between tier-1 and tier-2 employees. 2nd tier employees should not be treated like 2nd class employees.

column12:
after shedding the fin-tech arm, it's hard to argue that GE is not an overall 'force of good' in the big wide world. When you get a chance take 10 mins and google some of the things GE sells. Jet engines nuclear reactors automation software ultrasonic and MRI machines. These are things that unequivocally benefit people. Now google top startups and look at some of the stuff they're doing...it's probably yet another "ground-breaking" app that lets you deliver food or schedule grooming for your cat or dog. This feeling outwardly manifests itself in the culture where your coworkers (across all departments- engineering sales marketing) will be passionate about their work and the business. They will generally be proud of contributing to technology that can be universally appreciated and not just for one niche purpose or clique. This isn't exactly easy to find at tech companies these days (trust me?)

You're also likely to get fantastic work life balance, BUT varying from business to business since GE is so large. Managers get legit leadership training and it no doubt costs the company $$$. It is noticeable, and does have a positive effect on the perceived and actual work/life balance when your team is well-managed. The longer you stay the more likely you are to get paid training and covered travel.
column13: the bureaucracy. Hands down. This is a BIG company. There's a saying about the left arm not knowing what the right arm is doing. GE is like an octopus where its every tentacle for itself. they've tried to fix this in recent years by being more "lean" but, unfortunately, it's just ingrained in the middle and upper level management to have more process rather than less. This may take decades to fix, if ever. you WILL be forced to engage in the latest and greatest organizational fad like 'Scrum' (previously Six Sigma. maybe soon to be Microservices) even if it makes absolutely no sense for the project at hand OR it is proving to be overly time consuming and ineffective. Not all sub businesses are created equal at GE and some are just way worse than others at staying ahead of the curve and not getting bogged down in endless processes. This may not be the best place for the young and brash - be prepared for moments where you simply cannot be productive because of your environment. But remember the environment does hugely depend on the particular sub businesses, like Energy, Aviation and Healthcare. Some are far better than others at being efficient.
column14: Keep metrics for average time spent on processes (including, but not limited to, team processes like Agile, workplace training, company-wide and team meetings, yearly HR requirements and performance reviews, marketing and engineering presentations) and aim, year over year, to drive these times lower and justify their contributions to productivity when this is not possible. Reward teams for delivering promising, tangible results and not just shoddy prototypes, documentations and powerpoints. Keep engineers in direct contact with friendly and willing customers; do not silo them. Focus training in the new grad programs (EEDP, FMP) not on presentations and competition but rather on innovation and collaboration.

column12: Decent pay and benefits, good safety culture.
column13: I see many on here claiming there are opportunities to develop and get promoted. Likely these are individuals spoon fed through the terrible OMLP program(which is clearly has a bias against males) or they are public relations people trying to make a false impression that GE invests in its employees. There is no investment, especially if you started in production at one of their factories. Got a college degree? Doesn't matter to management all while they'll bring in inexperienced and naive into terrible "leadership programs" that should be given to CURRENT employees who utilized tuition reimbursement. Good leaders have progressive work experience starting at the bottom. Terrible leaders are given jobs without earning them.
column14:
Promote, train, and develop from within your group of employees who earned their education while WORKING at GE, not the clueless and entitled you'll find at the local university.

Willing to bet GE won't have the guts to respond to this!

column5: Large, complicated organization with much chaos and need for streamlined processes
column12: Training provided throughout year, opportunities for growth, flexible manager on time in/out, employee recognition, convenient campus facilities like medical center, cafeteria, gym, etc.
column13: Often the organization seems to have grown so large that there is lack of accountability on projects, miscommunication, departments don't know what each other are working on (even within departments). Way too many emails and over-communication on useless things. Terrible onboarding process.
column14: Fix the onboarding process; it is a chaotic mess. Hold people accountable for when huge mistakes are made. Cut down on emails by providing usable intranet sites.

column5: A place to acquire leadership skills while working with ver competent engineers
column12:
Very Good leadership training
Great senior management
Very competent colleagues
Cutting edge technology work
Lots of cross business employment opportunities
column13:
Lots of big company red tape
Takes forever to fire incompetent people
Cunning human resources with most influence on employee's professional lives very repulsive
column14:
Fight for your team
Practice work life flexibility
Need to communicate much better down to individual employees
Be fair about internal promotions, posting an open job even when u know who will get it just to bypass rules is disgusting and unfair to others because it's not a real opportunity for them

column5: Why wouldnt you want to WORK here?
column12: Working with a thinking moving company with a lot of room to grow. Pay and beenfits are very competitive for engineers. Safety is priority one on manufacturing and other activies. Owns and develops technology, even has an (albeit small) R&D department.
column13: You can expect to work long hours and it can be a challenging work environment. The training runs by quick so be sure to take mental and physical notes as soon as you start.

column12: GE has great benefits and there is so much opportunity to advance or relocate. You have access to so many difference culture's and meet people.
column13: The management where I worked had no clue how to manage and it was family oriented. Only family or people who are in the "click" got promoted amd received decent raises.
column14: Make sure the people who are being promoted are qualified for the job. Have a standard position description allowing fewer modifications so jobs cannot be modified to fit a certain individual just be they are friends or family.

column7: Drive Control and Software Engineer/Electrical Engineer
column12:
time is flexible, locomotive manger is really good. 
time is flexible, locomotive manger is really good. 
time is flexible, locomotive manger is really good. 
time is flexible, locomotive manger is really good. 
time is flexible, locomotive manger is really good.
column13:
there is a lot meeting. factory noise is too much.
there is a lot meeting. factory noise is too much.
there is a lot meeting. factory noise is too much.
there is a lot meeting. factory noise is too much.
there is a lot meeting. factory noise is too much.
column14:
no advice.
no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.no advice.

column5: Great Company but lack of Vision & a good strategy at top level
column12:
Lot of talented peers to learn
Reputed company & tremendous opportunity to learn process, Manufacturing & rigor
column13:
Lack of Vision at the Top
Long Hours & intense work load
Salary growth is small even when rated as the Role Model in annual review process
Hire & Fire strategy on Contracts does not keep them motivated on deliverables
column14:
Top management should pre-empt trends and plan for future instead of eternal corrections.
Current CEO lacks the leadership skills to portend future and plan for it. 
All actions in last decade are reactive responses rather than skillful strategies.

column12: None to speak of, at least relative to the competition.
column13: The much-vaunted 'unlimited vacation' policy is frowned upon if used, and will make you look bad for asking. Its a great culling tool when layoffs are near. Despite how it sounds on the surface, veteran salaried employees are routinely denied ANY time off for months at a time and appointments with mgmt to schedule family trips are routinely cancelled. If you travel for the company, they will make sure you have to travel on bookended weekends that are not rebated. Good luck if you happen to be married or have kids. You'll never see whats-her-name again during waking hours. This is not sarcasm. I am not being particularly unkind. It's just 100% true. It's as bad as it sounds.
column14: Keep your 'unlimited vacation' label if you like, but include a minimum guarantee that full-time employees will get at least 1 measly week off per 5 years of service. A cancelled meeting to talk about vacation should be taken as a 'yes' by the employee instead of a threat.

column5: Avoid if you are in IT
column12: The have a decent benefits package and reasonable time off policy by American standards.
column13: The entire organization is unable to execute. Getting simple resources like a server are next to impossible even on critical projects. You are buried in "required" training that does nothing to benefit the organization or your career. Lots of hubris throughout the organization. They talk about developing a center of excellence, but they are far from achieving any of that. The environment, and talent that is attracted to it is not the best and the brightest. Lots of customer commitments have been made for products the organization does not have the ability to deliver on.
column14:
Smart Grid is about software, but your organization is set up for making big machines such as gas turbines. You need to either be willing to 
1. Set up your organization with a clean slate, with a culture and appropriate processes
2. Buy a company that actually has the ability to do this
3. Get out of the smart grid business.

column5: This is the place to work - great resume builder
column12:
- Strong brand name you can leverage in the future
- Great training so you learn a lot and fast
- Brilliant people keep you on your toes and get things done
column13:
- Very rigid - if you are not a CAS (Corporate Audit Staff) monkey then they don't promote you
- Too much in breeding with their internal training (CAS, FMP etc)
- Most people leave within 5 years and they don't care about it
column14: Stop promoting from within - those CAS and FMP people are just stupid and don't think outside of GE!

column12: As much as some employers claim to offer internships with "meaningful work", GE is one of the few where a college student can actually leave with an understanding of the impact they made, makes it feel much more worthwhile.
column13: Internship quality can vary somewhat depending on assignments, but then again so can any other job. Slightly lower pay for a CS student than a straight up programming gig, but worth it if you don't want to be stuck at the same desk all day.
column14: Program might be improved through increased communication between assignment leaders and the program heads.

column12: Lot's to learn. Big player in industry. If you are self motivated there is an endless amount of information to pull from. GE brand certainly helps sell products that might no be purchased if it didn't have the meatball on it.
column13: The restructuring of the sales force caused and continues to cause complete chaos. Despite the "one GE" attempt, the company is simply not there. Too political and the customer in the end suffers from very slow responses. From a product perspective, in healthcare, GE is behind the times. In a majority of categories there is a superior product on the market. At the same time when there are major quality issues, things are not escalated to address or fix due to channels need to put up numbers
column14: GE is not the military, make it easier for the folks taking care of customers to get to the right person without fear of hand slapping or worse.

column12: There are many positives about the company. Integrity and a constant interest to 'get it right', to do the right thing, abounds throughout management and the company, for example. The company is always seeking to do things better, improve, innovate. Rotations around the company are encouraged and expected, which keeps things exciting for employees, is a key retention tool, and supports constant learning throughout one's career.
column13: Location can be the biggest drawback, especially if you want to work in New York City or do not have an interest in moving every few years for your next rotation.

column12: The FMP training program is awesome, you get exposure to lots of financial tools and materials. Great competitive culture to succeed. In general most people are helpful. Work hard, play hard the managers are great especially with time-off compensation and happy hour splurge after a rough quarter end/month end close. Truly enjoyed my experience with GE.
column13: Office politics, gossiping and back stabbing from some female managers I witnessed in the Charlottesville VA location. Worst unfriendly location I ever worked at within GE.
column14: Some locations just seem very far removed from overall corporate culture goal. promote uniform change.

column12:
Great medical, PTO, etc
Upper management seems to be serious about learning how to manage software development teams/projects (but they still have a long way to go)
column13:
GE Transportation is still figuring out how to manage software development and there are some growing pains.
Performance review systems are excessively time consuming and tend to reward the most narcissistic.
Software engineers are treated like interchangeable cogs in the machine.
column14:
Increase granularity of software development roles and titles. There are at least hundreds of different types of software developers. The current structure seems to ignore this.
Appoint managers and team leaders with the knowledge, experience, and freedom to be effective managers. Bringing in managers from different domains and expecting them to properly manage a software development team is not realistic.
Do some reality checks on your hiring process. It does not currently allow team leaders and managers to find and hire the people they need.

column5: Good place for new Grads, not so for experienced
column12: Great company, proud to say I work for GE, great benefits, great people to work with.
column13: If you are hired as a 20+ year veteran and not coming into E-band, it is very difficult to move within and upward, even if you find that you are more qualified
column14: Try to address the Con, would of stayed if it was not so frustrating to work so hard and not get a chance to take on a leadership role

column12: Over a lot of overtime
column13: Pay Gap between METD and Assembler/Machinist is absolutely ridiculous. As METD we get treated like crap and have more injuries occur. We have less guys on the line and they still expected us to have the same number of engines. To add to that we had a worker on the line get hurt and our TA told us to slow down but then proceeds to yell at us for not moving the line quick enough. What I’m saying is that we as METD feel that we aren’t compensated enough for the stuff we go through on a day to day basis. Either close the pay Gap and bump METD to a different labor grade or figure something else out.
column14: Encourage workers with goals and recognition. For instance, when I first started we would get recognized for reaching a goal or good work. Now we don’t get notice or nothing besides get treated like crap.

column12: Union plant, meaning reasonable pay, and accrual of paid time off.
column13: Management often creating shortages of parts and supplies, then pointing the finger at the people doing the "actual work," in an effort to cover their many shortcomings. Integrity, honesty, and reasonable treatment of employees is severely deficient. They were slowly and systematically doing whatever they could to try and make this plant "look like" it was inefficient in a concerted effort to outsource production and force people to be laid off in order to weaken the union.
column14: There is literally nothing that can be said to encourage the management of this place to do right by the workers or the community that their hard earned dollars are being taken from. Greed has no empathy, integrity, sense of honor or loyalty. Your stock continues to perform dismally because of the damage that has already been done, and that shame is solely on the management to own.

column5: A great place to work, if you can keep up with the pace.
column12: Explosive career opportunities -- you can stay within GE, but move from business to business with unlimited growth potential.
column13: It is huge - which means that each business does things differently. It's hard to leverage best practices when you spend all of your time trying to identify who's doing it "right."
column14: Keep looking all the way to the "bottom" when you look at potential talent. If you come in at the bottom of an acquired company, it's hard to get exposure to "Big GE." Help us out!

column5: GE a Great Employer for strong, motivated, intelligent future leaders of the business world
column12: GE provides access to state-of-the-art technology and management training, unparalleled by other companies I've seen. Employees are encouraged to continue education by refunding costs for advanced degrees at academic institutions as well as sponsoring them to go to training classes and external seminars/workshops throughout the year. GE makes good on its claim of being a diverse employer with meritocracy-based advancement. The Company sponsors several affinity networks to help African American, female, gay/lesbian/bisexual/transgender, Hispanic, Asian, and Native American employees feel comfortable and confident that discrimination in the workplace is completely unacceptable. GE also has one of the most comprehensive benefits packages in the world including being one of the few employers to offer a full pension after retirement. GE offers many programs for flexible work arrangements as well, making it easy for employees to work remotely and spend more time with family if they desire.
column13: There is a lot of pressure to be cost-conscious and spending on things like celebrations and office comforts is very limited. Employees are constantly trying to take cost out of operations to bolster the bottom line. While being cost sensitive is a good discipline for an organization, I think that GE goes overboard sometimes in order to make profits as high as possible. When the company puts out hundreds of billions of dollars a year, it's hard to understand why the people who make it happen can't even get a free cup of coffee in the office lounges. Other than those minor things, though, there aren't a lot of major pitfalls to working for GE.
column14: To senior management, I would say to examine the lower ranks more often and find ways to motivate the "worker bees" who are doing what they can to keep this great company running full steam ahead. I would also say thanks for the great leadership and guidance to help people like me grow!

column12: Strong management capability and very high level of technical expertise and ability. Very friendly people and lots of comraderie among the scientific staff. Very cool for a company so large. The Research Center performs cutting edge research.
column13: Cafeteria food was so so. Had to go out for chinese food often. Car would freeze in parking lot, as there is not undercover parking in Winter! Had to use hot water to defrost windscreen wipers on at least one occassion.
column14: Put a cover over the cars for Winter, or at least have some tarps and steaming hot water readily available.

column12: GE is a larger company that has a lot of resources and is not ever really hurting for money. Because of that it is very easy to get help and to try new things.
column13: In my area there is a very strict advancement schedule which was a big factor in my resignation. It is a big company and you are often feel lost. There were times that I felt like employees were not valued much.
column14: Have a little more focus on your own human capital. They are very important to your success.

column5: GENERAL ELECTRIC MEDICAL SYSTEMS, INCORPORATED is not a company I would ever agree to work for in the future.
column12: They started me out at a good salary - had good benefits package.
column13: Uses SixSigma Program as blackmail tool to squeeze ideas out of employees. No SixSigma report, No raise possibility.
column14: Stop doing what is described above. As a result of my experiences with your company, i would NEVER work for a SixSigma company - any SixSigma company - EVER!!!! This company requires all employees to submit SixSigma reports on a minimum of one per year in order to be even be eligible for a cost of living increase in salary. in addition, they allowed no time during the normal work day to prepare these reports. The employees were EXPECTED to come in on weekends and stay late in order to complete them. If an idea was accepted, you were rewarded with theater tickets or something similar - even if the idea saved the company millions. Upped management really loved this SixSigma program - probably got them huge bonuses. Personally, I think it stunk to high heaven!!!! And so do they!!!!

column12: The atmosphere and co-workers are great. Everyone is very helpful and will help with any issue. The company has many perks such as incentives, moving to other locations, and moving to different positions within the company. The company also has excellent moral values. There is vacation time and rewards are given to the best team. This is a great company to work for. Also the health benefits are excellent.
column13: The time schedule may be difficult to work because you bid for your time to work. There are flexible hours but people with seniority get the first choice.

column5: GE is great, this locations leadership is NOT
column12: Lots of development opportunities, great stuff (on paper), and with the right leadership; you could do well. Leadership off-site and the vision they espouse is outstanding. Not sure how there is a disconnect between corporate and the local plant in terms of leadership values and ideals.
column13: This location's leadership is more about backstabbing and micromanagement. Everyone acted like you were trying to take their job or trying to do their job. They don't believe in getting both sides of the story, just whom they want to believe and push an agenda that they previously set. Steal ideas as well.
column14: Listen to both sides of the story and follow the facts. Leadership lacks credibility when facts are ignored. Additionally, a good idea is just that, should not feel threatened by good ideas. A place hostile to initiative is doomed to never reach the heights they could.

column12: This is of course a big American brand name, great to add your experience to your resume, more opportunities to move across different business
column13: I was working more than industry average, while I was unsurprisingly paid less. As you work for super big corporate, your voice is rarely, if never, be heard. Of course politics are a big culture of big companies like GE. Very slow in changes are expected
column14: They need to transform themselves to catch up with growing startup, or they will be left behind. Probably they need to learn from IT giant, adapt to fast pace industry

column12:
- Company gives a lot of autonomy to take on responsibility and grow. Not a lot of barriers to expand yourself technically or functionally.
- Work-Life balance is good
- Unlimited vacation time
column13:
- Leadership vision : Jeff Immelt fostered a culture of selling a great vision to customers and employees. As it turns out, no one in leadership is that great in bringing a vision to reality, which is why GE is where it is. It is clear that under Immelt GE lost its expertise in running businesses and teams.
- Identity of GE is now lost... GE is now even a smaller footprint and whatever is left doesn't create a sense of GE. 
- Culture is a mess....
column14: GE is no longer a conglomerate company... so stop trying to act and organize as one. Find good leaders who have actual expertise instead of promoting glorified project managers and auditors into leadership positions.

column12: Very flexible for family and work balance is good overall and co-workers are very supportive of each other. I think it is a great place to work if you have children as they are very compassionate about family situations and the benifits are very good also. I am sure not every department is the same but the department I was in really impressed me and although I have just moved away and had to end my employment I miss the job itself along with many of the very wonderful people who worked there. Great job to Jonathan May for being an excellent manager.
column13: Not much recognition for jobs well done from the immediate supervisor. That would be my only complaint really. Besides the fact that there is a lot of management employee relationships/ marriages that I think affect job performances sometimes. People who are not managers tend to think if they are dating one of the managers that gives them managerial rights and although this is not the case it is not handled very well by management and not stopped. A shame because this could be a perfect place to work but this is a big problem and needs to be taken care of.
column14: Please acknowledge how hard people are working and as said above: Not much recognition for jobs well done from the immediate supervisor. That would be my only complaint really. Besides the fact that there is a lot of management employee relationships/ marriages that I think affect job performances sometimes. People who are not managers tend to think if they are dating one of the managers that gives them managerial rights and although this is not the case it is not handled very well by management and not stopped. A shame because this could be a perfect place to work but this is a big problem and needs to be taken care of.

column5: The elephant should learn some new dance steps
column12: There is plenty of opportunity to be highly technical. Engineering is a valued skill at GE and there are many options for career paths. The work is challenging and there are a lot of resources available. The goals of the business are clear and there is a strong emphasis on values and credibility. There is a lot of internal career training opportunities and a large array of business tools the company uses and teaches. It is possible to transfer internally from one division to another and make a major career change while maintaining benefits and years with the company. The company reputation is great for training good people and GE alumni seem to be in demand.
column13: Changes are made quickly and sometimes without warning. Our business name has changed 3 times in the last 5 years, our CEO has changed 3 times in the last 5 years, and we seem to be constantly going through reorganizations to realign our portfolio for the stockholders. Quarterly profits are the most important metric. There is a culture of fire-fighting mentality and priority is not given to documentation or projects to improve communications and job-specific training. IT and Engineering software tools are often developed in-house on shoestring budgets which is often less reliable than commercial software packages. The company is conservative when it comes to business innovation and cultural change. There is always more to be done than people to accomplish the work. Individuals are often given demanding auxiliary jobs to do on top of their primary focus.
column14: Increase focus on best-practice sharing across businesses and departments. Increase transparency around business and HR changes. If productivity is a true priority, allocate resources to implement real productivity changes. Stop trying to do more with less time and resources - there are already too few people to accomplish all that needs to get done and we face many complex technical challenges. Refocus IT, IM and GRC tools development groups to serve the customer needs and deliver more valuable and usable tools. Hire quality software engineers. Simplify and reduce bureaucracy. Improve morale.

column12: GE has a strong reputation for producing engineers capable of managing projects. Most the work involved managing a project to some degree, which is useful experience. For their Edison engineers, they offered a strong training program that included leadership workshops through corporate. Most employees seemed to care about the job they did. That being said, most do the 8-5 routine.
column13:
Red tape and uncertainty of what the future will hold about sums up the cons. Given that GE is a large company, it can be very challenging to get things done in a timely because of all the paperwork and approvals required to make a change to anything. I worked at GE Consumer and Industrial and at the time corporate announced C&I would be up for sale. When corporate couldn't get a good offer for the business, they decided to spin it off. After I left, I believe they decided to keep the company until the economy turned so they could sell it for me. Rumors of a sale of C&I have been around for years and won't be be gone until a sale does happen. 

It seemed like much of the engineering work was being outsourced to India. Almost all of the CAD work is done in India. They also have a program that brings engineers to India for rotations. I certainly got the feeling that company was in the process of handing over much of the engineering work to India. Since there are alot of engineers in India willing to work for a lot less than an American engineer I would expect this trend to continue
column14: Management within the C&I business was fine. Most of the issues are a result of the actions by corporate. Management seems to care and is approachable.

column12: I was fortunate to work at a smaller GE manufacturing plant with 4 or 5 other interns rather than in Schenectady. The computer software was old but the quality of my assignments were much better than others at larger locations. Great work for an intern with a mix of design and hands on experience
column13: Very corporate atmosphere. GE seems to reward middle managers for doing less real engineering work. average pay for entry level engineers
column14: reward engineers and weed out middle management types. Up the starting engineer salary and add a week of time off

column5: Doesn't live up to it's reputation
column12: Highly regarded company, great advancement opportunities (for some), world class training facility (Crotonville). Senior leadership is pretty strong, middle managers are hit and miss. Lots of very smart and talented people here. Work anywhere in the world.
column13: Lots of competition, internally - not just for good jobs, but lots of finger pointing to avoid having your metric look "bad". Quality is talked about, but not a lot of commitment on the part of leaders to really do what's needed. Bonus compensation limited to execs and certain other roles. Health plan stinks. Technology is old and outdated - enterprise apps are vintage 1990's, and the place still runs on spreadsheets to some degree. Outside hires have a tough time figuring out the organization's cultures and matrices.
column14: End competing metrics, break apart the silos. Bring back quality as a critical, sought after place to be in the organization.

column12: you get to work with talented people and exposure to a global business / GE on your resume is a step to a next and better job / pay is the only advantage based on the limited options and low pay at other Erie companies
column13: salaries are not competitive / no bonus or incentive comp / benefits reduce almost yearly / business is very cyclical which equates to semi-regular layoffs and salary freezes / career advancement is limited / HR is completely disengaged and provides no support / employee satisfaction and morale tends to be low / work-life balance is more of a slogan and not reality / vacation time is generous but using it is discouraged or disregarded (plan on answering emails and calls while on vacation and you'd better respond no matter what)
column14: executives receiving a chairman's award as the best financially performing unit of the year in the company, and high-fiving each other on the stage while collecting bonuses is an insult to the employees who delivered those results for you and they're lucky if they receive (and convinced to be grateful for) an at best 3% COLA.

column5: Good experiences could be made Great experiences
column12: Highly skilled, hard-working employees who strive to be the best at what they do. Family-type atmosphere at my site. Opportunities for advancement though may require relocation. Great communication to employees.
column13: Work/Life balance is not as good as it once was. Increasing headcount in Operations, Engineering and Quality organizations means increased workload for support functions but they get no relief. Fifty to sixty hour weeks are common. Simplification needs to be applied to all processes. Takes numerous workflows and approvals to get anything done.
column14: SImplify all processes.

column5: exciting company, strong culture but too focused on the short term
column12:
Despite being one of the largest companies in the world (300,000 employees), GE still feels like one company, driven by one very iconic (and highly respected) leader. The leadership are strongly committed to developing employees and the opportunities are limitless if you are willing to relocate frequently. You could easily spend 20-30 years at this company, moving into a new role every 2-4 years in a new industry and even a new country - it's not uncommon for people to have lived in 2, 3, 5 or more countries during their careers at GE. The compensation is good.
Also, GE is all about delivering - the processes are incredible here. If the company wants to roll something out, stay out of the way! The downside, though, is that there is a lot of process and a tremendous amount of bureaucracy, despite the strong push from the highest levels for simplification. Overall, though, if you are looking for one company to stay at for 20+ years and build your career, GE is a great option and you will never be bored.
column13:
GE is so focused on the short term (meeting quarterly targets) that long term planning just doesn't happen in most of the business units. It's surprising. There are many extremely smart people here but strategy seems to be done only at the highest levels - everyone else is very focused on process and short term goals. There isn't a lot of entrepreneurial thinking here - people generally wait to be told what to do - and then they'll do it exceptionally well - but they don't come up with the ideas.
Also, the perks are great but the benefits are terrible - they are massively shifting costs to the employees to reduce the overall costs to GE.

column12: GE is very fast paced and exciting with great company benefits and quirks if you do your job and show promise. GE gives freedom for growth and self development.
column13: Work life balance is challenging and if you don't "fit in" or play the "office politics" your career can go from one of extreme satisfaction to one of chaos and heartache. Although improvement includes challenging "the norm" at times, if doing so involves the wrong individual in authority, your future within the company is grim.
column14: Consider corresponding with the supply chain employees Middle management does not endorse. Their favorites do as they do, thus the reason they are acknowledged. Communicate with the one or two who do not appear successful as they are the ones challenging the norm with out of the box thinking and those employees are actually key in the new leadership and will be needed to take back our position as the number one company globally.

column5: This was my first engineering job out of college.
column12: Working for a big company, I got to travel and learn new skills working with many different people. Employees were also provided training and required to study six sigma.
column13: Working for a big company sometimes you felt like a number. The 360 review process was unfair to employees and sometimes cause animosity and competition among groups and teams, which created dysfunction.
column14: They should encourage team building and have better support from people in upper management for people in middle management or at the site level.

column5: the place where people love to learn, innovate and grow
column12: expected to perform to a high standard, everyone is smarter than you so you learn a lot and you're challenged to keep improving and growing
column13: each business unit has its own sub-culture so sometimes those are tougher to survive in especially if the industry is going through a tough cycle or it's not as mature as some of the others
column14: continue to move faster on the culture changing things you're trying to do -- invest in your SPB and LPB now more than ever

column12: If you fight, you will be adequately compensated for your level of effort expended. You will need to learn the culture and what is valued to really excel.
column13: The culture can get a little insular. There should be a guide that explains things one wished they knew prior to starting. That said, it is workable if you are flexible.
column14: Executive leadership seems oddly on point for future state considerations for the long term solvency of the company. Middle-HR should drop its arbitrary and Welsh-esque notions of what is required to be a leader in the company.

column12:
Technology and people are fantastic. 
The diversity of products leads to many opportunities. 
This company does good for society.
column13:
Run by a finance team and lack the ability to drive new technology. 
Manufacturing is so disconnected from the business and there are to many silos. This sets up for organizations making sure they are successful vs making sure the business is successful.
column14: destroy supply chain. The business needs more ownership. Run each business like they are each a small business with the backstop of GE. Like Jack DID.

column5: Very good people, personal and professional growth
column12: Good people, corporate processes, onboarding, coaching and mentoring. Great place to build career.
column13: Matrix organization, can be confusing to people who have not worked in this type of organizational environment. "Decisions by commitee." Younger, leadership...too much "inside the box" thinking...not enough external experiences by leadership team. Most manager have spent 8-12 years from college, and then run an organization..the "GE way"
column14: Simplification and eliminating "red-tape" grew GE when Jack was running the organization. Too many layers. Length of decisions cost money and resources...get back to basics!

column5: Solid company but difficult for new employees to learn the politics and how to navigate the system
column12: Great brand recognition, many of the factory employees have been around a long time and have a ton of knowledge
column13: Sales management a local regional levels lacks sufficient leadership skills to be effective. Local account managers are held accountable for everything but have no authority to make changes bases on current market conditions. GE Industrial policy of signing any distributor up only pits GE distributor against GE distributor which erodes market pricing. Too much of of the good old boy network means local sales management never gets challenged or held accountable.
column14: Move DSMs out of that role after 5-7 years, they get to the point where all they worry about is doing and saying anything to keep their jobs. When you have account managers turnover at the rate of 4-5 every 2-3 years then management is not doing their job.

column12: Independent work, creative freedom, flexible schedule, minimal micro-managing, exciting projects and novel work, good starting base salary, clearly defined career path within the technician band...
column13: ... However no real path from technician to professional band, ceilings for positions are clearly visible - particularly referring to salary and mobility within the org, HR-heavy and very bureaucratic processes slow projects and teams
column14: Don't be afraid to stick your head out of the box and challenge HR. Step up to bat for your employees and provide a clear interest in the advancement of their careers.

column5: Pretty good company over all to work for
column12: After almost 15 years for this company I have learned many things and have made many friends. The benefits were good and the money wasn't bad.
column13: Favoritism, it was hard getting a promotion because I found out it was not so much of what you knew, it was who you knew.
column14: You should promote people who deserve the job, not hire someone off the street that has no idea of the job. Also you should pay temps more and hire the good ones sooner to be able to keep quality people.

column5: Good Technical Work, Good Benefits, Lots of Burocracy
column12: Interesting design and manufacturing challenges to solve. Good pay and benefits. Good flex time and vacation time.
column13: Lot's of red tape involved in all the systems and processes that can be a pain to work through.
column14: I know the company is always talking about simplifying things, but they often make it worse. If I.T. help was improved and you could easy have an I.T. person walk over to your desk and help you navigate all of the computer systems which are always changing, that would be so helpful.

column5: Proud to be part of GE family
column12: Working with people who you can learn a lot from. Challenging tasks are constantly presented at you. Great health insurance benefits for the whole family. The best maternity leave benefits especially for managers - get total of 16-18 weeks paid leave. Company is very accommodating for their employees in hard life situations.
column13: Capital side of business got dissolved and opportunities in Chicago are almost non existent. Just changed their 401k match policy where you won't receive the company contribution for the year unless you are there on December 15.

column12:
Complex business problems due to the tax planning strategies they execute on
Large volume of diverse business scenarios 
Large data sets required use of technology to manage volume
Frequent buying and selling of businesses forces professionals to integrate and divest businesses
column13:
Company has lost focus on back office head count control leading to company wide layoffs
Size of GE can make increasing the priority of you business request due to competing business scenario priorities
column14:
Get back to the days of controlling head count and raising the standards for employee professionalism
Don't rush to hire, wait for the right match

column5: Strong Company, but Just a Number
column12: 401K, Good Benefits, Household Name, Numerous Oppurtunities
column13: You're literally just an SSO number, very little room for mistake, the budget and the project are all that matter, very little to no structure at the site level, not having the proper tools, conflict of interest, and upper management not having your back.
column14: Wind energy within GE needs a revamp, from safety to customer relations, and site management to training. GE wind does not represent the rest of the company as well as it should, and that starts from the top.

column5: Working here is not what it used to be
column12: Opportunity to see lots of various products and work in different types of business. very open to movement between functions. Flexible work after proving yourself.
column13: Leadership is not always chosen/promoted for the right reason... it seems to be getting more about who you know and less about acheivement being recognized. Retention problems.... losing good people because engagement is low.
column14: Focus on employees and engagment. Present career paths and development programs. Refocus efforts on lean ... get back to basics.

column12: Money and benefits were good. There is a lot of room for promotion if you're willing to play the politics.
column13: Watch your back. People working for General Electric are way too competitive. If you want to get promoted you have to be on your game at all times.
column14: Relax the business etiquette so that employees feel more comfortable. Offering a BBQ every once in a while doesn't make up for the fact that the people working for you are miserable.

column12:
Unbeatable reputation - The name and the corp structure helps keep that reputation
Diversity - Many different divisions to move around to and from
Structure - Management approach
column13:
Salary low - not very competitive to keep good talent
Does not weed out the real talent well-Managers are not trained to nurture good employees
Promotions are few-have to be "connected" to move anywhere
column14: Try harder to keep the good talent you have, but also think about past talent that you could use right now. Some people went through reorganization, but would love a welcome back if asked.

column5: A pretty good place to work
column12: They have the capital to research ideas, and develop new products. There is always interesting programs to work on. They have many talented people.
column13: Way too many layers of management, lots of institutional inertia, too many managers of engineers with little to no experience in the area that they are managing. Programs get cut with little rhyme or reason.
column14: Try to reduce the number of layers between the decision makers and the individual contributors, the message (top-down and bottoms-up) seem to get lost.

column5: Great Work/Life balance; poor insurance benefits
column12:
-Commitment to quality and excellence
-Higher average pay than other companies in area
-Semi-autonomous work environment
-Excellent training programs
-Advancement opportunities
-100% tuition/books reimbursement while employed
-no retaliation guarantee for raising concerns
column13:
-large campus, lack of personal privacy
-insurance is horrible (office visits are not $25 copay - you pay all until deductible met)
-small fish in big pond, lack of interpersonal relationships you would find at smaller company
-chain of command gets complicated, tasks re-prioritized frequently
column14:
-work closer with employees on career goals and allow them to spread wings (advancement)
-promote self-assessments, manager assessments, team assessments
-promote volunteerism outside of the company

column12: There is seemingly a system or workflow for everything. GE really does work hard to structure the teams to reduce conflict of interest and relieve the potential for politics.
column13: There is seemingly a system or workflow for everything. It can be very bureaucratic, and many managers will want to see six sigma methods applied even when it isn't appropriate, like treating software defects the same as manufacturing defects.
column14: Develop or hire some technical managers, there are far too many layers of useless management even after the de-layering.

column5: Wonderful co-workers. Great place to work. Don't drink the water.
column12: Outstanding people with integrity. Plenty of opportunity for career growth and personal development. Respectful of work-life balance. Overall a great place to work.
column13: Rather political. Getting a head is more about working the hallway than work done at your desk. Many leaders and very few worker bees.Lack of business direction and leadership by Chip Blankenship has been a torn since 2010.
column14: A healthy look in number of women verse men in leadership. Or minorities for that matter.CEO & his staff are a prime example.

column5: a solid company to work for, if you are willing to put in what it takes
column12:
Opportunities for advancement.
Professional peers.
Numbers driven.
Deep financial resources ... if you can justify them.
column13:
Taking away longstanding salaried benefits with just a letter is eroding the trust and respect of employees.
Years of closing down operations in the US.
Over emphasis on meeting inventory numbers.
column14:
Keep focusing on customer service. Your best decisions have been those that have benefited the customer.
Cutting out all travel is rarely a good idea.
Don't lose site of delighting your employees. You have taken away a lot lately ...

column5: Trying to do the right thing
column12: Great people. Everyone is really bright and trying to do the right thing. New innovations are always discussed and worked on. Great work space!
column13: Big company blues: The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing. Too much bureaucracy and lack of quick decision making.
column14: Pick an idea that you want implemented. Pick the team. Fund the team. Trust the team to execute (i.e. don't micromanage them and have them beg for money every 6 months nor make them do exhaustive reporting.)

column12: GE Railcar gathered leaders and positively influenced the railcar industry. They chose to do the right thing even if it cost more, if it is better for the environment or the workers they did it.
column13: GE corporate sold the business in 2016. The leaders have spread out to other companies in and outside of the rail industry.
column14: Where ever you are, keep doing the best of the best work. We may have complained while we were there, but truth is it was good.

column12: Great exposure to upper level management. Solid work life balance. Opportunities for growth within the company. Leader in the digital industrial space
column13: Location is not the greatest if you are not a cincinnati native. The work can be difficult as there are old systems in place and many different layers to the organization. Limited opportunities to relocate to different businesses
column14: Increase salary and demand more from employees. There is often times a work atmosphere that is too laid back and relaxed. Bring in more external talent so that the culture does not become an echo chamber.

column12: Lots of growth opportunities for entry level and mid level employees. Ability to change functions or even business units. The company loves to invest in employees (especially top performers)
column13: Be prepared to drink the koolaid and be 100% on board with every top management decision. Lots of politics played amongst execs and sometimes individual manager, functional, or business unit KPIs take precedence on whats best for overall business.
column14: Try to limit some of the bureaucracy and administrative work so top employees can actually focus on getting things done!

column5: solid work environment with competitive pay
column12: They offer a competitive salary for new comers and really stress moving up. The leadership programs are amazing and really help people get ahead if you know how to work.
column13: The leadership programs make you be away from home a lot and the work hours can mount to up to 20 a day. Sometimes can be overwhelming
column14: If I was in your position I would attempt to eliminate some of the duplicative efforts going on. It seems like a lot of people are doing the same job.

column5: A great company to work for
column12: Great pay and benefits compared to other companies for co-op, company takes care of its employees well. Was given much responsibility within the position and was rewarded with a pay raise half way through my rotation.
column13: Company can be very demanding to work for at times, which makes it especially hard if you are working in a division that is a dieing business.
column14: Upper management needs to get to know production plants better before giving them unrealistic targets to reach.

column5: A great business to work for, however it's a very cut throat environment
column12: I think GE is a great company to work for, everyone on the team was very competent, friendly and willing to share their knowledge with you.
column13: It's very difficult to get a full story about something. Information sharing is a definite challenge. Also you are held accountable for the mistakes of others if your project suffers even if they aren't on your team.
column14: I would say that the managers need to tighten things up in terms of information sharing and cross team collaboration.

column5: Ge has gone from GE is ME to cost reductions and profits to please stock holders
column12: If you have the self discipline for self learning, there are many opportunities there. Pay and benefits are okay. 401k matching is fairly good.
column13: GE doesn't seem to really care about it's people any more. It is very risk adverse. I was told that in order to be successful at GE I needed to be an aggressive a-hole (which is not my character). Even if you are within budget, funding for your project may be cut with only a day or 2 of notice. Typical 50+ hour work week. You can talk about GLBT (gays, lesbians, bisexuals, and transgenders), but to mention Christ is forboden.
column14: Vision on what is going on and where GE is headed is not transferred downstream very well. Change is slow and not much recognition.

column7: Software Distribution and Asset Management Engineer
column12: Management listens to employees and seem to honestly want feedback. There are a lot of opportunities for growth and advancement. The company is very willing to send you to training classes that target the career goals you have in mind. You will most likely get Six Sigma and Leadership training within the first 1 to 2 years of being on the job. Also may opportunities for technical training if you speak with your manager.
column13: Sometimes it may seem as if you have more than one job.
column14: Provide a better benefits package.
