column12: GE has a strong brand and overall a solid reputation. It's a good experience to work for GE.
column13: They don't have a strong training program. They have a complicated compensation plan for the sales team and they are likely to change the compensation plan at any given time. Its such a large company (over 300,000 employees) and each division/business unit has the authority to run their own business which makes it difficult to work with other businesses that have their own goals and agenda.
column14: Spend more time with the customers and the employees who work with the customers on a daily business in order to have a better understanding of customer needs and to learn about how GE can provide more value to its customer base. Also, changing your sales team's compensation plan in the middle of the year is a terrible thing to do and its a bad way to retain your employees.

column5: Very nice co-workers and a relatively relaxed work enviroment
column12:
Great management, the project managers give you adequate time to work on projects.

You can choose what time you want to come in and leave for the most part as long as you work at least eight hours a day.

You get your own office.

Opportunities for managerial and lean training are available.
column13:
Relatively low pay compared to other companies.

Raises are not a lot and do not happened very frequently.
column14: No real advice to management, they were great, the only advice would to be maybe make the salaries slightly more competitive.

column5: Great company working to shed big company burdens
column12: Opportunity to work with incredibly smart people, some of the world's best leaders and sell arguably the best products in the industry.
column13: While they're working to improve upon this, the company continues to struggle with bureaucracy, slow customer response times and other a litany of non-value add requirements.
column14: In order to maintain continuity, some leaders are hesitant to promote or allow high achieving employees to explore other roles within the company. This hurts both the company and the employee as it often results in the employee leaving the company.

column12: The Job security is great, being able to learn and continue new experiences is also a plus. the ability to advance positions is always an option as ling as your willing to work hard for them. being part of an organized team and having professional bosses that are willing to help with anything you need is great.
column13: the only con could be that I had to leave the company due to relocation.
column14: recognizing hard work is always important, giving the chance and ability to allow workers to prove them selves as well.

column12: Great training programs and a great place to gain experience at the beginning of one's career. Surrounding by very smart, accomplished people.
column13: It's a large company and can feel very large company. If you want to build a long career at the company, while also advancing your career forward, can require moving your family time and time again, possibly all over the world.
column14: No advice. I think they've done a really great job of bringing more focus and cohesion to their portfolio, especially by selling NBC Universal in 2011 and GE Capital in 2015.

column12:
-Great Place to learn
-Adopter of New Technology
- Recognition and oppurtunites if you are a star performer and have a Greencard / are a US citizen
column13:
- Projects tend to not finish on time
- Insane amount of office politics by fulltime employees
- cut throat culture
- Every day seems like a new deadline on critical projects
- Deadlines can get very stressful
column14: They just need to cut down on the politics to increase productivity, but I guess that is sometimes unavoidable when you have so many Type A people working at one place.

column12: A great place to learn and grow. If you want to plug in and get involved there are lots of opportunities to do that. Great training programs. Lots of room to grow. Leaders are responsible for growing their people.
column13: It is a really big company and easy to feel like you are a really small fish. You will need to have initiative to figure things out and jump in. More work than time to get it done so work life balance is a challenge
column14: More Change Management around M&A

column12:
A wide range of extraordinarily intelligent people
Terrific infrastructure 
Global reach
Some areas are great to work with and for
Genuinely committed to diversity of gender, ethnicity, veteran status, sexual orientation, etc.
column13:
Many executives are in their roles short term just to cut a notch on their belt - it's brutal on the teams who sincerely believe in the company and projects
Over-the-top bad behaviors by senior management is allowed
Infighting and fiefdom building
Major overtime required to hit deadlines - often for months on end
column14: HR must address behavioral issues

column5: Great job now, but career doesn't look promising.
column12: Exciting work in a high growth company. Good pay. Good entry level job. Work 40+ hours a week with very little travel.
column13: Unrealistic schedules. Poor communication between management and employees. There's no real technical career path (even though one has been in the works for close to 2 years, it has yet to be put in place and we've been assured it won't affect salary). Engineering (SW/HW) positions are growing faster in India, but it's still mostly Product Acceptance. Very little exposure to customers. Our measly bonus plan was done away with last year not that it mattered much as it was only about $250.
column14: Get to know the people working for you. Motivate your teams through common goals. Don't allow silly corporate politics to interfere with the work of your employees. Cut out the "corporate" language in presentations.

column12:
-Meritocracy, the better you perform the more highly you are valued.
-Excellent people around you.
-Large breadth of knowledge withing company
-Great mentors are available if you take advantage of them.
-Opportunities to move between businesses
column13:
-work/life balance
-compensation is below average

You can easily work as many hours as you can spare. This is actually encouraged. 
The beauracracy that comes with a large company is very prevalent. Sometimes very difficult to make the right moves and decisions due to red tape and "the process".
column14: -More strategic "longer view" thinking

column5: Salaries for engineers at GE Infrastructure are too broad.
column12: Career development through training and the chance to further your education is excellent. Benefits package are great. They encourage fitness and the fitness center is nice. Ability to put your money to work through a nice investment program.
column13: Salaries compared to equals are unfair. I found out that a new guy just out of college doing the same work as I with 4 years experience was getting paid 10K more than me. Salaries for engineers at GE Infrastructure are too broad, meaning the bands need to be more disipline specific. Some managers say that health and family come first, but when you ask for time off they can get angry when deadlines are near. Other managers don't take the time to get to know you and tend to have their favorites. Some managers don't have the correct background for their position.
column14: Give equal salaries, meaning adjust for inflation.

column5: All depends on whose team you're on
column12: Great depth of resources available. Opportunities for developing knowledge and new competencies. Decent pay and benefits. Relatively stable senior management.
column13: Very demanding in terms of work hours and intensity, with people resources tight at this time due to cost reductions. Value of your contributions is highly dependent on your group's overall image and manager's status in the organization.
column14: Keep up the good work with thinking outside the box on energy management initiatives. Focus on retaining valuable folks who are mid-career.

column5: Looks Good on the Resume, but ... No Good Deed Goes Unpunished
column12:
Many opportunities to move within the company.
Nice name recognition for your resume.
They like to hire former military.
There can be some good training ooportunities.
Some good perks if your lucky.
column13:
Seem to always meet cost targets by cutting headcount.
Sometimes too bureaucratic to get anything done.
Long hours are unwritten rule. (Get to work before your boss/manager, and don't leave before they do!) 
They talk about work/life balance, but that is just a program.
The almighty dollar is king- stock price is the golden idol.
Some people horde information, to ensure job security... makes it harder for the rest of us to do our jobs.
column14: Don't always cut costs through headcount reduction. Don't "spread the Wealth" making all business units take the same cost cutting actions- reward the better performing ones by not hammering them so hard, and squeeze the laggards harder... it is demoralizing when "No good deed goes unpunished!"

column12: great people and a great environment; it was refreshing to be surrounded by peers who seemed to be "at the top of their game"
column13: the environment at GE is very cutthroat - either you get it or you don't; sometimes management wasn't as understanding about the personal life-work balance, however, this varied with the manager you were assigned to work under
column14: please give more informal feedback throughout the FMP program; ultimately, we learn from your experiences and are thankful when receiving constructive criticism

column5: Good place to grow. You can succeed only if you break your butt.
column12:
Management does not micro manage. They give you the goals, its up to you to get the job done. Many times the job is what yo make it.
There are very few to no slackers at GE. Its a great opportunity to work with the best and brightest for the most part.
column13: You must be willing to go the extra mile to succeed. You will get what you put into it.
column14: Hang in there. If you can succeed in appliances you can succeed anywhere.

column12: Not being in production environment, Good place for team work and working with Smart qualified people. State of the art equipment.
column13: At the end of the day, you could have the best relationship with your immediate supervisor, and be a great employee, but you are still just a number to the Vp's.
column14: Find a way to get the older employees that are just taking up space, to move along or fire them, because you have too many 20+year employees that are taking advantage of the company and are just waiting on retirement.

column5: Large, diverse business. Locomotives to advanced control systems.
column12: Great people, very experienced local leadership and engineering staff. Market leading technology and GE brand makes this a stable business. Small customer base allows for intimate technical and commercial interaction.
column13: The railroad business is very risk averse and new technologies are shunned until proven successful. Internal battles for company funding and staffing for engineering development are brutal.
column14: CAT's purchase of EMD will create a new competitive environment. We need to respond with more technology investment to keep the edge.

column12:
Leadership programs, excellent training - provides a ton of resources
Interesting and hard working people
Diversity is extremely important
Good benefits, flexible working hours
Good recognition and at least in Power & Water - quality products to work on
column13:
Engineering pay is just average
Sometimes difficult to get overtime pay for long hours
Sometimes can be resource constrained
Large corporation tied to shareholders and profits - hard to push for more innovation
Outsource a lot of the "fun" work because it's cheaper
column14: Give back the fun projects to internal engineers - we don't always want to be program managers

column12: Great company to work for they are very ethical in how they treat people and all the other workers were easy to get along with
column13: there really wasn't anything that struck me as a con at GE. I guess being ChemE and going into a place that doesn't staff many ChemE's because they don's tailor to ChemE skills you take a bit of a pay hit.
column14: Be more accepting of people that want to learn stuff on the more general scale such as a ChemE wanting to work in the MechE side of GE.

column5: Great for entry level profesionals and new hires
column12: Great for new employees. GE likes to invest in new talent, new college grads, new people career development training programs external training opportunities
column13:
- Mid career professionals struggle within the company (very limited investment and training)
- HR offers no value to help employees grow their career
- GE has no place for individual contributors only leaders and project managers thrive
- GE seldom promotes in current job titles it is instead encourage to switch jobs
- Many of the retirements a forced by emails sent to retiree distibution list 
- If you're over 40 forget about a leadership opportunities coming your way
column14: Jeffrey wake up! You're losing all the talent of the knowledge workers. Project managers alone cannot run a business Develop the individual contributors so they are learning and developing their skills so they don't become obsolete. Predix is a piece of crap.

column12: 19 years of unbelievable opportunities in four countries across two continents. A meritocracy. Great leadership role models in multiple organizations. The way diverse people collaborate and build great products and outcomes are second to none.
column13: Not too many. Sometimes certain corporate initiatives get overly political and taken to the extreme to be then overwritten by a different initiative a year or two later.
column14: Keep doing what you are doing - and solve for promotional opportunities for top talent amidst simplification as promotions to the next leadership band are becoming more scarce.

column12: Director of Service (DOS) and Co-workers were excellent to work with. Many challenges working multi modalities (CT, PET, AW, and Ultrasound). Remote support and documentation is excellent and getting better. Overall, excellent job.
column13: No work life balance. As most, if not all, large corporations do more with less. A work week of 60 to 70 hours was the norm not the exception. I choose retirement due to NO work life balance.
column14: Hire more engineers to do service. This would reduce OT and improve overall work environment.

column12: Ultrasound Only- Leading products most care areas, great innovation brining products to the market that matter. Product development and engineering are shining jewel of company. Segmentation in product development is a key strength sharing innovated ideas across product platforms.
column13: Ultrasound Only- On the commercial side- broken culture driven & managed by fear, extremely transactional, non inclusive, too segemented to a fault in commercial structure, poor leadership at the highest levels. Current distribution model has peaked and needs significant leadership change to correct course.
column14: Ultrasound Only- Become strategic in the deployment model or continue to observe stagnation to negative gains in market share growth. Make a change in Commercial Leadership to change the culture. The people in the field make the company, not the leadership that has created a frail self destructive environment. The rest of the GEHC has worked hard to create a great place to work. It is time for a make over in Ultrasound.

column12:
- Real products, with a vision to power, cure and transport the earth's people. That's pretty cool!
- Diverse work opportunities within GE
- Increased transparency is helping
column13:
- Company vision is polarized between cost-out and innovation, and between centralizing (Corp shared services, horizontal teams) and decentralizing (businesses autonomy) ... these opposing fronts create mixed priorities at every level, lengthy decision-making, excessive resourcing, and weakens both strategies.
- Due to cost-saving-restructuring, many leaders are in dual-roles... this means they are spread way too thin and have conflicting priorities. All new "big" jobs are being given to existing leaders, who get to keep their current job!
- Significant financial issues with no end in sight - management is making short-term decisions in order to weather the storm. Financial issues have impacted employees: significant cut to bonuses and minimal annual pay increases. And - stock options, granted annually, haven't had any value for employees for the last 20yrs.

column12: There is a Large Network of peers for knowledge sharing, flexible work hours/locations (for engineering), flexible permissive time, opportunities for travel
column13: Engineers are punished for staying in current roles. Expertise is highly valued and used, however the annual raises for an employee that stays in the same team (which people rely on) is much less than for an engineer that changes jobs.
column14: Reward expertise and being a go-to person. Provide a reason to stay on the technical leadership path, we need these people and we're losing them to better paying companies.

column12: I got exactly what I was sold when I was recruited out of college into a leadership program and my career has taken me all over the world with exciting new roles.
column13: Balance has improved since I started. Some of the leadership at acquisitions lack GE's values. The travel is a necessary part of the job that is more positive than not.
column14: Guard GE's reputation better and more like the way Welch did. Iran sales and NBC are blackeyes that make me less proud to work at GE.

column5: Great introduction into the corporate world
column12: You get to work with great people who have a strong work ethic. There is the opportunity for gaining experience in many different types of engineering jobs--from the design side to the product maintenance, innovation, etc.
column13: The work is demanding--if you don't enjoy what you do, it could be rough. Enjoy engineering, and it isn't as bad!
column14: Keep hiring people who love their jobs. The people make the job. Being in a community of knowledgeable and interesting people is one of the big reasons I enjoy my job.

column12: Good learning opportunities. Good work life balance, work from home whenever need be, HSA, DFSA etc are good. They have an office almost any where in the world. Good support for new mothers.
column13: If you get stuck with a bad manager, there is nothing to save you. Raises are very less. No bonuses. Need to manage up, down sideways. If you accomplish one thing, you have to tell 20 people for it to get noticed.
column14: There are so many managers at GE its hard to give one advice that will apply for all.

column12: If you have the skills and continue to agree to accept more responsibility, you can move up.
column13: You have to prove yourself for a quite a while before you can move up. You may also have to make opportunities for yourself rather than anyone handing them to you because you've excelled. Company culture of people who actually do the work is caught up in a lot of CYA--lots of employees scared of reprimand, etc...
column14: Gain a better understanding of the work your employees are required to do.

column12: GE is working on a lot of projects which gives you a good opportunity to work for other functional teams if you talk to the right people. Always ask if there is anything else that your boss or another congruent functional team needs help with. If you have that attitude during your co-op you will get a great co-op experience. Co-ops are given a good hourly wage and a living stipend if coming from outside the louisville area.
column13: During some phases of development there is not too much to do.

column5: GE is a great place to start out
column12: Training opportunities, flexible schedules, travel opportunities, reasonable salary for area, exciting projects to work on. You will work with great people for the most part.
column13: As with most large companies, frustrating bureaucracy slows down / inhibits work. Lots of office politics... more so recently than in the past.
column14: Become better at determining which products are truly important to the market. Many projects fall short of being what they could be, due to lack of funding, lack of staffing, and lack of proper leadership.

column12: Good place to start a career and with many opportunities for career branching with the many different businesses under GE.
column13: Not many to point out besides the fact that it is a very large company. If large companies isn't your thing then you might want to look elsewhere. Other than that there is nothing egregious to point out.
column14: Management has been pretty good overall and they have shown that through the ability to manage large teams with good composure and grace. There is no micromanaging either, which is good personally.

column12: The company has very high integrity standards. There is lots of room to grow and develop your career. I feel respected in my position.
column13: The new (2015) performance rating system is vague. When business is booming overtime becomes nearly mandatory for salary shop managers. When a site down sizes they expect the remaining employees to "make it work." Which can be very difficult.
column14: The best managers are very approachable and make time for recognizing the good work of their team .

column12: Great emphasis on speed, innovation and digital transformation. Leading the charge into the Industrial Internet of Things.
column13: Emphasis on speed not aligned with budget processes and support functions. HR, Finance, Purchasing, etc. are incredibly bureaucratic and slow. Suffers from a tendency to "inflate" achievements beyond actually delivered results at times.
column14: Maintain focus on strategic directions, but make sure that the focus on short-term financial numbers doesn't undercut your strategy. If "the numbers always win", then you really don't have a strategy, just a stretch goal.

column5: Not all its cracked up to be
column12: It was good pay and benefits. Getting to know some of your coworkers was great and i truly developed from lifetime friends.
column13: Well, where to start. First, the management sucked. No one was on the same page and so many different things were told differently depending on who you were talking to. Second, The perks of being a GE employee got worse and worse every year. Third, one minute the company was thriving and the next minute we were getting laid off. There was never an honest story told to employees by any management staff. We never knew if we were going to be working for a long period or periodically laid off, which happened quite a bit. One day I was making $22 an hour and then told that i got bumped down to entry level, making $16 an hour with no big heads up on the change. And now to learn that the company is up for sell. The communication is awful and the little people don't matter at all.
column14: Care more about your employees than you do currently.

column12: Plenty of opportunity. Good project selection. Lots of freedom to explore and present ideas for growth. The management team is awesome and the company has plenty of room for advancement.
column13: I don't k ow if it's necessarily a bad thong, but GE really pressures its employees to stick around. Once they invest in you they want you to be there to invest your knowledge in the company.
column14: Continue to do what you do. Continue to congratulate employees on promotions and jobs well done. Continue to place employees in positions for immediate growth.

column5: Tons of options in a great company
column12:
- Healthcare benefits are good (but they used to be a bit less expensive)
- Pay is fair
- Amazing opportunities to move from one company within GE to another while retaining your years of service and benefits
column13:
- LARGE organization that is a bit slow to change at times
- some of the business units are rather political in how they are run (Supply Chain)
column14: Look for inconsistencies in how the different P&Ls are being run, some have great processes and leadership, some have a lot of room for improvement. Keep innovating!

column5: The two happiest days of my (professional) life, the day GE hired me and the day I resigned.
column12:
- Compensation & benefits were decent
- About 1/3 of the people you work with are truly pleasant to work with
- The company name caries prestige
column13:
God, where to begin...
- The majority of leadership I encountered were incredibly demanding of their subordinates, but rarely held themselves accountable for anything
- Be prepared to spend a sizable amount of time per day on CYA activities; seriously this will become your new part time job
- Get used to senior leadership having 'favorites' and God help you if you're not one of them
- Do you like a 40 hour work week? Double it.
- Don't care for profanity in meetings? No one cares, get used to it.
- Need support from a leader to resolve an item at work? You'd better hope you've done something for them lately or it's not going to happen.
column14: Haha, as if they'd ever stoop to take feedback from their employees, seriously I laughed a bit to myself at the prospect of giving advice to those people.

column12: Good focus on training and development in early portion of career as a young engineer. Technical development programs are very challenging but worth the time and effort.
column13: Very long product development cycle. For a yong engineer it takes a long time to see multiple design cycles full-circle.
column14: Upper management has been good about extending more progressive vacation benefits to younger employees. (3 weeks after 1 year and 4 weeks after 5 years). In order to keep younger millenials, it will be important to enable transition within the different business and locations.

column12:
GE is a great organization! A company with great reputation and integrity!
The meritocracy here is real and all the leaders take it in consideration for promotions and recognition.
We also have a great portfolio of products that add value to our clients and community!
column13:
High level positions are filled with expats. International career outside the region became a challenge.
The local executives have no empowerment and the position is not so porwefull than in the past (lack of empowerment, poor trainings and limited opportunties).
column14: The company should be more care more with their executives!

column5: Great company for entry-level hires, leadership programs are best in business.
column12: Came in as a college hire into one of the leadership programs. The development you get in the program is top notch. GE is known for its leadership programs and it's a tremendous career accelerator.
column13: Working with a global audience has pros/cons. You might not move as quickly as you would with people from your country, but a great learning experience none the less.
column14: Much outsourcing makes it difficult to communicate/move as fast as we need. Need to hire more in-house talent.

column5: Good and bad, depends on division
column12: Incredibly smart people, most are trying to do the right thing. Leadership training is the best in the world, and there are lots of opportunities.
column13: Finance people get way too much say in business decisions, and the culture of meetings and processes is paralyzing at times. When the business hits a snag, the playbook is to cut costs, rather than try to grow out of the problem. Very short-term focused on the quarter.
column14: Focus on the customer and on long-term growth elements; get finance out of every decision.

column12: I work at GE and it is a great place to work. I have no complaints as of today.
column13: GE will not hire very experienced people in particular areas for very strange reasons. I don't understand why they do this.
column14: Hire domain experts. If you have someone with 15 years experience building and designing rail traffic control systems you should jump at the chance to hire him. But instead, HR will block him because he interviewed previously for another position at GE for a totally different non-domain related position.

column12: Good pay and benefits package. Decent retirement benefits and 401k. Clean work environment air conditioning. Good coworkers.
column13: Very poor management and leadership. Very poor planning to keep the work flow moving through the shop. There is no real supervison of the work force and a lot of the good old boy culture.
column14: Be honest about what is really going on and stop making promises that will never be met. If you are going to have teaming make everyone feel like they are part of the team and the suggestions will be taken seriously.

column12: Good benefits, global company, generally smart people work there, lots of opportunity if you are willing to move and be flexible. Good opportunities for training and personal development. Good recognition of brand and company and adds lots of credibility to your resume.
column13: Work-life balance can be difficult, lots of bureaucracy, type-A personality dominates. Sometimes it can seem as if certain people are "chosen" to be successful and are then coddled and promoted regardless of their performance.
column14: Sometimes too much emphasis is placed on processes and not on results.

column5: good place to learn and grow
column12: Lots of best experts to learn from, best training system in industry, best industrial research center. lots of interesting research projects. Good growth in management, presentation skills, in addition to technical growth.
column13:
heavy work load. 
the location of GRC is not ideal to me, cold and long winter with heavy snow.
column14: My manager was very nice person and gave me the due credit for my contributions. I'd say GRC has professional management. (I did not work for long at GRC to provide good advices)

column5: GE is a great place to work! The freedom and opportunity to drive your own career!
column12: Tremendous freedom to develop career path, Great Technical Expertise, Challenging problems, Great industry, Opportunities, Competitive Salary, Strong Senior Leadership, Awesome Training,
column13: A bit heavy on the beauracracy. Things can take a while to develop. There can be some frustration with the slow pace. A big company can often get in the way of its own progress.
column14: Identify great talent and challenge them with huge problems if you want to change the game!!

column5: 6 years in GE Energy Air Filtration Sourcing Organization
column12: Good compensation relative to other companies, constant training, high expectations. Very much enjoyed co-workers and my cross-functional team.
column13:
Our small business has had 4 different General Managers in my 6 years - I've had 3 different direct managers in the same time. Thus the vision and path to achieve it has changed pretty radicaly multiple times.

Only as our office is closing is there any real interest to deeplu understand what I do and how I do it.
column14: I don't have any advice.

column12: exposure to leadership, training, good pay
column13: big company so there is a lot of bureaucracy, locations could be better
column14: When hiring/interviewing, let prospective candidates know about the work locations that they'll likely work in and where most of the jobs will be off-program. Some assignment leaders are better than others and having a good assignment leader makes all the difference if a rotation ends up being a good one or not. The screening process to make sure assignment leaders are good enough should be more rigorous.

column12: GE Transportation offers a great work environment. The people are friendly and make a great team. They had a good mentorship program which had you reporting to a single engineer to learn and obtain work projects that could easily build up your skills. The life-work balance was excellent..
column13: Some of the tasks could become repetitive and you could get yourself pigeon-holed into only doing a certain type of task if you don't actively seek out new challenges and responsibilities.
column14: Create a better training/indoc process and materials.

column12: Great town. Minutes from the beach and 2 hrs south of Raleigh, NC. Great management and the teams are very helpful.
column13: Seems to be a bit of clique-ish. They have their circle of engineers they know and trust and then there is all the rest trying to get in the "inner circle".
column14: Allow all engineers to learn more about the various aspects involved on their team and not just........."Bill is our best engineer at this so he does it for all the projects."

column12: GE Aerospace -- now no longer part of GE -- was technologically at the cutting edge of what we did. Management focus, tracking progress, and support of their employees was very good.
column13: GE Aerospace would cut our budget requests by 5 to 15 percent but still require the same output. Therefore we routinely requested more funds than might be needed to compensate for the expected shortfall in funding. It was a stupid game, but we were good -- out of necessity -- at playing it.

column12: This company spends many resources developing their talent. This creates a rich pool from which to promote and advance careers.
column13:
There are too many instances of roles being filled with Good Old Boys. Nepotism is too obvious for such a large, progressive corporation. Recently, roles have been combined instead of being filled with new candidates.

The pending merger with Electrolux has only made these shortfalls that much more obvious.
column14: Appliance Park used to have a bad reputation from field sales managers for having a "bubble." Decisions that affect the sales team in the field were made in a vaccuum by managers at headquarters. Since the pending sale to Electrolux disrupted the organization, the Louisville Bubble has become more of an "Iron Curtain," and the field sales team feels closer to the end of the whip, waiting for it to crack, now more than ever.

column12: great way to gain experience and plenty of room for advancement whether in my field or in another part of the company
column13: Long hours and the environment can be cutthroat. It would be better to have more opportunity to learn instead of having to feel anxious about my job and if I'll be able to succeed over my coworkers
column14: management should focus more on training and promoting more of a team approach while tapping into us newbies' ideas instead of making all of us fit into the generic GE box

column5: So far very satisfied- learned a lot and have grown
column12: Many opportunities to contribute and grow your career. Hard work is recognized. Flexible work schedule can be arranged. No hard limit on vacation days as long as you complete your responsibilities
column13: Too many reviews and pressure to save cost; going back to old culture when we're not fast and nimble. Management tends to promote Engineers who are hired in the Edison track versus who aren't
column14: Try to simply work process for engineers who work for you

column12: Very friendly coworkers, worked at your own pace with minimal interruptions a lot of employees brought head phone sets and listened to music while they worked, casual dress and great pay. Always had luncheons, pizza parties, and employee events. They give their employees optional Fridays off during summertime so they can be home with their kids but of course take their work home.
column13: Employees seemed to be overworked a lot of them would take their work home with them.
column14: I recommend hiring more employees to minimize the workload.

column12: The people, the benefits and the culture at GE is great. GE has been doing a great job to drive a successful business while becoming a company that truly cares about their employees.
column13: While there is always a need to evaluate workforce to ensure operational effectiveness, efficiency, and cost savings, it occurs more often than preferred. 2 - 3 times a year on a year over year basis. It is only fair to state that this is just not GE specific, this is happening across the entire healthcare/medical device industry.

column12:
The people and environment is great! Everyone is busy, yet they are still happy to stop and help you! Additionally, as an intern you are not just given busy-work projects. I worked in the manufacturing plant, and the projects I were given had a big impact on the company. 

I value my time I had with GE!
column13: I worked approximately 10 - 13 hours per day. It wasn't mandatory to work over-time, but my projects required me to stay in the plant longer than 8 hours.

column12: Flexibility (work from home, part time), good experience, talented people.
column13: GE is going through some major cost cutting right now.
column14: Please be honest with employees--in cost cutting mode, let employees know that it's because the business is down, not because reducing pay is actually good for the employees. Also, it would be helpful to share how executive level is also feeling the cost cutting; it just feels like employees are being laid off or not getting salary increases, just so executive levels can maintain their bonuses.

column5: GE's a good starter for a career moving forward
column12: Huge company gives lots of opportunity to try many different areas. If you work in a certain area for a while, you can try a completely different type of work within the same company, same pension, etc. By staying within the same company you can keep your seniority while trying to advance your career in different ways.
column13: Since it's such a large company, you can find yourself in lots of bureaucracy.
column14: Make sure to paint clear visions and not leave things open ended

column5: GE Energy, tough reliable job that pushes your limits.
column12: Stability -- harder you work, the more you take upon yourself, the more you're rewarded. Pension.
column13: It's a big company. If you're looking for a smaller feel, this is not the place for you. You have to prove yourself everyday or you'll be swallowed by the beast.
column14: Mentoring your people to grow your team will ultimately help the company and will make you look better. Help your people grow as priority number one.

column12: GE is not afraid to stack on the responsibility, the amount of experience from this internship is pretty serious. I've learned a lot about being a professional.
column13: Material can sometimes be a bit dull, but the great thing about IMLP is you can start somewhere fresh in 6 months. Also it's a little tough to move from business to business.
column14: Leadership should make it a bit easier to move around. I'd like to see some more international experiences offered for those of us who want it.

column12: Friendly supervisors, weekends off ,decent starting salary,many raises,huge opportunitites to advance yourself within the company,and a work schedule that fits everyones needs.
column13: Not the best benefits package available,some jobs are very dirty and noisy,The on the job training could be more clear. You are shown what to do but a lot of the times why you have to do it a certain way.
column14: I think when being trained we should be shown why we do what we do along with how we should do it.

column12: The engineering management team was amazing to work with. Some of the most intelligent and competent people I've ever worked with.
column13: The purchasing and accounting systems made it almost impossible to get vendors into the system and pay them once they were in. All of the vendor support was in India and they would always refer me to the same website which was never able to help. I couldn't get the lab equipment I needed because I couldn't pay the vendors.

column5: GE is a great company to work for especially starting out as an intern or co-op. I'm glad I have the opportunity
column12: Team based environment, opportunity for advancement, opportunity to grow and develop professionally, Celebration of Diversity and culture, great pay for interns and co-ops
column13: Atmosphere can be too laid back and boring, over hear about people getting laid off often
column14: There should be at least one day out the week dedicated to all work no meetings, and another and certain hour dedicated to team members focusing on a new innovation

column12: The company is very good at allowing work-life balance, and offers great training courses. The pay is equivalent to the averages.
column13: Very complex company politics that usually hinder performance. The company politics usually cause information to be slowed and sometimes not transferred as it should be. This can be very stressful for everyone with tight deadlines that have metrics tied to your performance. This is a large company so that disconnect can be expected, but it seems to be so large that it may never be corrected.
column14: Clean out the systems to have one uniform communication. Allow the employees/managers to set the metrics that best show their performance. Have dedicated facilities for high priority tasks that only the EB has access to. Realize that the cookie cutter roll-outs which the employees, IT, and interfacing parties are going to follow is not always better than what was done before.

column5: GE Global Operations is the new GE
column12: Taking a giant company that has been around for years to the next level. Evolving company culture to attract millennials and empowering intelligent employees. If you have good ideas, they will be heard! Relaxed dress code (jeans Mon-Fri) and upper management and executives are easily accessible and encouraging.
column13: Acquisitions can make things messy when not consolidated. I can't really think of any con so far from my experience.
column14: Keep empowering your employees and providing good leaders to share knowledge.

column12: Great people; great projects...stimulating work environment. There's never a dull day. High-impact projects that you can really get behind.
column13: Priorities often shift too quickly -- hard to stay focused. Also, typical large company issues (bureaucratic, sometimes slow to change -- though improving). Some managers manage only "up" instead of training, empowering their teams.
column14: Same as cons: Priorities often shift too quickly -- hard to stay focused. Also, typical large company issues (bureaucratic, sometimes slow to change -- though improving). Some managers manage only "up" instead of training, empowering their teams.

column12: Metrics-driven so performance evaluations feel fairer than other places. There is an ability to move roles every couple of years. In general, smart people.
column13: It is a huge company so it can feel bureaucratic at times. Unless you are at the very top, salaries are lower than equivalent jobs in the marketplace.
column14: The company will have to continue to evolve - the current positioning of GE as a digital company is a smart one. Hopefully, you can attract top talent with the new focus.

column12: Challenging projects, high level of responsibility and good salary. Benefits are fair, but pension no longer offered. Strong management training program.
column13: Business objectives are not clear as company transitions in a digital direction. Management structure was bulky, but is flatting and maybe becoming less transparent. Shifting corporate priorities resulting in force reductions.
column14: Be honest and communicate to work force about shifting priorities and market forces. Retaining good people was always important, but recent actions are suggesting otherwise. Allow high performers to reinvent themselves.

column12: GE is so big that one can do anything once they have joined. It is easy to start in one field and end up in a totally different field.
column13: Co-workers will treat you like competition. Management preaches teamwork but creates an environment in which co-workers have no incentives to work together.
column14: Company has not grown in almost 20 years. Stock has been flat for over 16 years. Management has been selling asset: GE Capital, GE water, GE Plastics, GE Insdustrial Solutions etc. Company cannot grow through asset sale

column12:
GE looks impressive on your resume to some people.
Nice building.
They teach you how to give a good pitch!!!
column13:
The whole experience of being a GE employee is a downside. GE is constantly hiring and firing people. They staff up for projects and then when the project is complete lay people off. GE has layoffs down to a science which is something they pride themselves on. Your coworkers are constantly joking nervously about the layoffs. Coworkers are not friends, they are your competitors and they will screw you if they can because it is the difference between staying employed and getting let go. GE expects that you put in a ton of hours all the time, so much for work life balance. Between worrying about getting let go and putting in a ton of hours most GE employees hate the world.

Stay away from this place at all costs. Quite frankly your better off unemployed than working here.
column14: Resign. Try treating your employees like human beings.

column5: Great place to learn, tough place to innovate
column12: Lot's of different opportunities, easy to move around to take on different challenges. Lot's of opportunities for training.
column13: To much momentum, hard to make changes or process improve. To many people are satisfied or comfortable in their position - don't rock the boat attitude exists from the top down in many places. To much overhead / wasted effort
column14: To many people working in a box, engineers are taking on assembly line tasks - people are forgetting why they do something.

column5: HR will make or break you
column12: Good company with plenty of opportunity for advancement and movement. Benefits plans have decreased dramatically in recent years, which is a big negative. If you are already with the company a number of years you feel stuck to see it through to retirement, but if you don't have many years in or were hired in after the big changes to benefits and pension then it's a good company to have on your resume and move on.
column13:
HR is very powerful within GE. You need to be very careful not to make an enemy of someone in HR because they can make life miserable for you.
No real training opportunities and management is unable to hold people accountable especially in the union environments.
column14: HR and Legal need to get a back bone and start holding people accountable, especially in the union environments.

column5: Never run out of new challenges
column12: Lots of opportunities for growth, competitive salary & benefits, challenging work. Comprehensive training program. You can go anywhere in the world with GE if you are willing to put in the hours and be flexible about moving. Lots of different businesses to get involved in so you really never have an excuse to stop learning and growing.
column13: Very long hours, lots of bureaucracy. Sometimes the simplest things are the most difficult to get done due to all the layers in the company.

column12: My co-workers and managers are great. There are interesting project assignments. The culture usually focuses more on finding a solution rather than finding someone to blame when something goes wrong.
column13: Since it is a large company, bureaucracy can come into play. Competing metrics can sometimes be frustrating as well.
column14: Continue to be supportive of your employees as they navigate the transition to Electrolux and be honest about the process. Make sure it is easy for your team members to know what their priorities are.

column12: You get a lot of relevant experience and exposed to a large corporate company. They have really amazing things going on and the really make you part of the team. Your work is taken seriously and some projects you may have may even be implemented. You also get to meet all the senior leaders. I even had a project that I worked on with one of the executive Vice Presidents.
column13: The offices are quiet. The cubicles are high up so you really can't see anyone else. Some people are outgoing but mainly keep to themselves for the most part. Don't ask to switch to another location because they probably won't give you another offer.
column14: you need to be more flexible with location and job preferences. Your employees will hate you if they don't like what they are doing it where they are and don't have a choice in the matter.

column12:
- Pay (they pay interns very well with overtime extra pay as well)
- Location services (gym, cafeteria, bus from building to parking lot)
column13:
- Sometimes you feel left out there with no real resources
- They say they will work around your part-time schedule but still expect you to put in full-time level of work
column14:
Work closely with the lower level employees because they are the backbone to the team and the their value to the team is just as much as anyone else. 
Treat all races equally

column12: Great company to work for. So many career opportunities for individuals looking to excel. Safety is very important @ GE and they do a great job in following procedures to keep all of us safe. GE site in Minnetonka continues to expand and grow. Everyone's friendly and supportive. Good Pay.
column13: So far so good, it has been 4 months for me and all I see is opportunity.
column14: Continue to Reward, promote and pay those who perform well so that way you will attract the best people.

column12: There is a lot of flexibility and opportunities to move around within the company and you are encouraged to work yourself out of your current role.
column13: It takes a while to adjust to the culture and make sure attempts to be helpful aren't viewed as "too negative" or "too aggressive".
column14:
Listen to your technical experts and focus on being their manager.

While you may think that trying to provide technical direction in a space you are just learning is helpful, it is really only getting in the way.

column12: It was a great company to work for. Excellent pay and vacation. The overall compensation package is great, they even offer stock options as well
column13: The work load can be a bit of a overload. However it is something manageable. Also there can be travel and relocation involved if you want to love up.
column14: There is limited opportunity if you are not interested in moving around. The cultures fosters a environment that in order to move up you have to be open to relocation at one point on your career.

column5: It’s ok so far but I’ve seen better...
column12: Great pay, benefits, & retirement package. The hours are good as well & you be off on weekends 95% of the time
column13: Poor management, takes forever to get hired on permanent & they put whites b4 blacks on the totem pole. I’ve seen a few guys come in & get trained then pass up the person who trained them...
column14: Change some things up & understand people have families to care for. Working a year with I benefits is hard...

column12: you can work in any of their business you like and people from one business can go to other very easily. GE gives flexibilty in terms or working hours and can pretty much get a job anywhere in the world
column13: i dont see any problesm perse but I believe if you compensation is biggest factor than they are not leaders in that area
column14: they ahve great job in maanging the company in tough times. but I think i dont I understand how they decide about selling businesses

column5: It’s a great company, but you have to be a GE type of guy !!
column12:
-Company has technically competitive advantage over competitors
-GE in your resume is very good
-Except for cost, Customers are generally satisfied with the services received
-Unlimited access to training Technical or Commercial
-Lot of Opportunities for growing (although up to some level)
-Benefits package is very competitive
-Sr level Managers are ok.
column13:
-As any other metric oriented company, there are a lot of work to do to have it met and correctly measure
-Salaries are bit short from when they should

column12:
- Opportunities are everywhere, but they are what you make of them.
- Majority of people are great to work with and are generally very bright and willing to lend a hand.
- Advancement of technology and information sharing is paramount to driving innovation and future growth.
column13:
- Large corporation with complex organizational structure and lots of bureaucracy.
- Government oversight due to the nature of the business reduces speed of developing new technologies and slows new product introduction to the market.

column12: ability to have 4 jobs in 2 years, gain domain expertise, grow your network, work on projects that are very significant to the business (sometimes with $MM in impact). Six Sigma Green Belt Certification, 100% paid tuition to either Georgia Tech, NC State, or UCONN technical engineering masters degree.
column13: You must be committed and have a strong passion for engineering. Buisiness taught Graduate School courses are challenging and have large time commitments. Many deliverables are required outside the typical 40 hr work week.

column5: Excellent environment, if you like what you're doing.
column12:
The sense of being a part of something special was pervasive throughout the company, which you don't really see at many other places. 
Most managers treat their employees like adults, and are flexible.
Benefits are outstanding.
column13: Once you're in a technical role, getting in to leadership is almost impossible. GE likes to scoop up college grads and run them through a 2-year rotation that spits out management. Alternatively, it's possible (though difficult) to get hired in as a manager.

column12: Inspiring company to work for. Tremendous opportunities for career growth. The company will always try to do the right thing for the customer and for the employee. Integrity and honesty is at the forefront. I am empowered to make changes and simplify my job.
column13: We work very hard-if you want a 9-5 you will not find it here. For someone that likes a challenge you will love it.
column14: Keep focusing on eliminating bureaucracy and empowering your employees to take risks.

column5: N Way in Hell I will Ever Work for GE Again
column12: Interesting work and I liked the people.
column13:
I know it is not fair to judge a company the size of GE by the small part I saw. However, I will never work for GE again.

I was in their complex in Louisville, KY. My office was next to an assembly line. The noise was horrific. The place was also filthy dirty. We all had respiratory issues due to the conditions. Was also told by maintenance that only about 40% of the building's ventilation system was working.

I went up stairs to escape these conditions only to find the dust was just as bad plus the carpets were dirty., moldy, and infested with vermin. At least it was quiet.

I left after 11 months because I could not do my job in that environment
column14: Spend some money improving working conditions. You could save some on attempting to cool the place by painting the roofs white. At least it wouldn't be so bloody hot in the summer

column12: Wonderful career with this company for thirty years. Have educated three children through their benefit package. excellent wags and benefits.
column13: Not enough overtime. I am an overtime hog. Otherwise I cannot think of anything negative to say about general electric company
column14: I am a humble worker and have no advice for managemenf other than get rid of the LEAN program . It frustrates workers and costs the company valuable time and money.

column12: Was a fantastic way to get paid to travel the world, learn about business, and do it with some of the most talented leaders out there.
column13: The company is very demeaning, it can be very inwardly focused, and obsessed with doing things their own way. Sometimes can lose sight on how importance cash & customers are to business, as it's so large.
column14: Don't be afraid to change, don't be afraid to break the corporate mold and do things outside the box. Their is life after GE.

column5: GE is excellent at developing their employees
column12: Career development. Their leadership programs are key to providing a very strong network and a skill set that will serve you the rest of your career.
column13: If you're unable to network you may feel stuck in what you are doing. If you are remote your results will be the your only chance to develop relationships to help advance your career.
column14: Continue to keep an open line of communication as it has continues to build trust

column12: Opportunities world wide, sky is the limit if you reach for it. Compensation and time off is very good, insurance is not. Also no bonuses for lead professionals.
column13: Insurance is basically catastrophic only
column14: Pay attention to everyone's input, not just ladder climbers...some of us have no desire to be executives, but that doesn't mean our contributions aren't valuable. We're the ones who do the real work. Great ideas are just that...it's the people who execute them that really make the difference.

column12:
-very intelligent and hardworking people to work around
-latest and greatest technology and equipment
-genuine concern for their customer
-great starting pay
column13:
-work-life balance non existent. expected to be on call 24 hours a day. attempt to make you feel guilty for taking vacation. 
-record sales but crappy raises, 
-preferential treatment for employees who are 'GE leadership program' graduates regardless of performance. very clear favorites...
-extremely toxic leadership.
-no room for growth
-compounding responsibilities without corresponding pay. 
-expensive health insurance. 
-inexperienced senior leaders who punish employees for constructive criticism for their terrible, made for TV ideas.
column14:
You have a plant that has record performance, those employees deserve record raises. a 1.5% plus raise is insulting and one of the most demotivating things you can do.
Your employees deserve time off, all of them. check on the offices/ departments that are very seldom on vacation. chances are, it isn't by choice
Stop promoting the same executives from Erie. it looks as if jobs are being made up for those guys. some are not qualified to be in charge of paper bags let alone employees and their well being.

column5: Excellent professional development and leadership training
column12: i have worked at GE for 6 years in GE Power. I really appreciate the managers that I have had and the opportunities I have been given. I especially love the formalized training programs and leadership programs (XLP) that I have taken.
column13: Not very many cons, as with any large company they can be slow moving to remove dead weight employees & are not the highest salaries in the business.
column14: Examine the formal review process needed for any performance issues with current staff.

column12:
- World-class training programs and people development.
- Very smart leadership, great to learn from.
- Strong organization around the business cycle, you know what to expect.
- Work/life balance is good, if you make it a priority.
column13:
- The organization varies drastically from region to region and between business segments.
- Difficult to create synergies at such huge scale.
- Politics can get in the way of the right people and right decisions.
column14: Don’t keep shedding businesses, focus less on the shareholders and more on the development of the company.

column5: The most important quarter is the quarter you are in....
column12: Name recognition. The brand name carries quite a bit of weight when approaching customers. This helps in high dollar and high profile competetive offerings... nobody ever got fired for buying GE. Not a bad place to be in a tough economic environment. It is also a pretty good resume builder... Fortune continues to rank it tops in management development and best managers.
column13: "What have you done for me lately" culture. Nobody celebrates the successes and everybody points out the faults. In addition, this culture is a very cover your butt mentality. Meaning, corporate climbers are everywhere looking to throw someone else under the bus to cover their own.
column14: Success takes your strategic direction, but do not overlook the hard work that goes on in the trenches to get that direction traveled.

column5: Decent place to work, but can be boring
column12: Working for GE allows to a lot of opportunities to move around, especially for interns. There are a number of programs available that allow for quick advancement and rotational positions. GE is a big company, but my location was pretty felt small and sedated. Being a intern I don't really know what kind of benefits full time employees get, but I get the impression that GE benefits are pretty decent. I liked my coworkers.
column13: Unfortunately, as an intern I didn't get much interesting work to do. I didn't get much real useful experience. Employee services like Payroll and IT are centralized and/or outsourced, and are thus a nightmare to work with. It took a week or two just to get setup to use a computer, and a few more just to get a paycheck.
column14: I didn't really have interactions with senior management.

column5: A great place to work and advance in your career
column12: GE's knowledge base is very vast you can get support from all segments of the business when ever there is a need. GE is investing lot of money into R&D, specially in energy sector. If you want to be in Energy filed then GE is one of the prefferred companies.
column13:
New acqusitions and differences in culture.
Because of the new acquistions, employees talk bad about GE because of the culture differences.
Lot of buarocracy as you move up the ladder..

column5: If you are a person who has no family or personal life or who doesn't care about it, this is the company for you.
column12: Compensation is comparable, BUT you work endlessly. Good place to learn, then get out of there after 2 to 4 years. It's kinda of like making a deal with the GhostRider mentality, damned if you do and damned if don't.
column13: Learn to play the HIGH Performance game early ON in your career here or else you'll find yourself under the bus everyday.
column14: Learn to LISTEN to logic and not what you think you know. Understand the value of thinking outside of the box instead of saying it to your employees and owning the implementation of the concept. Since you admire your CEO so much, review his management style and then look at your own. See how that aligns & works for you and your department.

column5: OK if you come in straight out of college
column12: Great Vacation and Sick day benefits. Good systems and tools. Supports diverse employees as long as you dress and act like everyone else.
column13: GE is risk averse and conservative in spending. Great place to be if you come in through one of the many college hire programs. Those are the people that get promoted. If you join later, career growth can be a real challenge or nonexistent. People with 10 to 15 years of experience are considered interchangable. Employees are not important unless they are senior level or higher. To move up you have to change jobs and cities every 2 years.
column14: No advice since no one will care unless you are really high up in the company. Until GE stops believing that they have all the answers and that those answers are the BEST, they will continue their downward slide.

column5: Huge company, good stability, slow to change
column12: I feel I have good job security. Most of the people I work with are really good at what they do.
column13: The company is really large and it is slow to adapt to external changes. The method of adaptation seems to be through acquisitions and divestments...not true internal change.
column14: Be honest with employees and not try to spin every company decision in a positive way. We appreciate being told the truth.

column12:
Smart people...
Good reputation...
Interesting businesses...diversity of experiences available
column13: Corporate is all about the next shiny object...the next initiative...the next program to make employees crazy. There is little awareness among the corporate types about how things really work at the businesses. It starts with Jeff Immelt who is incredibly out of touch with the "real" world in which the GE businesses and employees operate. The amount of bureaucracy and churn caused by him and his leadership is ridiculous.
column14: Get a new CEO/leadership that leaves the businesses alone and lets them operate without the corporate bureaucracy and focus on the initiative of the day. Under Immelt's leadership the stock has languished. Any other corporate board would have moved him out already. It's frustrating as an employee to experience that while being "jerked around" wasting time and money that could help us do better/increase the value of the company.

column12: GE is a great employer and they have great benefits. GE is on the cutting edge of the latest technology and they provide the IT professional with the opportunity to use the latest tools to support their complex environment.
column13: Some GE businesses are failing and GE has to cut cost. From day to day, you are not sure if your team will be eliminated or laid off. When you work in a technical discipline at GE you can get stuck in that area. This is a great place for experts; however, new technologist that may want to branch out to different areas have a more difficult time. Lots of free internal training is available.
column14: During layoffs make a focused effort to retain your strong talent. Recognize the need to have leaders that will coach and develop the new IT talent.

column12: Multi-Industrial, global organization. Global research and development network. 125+ year old institution that has worked through troubled times before. Because of its diversity, GE has positions for many different backgrounds and skills in its varied business components.
column13: Cost cutting, reorganization, bad bets and circumspect accounting practices all indicate a downward trend for GE, The stock is down 45%+ while the market has been up the last two years. The company needs to pick a direction that works and treat its employees more like the valued talent they need to retain then disposable commodities with a 3-5 year expiration. Environment may work for the younger generation but there won't be much older talent left within the next few years.
column14: Cost cutting is fine but you've cut beyond the bone and need to take a second look at how the company is restructuring, especially from a talent perspective. Culture and values are held in great esteem, which they should be, but the only folks benefiting at GE are the senior management.

column5: Safe and secure, definitely not high tech, and poor facilities.
column12: Benefits: work from home, flex hours, benefits. Career opportunities are there, but will have to work hard for several years to be realized. Communication between management and you is OK, but only quarterly. Leadership is good, but takes forever to get anything done.
column13: Working in a cubicle in a trailer. Boring work. No investment in future products/tech. 8 year old computer software. "Only software and systems we have are broken ones." Was sold as more high tech than actually is. Communication between peers is lacking, then you get the not particularly intelligent "loud mouth" that has the managers ear. Morale is pretty poor since sub-business is losing money and work conditions are poor (cubes in trailers).
column14: Investment in future products/tech. Update and reduce procedural requirements. Acquire good facilities for employees. Be honest when hiring new employees.

column5: Good place to learn business fundamentals for Engineers
column12: GE Energy is a good place to learn fundamentals of how a business is run from the top down
column13: It is very slow to adjust to market conditions. Aquisitions are a commonplace to compensate for not being able to develop new technologies quickly. This isn't necessarily a bad thing for the business, but as an Engineer you need to understand tha most Engineers do sustaining type work rather than New Product Development.
column14: Prioritize better

column5: Performance-driven culture with great career opportunities and really smart people.
column12: Integrity matters...performance-driven culture...opportunities for advancement...exposure to senior leaders...strong benefits package...listening and learning culture...solid performance review processes...basically if you perform at this company you can go far...socially responsible employees and supportive Company...strong internal and external support of Green and Health initiatives
column13: Can be too bureaucratic...not always a "make the market" company, but a fast follower...fairly conservative, which actually has served them well in the recession...
column14: Keep innovating on the industrial side - the future is in global infrastructure

column5: Good Campus to Start in GE, but.......
column12:
- Good if you just graduated from College
- Training opportunities
- Diversity awareness
- Small headquarters. Therefore, high probability of upper managment exposure
- Most of the managers understand the concept of Work–life balance
- Healthy Leaving awarness and program
- Erie is safe, cheap and friendly
column13:
- A lot of people get good jobs because they are good seller of themselves, not exactly good performances (Networking)
- Few good Human Resources Managers
- IT support is almost null
- Poor Health Insurance
- In most of the cases, Company prefers to lose people than let them go with another GE Business (easier to move if are in an upper management level position)
column14: Changes are good, but first you need to fix old processes before to start a new one. Need to analyze better the side effect/long term impact of big projects that look good in numbers ($).

column5: Decent entry-level sales support position, but low pay and high health insurance costs
column12: GE Lighting seems to be a stable place to work. Many of my coworkers have been here 15 years or more. Managers are very open minded and do not micromanage. Each DSS employee is given a few dozen accounts to manage in a particular region of the country- all lighting distributors, business-to-business sales support - so job is very professional.
column13: Opportunities for advancement at GE Lighting are few and far between - only 5 managers and one field sales rep in the Richmond region. Pay tops out in the $30-$35 K range for this position and is flat salary, no commission. Only high-deductible health plans are offered (premiums are free, but a $3200 yearly deductible for me and my spouse).
column14: Offer some more incentives for merit-based pay. I can't support a family on my salary.

column5: There are good and bad elements to working for GE. It really depends on the leadership of the specific GE company
column12: Innovation, and the sr. corporate leadership group is second to none. Learned a bunch from the Marketing and Research Group - again, from the Corporate group in Fairfield, not my specific GE company.
column13: Benefits went downhill a few years ago. Too many long-time GE leaders, insider politics rule, so if you're on the outside, salaries are not competitive. Advancement of women and minorities is a joke in some GE companies, others not so bad.
column14: Be aware of the insider mentality - it's getting worse. Base rewards and advancement on results and not popularity. Middle managers are aware of the pay inequities, and you are losing great people because of it. Would recommend GE Corporate, Healthcare, Energy and Aviation, but not the others.

column5: Little consideration of the employee that has the knowledge of what's going on.
column12: local, decent pay, people are ok
column13: I have worked for GE in 4 different states, and their M.O. is always the same...they take into consideration "newbies" straight out of college with no experience, long before they give consideration to the employees that have made them a business in the past. Likewise, when times get a little tough on their books, they, without advance notice, chop the obvious....the higher-paid contractors, who are, most likely, the ones that made their product work to begin with.
column14: Look at the people (regardless of direct-hire or contractor) that contributes the most to your program, before you simply cut back on the higher-paid people. Getting rid of people who know what's going on, and substituting a cheaper south-of-the-border employee is NOT the answer to making money.

column12: Very good company, everyone was really nice and did good work. I learned a lot while I was there. I also had a lot of fun.
column13: There isn't really anything wrong with the company. It's a very good company. Sometimes I had too much fun. But that's not really a fair complaint I suppose.
column14: I don't have any advice for management they did a really good job at everything they did I could see they were working really hard all the time and I respect that

column5: Great Team Culture - Easy to get Lost in the Machine
column12: My manager did an *excellent* job of cultivating a fun and engaging team culture with outings and team events. As a result I really loved working with my team, more so than any other job I've ever had.
column13: GE is a big company and suffers from the common big company problems. It's easy to get lost in the company and feel like you're not contributing or not making a difference, or be subjected to endless indecisive meetings.

column12: Great place to start out if you don't know what you want to do in Finance and you want to gain different experiences in a short two year stint.
column13: Company is currently going through a shift and the exit opportunities sometimes aren't as comparable to IB, Consulting, Corporate Strategy, or when applying to business school.
column14: Keep the 2 year structure, but offer more roles for industrial FMP program participants to gain exposure to strategy, and BD as well as the core finance functions within the business.

column5: Great place to work, be ready to navigate the political landscape
column12: You can expect good pay with GE. There was a laid back atmosphere in my location, but I'm sure that varies with location.
column13: With a big company, you're probably going to get some politics. Ok, a lot of politics. It's annoying. my position, I found some people were open to change, while others were overly skeptical.
column14: Take a step back and look at the big picture. There is more than one way to skin a cat.

column5: Good Company, but slowly getting worse
column12: A huge company that can get exposure to just about any industry that you want. Excellent leadership opportunities.
column13: Currently stagnating, high up leadership has made some huge multi-billion dollar mistakes that the entire company is currently paying for. Benefits suck and have slowly been getting worse every year.
column14: Get back to doing what GE did best in the 70s. Innovate. Stop spending billions of dollars on other companies just to sell off their sites and abandon their technology.

column12: GE has some of the best and brightest people to work with. The work-life balance has really improved in recent years.
column13: Wall Street perception is so important to leadership that it appears all-consuming at times. The corporate bureaucracy and layer upon layer of reviews is not efficient.
column14: Focus on your customers and employees. When you delight those two groups, the rest will come. Continue to communicate the role GE plays in the world.

column5: Internship- Great learning experience and an eye-opener into GE culture.
column12: I feel that there is no glass ceiling in GE and it has a reasonable meritocracy, since there are so many higher-level positions available. Also, the benefits are pretty good. An internship at GE is a great way to learn and I am given adequate responsibilities
column13: "Doing more with less" seems to be the mantra at GE- I frequently see salaried workers at their desks 60-70 hours a week, while the hourly workers have paid lunch. Also, the environment is very competitive. My ideas are frequently shot down when I'm heading my own projects, but then my manager gives his own opinion for the project and thus, the new way of the project is decided.
column14: Put less pressure on cutting costs and doing more with less, because at a point it starts to wear thin on the employees.

column5: Still a behemoth, opportunities for success highly depends on business unit.
column12: General Electric has great name recognition, and is a very well respected company. Their management training programs are well known and can be a great start to your career.
column13: As with any large organization, the bureaucracy can be difficult to work through. Management does not move quickly to make decisions. GE is of course going through some interesting times, with businesses being sold off and reorganizations occurring leading to instability within some businesses, but is a sign of the times. Employee morale could be better. Traditionally, GE isn't a great paymaster since they believe it's made up for through the opportunity to work at GE at all.
column14: Treat associates with more respect, and you'll get more back with higher morale and increased dedication.

column12:
Experience, Exposure, Resume builder. The brand is powerful for both customers and prospective employees.
Individual actions have a greater impact with so much resources behind you.
Leadership programs are an excellent means to acquire a good perspective of the company and opportunities within the business. GE spends more on training than another other company i've seen.
column13:
Patience required, as the opportunity ladder takes a while to climb. Insiders are promoted first, so don't expect to come in quickly and change things. 
Locations are not glamorous and usually in a low cost manufacturing area. If you have a family that is bearable and affordable. If your looking for a fun single scene then look elsewhere.
column14: Would pay to be more nuturing towards employees. Often a disconnect in treatment between the highest up and the lowest on the totem pole.

column5: avoid GE energy in Houston site, not good for experienced technical person
column12: GE, the brand which will helps your next job. not bad benefit, especially medical and dental insurance with low premium. good life/work balance with compressed working schedule. good training.
column13: too much political. the management didn't care about employee career development at all. the only thing they care about is their managers. they functions like their manager's shade, follow them everywhere. sad thing about GE Energy for experienced technical professional, if GE is not your first employer, you are probably not inluded in the loop. manager wants junior engineer to lead project which the senior engineer only functions like a consultant. poor vacation weeks, even you are very experienced, your vacation starts from two weeks.
column14: the management needs to be more inclusive. more respect to senior technical guy, let them lead the project, not the young edison engineer.

column5: A Really Alright Place to Work
