column12:
+ General Electric is a well known company
+ Great leadership programs with defined promotion sequences
+ A truly global corporation
column13:
- I found senior management to be lazy and incompetent more times than not
- Finance professionals at GE aren't encouraged to achieve advanced degrees in finance
- Pressure to become a GE "lifer"
column14: Encourage GE Finance professionals to achieve advanced degrees and pay for their education. Finance professionals at GE I found to be too normal for such a large and successful corporation.

column12: In general management is very good. There are a lot of training opportunities within the company for individual contributors. Pay seems ok.
column13: Offshore IT folks are a disaster, GE gets the cheapest offshore folks they can, projects often take 10 times the time they should. Healthcare benifits are really poor for a large company having a baby is very expensive.
column14: Fix the IT software development processes. In my experience this is more a matter of getting the right peopel then new initiaves. Reduce the buerarcracy

column12:
Pay- better than average
Autonomy- allowed to be creative with job
Time- will allow you the time you need to take care of family issues
Training/schools - will pay for a variety of education
column13:
What have you done for me lately mentality
Must move jobs every 2-3 years they don't like for you to be sedintary
Tough glass ceiling - thousands of people for very few upper management positions
Watch your back- very political, keep your friends close and ....
column14: everybody wants your job

column12: GE management is top notch. Good decision makers in the right place. You should be an over achiever in order to work or succeed here.
column13: GE has a great name, because of that a lot of people want to work for them. Therefore, the pay might not be as competitive as needed.
column14: Filter out some of the irrelevant paperwork to the lower lever employees.

column5: Good for your first industry job
column12: Diverse areas of research, academic-like environment, flexibility, freedom for new ideas, lots of learning opportunities, good job security, nice area for living
column13: The hierarchy may be too flat, such that there are less opportunities for promotions.
column14: Create more opportunities for new/young people. Not everybody follow the same career path or at the same pace. Give those who wish to advance chances to shine. You may be surprised (in a good way). Be more open to new ideas, even the far-fetched ones.

column5: GE is full of amazing opportunities, in any field you can imagine.
column12: GE cares about it's employees, has great benefits and help, is full of growth opportunity, and wants to see you succeed.
column13: Because of the nature of the business, some of the job functions can be more difficult than they need to be. Communication isn't always the best, but it depends on what each individual makes it.
column14: Do more for the people at lower levels who do the brunt of the work.

column5: Wide breadth of possible finance experience
column12: GE invests in it's finance employees with programs such as FMP and Corporate Audit Staff. The portofolio of GE businesses across both the Capital and Industrial industries is limitless and a core set of GE finance skills enables long-term employees move among them.
column13: The salary and benefits GE offers do not match the number of hours finance employees typically work. The company is pushing to make work easier by simplifying processes, but in such a large company, nothing is ever simple.
column14: Employees are not given the freedom to make decisions and be held accountable to those decisions. You continually have to go through layers and layers of approvals. If something doesn't pan out, the person on the bottom is held accountable even if leaders have approved their decision but have done nothing to help clear roadblocks.

column12: Dynamic and fast paced work environment. Allow to work on new and important projects within the company. Overall a good learning experience.
column13: Can take time to become familiar with technical terminology and company acronyms. Also takes some time to gain access to folders containing needed documents.
column14: Have system set up to request all database accesses needed by employee by the start date. Wastes time to wait until their first or second week to request access because it doesn't happen all that quickly once requested.

column12:
Very supportive co-workers.
Lots of work, never bored.
Friendly, open co-workers.
Flexible work schedule. Depending on job, can work remote, can change location.
Accommodating and understanding.
column13:
They work and work and work, faster, better, more. If you want to slack, this is not the place for you.
The people are stressed out, always on edge.
Everything is an emergency.
column14: Build reasonable goals and timelines. High pressure work increases costs and limits your ability to leverage strategic plans to improve your business. Constantly "putting out fires" is not strategic and not sustainable.

column5: Terrible place to work if you want to have a life.
column12: The only good thing about this company is the name looks good on a resume. Leaving here is the best thing that can happen to your career. Sorry for the long explanation but I entered "None" for the Pros and received an error because my description was not long enough. Look elsewhere.
column13: Too numerous to list. This was the worst company I have worked for in my life. I had respect for some Sr. managers. With the exception of 1 of my direct managers, the lower management is so concerned about their careers they do nothing to help or build the employees or their direct reports. I gave this place 1 star because it would not allow for 0 stars.
column14: Let the employees have some time for their personal lives. All work and no time for family is a terrible way to run a company and you will continue to lose the best people when they realize how lopsided your "Life / work balance" is offset to work.

column12: great company to work for. they provide great benefits, and do not micro manage employees. company also provides continuous training for employees.
column13: takes some time for employees to climb the ladder. management also needs to give positive feedback to balance the negative. positive definitely outweighs the negative.
column14: give employees positive feedback. constructive criticism goes a long way. Continue to provide the great continuous training you have been providing to on the field employees.

column12: Global organization that offers exposure to a wide range of professional opportunities across many business channels. The company promotes an environment of continuous learning and provides opportunity to grow and to move within the organization.
column13: GE Lighting is currently undergoing a transformation from a lighting company to a concentrated focus on digital energy technologies (Current, powered by GE). With change does come a degree of instability, although it opens doors for professionals with a different skill set to join the business.

column12: For my position it was great working with people who are open to simplifying their current process.
column13: Getting a simplification project complete is extremely challenging in most areas because the people are unwilling to adapt to the new Digital culture GE is pushing too.
column14: Challenge your leaders on why Digital processes are taking so long to implement. You may find out that your leaders are not open to changing their own process in which it makes it very hard to implement new technology.

column12: Generally good work conditions and pay but they will wring it out of you
column13:
Spineless leadership, solely focused on profits and cash flow
Strings attached to every benefit/ reward
Fake advocacy for the trend of the week ... we're pro veteran, we're pro LBGTQ, etc (back to the spineless leadership ... no one stands for anything EXCEPT GE)
Cult like atmosphere at times ... "what have you done for mother GE today"
column14:
Get a back bone. Stand for something. Get some ethics. Stop being a narcissist and look out for your people. 
Being a part of something bigger doesn't mean "do anything to bring profits to GE"
To the good ones - Watch your back... even at the executive band level, people are just another resource that the big GE machine chews up and spits out.

column12:
1. The GE brand
2. Benefits
3. Six Sigma Training
column13:
Horrible work culture at the Grain Valley Campus
1. Every employee only care for themselves. If a new employee ask for assistance or guidance, the more senior employee will not help, citing direct orders from the Manager to do so. When confronted, all the Team Lead or the Manager say is "Shut up and get your job done, else we'll get someone else to do your job". 
2. Back-stabbing is a norm and is accepted by management.
3. No team spirit within the GETS work groups.

Incompetent Management at the Grain Valley Campus
1. Managers will not come down to the field to talk and encourage employees.
2. Favoritism is rampant. It's about how you butter-up to your manager.
3. Team leads will throw any team member 'under-the-bus' just to save their own jobs.
4. Ridiculous expectations. Everything should have been done 'yesterday'.
column14:
1. Get rid of the 'rank-and-stack' culture of evaluating your employee's performance. 
2. Don't hire folks who don't fit in your dog-eat-dof culture. Simple as that.

column12: GE trains their talent to lead teams and deliver results in every circumstance and atmosphere. They have world renown leadersip programs that greatly benefit an employee in GE or as they look elsewhere.
column13: GE does not pay competitively, and they often ask talent to move or travel frequently. They sometimes decide what your next role should be rather than leave it to an employee.
column14: Pay more money to your rising talent; you have invested a lot of money in them.

column5: Practically unlimited career opportunities, fantastic professional development
column12:
Practically unlimited career opportunities - can do just about any type of job, just about anywhere in the world... if you want to.
Great professional development - both from training as well as learning from colleagues.
column13: Working for the wrong person can be devastating to your career. Generally not a problem, but if you are in the wrong department at the wrong time, job cuts or shut downs could end a long, successful career before you know it.
column14: none

column5: Blue chip credentials. Be prepared to work hard.
column12: Amazing coworkers. Drive to deliver excellence. The high bar is always being raised higher. You'll never be bored.
column13: Extremely high work ethic. Long hours required to deliver excellence. Competitive ( but fair) environment to get ahead.
column14: Resource your team a little bit better, so they don't have to work so darn hard to deliver the basics. The worklife balance is what causes turnover here. Generally speaking, a very well-run company to work for.

column5: Nice place to work but could be so much better
column12: Talented people to work with, extra events/challenges to take on and great products. Plenty of opportunities to learn and take on additional responsibilities.
column13: From technology perspective, Product management/Marketing is very weak. Sometimes very difficult to accomplish very simple things. Seems like many of the more senior people are just planning to work here until they can get retirement benefits. Extreme sensitivity to diversity.
column14: Lead. Be decisive and not afraid to fail.

column12: GE is a great place to work. The benefit package is outstanding, though salaries tend to be somewhat lower than industry standard. GE offers an outstanding 401K with matching, tuition reimbursement that is one of the best out there and for non-bargaining employees a generous holiday schedule. Tons of opportunity, but moving between industries can be challenging.
column13: Work / life balance leaves something to be desired. You must set your own balance.
column14: Create defined career path opportunities.

column5: My experience was positive and focused on professional development and management training at an early career level.
column12: professional development and growth opportunities. Integrity is very strong.
column13: Exposure to the big picture is challenging due to diversified portfolio of business, but that makes it also interesting and challenging to push yourself out of your comfort zone.
column14: Leadership programs are positive and create a great pipeline for the business. Finding a way to keep those employees via job placement once trained could be a bigger focus.

column5: It is what you make it
column12: GE will allow you to make your career whatever you'd like for it to be. It is a large company, so location and job scope can really be determined by the individual if you are a high performer.
column13: Networking can be somewhat difficult at a smaller site, but the opportunities are endless. Very metrics driven, which can sometimes influence negative behaviors.
column14: Continue to lead at developing leaders. Empower them to experience multiple businesses rather than remaining tied to one silo.

column12: Good pay. Good company to represent because of brand recognition.
column13: Little direction. Very chaotic internally. Very high management turnover.
column14: Stick to an idea longer than a year. Just as a new idea or business approach was ramping up they would think they needed to change it because they didn't get the results they wanted immediately. They were too impatient. Stop changing territories and product lines so frequently. It confuses not only the rep but the distributors and customers.

column12: Benefits, flexibility, investment in employee growth and leadership training. Very challenging environment. Get to work with very smart people.
column13: Salaries tend to be well below market. Its a huge company with a tough political environment to navigate. Very difficult to get noticed and most often a lot of people slip through the cracks.
column14: Great job on the recent transformation of the organization, not just in terms of the company's strategy, but also on changing the culture to become a nimble, diverse technology company.

column5: GE - Great place to start career
column12: GE is focused on employee growth at its core, make sure every employee gains constant feedback, works towards tangible goals and has a path to get there.
column13: GE is large, so the layering and bureaucracy that come with that can be difficult. There are also numerous leadership programs within the company that dictate employees' trajectories where - had you not completed one of these programs- you're less likely gain executive status.

column12: Pay was not bad at all for a welder in dallas/Fort Worth area. I worked at the fort worth locomotive plant. GE trained well and also provided me with all the welding equipment I could possibly have needed.
column13: I got laid off after orders for locomotives dropped off after 2016.
column14: I would say the discipline was pretty lax. Some people would put in a real days worth and others would just put only half a day and screw around the remaining 4 hours without consequence.

column12: Great people, decent culture. Attempts to keep pulse on culture, and actually attempts to address perceived drawbacks to culture.
column13: Great people, decent culture, until you aren't part of it... I have seen people go with 5, 10, 15 & 20 years of service, with no real justification other than a slowdown. Our health insurance is useless, highest deductables of anyone I know. Career opportunities heavily favor GE "program" graduates. The pool for raises is lower than most companies, regardless of the economy, be cause you are always coming out of or going into a bad year.
column14: Stop having Interns and OMLP's attempt to drive up you glassdoor ratings. The biggest detractor at GE is the rigid, almost computer-like evaluation against goals and objectives; it has driven a culture of yes-men working their own silos while eliminating controllership/stewardship to the business.

column12: Lots of smart people, you can learn a lot and the teams are really close knit. Really enjoyed the people and the industry.
column13: If you come in mid career and don't come up through the GE CAS program for Accounting or Finance people, you will struggle to get any promotions. For Finance and Accounting with GE if you weren't part of the Corporate Audit Staff, then you really didn't matter.
column14: Value peoples experience that come from outside GE.

column12: GE gives you the opportunity to work in different industries without leaving the parent company. Training programs are very good. Benefits seem to be slightly above average. I would say flexibility is high by leveraging electronic tools you can work from anywhere, at any time of the day. Recognition and extra rewards if you are rated high in you annual performance review.
column13: GE has a strong corporate culture- an asset as it drives consistency between businesses- but also can feel rigid with little flexibility for outside thinking. As an employee, the bar is always moving higher and job security is always a question in the back of your mind.
column14: Focus more on the long term. Promote sharing of goals and objectives to promote more teamwork between functions/p&ls/divisions. Focus more on customers and employees and results will follow.

column12: There are a lot of positions for engineers
column13: When a professional leaves GE for opportunities elsewhere it has ramifications for future employment anywhere. Once out, there is no access to the GE Web Site Career Page; no way to resubmit for employment anywhere within GE at any location worldwide. GE will not allow a professional to be submitted for a contract, working for another firm, another W2, if it is contract work for GE. Employment with a firm, not GE, a supplier that provides out sourced labor or product, is not possible, since work related access to GE is not allowed. In regards to working for contract firm or for a GE supplier the web of GE is everywhere; a 'personna non grata' is thus greatly restricted in the job search.
column14: HR practices towards previous employees a bit harsh.

column12: Excellent mid to upper mgmt that care about there employees. I feel very proud to work for this company and to help our customers get the best value for there product.
column13: Sometimes get lost in the company as it is very big and can get very competitive within each of the different levels of employment and careers.
column14: I would ask that they continue to respond to the needs and concerns of the employees that make this company what it is.

column5: Challenges you to be your best
column12: Chance to work on cutting edge technology with the best and brightest people across all levels of the organization. Possibilities are endless.
column13: Health benefits require high out of pocket annually if you suffer from any kind of chronic condition. Available office and conference room space is scarce and cubicles are small and noisy
column14: Embrace use of remote office technologies to ease site congestion. Award productive gains made by work from home colleagues. Trust your employee to meet goals.

column12: Multiple options for career advancement. I literally felt as though I could be anything I wanted to be in the company. They have a great training program and with the abundance of opportunities within the company, you are sure to find positions that fit your wants or tailor a path to your needs.
column13: There are very many smart people that work here and you have to be willing to deal with the egos that come with this.
column14: Keep up the good work.

column5: GE is one of the best places to work
column12: Very good company for long term career development and growth. They invest in employee development and have plenty of job opportunities to challenge you over your career.
column13: salary increases are low unless you change jobs frequently (2-3 years), can be very bureaucratic and has pockets of if it's not invented hear, it has no value.
column14: need to value long term employees more. They have significant work experience that can avoid future issues

column5: Great opportunity - awesome learning experiences and training once reach right level
column12: Peers are almost always great people and a joy to work with. Most managers truly care about their employees.
column13: Upper management keeps much close to the vest hampering the ability for orgs to achieve common goals. Politics and constant org changes exist as would be expected in any large organization but it is manageable.
column14: Trust other organizations and their staff - care about the careers of others besides yourself and direct reports.

column5: An Easy Job With OK Income
column12: The workload is quite light and the culture and colleagues in the East Bay area are quite pleasant. For the amount of work the pay is good.
column13:
Its seems to be a 50/50 shot of having a manager who leads valuable ideas. Some groups are very poorly run with a manager that talks the talk but does not walk the walk. In fact, this talk-the-talk type mentality is greatly encouraged and valued above all else in management.

A caveat is that some groups are run with laser precision and work on leading edge ideas. Its hit or miss. The disappointment comes from having a poorly run team not have any managerial consequences.

The variability of this drives me crazy.
column14: Listen more and talk less, be humble, and take some time to learn the technologies in more depth.

column12: Keen focus on development of employees, fast paced work environment, financial focus to management
column13: Long hours, many layers of management and reporting due to the dual Corporate & Business structure, may require relocation in order to advance
column14: In poor business environments, GE seems very quick to cut any benefits - no raises, low bonuses, no internal travel. While some of this is necessary, the inequalities between P&Ls (even within the same Tier 1) may be very demotivating

column12: Long term stability, respectful company culture, management is open and patient. A lot of very kind people. Work environment is friendly. Introducing a lot of startup type perks (free juices, ping-pong table, choose your own laptop)
column13: If you are an IT person, it's a bit behind in tech (but is earnestly working on catching up). Many projects still use very old tools. You will learn patience here.
column14: Keep T&L budgets high. It's one of GE's best motivators.

column12: Solid company with hard working people. Six sigma is a big part of their corporate culture. Everyone needs to be onboard with the methodology.
column13: They sold GE insurance to Swiss re. They sometimes struggled running an insurance company with their demands for predictable consistent earnings
column14: since selling the insurance segment to Swiss re, this segment has thrived and has delivered considerable value to Swiss re. Other GE businesses continue to grow and develop.

column12: Great training and experience. Clear path to climb if you want to stay with the company. Awesome networking ops and exposure to senior employees. Positions you well for some exit ops.
column13: Do not pay for business school (and there are rumors of managers writing bad letters of recommendation). Want you to stay for life. Pretty long hours/low pay vs other finance gigs. Hard to advance without doing corporate audit staff. Heavily accounting based -- forget banking or anything close to it.
column14: Millennials don't want to feel trapped in once place or that they aren't marketable to the outside world. Provide tuition reimbursement plans with strings attached. Raise the salary if you want to recruit at elite schools. Base pay is below average for what some T50 school's avg Econ/finance majors earn after graduation. Claims of prestige aren't the same as actual dollars.

column12: Great benefits and culture. They invest a lot into their employees. Always have volunteer opportunities and advanced learning seminars.
column13: Not really much. Maybe public speaking. Your expected to be able to present infrom of people from the second you walk in. It's nerve racking at first but you get used to it.
column14: Keep doing what your doing. I felt apart of the team and was always included. The culture there is great and a good reason why you attract the best talent.

column12: Great teamwork. GE management knows how to win in the various industries they operate in. The culture is fantastic, which makes for a successful work environment.
column13: Large company which welcomes bureaucracy. It could be difficult for ambitious and gifted employees to climb the ladder as quickly as they would like to.
column14: Keep setting your teams up for success by making good decisions. Keep striving to make GE a great place to work and a company that we can all be proud of.

column5: Great company to work for. Works is great and working with a diverse team is a pleasure.
column12: Great company. Benefit and POV. Pay is close or above market. Opportunities to move within is possible. Exposure to support a global process and teams are there since it is a huge global company in many businesses.
column13: Not many opportunities left in CT since company HQ moved to Boston and change of direction. Most new jobs are located in there new hubs

column5: Poor benefits, poor performance, poor work life balance
column12: The company has a great reputation for developing leaders
column13: The benefits are very bad, and the work life balance is horrible. The company always seems to have cash flow problems and as a result we've only been getting a raise every few years... can't remember the last time I got a bonus. The focus is always more on saving money than innovating and sales are constantly hurting as a result. Company leaders are promoted to technical positions with a lack of technical knowledge and make bad decisions as a result (its really surprising when that art history major running the IT project gets taken for a ride by a vendor... sarcasm). And if you haven't been in a training program, forget it - you'll never go anywhere in the company.
column14: The company needs a Jack Welch style shakeup.

column12: there is a Constant Challenge to over deliver results. Work load is quite heavy but you need to learn to prioritize. It is more important to deliver excelent results on 5 items than half finished on 15. The exposure to senior level managers is very positive as is the accesibility to them. Corporate traning is among the best especially in the Crotonville training center. And a given but important above all today is that integrity is impecable.
column13: Work life balance is a real challenge. The company will demand more out of you, your job to determine priorities. The resources are tight especially the people. Very lean organization. Work for the 500 lb gorilla ... lots of competition and many people like you. Really have to outperform the rest to stand out.
column14: Personal involvement in rewarding good performance, Think long term .. not just next quarter.

column5: Lead Mechanical Engineer review of GE Greenville, SC
column12: Large multinational company with many opportunities to move. Company has such a dominance inthe marketplace, there is some feeling of security, although that is never truly guaranteed. Company can compete very well when it comes to salary and the ability to pay for a relocation for experienced emplyees.
column13: Very rigid with respect to HR policies and making individual allowances. Company does not like to vary from it playbook of rules. A potential employee gets the feeling that they are worried about conflicts concerning alignment of benefits. The company is highly political. The workload is exceptionally high, and turnover is a serious problem.
column14: For Senior Engineers who transfer with significant experience, an allowance should be considered with respect to vacation weeks. Offer the ability to purchase vacation days.

column5: Not what GE used to be
column12: Job security. Still a good name to have in your resume
column13:
• Little or no training except for a very few selected ones
• Cheap, cheap. Poor performance has put pressure on everything including travel, and training
• Jack Welch’s GE is gone. Layers and layers of bureaucracy have been created with mediocre and unprepared Managers.
• The employee evaluation system is outdated 
• Metrics and useless processes are a waste of time and money and become extremely frustrating for an employee that really wants to get his job done
• High turnover, especially young employees
• Bad healthcare benefits
• Terrible computer/IT resources
• Politics and backstabbing culture
column14: If you really want to fix this, start with upper management and not with useless reorgs. The Managers of this company do not have accountability and go through one reorg after the other trying to kick the can down the road.

column5: Great environment for job development and growth.
column12: Everyday at GE provides you with learning and growth opportunities. You are exposed to so many different aspects of how a large business runs and how all the various teams interact with each other to make the Company successful.
column13: It can be easy to get lost in the complexity of such a large organization. It takes effort to network and to make sure your contributions are recognized and appreciated.
column14: Continue to seek out and nurture internal talent.

column5: Great Company to help grow your career from the beginning.
column12: They'll invest in you if you invest in them. For early-career, I think this is one of the better Company's to work for. They're intern programs can be really good if you're lucky to get on a good team and their leadership programs are unparalleled if you're accepted.
column13: Things are always changing around here with new re-orgs at least twice a year. Sometimes that makes it hard to plan your 3-5 year career goals.

column5: Experience working at GE Energy Financial Services
column12: Smart and nice people, invest across several sectors within Energy, as well as in debt and equity, a lot of in-house functional experts to opine on potential investments, ability to move around the organization and try out different teams, decent hours
column13: bureaucratic, need to vet a lot of potential deals through GE Capital, promotional opportunities slowed down in recent years due to the top-heavyness of the firm, salary less than market rate (but work less hours),

column12: Best corporation to learn the fine art of recruiting from. Numerous best practices which enhanced my career. Given a lot of autonomy to work with hiring manager and influence hiring decisions. Value the recruiting function which in other Fortune 500 corporations is not always the case.
column13: Hiring "hi-potential" leaders is a serious challenge. Everyone needs to be a hi-pot.
column14: Constant fast pace is at times hard to keep up. Need to have fun once in awhile.

column12: Great culture, manager was focused on me having a good internship experience, exploring interest, building skills, etc.
column13: At the time of accepting offer, no idea (other than engineering) what type of daily work I would be doing. Ended up in a role that didn't really match my interest, but was given the flexibility to explore other areas by shadowing, defining my own goals, etc.
column14: More specific job descriptions made available during offer would have been great. Professional development opportunities were good.

column12: Large company with many opportunities. Challenging programs to work on with options to travel small or large amounts of the time.
column13: Large company and easy to get lost in the noise. Large programs can make a work life balance difficult to accomplish.
column14: Acknowledge those who have been working well for the company for quite some time as they have a lot of historical knowledge which when it is lost can cause issues. Also it is less expensive then hiring external.

column12: Fantastic opportunities to learn and grow professionally. Great people and products. Very dynamic learning environment. Fast promotion if you do well in your job.
column13: Demanding work load you need to be 100% devoted to work in order to succeed. Expectation to travel and be flexible in where you live and work. Change jobs quite frequently.
column14: Empowering young leaders and letting them learn by doing. Trust in the future leaders of the organization will continue to help GET build sustainable teams.

column12: Legacy Programs bring continuity to multiple businesses. It is easy to move within businesses. Great educational benefits as well.
column13: Currently, there is a major upheaval and the uncertainty is distracting. It is hard to get employees to concentrate on work while they worry about their future employment.
column14: Restructure only once per year so people can focus on their jobs instead of what keeps them up at night. It's hardly productive.

column12: Love working with Train motors. And making sure we have the safest shop in the Buisness. It’s good to know you are putting the best products you can out the door.
column13: Having to deal with sub standard equipment. And the lack of communication between mgmt and the employees. Only having two maintenance personnel.
column14: I’m prior ARMY and I strive for Loatlty Duty Respect selfless Service Honor Integrity Personal Courage. And if I am hired I will give nothing less than 100%.

column12: Very innovative, Allows work life balance with permissible vacation days, great salaries, multiple businesses and opportunities for growth
column13: Expectations very high on new assignments or roles without proper training with immediate results, some nepotism, a lot of layers, older commuter systems, communication can be lost with layers of management. Very different culture to learn fast.
column14: Provide direct outcomes and objectives for employees, allow proper time to learn the position and provide better training, more open communication.

column12: people..The most valuable asset a company can have, and previous alstom \GE employees are hard working , competent and diligent. Given strong management, budgets and a clean direction. Things will get done
column13: GE management is based and derived on how to save a buck. Anything goes even if the short term decision is going to be long term negative. I have not worked for a company that makes so many poor financial and personnel decisions.
column14: Start making decisions that are in the best interest of the employee's and what will benefit those employee's in the future. Quick hits to make yourself look better only show how detrimental you are too everyone else. There seems to be little to no forecasting and direction setting. There are no budgets to be checked against. Upper management is only worried about how they stay in upper management. Work as a team not in a silo. Just because it was someone elses idea, doesnt mean it was a bad one.

column5: Find ways to succeed and not fail.
column12: GE Consumer and Industrial is a well managed company. Recently effort to disposition appliance business and difficult economic climate has reduced the employee morale and advancement opportunities.
column13: Merit increases are floated out 13 - 18 months and average to slightly above average.
column14: Communicate with all levels and functions in the business. Improve efficiency and reduce base cost, but start trying to find more ways to grow the business to limit the impact employee lives.

column5: EID Internship: Great for career development w/ competitive salaries
column12: The EID co-op program provides great opportunities for career development -- especially if you're interested in applying for GE's leadership programs -- and provides competitive salaries and benefits. If you're willing to take on a large project, GE will be more than happy to give it to you.
column13: EID interns don't technically get paid sick days but most managers will let you take them off anyway or let you make up hours.
column14: None.

column5: Take the opportunity to learn as much as you can when you work for GE, but leave for a career
column12: Some opportunities to work on cutting edge technologies and learn from world class professionals.
column13:
-Low respect from management to their people. Lots of bureaucracy, politics and nonsense

-Terrible performance evaluation system. It's a relationship-to-your-manager evaluation system, not technical performance evaluation system. 

-Engineers and researchers have to fight/stable each other for work. Research lab managers are not doing their jobs to find work/project for their people, but whipping them to find work themselves. If people could not find enough work to cover their time, they get low evaluation and suggest to leave.
column14: Middle level managers, lab managers, should pay more attention to your researchers and engineers, not just your boss. Treat the people who do the hard work for you like human, not slavery labors.

column5: GE Security is a fraction of what it could be
column12: The company has great compensation. Working for GE is currently looked at as being a positive when trying to find a new job.
column13:
Instead of trying to grow most of the aquasitions, GE consistantly focuses on making profit by cutting the bottom line. They constantly look for cheaper ways to build product. While this basic idea is not a bad thing, their presure to do this is extreme. After some time, the quality goes.

Their employees are only numbers to them. Their basic policy is to force out 10% every year. They do this by forcing managers to put 10% of their people into a catagory indicating they are sub-par. This should be based on the managers opinion, not some moron in Bradenton!!!
column14:
1) Listen to your people. I mean the workers, not managers.
2) Think further out than next quarter. Every year, management says the are going to do this, but it does not happen.
3) Listen to your customers. Not just the largest 2 of them.

column12: good place to learn the fundamental knowledge of this fields ,best for the fresh graduate to gain experience first for the entry level, benefits are good
column13: slowly raise salary, no pension currently , a little bit down pay in this fields , career develop spaces is limited to engineer, try become expert in this field first.
column14: there is some program offer frequently to get responding training in leadership, as long as you have gain enough experience first .

column12: Cutting edge management techniques. Learn from the best. Always the best equipment. More of a meritocracy than most companies I've worked for e.g. Lockheed Martin, DuPont, Xerox. No place for drones to hide. Either perform or out.
column13: No longer offer pension to new hires. Draconian health care plan that sucks money from your pocket. Great sick and personal day allowances..... but if you use them, it's frowned upon and mentioned during your annual review.
column14: The performance of employees is what drives the bottom line. Since Immelt took over, he is reducing benefits of employees and taking money from their checks. Sooner or later this will lead to an exodus of top-notch people and the general quality of employee will decline... as will profits and the stock price. Pay more attention to the long term consequesces of your "bottom line" employee-squeezing decisions today.

column12: The people are very good. There is a lot of talent here. The company has the resources to bring new products to market and to stay on the cutting edge.
column13: Company spends too much time focusing on shareholders and not enough time focusing on customers and employees. Benefits have gone downhill tremendously over last ten years.
column14: We are only here as long as our customers continue to purchase from us. Make it easier on them.

column12: Salary EE’s allowed to deploy disruptive innovation on a continuous basis. You have to work hard, given more than you can possibly get done. Consider it refreshing, reflecting good old fashioned hard work that is expected and rewarded.
column13: The “good old fashion hard work” mentioned above does not cascade down to hourly workforce in the form of responsibility & accountability. Too much entitlement mentality.
column14: Customers first, they are why a company is in business.

column5: Great company for a self-motivated, ambitious person.
column12: The opportunities that only a company the size of GE can offer. On the forefront of innovative technologies, and plenty of training opportunities for the self-paced, energetic learner.
column13: Detachment from various levels of management and disorganization. It is up to the individual to progress their career, GE will not go looking to advance you, and rather is glad to keep you in your current role.
column14: Place emphasis on career development from within the ranks.

column12:
Great team
Great organization support
Constant innovation
World class company
Opportunities in different areas, countries and divisions
column13:
Since its a big organization some decisions have to pass to many filters or levels
Silo-style organization makes complex to work in some solutions while a member is just focusing in his personal or area success.
column14: Work to reduce the barriers that each area objectives have with other ones; this is a real challenge when a top problem has to be solved and no one was to give room.

column12: Great place to work , really enjoy the people and the products they make . Overall it is a very secure and successful company .
column13: Being part of bigger GE means getting involved with a lot of processes that may or may not be relavent to you . Overall I don't view this as a con .
column14: Have a more active engagement with employees . Yes GE is a large company . There are ways for managers to be more involved

column12: Team oriented environment with opportunities to grow. Very strong mentors. The work and life balance was also very fair - unlimited vacation and family first mentality.
column13: The pace of work was very slow at times. There are a lot of people to talk too in order to get very basic tasks finished.
column14: Create a more free thinking environment where employees are encouraged to take risks. You can also eliminate all of the different barriers of people that are required to engage.

column12: You'll get exposed to many large and small projects; will be working with many well-known customers and people; You'll be involved in technology trends and innovations; You'll see the impact of the work that your business is doing; great company benefits.
column13: As is the case with many large corporations, there is quite a lot of internal bureaucracy which makes things slow, sometime to the point of frustration.
column14: Continue simplification and make customers the highest priority; thin is fast.

column12: Flexible Work Schedule, unlimited time off, on-site gym. brand new office building.
column13: Poisonous Culture. Management continues to change priorities and plays employees off each other. Unclear goals, causing long hours and a stressful environment. of spinning your wheels. Also, my title was a misnomer. There was no Analytical work, only accounts payable work.
column14: When I started at Global Ops, I was told I was empowered to make change. In less than a year, I learned that was nonsense. No change will occur until Management truly embraces open communication and truly cooperating with other teams to resolve process problems. Also, Management really needs to understand what their teams actually do on a day to day basis. Stop preaching the goals if you don't even realize we aren't doing anything to reach those goals.

column12: Results driven, autonomy provided, surrounded by smart people
column13: This culture is not for everyone and GE is working to re-right the ship, but if you enjoy an environment where you learn new things every day, are encouraged to stretch and develop yourself, and you are results oriented, then you will enjoy working here.
column14: Career opportunities are limited within GE given our current environment so the value prop needs to be well articulated as to why employees should continue working here.

column5: Heavy Bureacracy, below avg pay, short term focused - sacrifices quality for cost, pressure packed
column12: Long term stability, good co-workers,
column13: Heavy Bureacracy, promotions are demographically based - not merit based, scads of do-nothing people, no pipeline of key talent, pressure packed to get things done immediately, outsourcing crazy to the point that it's worthless, poor short sighted leadership - they've got their money & options and they're not going to rock the boat, below average pay for the worker bees. Short term focus inflicts permanent damage - case in point: Appliances.
column14: Listen to the workers - need to have bottoms up rather than top down. Stop promoting boobs who rotate jobs every two years. Stop outsourcing just to outsource. Focus more on Long term rather than short term. Insource key talent positions and pay according to industry average. Get rid of dead weight.

column12: The people at GE Transportation are great to work with -- very supportive and want to help you advance your career. Accessible upper management as well.
column13: Lots of bureaucracy. Promotions are not always given out on the basis of quality of work.
column14: The pay, while good for a small town, is not very competitive with other companies. Also, the pay structure for entry level into the Corporate Leadership Program does not account for students graduating with Masters.

column5: Great place to work, some managers better than others
column12: Personal Growth, Great launching pad, good benefits, decent salaries. If you get a good Assignment Leader, you can learn a lot!
column13: Job security is nonexistent - Consumer & Industrial is the red-headed stepchild of the company. Your experience could be wonderful or horrid, make sure to target good assignment leaders!
column14: Make sure that you have COMPETENT people leading your Intern Assignments who are willing to devote time and resources to the project.

column5: Good salary, benefits, but no job security.
column12: Good salary. Good benefits extended to family of employee.
column13: No job security. As with most major corporations, decisions are made based solely on $, with no thought to people, quality, or impact on American jobs.
column14: To the Top management, please remember the "Corporate America" includes some thought to being loyal to your home country. If decisions are based only on the bottom dollar, there won't be any "America" to worry about.

column12:
Strong performance gets higher responsibility 
Team atmosphere - everyone is in it together
Great annual performance evaluation process
Good time-off benefits
column13:
Good performance isn't always recognized 
Highly matrixed - too many "bosses", takes too long to get a decision made
Sometimes you feel very stuck in our your own site, not necessarily part of such an enormous corporation
column14: Take the time to truly make things easier, don't just say you're going to simply but actually do it at all levels.

column5: GE is a good place to gain experience that you will be rewarded for elsewhere.
column12: Very safety orientented. Pay was better than many in the industry. Benefits were good (health, dental, 401k, etc)
column13: Promotion / hiring practices inconsistent with stated corporate policies and values. Limited advancement opportunity for experienced employees.
column14: Weed out the underperformers in the technical and management roles in order to create a safer and more consistent work environment where the hard working and passionate can thrive.

column12:
Big company with lot of opportunities to work on projects & technologies.
Detailed and process oriented work environment.
Great people and good managers.
column13:
Bad local management who are more concerned about their own growth in GE.
Long hours without rewards (lot of leadership & business people have to vouch for you to get a promotion, you are at a disadvantage as there is no leadership or business in MI).
VanBuren, MI locatio is a glorified contractor shop (masked as employees).
No bonus & average industry salary. Benefits are pretty bad; ask any current or former employee (@ Vanburen) about health benefits.
Tough bureaucracy to work with & achieve anything.
column14: Stop acting like you care for MI employees. You are here because you got tax breaks & thought you will get cheap but good talent during down times.

column5: i joined GE as an Financial Management Program trainee. After graduation, i was enrolled in another program called CAS.
column12: Good learning opportunity, rotational nature of the job enables exposure to various industries and functions, intelligent people.
column13: Hierarchy exist in big companies. sometimes the location is not 100% ideal. need high degree of flexibility in terms of the job location and hour
column14: More cross-functional job opportunities. More global job opportunities to people with different background.

column12: Huge exposure if you're in financial management as you are often expected to advise leaders of different functions. You get exposed to many industries over time and learn a lot about industries, leadership and yourself.
column13: Locations not always the best for the industrial divisions. Generally you'll face red tape, need to earn your way up (time, network, influence.)
column14: Keep up the good work with simplification and entrepreneurship culture initiatives. Constantly provide value to employees: training, job design, fair evaluations.

column12:
I love the flexibility and the people. 
The benefits are wonderful
Vacation Time and PTO is a big plus
column13:
- Favoritism is shown the faces of all employees
- Not much room to advance unless you brown nose...It is all about who you get along with and not based on hard work 
- Pay sucks so bad...they are under the median compared to other companies pay their employees.
column14: There are very hard working people in the company that deserve to be noticed.

column5: Great company with room to grow and learn
column12: Lots of opportunities to learn and to get involved with a variety of different groups and specialties.
column13: It is a political environment and knowing how to work within that type of culture will help you in the long term
column14: Find ways to develop the mid level long term employee that provides sustained consistent performance year after year. Sometimes these employees get lost in the shuffle and there is a risk of losing them

column5: If you like to work with teams and get stuff done, not just talk about it, you'll love GE
column12:
- Integrity is core to the culture
- Collaborative
- Broad opportunities
column13:
- Culture is very strong; you'll need to learn to adapt to it and leverage it because you won't be able to change it. That's not a con, per se ... but it sometimes frustrates new hires
- it's still a company of human beings, some of whom are better leaders than others.

column12: Incredible resource investment in leadership training, Great people, Ability and openness to moving into new roles and functions. If you deliver results, flexibility is excellent. True meritocracy... except (see below).
column13: More work than people. Very unstable job situation internally, as cost pressures are forcing much deeper cuts than I had seen in my extended career.
column14: Even if it hurts in the short term, they need to employ resources to drive some level of org and process standardization.

column12: GE is a great place to start your career if you are hungry and ready to work hard. It is generally a meritocracy, but there are some leaders than slow things down.
column13: The company is going through a lot of change so there is constantly uncertainty. Also, its a culture driven by finance - so it lacks a real appreciation for commercial functions and a respect for engineering and product managers.
column14: Continue to invest in leadership development.

column5: WARNING: Got hired at GE Transportation? Prepare for WAR everyday.
column12: The projects and work scope. Many of people and managers are knowledgable. The product is high-tech for its class. The pay is good. The vacations are good and easy to take off. Lots of personal days and sick days available. Good set of Holidays. Lots of extra GE Volunteer activities. Encouraged to be involved in the Infinity Groups and activities. Lots of chances to meet upper management during the Infinity Group acitivities.
column13: Very competitive to the point of everyone for themselves... no sense of team-spirit... no sense of company pride. The people are cruel and back-stabbing. Even when managers and HR are aware of it, they do not address it. They just let it go on and say that it's the culture of the company and that they forgot how hard it is for new people coming in.
column14: Deal with employees who are back stabbing... not reward them.

column12: Good experience with lots of exposure to the business. Moderate tasks and projects were given in terms of responsibility. Working for the company looks great on a resume.
column13: Working in Cincinnati, you will be getting up early in the morning, but its nice getting off work around 3:00 p.m.
column14: Management does a great job, but usually does not prepare very well for incoming/new co-ops and interns. Also sometimes work assigned may be tedious.

column5: No matter what widget GE is selling, it is really selling it's people.
column12: Good professional development, variety of things to work on. This location provides significant collaboration and learning opportunities.
column13: Don't work here if you are lazy or think that your good personality will carry you. It is a large company, so there are lots of processes you go through, sometimes to do something simple.
column14: More often than not you have good, dedicated people that work for you - empower them!

column5: Huge company with great training and resources, but not very personal.
column12: GE has some of the best business training in the world. Some is available for all. For the best classes you must be nominated. Your fellow employees are some of the most talented people available. Some employees can successfully move from one industry to another.
column13: Regardless of how well you perform, decisions about your employment are made far above you, often by someone you will never meet. It's all about the numbers. There are unbelievable politics and layers to navigate here. The commitment to integrity is put to the side when it comes to reducing staff to make numbers.
column14: Don't make decisions about eliminating top talent without careful consideration. These choices appear to be made in a vacuum, looking only at the numbers.

column5: Not what you would think it would be for a company that size
column12: Work with some nice people, nice office environment
column13: Salaries are much lower than comparable work at other large companies and in the years I have been with the company, the benefits are not that great. Several managers and other employees have all come from the same employer, and the management really has no idea how the business really works. Some management definitely has favorites, as to some things that employees are allowed to do with no repercussions but if others did the same they would be out the door
column14: Management needs to really learn the business and understand the jobs well enough that they could do them if they had to, stop playing favorites and come through with rewarding those who put forth the extra efforts.

column5: Ever Changing experiences, new People and New technologies sum up GE's IT Environment
column12: Goal Focused and a great faced for younger employee's who are interested in learning something new or improving their current experience
column13: No Cons to think of about the company
column14: Management needs to have a more communicated approach to changes and be able to listen to Employee's who have been in place for multiple years when it comes to knew processes and SOP's

column5: This company cares about its employees.
column12: Excellent benefits, Education benefits are great. Hires people with disabilities and works very hard to make sure employees are properly trained for thier positions.
column13: Difficult to advance within. Low salaries in Phoenix, AZ. Had to work 60 hours every pay period to make ends meet.
column14: Review all employees backgrounds and resume's to make sure you are selecting the best candidates for the position applied, and not making selections based on most popular person.

column5: Great people, great products and great customers.
column12:
Challenging work with several opportunities. 
Intelligent employees who work together to do great things. 
Amazing products from locomotives to make Ning equipment to a marine engines to drill motors.
column13: Ge can be challenging and stressful. Conflicting metrics can drive confusion and waste. The days can be long and work life balance is often poor.
column14: Set clear goals and objectives that don't conflict between organizations. Evaluate to the waste in the business and eliminate it.

column12: Great atmosphere for motivated individuals looking for a broad company to work for. They are constantly evolving to changing times and give you the opportunity to take on projects that align with your interests.
column13: It can be difficult to get promoted if you are not willing to relocate with the company but if you are willing the possibilities are endless.
column14: Continue to allow team members to take on cross functional projects and simplify business operations!

column12: The company had reasonably generous benefits including vision and dental insurance coverage, 3 week sick days, personal days plus vacation. Management got even more personal days per year.
column13: the rate at which vacation time is earned is a bit stingy when compared to other companies and also unused time could not be "banked" for the following year.
column14: make the rate that vacation time is earned more in line with everyone else (more competitive).

column12: Good salary, great people, easy to move up the ladder, very clear expectations, ability to travel, supervisors were all great
column13: Had a really bad work-life balance. Very hard to finish the week with anything less than 60 hours. Definitely wouldn't recommend it to anyone that has a life outside of work.
column14: Hire more people! The job was fantastic aside from the work-life balance. I really enjoyed going into work every day, but after a while it was just exhausting.

column12: Good people, diverse industries, great brand name...VERY flexible for work/life balance. Low stress environment. Cool technologies and opportunities to be hands on as an engineer.
column13: Slow, old corporation struggling to adapt even though it wants to. Has all of the resources needed to change, but is bogged down in process/history/approvals.
column14: Be risky! Shake things up and encourage your teams to evolve EVERY DAY. Demand more from your employees and encourage cross pollination with other teams.

column5: Very smart people but the politics will kill you.
column12: Very smart people but not the most innovative. Plenty of opportunities to learn. Being part of the GE family.
column13: Older management and workers (engineers) slowing down the business. Communication between P&Ls happens at the top level or by chance. Food in the Atlanta and Schenectady campus is expensive and worse than prison food. Schenectady is a very depressing place to work.
column14: Need better communication with the P&L's.

column5: Know the perks as well as challenges into before joining the GE juggernaut.
column12: GE is a global company with a lot of opportunity to learn in an extremely professional environment. GE is very structured which provides the employee comfort in knowing what is expected and what needs to be done in order to perform well in your role.
column13: The company does not want to face feedback that is anything but positive and glowing from employees. If you have a problem with management, best to keep the issues to yourself, should you approach HR or senior management, you risk jeopardizing future opportunities for promotion. Also, HR is there for management, do not expect there support unless you are highly ranked in the company.
column14: Be more open to all types of feed back, have more honest communication.

column12:
Plenty of training available
Management was solid
Plenty of opportunities within company because of its size
In my job, I was given the opportunity to take initiative on a lot of projects.
Flexible with my school schedule
column13:
Lay-offs
Hard to find information within company
Hard to obtain feedback on my performance
Hard to locate key people needed for information
column14:
Give employees regular feedback
Try to make finding information easier and less confusing
Make it easier to access people who work in other GE companies

column5: Breadth afford opportunities, bureaucracy minimizes them
column12:
- Sheer size & scale of operations 
- Great internal leadership programs such as FMP, CAS etc.
- Generally intelligent & driven employees
column13:
- Fed oversight bearing heavily on productivity, creativity & profitability at GE Capital
- Industrial side of business not growing earnings quickly enough
- Tax as one of top 5 P&L's by net income: probably sustainable, not equitable
- Too inward-looking at all but highest levels
column14: Fix Healthcare business, open Crotonville up to lower-level employees

column12: Free lunch on Fri. Can't find any other compelling pros that gives GE an edge over other companies.
column13: Salary is not with par to other companies in Bay Area. Too much favoritism from Sr. management in the Platform team. You work overtime almost every other day and you are not allowed to report that time. If you bring this up with the mgr, the response is that you are expected to share other's work load.
column14: Be fair to everyone and hire more people when you know there is a lot of work. Compensate people for working overtime. And when people with designated responsibilities are willing to take up more responsibilities, make sure they do their original responsibilities along with the newly accepted work. Don't expect some one else to pick up their slack on the original responsibilities.

column12: Employee relationship to upper management is quite good. Upper management is interested in hearing employee opinions and feedback for continuous improvements. Good training opportunities. Good perks for GE field engineers employed in Energy Services.
column13: Outlook doesn't look good for energy services field engineering. Lack of hiring of field engineers in North America. Low base pay. Difficult to move within the company.
column14: There needs to be more opportunities available for internal employee cross training and movement.

column5: Great company but needs more long term planning
column12: Flexibility and respected culture. It is great to have an established brand to rely on during the ups and downs of the economy.
column13: Focus seems to be very quarter and yearly driven, rather than focusing on long term success
column14: Manage the business like you would manage your own. Sacrifice short term wins for long term success. GE has the clout and money to handle long term investments in people and products.

column12: pay, flex schedule, opportunity to grow
column13: layoff potential and strategy during tough business times
column14: during a tough business environment and layoff, its hard to keep the culture positive when your are spending a ridiculous amount of money moving people around into different workspaces and keeping those employed based on years of service vs the output of work. Also keeping contractors while your laying off regular employees never looks good.

column12:
Flexible about working from home if necessary. 
My experience gave me an edge, as others around me didn't have much of a clue about how effective software development and maintenance should be handled.
Most everyone was very pleasant and reasonable to work with.
column13:
Skills were proprietary and non-portable, and the job was maintaining an old software system needed for daily analyses. 
Working as overhead is never a good thing; you wear a bullseye all day long.
This particular department manager had a reputation for being unreasonable, and that proved true.
column14: Stop treating the IT function as overhead. Without the continuity of FTEs, you end up with a constant stream of temps that have no idea what happened in the past, and have no time to figure it out. Your infrastructure suffers, as it ossifies into an unmanageable heap.

column12: stable company, good management structure. Still a prestigious name to work for.
column13: can be boring, you start working at GE and stay there for years possible retire in the end. This may be a good thing depending on what you need / want. You think you can move to different businesses and roles but it is extremely hard, you usually get stuck in your role and business.
column14: make working at GE more rewarding in terms of job satisfaction

column12: Excellent company to work for in Signal Hill, but the Oil & Gas sector of the CA economy is doing poorly
column13: Excellent company to work for in Signal Hill, but the Oil & Gas sector of the CA economy is doing poorly. The low price of oil has hit the business
column14: Just keep an eye on the price of oil and adjust salaries as the year progresses. Hopefyly the price of Oil will increase thus increasing salaries.

column5: GE moving to the cloud is a joke!!
column12: Good pay and opportunities at Crotonville.
column13: You are micro managed and there is no real sense of empowerment! Within their Corporate IT Shared Services Unit it is an absolute mess! They can not figure things out and stay straight on a strategic mission for more than 6 months. A behemoth like GE can not turn on a dime. GE moving to the cloud and their Predix Platform is a big joke and they are wasting tons of money on it!
column14: I thought you were a much better leadership company that what I experienced! Managers are the worst. The company's culture is not the best and unlike other GREAT Fortune 500 companies you will never see the CEO set foot in your building!

column5: An Exciting Time to be at GE!
column12: Progressive culture on performance tracking and improvements as well as flexible work arrangements. Encourages ownership and empowerment in your role. Feel like you're contributing to something larger than yourself & helping on our mission to improve the world.
column13: Can be difficult to create changes quickly at times as it requires close coordination of multiple teams.
column14: Stay focused on improving our technical capabilities and our mission as Digital Industrial. Continue to break down silos!

column5: Can be a wavy ride, but worth the sea legs
column12: Outstanding and inspirational managers and executives. Training, growth opportunities, affinity networks, inclusive community & cool perks.
column13: Regular restructuring, lots of layoffs, communication limitations, time consuming processes that aren't always valuable to participants.
column14: Consider more cross-training of current employees - even across businesses. Many exceptional dedicated employees are willing to learn and grow in all directions and will provide greater value to the company when experiencing harder economic times.

column12: You can do almost anything at GE. It's a global company that's doing some amazing stuff around the globe.
column13: GE has a tendency of promoting those that are the loudest/showiest in their work vs the ones that actually do the work.
column14: GE's stepped away from its core competency - leadership. I would love to see it return to having leaders with strong integrity and the ability to make the hard, but right decisions.

column12: The people are fantastic, collaborative environment. Big focus on development of talent. Significant opportunity for career progression and growth.
column13: Tough business cycle, lack of transparency in the past has led to the need for tough decisions today. Need better systems and improved processes to avoid too much unnecessary churn.
column14: John Flannery has been enforcing a culture of transparency, needs to continue. Tough cycle for the business, but find ways to motivate employees to stay and feel appreciated.

column5: Manage the end to end process of aviation projects
column12: Good Benefits, and ability to transfer positions almost anywhere in the United States
column13: I’ve held 3 positions with GE and all have been positions at newly acquired business. This means implementing a new culture, business structure, processes, and can be chaotic
column14: Do not treat your star players the same as you do the bottom achievers. Everyone must be held accountable to their results.

column5: GE a great place to work, if you like process.
column12: It was a place with great people, and great process. (If your not into process clearly might not be a good place for you)
column13: It's a very large compnay and all the units don't always work together; so think of your self of more working for one of the GE companies rather than GE as a whole
column14: Have fun, think like a small, agile company... create something exciting.

column12: Worked closely with current employees on projects that helped all of GETs tremendously. A lot of free will and self management required.
column13: Sometimes there would be down time when projects would be slow because of all the red tape that might need to be completed to have something worked out.
column14: Overall great job. Keep up the good work and keep offering positions. Hiring process was great and the experience was one i will always remember.

column5: Great experience at a great company.
column12: GE has good pay and benefits. There are lots of opportunities to take on new projects and create new projects. Additionally GE has exciting and various product lines.
column13: Employees at GE seemed to be over worked. It seems to be a very political environment. Employees are not always treated with respect by management.
column14: Make sure to promote people who are qualified. Treat employees with respect.

column5: Great place to gain experience and network in a corporate environment
column12:
-Assignments are what you express interest in
-Salary employees are very friendly and happy to work with the interns
-employees and management are supportive
-The IMLP intern program does a good job of holding roundtables with upper management (we met with the CIO), planning volunteer activities within the community, and trying to make the program fun
-
column13:
-Ladder climbers
-bureaucratic
-encourage staying after work hours i.e. work/life balance shaky
-Expectations are not well expressed

column12: A very large and proud company with many grow opportunities so long as you are one of the "insiders" and/or the "choosen" to be a active, valued contributor for the business.
column13: My experience is that opinions outside the mainstream or "NIH' are not recieved well, especially when they point to a flaw or fault in a business plan. This happens a lot with an acquistion because it's not the GE way, which by definition is wrong.
column14: As part of a small acquistion, I feel management needs to be more honest with the employeees on why the acquisition is really happening...is it just to fill a spot on the "line card,' or do you intend to invest to grow the business, committing to the future. Managment most often doesn't care to share the long-term plans for the business.

column12: Company invests in employees, great training program. Locations all over the world so you have options. Really smart people so you have a great opportunity to learn.
column13: Sometimes too structured. In addition, can sometimes be very political. The GE culture is very unique, and some people do not fit so you be unhappy if you really dislike conflict. I do not have anything else bad to say about the company.
column14: Decrease bueracracy

column12: Fast paced environment working on some of the most interesting projects with talented individuals. Very open to R&D activities and also to implementing projects based on good ideas that folks have.
column13: Long hours and very little focus on long term incentive plans. Sometimes your voice will get lost in the crowd without senior leadership support.
column14: Focus on retaining top talent and celebrating the successes of your teams - even the small ones.

column12: Can be very fast-paced and engaging. Senior leadership are competent and engaged. You can learn a lot if you take advantage of all the opportunities.
column13: It's easy to get overworked and burned out. Sometimes direct managers can be distant and uncommunicative. Be careful not to get to cynical if you stay for a long career--that seems to be the fate of a lot of long term GE engineers.
column14: More team building exercises/events.

column5: do more with less and quicker
column12: great people; very smart, highly self motivated & technical with deep expertise who are very professional; no small office gossip; office setting is low stress, no micromanagement
column13: trying to keep tabs of who the company leaders/ executives are at the time... they seem to change annually; leadership seems out of touch with the foot soldiers sometimes
column14: don't let the pursuit of $ blind you into letting go of highly productive, good people.

column12: This was a great place to work with very good benefits. The pay was good and the working hours were flexible. There was a lot of good safety procedures and training in place.
column13: N0 onsite HR person to talk to if you needed to. Most of the scanning equipment was out dated and in poor working condition.
column14: Keep up the great safety training and give people a few more options on what they can do.

column5: Working as MS SQL Server Database Administrator with detail oriented, analytical and troubleshooting experience
column12: This is a Good company with great opportunities, great benefit, good working environment having cooperative employees with knowledge sharing which helps to build a good team
column13: comparatively low salary for a newly hired employee and has less working experience in
column14: all the management team or seniors have very good leadership capability but still there is always something to perform better then what they have

column12: Very supportive of community, volunteer organizations and veterans. There is opportunity to move to other positions every couple of years so you can take on new roles within the company.
column13: Many employees don't help each other out or work as a team. Appliance Park is very run down and the roof leaked in the building I was in. The restrooms and common areas were filthy. It can be very difficult to get things done on the line since working with the Union can be very challenging.
column14: Add some type of bonus plan to retain employees. The $100 gift cards don't cut it. More effort needs to be placed in upkeep of the buildings. Simple things like making sure the roof isn't leaking, filthy carpet is replaced and the restrooms are cleaned would go a long way.

column12: I enjoyed my colleagues. I enjoyed the work.
column13:
Does not necessarily promote from within. 
The company buys and sells companies all the time. Therefore, you may get sold.
Reorganizations are frequent, due to acquisitions and dispositions.
column14: As the company experienced a "reduction in force" I was disappointed in managers that hired for open positions from the outside. In my opinion, folks that were impacted by restructuring should have filled newly created open positions.

column12: Excellent reputation in the industrial industry. Working for GE opens many doors automatically. Conventional "cold calling" doesn't exist because, in general, most customers are receptive to hearing what GE is doing within their business.
column13: Legacy employees are slow, very slow, to adopt new direction and cutting edge products. In some situations they are "going through the motions" until they retire. Less interested in driving new growth and breaking out of their comfort zone.

column12: Very organized, professional, and reasonable company all in all. Gave reasonable amounts of responsibility, expected you to do your work effectively and efficiently, and provided help and feedback as needed. Excellent work-life balance.
column13: Not many downsides can be applied to this plant at GE Lighting. Really one of the only things there were was that the inventory system could have been improved in one part of the plant.

column12: Great for learning, very challenging environment, it really push you to your limits and forces you to improve yourself.
column13: Very hard to advance if you do not come from one of the programs of the company, even if you are very experienced they would promote someone from the programs with less experience.
column14: People who come from outside provide diverse perspectives, enriching the company. Not everything is the company's way, there are sometimes better ways to perform a job.

column12: Good benefits such as maternal and paternal leave after the birth of a child. Site includes a cost estimator for understanding how much a procedure will cost.
column13: Deductible health insurance plan vs. a co-payment plan. Includes a health savings account which you can contribute to and take with you.
column14: My advice to management is to be more transparent with the financial aspects of businesses and communicate how the markets will affect positions.

column12: Flexible work arrangements. Exciting and complex sales opportunities create a rewarding work environment.
column13: Stressful work environment. Low work - life balance. Every year seems to be a stretch year, with little to no rewards for what should be considered a fantastic year.
column14: Advocate for employees development and promote organically. Create reasonable sales targets which will be an incentive the sales teams instead of a goal that cannot be met.

column12: The most professional and educated group of people I have ever had the pleasure of working with.
column13: The nature of a company this size is that you are boxed into a specific role and set of tasks. If you are a diverse person, who thrives on changing demands and roles, you may find a job here a little confining.
column14: The appliance division needs strong leaders to drive through adoption of the ERP system

column12: Iconic company that is essential to the world in so many ways. Rich culture and long history of innovation over its 125+ year history.
column13: Company is going through some stress right now, but new CEO leadership is inspiring confidence that the right moves are being made to keep GE in a leadership position and around for another 125 years.
