column14: Company needs to keep keen focus on execution and driving results and keeping its employees motivated and engaged.

column12: One of the best technological company to work for, lot of learning, innovations and new ways to work are encouraged, best company to start a career.
column13: Currently in challenging times, unnecessary attention from Wall street, hopefully company will come out of this challenging times soon.
column14: Spin of the units and have separate, independent and autonomous boards, take the cyclical business private and let them be adapted by bigger units, example: Aviation adapting the Transportation business.

column5: Large company, with varying degrees of competance
column12:
-Very competant engineers
-Lots of money within the company to fund new ideas
- Management makes an effort to support the interns
column13:
-Large company, very easy to get swallowed up
-Sometimes difficult to obtain work as an intern
- Since the company is so large, management styles vary greatly
column14: Please remember that interns are a valuable resource, and many of us are only a few quarters away from being eligible to become full time employees.

column5: I was surprised by what I found..
column12:
Easy going staff
Bsness Casual attire
Can work from home if needed
Flexible if need time off and/or to leave early, come in late etc...
No micro-management
Nice cafeteria on ground
Large parking area directly across the street
Nurse's office on ground
column13:
Not a lot really :
If you are a contractor chances of becoming Perm is VERY VERY rare - bigger chance of you contracting long term and being extended numerously.
Cafeteria is in building but somewhat pricey

column5: Difficult archaic culture with low employee respect at GE Transportation
column12: GE produces incredible products, from jet engines to locomotives to MRI machines. It is a product company.
column13: GE is made up of numerous divided and disconnected operations. The cultures vary depending on where the employee is. from an employee standpoint GE's business producing jet engines is A+ while GE's business producing locomotives is an F. So, if you are considering a job with GE, make sure you look at the operations as separate companies. GE medical and GE aerospace are recommended. Stay away from GE transportation, where the culture is hard and miserable and new comers are treated as second class citizens.
column14: Advice is targeted specifically to the management team in GE Transportation: Make faster decisions. Appreciate new ideas and new comers to your business. Get ahead of the technology curve by leveraging solutions from the automotive industry. Slow down on the continuous meetings with the same people, since nothing new gets invented within a committee.

column5: Good place to work. It's a big, dumb company, but it could be a lot dumber.
column12: Good benefits. Offers excellent training. Lots of opportunities to advance if you're willing to move around a lot. Overall good corporate culture.
column13: You pretty much need to be willing to relocate if you want to advance very far. Lots of things move very slowly. The corporate culture does vary somewhat from division to division.
column14: Try not to be a big, lumbering company.

column12: The benefits are awesome. The main reason I decided to join the GE team is because they will pay for college.
column13: The company is too big at times. The systems in place slow down the workflow.
column14: When I was hired on I was told that there were bonus systems in place. For example a quarterly safety bonus. I have been with the company through many quarters and yet to see a bonus.

column5: Good Company to Start Your Career
column12: Provides great training opportunities. Very friendly environment with great management. Plenty of chances to be promoted and work your way up in the company. Generally promote from within.
column13: Poor communication between various departments within the company. Many competitors offer higher base salaries. Somewhat of a men's club in upper management.
column14: Find ways to communicate with all levels of the company more efficiently. Create one purpose between each department.

column12: Good pay and benefits. lots of job mobility if you are willing to relocate. Opportunities to learn many things.
column13: Lots of changes happen in a short period of time (can be good and bad) - reorg, acquisition, sell-off. Too many cheerleaders, not enough doers.
column14: Keep employees at their roles at least 2 years. They move around too much and there is a lot of wasted and ineffective knowledge transition and buildup of foundation.

column12:
-Company culture 
-Immediate responsibility 
-Constant feedback
-Ability to network with top executives
column13:
-Low salary compared to other finance jobs
-Rotations (geographic) make it hard to have a relationship/establish yourself in one city
column14: If you want to recruit more students from top 25 schools (national university/liberal arts), you are gonna have to pay more. When you graduate from Wharton and GS offers you 135k right out of college, you won't even consider the GE offer...no matter what you'd be doing.

column12: Able to grow and lead, changing roles is easy and the pay isn't bad in comparison to industry/location
column13: No advocacy for career - you have to manage it 100% or be lost in the numbers. Can feel like a cig in the machine if you let it.
column14: More active roles in all levels of organization. Don't rely solely on voice of your directs - go deep, see the actual vs the simplified version.

column12: GE has a great culture of collaboration and professionalism. It has its fair share of large corporate bureaucracy, but greater emphasis has been put on driving that out. At this point, the organization is fairly efficient given how large and geographically disparate the workforce is.
column13: I work in GE O&G, which is suffering layoffs and pay freezes due to low oil & gas prices.
column14: Limit "transitional" roles to 6 months, max.

column12: an amazing company to work for ... great benefits, very progressive and always improving. GE has a great reputation for very good reason.
column13: GE is always changing for the good and for the bad, if you don't deal with change very well it is not the company for you to work at.
column14: change for the sake of change is not always the best idea, be sure that there is good results for the change

column12: GE's scale and diversity is often unmatched and thus you get a diverse experience with the opportunity to move into different roles in completely different businesses or functions.
column13:
HR / hiring tends to be a painfully slow process.
Salary will almost always be lower than other companies.
column14:
Speed up the ability to hire.
Offer true market rates for salaries or slightly higher to retain existing talent that wish to take new roles but remain in the company.

column12: Diversity of talent, Global thinking, International travel, Executive training, 401K, Preferred Time Off
column13: Transient leaders, frequency of strategic and cultural changes, non competitve healthcare benefits, non competitive incentive compensation programs, lack of transparent performance development process, salary freezes are demoralizing.
column14: Get to know your team on a more personal basis. Work harder on developing executive talent within vs hiring externally. Expand the banding system as there are way too many resources stuck at SPB.

column12: As a GE employee your on your own. Salary is average for the most part.
column13:
Don't expect managerial support or help from above. Management will make unreasonable work load demands on employees and their off-time. Family means nothing . . . . . ZERO to GE Management and believe it or not, HR is the enemy.

As for Safety, the managerial application and demands for mandatory compliance became the "Problem" and actually resulted in many injuries of workers trying to comply with "Stupid" mandates and requirements created by incompetent and/or task ignorant safety people, using a one size fits all mentality. 

Don't expect to have a job if management needs to boost their stock prices.
column14: Listen to those of knowledge with experience, who work the jobs. Pay for talent.

column5: Satified with the company but stuck in the rut.
column12: Personal development and how they want you to change jobs and grow within there.
column13: easy to be lost in the shuffle of a very large company. Hard to see what is happening outside of your location or department
column14: I think they need to see what is happening down low and less stress on us at the bottom. Listen to what we say and create a more open enviroment.

column12: Many opportunities. Signficant latent capability in terms of technology and market power to utilize
column13: Broken session C process (annuan HR process for promotions, evaluations etc). GE culture of meritocracy in advanced stage of decay. A generation of weak leaders are now in place and continue to groom same. Evidence is in the repeated misses in critical areas, lack of preparation for and sluggish response to the economic crisis and the embarrassing outperformance of GE by Siemens... a competitor with a demonstrated track record of no integrity.
column14: Fix session C. It is broken, all of the corporate surveys show that it is. The rank and file have lost confidence in the leadership. Too much focus on diversity, style, stories, not enough focus on execution and business sense.

column12: Its GE. One of the largest companies in the world. They have lots of opportunity to grow, and push you to do your best.
column13: Poor Mid Management. Senior management is solid, but mid management is often unqualified and very rude and difficult to work with.
column14: promote only experienced and qualified employees. College does matter, and don't promote just because of seniority. Effort and intelligence should be the requirements

column5: Overall striving to be a good company, yet too large for consistently fair treatment and motivation of employees.
column12:
Technical depth (engineering) or other technical fields. 
Large company size - lots of internal move opportunities (if only theoretically)
Resource availability
column13:
Too big to be efficient
Theoretical opportunities seldom play out 
HR and Finance play too big of a role in management (running the company instead of leaders and managers)
Very slow to make any significant change
Compensation/benefits are not competitive to market
column14:
Hire only best people for middle-managers to make sure you can trust your team to foster and maintain the type of environment that will attract and retain talant. 
Focus on long term, as opposed to short term live/die by the quarter - travel freezes and other policy rigidity only hurts the company and employees in the long run

column5: Great place to settle into a career . . .
column12: Easily one of the best places to work if you're interested in learning how to manage people. GE basically wrote the book on people management (and for good reason). It's been around on the NYSE since it's inception and makes a huge effort in developing future leaders. Great company if you're a more seasoned professional in Finance, Legal, or one of the hard Engineering Sciences (Mechanical, Electrical, Material).
column13: Software Engineer and Computer Science employees are quite often referred to as simply "IT". This can be very troubling if you want to develop great software products or simply be on the cutting edge of technology. Very bureaucratic, often to the point of reduced productivity. Definitely a management culture and not an engineering culture.

column5: Excellent company, lot of opportunity spanning various industries and ability to move into various roles.
column12: Great training and employee avocation. Due to the large size of the business, there a full range of activities that can keep you busy through your career. Lots of opportunity to grow your career and continue to take on new challenges.
column13: Large corporate company feeling - older primarily industrial business. Work life balance can be low depending on your role.

column12: Lobe the environment. They actually have a restaurant in the building I was in (5). Loved the people too.
column13: 2 teir scale will never work unless your an idiot who does the same work as the next man but makes half of what they do. It's really a slap in the face.
column14: One wage! Or just sell appliance park like you've been trying to. This is not a place one can retire from anymore.

column5: Laid off after GE acquired company and consolidated it
column12: Great pay, but that was due to the fact that it was a union shop before GE bought the company.
column13: They acquired the company and implemented a lot of changes that affected quality control and delivery times. Then they built a multi-million dollar facility in Jacksonville Florida. They also bought out the majority of our competition. They began shuttering all of the plants that they bought out and consolidated them in Florida. They now have a non union shop and subcontractors make the products which they assembly in Jacksonville.
column14: If you think because it's a big company that you have job security, then you're mistaken. Take a look at the turn over for mid level management and labor. It's staggering. They go where they get the most tax breaks.

column12: large company with big resources to solve problems. people are generally ready and willing to help. Employees are treated well.
column13: large company causes difficulties to coordinate efforts across many barriers. too much consultation necessary to get things done. pay raises are very rare.
column14: keep working on breaking down barriers. give more autonomy for decision making. be flexible to accommodate home life and family.

column12: Great pay, great benefits, dedicated professional staff, excellent working conditions, every day is a new challenge, product line benefits people's health.
column13: Some people do not like the working atmosphere in a large corporation. The potential for advancement is often limited to political expertise and job performance. You have to get along to get along.
column14: Continue with the current structure but beware of the upcoming generation, they have different values than us "old timers"

column12: Culture and environment is great, progressive mindset. Provides global experiences you wouldn't naturally get in other companies. Aggressive business development initiatives, allows them to make smart business decisions to develop and grow their business units.
column13: Limited opportunity. If mobility is a restraint and you are in the higher professional roles, its near impossible to move to the next level. Bureaucracy still makes it difficult to do business internally.

column12: Great teamwork and advancement opportunities. Work/Life balance was improving greatly.
column13: Below average salary and compensation. Talk about retaining top talent but no actions behind it. Very little differentiation between poor to average performers and those that go above and beyond on a regular basis. It is recognized by your managers and 1 over 1, but all the control over your compensation is dictated by HR who has no involvement in your day to day efforts.
column14: Give more control to direct management to run it like they own it. Give employees incentive to go above and beyond. For cost savings projects, offer the project owner a 1% return for their efforts on realized savings. This will push more projects and you will see them done faster.

column5: No joy being a small fish in a big pond
column12: If you can navigate to a part of the portfolio that the core biz really cares about, you will have access to quite a bit of cash to make things happen. Even with GET being on the auction block, the locomotive production aspect of the biz is not going away anytime soon...even in "down market" years.
column13: GE has a penchant for gobbling up smaller companies. If you are an acquisition, you have to make it YOUR JOB TO integrate to Big Brother. GET has proven time and time again that they are terrible at integrating acquisitions across all P&L's. Really astounding, I might add, given the frequency it happens.
column14: Make it part of your job again to steward the people that report to you.

column5: Overall a great company to work for
column12: Permissive Time Off, very personable managers, active career tracking and assistance when transiting to a new role, very progressive and forward thinking leadership
column13: Very big company so it makes you feel unconnected to some of the things that go on. Many times it is difficult to get a straight answer when important, company-wide news comes out.
column14: Progressively changing a huge company takes time, dont expect culture to change overnight.

column5: Great for entry level college grads.
column12: GE offered great training, including both on-the-job training as well as a generous tuition reimbursement program.
column13: Large company, often times you must go through several levels of management to do things that might be out of the ordinary.
column14: Focus more on operations-level quality improvement like the Japanese countries do. Six Sigma is great but doesn't do much for the average worker and focuses more on GE's products and services.

column5: Great engineering resources... Not the best utilization
column12:
- Amazing lab/component-development and testing capabilities
- Direct access to manufacturing and repair
- Largest installed fleet of gas turbines
column13:
- Too many people leading to too much politics
- Very limited room for creativity because of management constraints and work being over-divided among people
- Very poor management.. more textbook and hypocritical
column14:
- Be open to feedback
- A big reward for engineers is mastering the subject and getting a sense of ownership and belonging to a product.. monetary rewards only dilute motivation
- There is very limited room for our creativity.. there are too many people and too little work
- There is an appearance of empire building and boss-pleasing
- Projects change too often and there is hardly any constancy before team and projects change

column12: Leadership Development, Adoption of great toolkits and business practices, Smart people
column13: Big, Highly structured environment, Type A culture, Women conform to a male culture to succeed
column14: Financial services business unit leaders do not always have a level of comfort in the industry necessary to effectively evaluate risk, and commonly do not have the respect of the individuals working for them who have a more sophisticated financial skill set.

column12: GE is one of the best places to get manager training. They have well developed processes even if they don't necessarily get used. Their Six Sigma and IMLP training pays off in the real world
column13:
Hyper aggressive cost based culture. As much as it can build people up, it will also tear people down and a lot of fast risers will often get "boiled" if they stay too long. 

Also the company is so large that one side may not know what the other side is doing.
Also GE tends to hire a lot of seasoned workers from other companies such as AT&T. This will have an influence on management which can create a hostile work environment.
column14: Keep on auditing your processes. Also, your ombudsman program is a sham.

column5: Great Company, A Lot of Changes
column12: Great Company, diversity programs, various opportunities to learn, network and visibility to leadership. They have a portal for on line learning including some Harvard classes.
column13: Too many changes in two years. The company is not recognizable from 5 years ago. Not sure if the company sees value in the work that you are doing.
column14: More communication is needed to low level employees to reduce anxiety and worry.

column12: Independent work with exposure to commercial teams and product management. Allowed me to work remotely. Great teams and direct management.
column13: Got a bit redundant and wasn't as challenging as I had hoped. I didn't have enough customer exposure. Would have liked the chance to travel more.
column14: Allow all employees the chance to meet and work more with customers.

column12: Lots of benefits and v job security working for such a large and diverse company, many opportunities for movement within the organization. Good compensation.
column13: It is such a large and diverse company that the sole drove of the company is to improve the portfolio and increase revenue for the stock holders.
column14: Fight for and pay more attention to employee needs such as insurance and raises for performance, sometimes the worker is overlooked.

column12: This place is a great day job if you like days. And having job. I enjoyed the diverse staff and the great breaks.
column13: This place is the only place that I have ever heard of being a place of employment were you work and every Friday get paid.
column14: Try to be a lit r let better a giving raises that will help a person substantially so that they can afford HE products.

column12: Looks out for its people. Always seems to be room for advancement. Get yourself visible and prepare to flex to new roles.
column13: Sometimes advancement is too quick (not necessarily a bad thing if you are the one advanced!), but this can lead to a lack of depth in expertise.
column14: Try to work on longevity of people in position. You can always add more, but to continuously shift leads to inconsistent results.

column12: Helpful teams that work with you and are willing to answer any questions you have. I never felt uncomfortable or annoying asking many questions.
column13: I did not think there were any cons to the internship. I learned a lot and they often do rotations with you if they think you were a good worker.
column14: I have never done an internship prior to General Electric, however I thought the management was great and very helpful

column12: Management was great to work for. Kept atmosphere positive and was very employee focused. Also the benefits and PTO were great.
column13: At times upper management expects too much. The deadlines were often not achieveable which had a negative impact on the morale of some.
column14: In order to keep the atmosphere fun and to keep employees motivated, it is recommended that deadlines be more reasonable and not expect employees to work OT to meet them.

column12:
Over 15 years with GE. Did lot of roles. Very diverse and best in class in company culture. 

Solid technologies and products - no fluff
Fantastic senior leadership.
column13: Too many re-orgs. Lot of layers created and then flattened resulting in reinventing orgs over and over again. Some mid managers not a good fit and spoil work environment.
column14: Be more careful in promoting / grooming people into their first manager role.

column5: Maintain, perform Preventitive Maintenance, direct operators, check out parts and attend status and C &I meetings .
column12: challenging work, problem solving, helping to make the machinery and facility as a whole better. Very full filling work and always learning.
column13: That the company was beginning to phase out and closing the doors this year. Having to leave what I tried so hard to help maintain and make prosperous. My fellow coworkers and manage team..sad.
column14: None

column12: Consistent opportunities, you're not usually worried about if your job is going to exist tomorrow. Plenty of opportunities to grow your abilities and career.
column13: Plan on being owned by the process, they are getting better, but sometimes GE is it's own worst enemy. Compensation is in par with most industries but bonuses are mostly non-existent or are based on business level performance over which an individual has no impact.

column12: Our mission is to build the Industrial internet. We are changing the world. It's a long journey full of wrong turns and detours. It's exciting and scary. You've got to bring your full personality to work and work at the top of your intelligence.
column13: Too far away from cool things. San Ramon is really way out in the middle of nowhere. It's a long commute from anywhere fun.
column14: Move to Oakland

column5: GE is a great mediocre place to work.
column12: You can gain lots of experience and responsibility quickly. It is a stable predictable company to work for. You can have a long career here and keep yourself busy learnign new things all the time. There are a ton of training opportunities available. GE won't make you rich, but it will pay enough that you won't be poor either.
column13:
Large beuracracy. Pay raises are small and follow strict guidelines. There is not much opportunity to increase your salary except to sit and wait as you get older and slowly collect incremental yearly raises.
Getting anything done is slow and painful. I guess this can't be helped when dealing with important technology.
column14: There should be some way to obtain bonuses based upon employee performance and overall performance of the company.

column5: A leading company in the security industry
column12: One of the leading companies in teh security industry, good pay for out of college graduates as well as benefits.
column13: career paths not well defined, this has been defined several times by upper managements but never really put into practice.
column14: Establish a management framework that values research and development projects; reduction of bureaucratic walls between different functional organizations; Shift focus to integrated security solutions instead of monolithic systems.

column12: Everyone who works at GE is intelligent, I am impressed by the level of all the engineers and at the work they do.
column13: There is little work-life balance, people often make work their life, and their personal lives suffer. For engineering, the locations are not desirable.
column14: Learn to explore work-life balance. Also make sure that the women do not get forgotten--benefits such as daycare would go a long way.

column12: Opportunity to advance and leadership programs are the best in the world. Leadership values and committment to company are evident in their success
column13: Being such a large company can lead to communication issues and can be slow to make decisions. But overall decisions are made for long term goals
column14: Continue to provide opportunities for leaders and managers to advance. The people are the company and continue to develop their skill sets

column12: A large company that offers a diverse career path in just about every technical field whilst keeping you challenged and engaged.
column13: GE is company desired by most people and thus allows a long list of people will to come to work for such a good company, salaries not always competitive.
column14: Management is great to engage the key team members but need to ensure visibility and exposure are maintained and appropriate recognition and credit provided.

column5: GE Works: for some but not all
column12: Working level people are usually really good people. Lots of community involvement. When there aren't any budget constraints the company can be vibrant and an exciting place to work offering many opportunities for people looking to stretch their talents
column13: Too bureaucratic and too many golden calves. Over emphasis on diversity at the expense of missing out on really talented people. Not a meritocracy but more of a who you know network. Old industrial style type management theories. Managing numbers quarter to quarter sacrificing long term growth opportunities
column14: Change compensation structure of executives to reward them for long term performance and keep executives in jobs long enough to reap what they sow. Expand IC to people who really drive the company Senior Professionals. Ditch Session C and revamp operations cycles.

column5: GE is a great place to work
column12: You can have a multi-dimensional career within one company and can carve your own path
column13:
constant reorganization
Spend a lot of time making sure you will have a good role for the next reorg, so you become too internally focused
column14: Invest for the long-term, not just the next 2-3 years. Technology is changing our environment quickly and we need to build the framework vs reacting to it.

column12: Company has a really good 401K plan along with a good pension. Many opportunies for growth and job opportunities in various businesses.
column13: Over the past few years, GE has taken away the pension for new hires and the health benefits are not as good as they were a few years ago.
column14: To save cost quit taking away from people who are doing the work and elimate middle managers

column12: GE is a large, multi-national company with strong futures in many industries. Hourly wages are some of the best in the area.
column13: Local plant is closing due to international competition. Work environment is not clean, and an attitude of apathy has crept into the production line. Two-tiered pay system contributed to an attitude of complacency and suppressed employee desire to do any more than the absolute bare minimum.
column14: Locally, there were no incentive devices regularly in play. Workers had no reason to continue to produce the high-quality, high-volume work that historically had come from the plant. As a result, waste increased and productivity decreased. Re-institution of regular employee reviews with recognizable, visible consequences (both negative and positive) should be put in place for similar situations.

column12: Good pay, Good learning environment, good people to work with. Knowledgeable staff, staff wanting you to succeed
column13:
Hours. Being in the locomotive department it never shuts down. We work 12 hr shifts sometimes even more. Barstow is not the best of areas, but it is cheap and money goes a long way. 
Need a better training policy in place for new hires.
column14: Train new hires more in depth.

column5: it's a very diverse company with tons of opportunities for growth
column12: the innovation is amazing, no matter what business you're a part of. incredibly smart people making great things happen. employee growth and leadership development is second-to-none. they are very serious about making their employees better at what they do.
column13: it's a huge company, so it can be frustrating to get answers and slow. They also pay on the low side.

column12: Good training/leadership development program, exposure is great. The company clearly values the program participants and sees them as the future of the company's finance leadership.
column13: Politics, but that is the case for any large company. As an FMP, sometimes folks that didn't come through the program aren't as keen on the participants.
column14: The program is good, was a great career launcher wishing the company and outside of the company if someone chooses.

column12: Great working environment with very highly skilled and knowledgeable people who are keen to share that knowledge. The pay was one of the best in the industry. When on the road living was considered "full and appropriate"
column13: Verry large corporation that expects to get it's pound of flesh from each and every employee each and every day. As a field service engineer one spent a lot of time away from home and family.

column5: A company that cares about it employees?
column12: It is a large global company. You can move into other open positions at GE
column13: I was laid off after many years. Close to retirement. Told I was being replaced by a contract nurse. It didn't matter I only had a few years to retirement nor could my immediate boss offer any input . It was a higher up decision. Loyalty and hard work of the blue collar population doesn't mean anything to the higher up. I worked so hard there. Made a lot of improvements in the day to day operation. I will always have this gut reaction of disgust and distaste whenever I see that GE logo .
column14: Is that contract employee really going to contribute as much, be as knowledgeable, or be as loyal as an actual employee? If the ship starts going down due to a leak , that contract employee is not going to bail water.

column12:
great collaboration between different business units, and a ton of mid-career professionals with experience from a wide-range of companies.

Outstanding environment/facilities, initially very friendly toward employee morale-type events.
column13:
Very limited opportunities to move into leadership, GE is very focused on using ITLP's for most leadership roles, even though the bulk of this location were mid-career professionals that have seen/done a lot more in their lifetime than the bulk of the ITLPs. 

Also was part of one of the worst RiF i have ever seen/heard of. Once given notice of my role (along with approx 50 other) being eliminated, I never heard from my direct leader (Cincy) or HR rep (Houston again), no closedown/turnover meeting on last day, so just walked out the door with $3000 in assets. Totally unprofessional and callous.

column12: Culture, Opportunities, many business are Perfect to work on, values, care about the employee, it is a great school. I learned a lot in this comapny.
column13: Some business way of work, New business integrations sometimes needs to be improved. Some business are very diferent form the normal GE.
column14: It was a lern journey, but new business integrations sometimes needs to be improved. Not all business use the same values when operating.

column5: Awesome Company with plenty of opportunity
column12: Great Pay, Decent Benefits, Travel, So much overtime your wife and kids will forget you actually exist
column13: Not much wiggle room if you need time off on short notice, not a lot of oversight where it's needed a lot of people slip through the cracks and are under trained or have some how fooled management on what there abilities are and are being overpaid
column14: More employee oversight

column12: Great leadership program with attractive starting salary. Plenty of smart minds working here. Work/Life balance is also better than I would have expected.
column13: Wage increases are meager. All benefits (travel, company picnics, happy hours, flying non-coach) have been removed. No bonus or incentives to work harder. Training and Conference spending has been cut as well. All the C-Staff level folks seem to think they are above you if you are not on the same level as them, its frustrating.
column14: If you value us, spend the extra couple of dollars to keep us. Give us the training dollars we need to stay current with this changing industry. Let us fly in business class when traveling oversees for work. Bring back to extra perks like company parties and recognition gift cards to make us feel loved.

column5: Consider only if you are offered an opportunity in a "core" business
column12:
If this could be a call a Pro...
Resources are very limited and you end up doing several other functions of what you should be doing... Hence you learn a lot of the other functions that help build your resume but be prepared for the long hours.
column13:
- 20% of the people do 80% of the work
- all about who you know 
- not great work/family balance
- be prepared to train your manager
column14: Do not use the "bring fresh ideas" excuse to put people in leadership positions in which they have no idea about. Instead, promote leaders who come from the bottom and know the ins/outs of the businesses and understand what needs to get done internally to get to the next level.

column12: Great pay, tuition reenbursement, monthly bonuses if you met the metrics, programs to help you advance, great insurance and price for insurance
column13: Management, constant nagging/ fear of being let go if your metrics aren't high enough, not flexible with hours, never ending phone calls
column14: Learn how to encourage your staff better. Help those who are struggling. Seek out those who aren't happy with their current position and help the grow. Don't play favorites.

column12: You have the resources and options of a big company.
column13: They are too ambitious in the amount of projects they take on and how much they expect their workers to handle. Employees are encouraged to communicate with their manager about workload, but managers are stretched so thin it's nearly impossible to get a hold of them. When you do and express your situation, you're told that everyone is busy so just make it happen. The facility in Erie is also run down. It's an old plant, which can't be helped, but a cleaner, more modern environment would improve employee pride for the company.
column14: Focus your employees on the most important tasks. Even after years of trying to simplify, there are still too many distractions for employees.

column12: learning opportunities, flexible work schedule, 2 days WFH a week, nice people to work with in the Global Patent Operation
column13: Sometimes you feel unappreciated or undervalued, uncertainty to the companies future at this moment
column14: make sure to make your employees feel like they are respected and valued. A note to their spouse is not a way to help them feel appreciated.

column12:
Global company and if you want to know the best plactice, you can access or get information within company.
Able to make a international connection if you have chance to work for Global program.
column13: hmmmm... Sometime very busy and you need to big carenge I guess this is hte downsides but also my favolite...
column14: It's better to share the company and Senior Management strategy more crearly, it will help employee and project team.

column12: The workplace is friendly and there is a lot of scope to learn new things. Immediate supervisors are young people so they move around very freely and are very approachable.
column13: The pay is just OK compared to the amount of work that you have to sometimes put in
column14: Better communication of the expectactions of the shop and better filteration of the information to the workforce will significantly improve the performance

column12: Good place to start on an internship. The people are friendly and helpful. so there is a lot of potential for growth and learning
column13: The work becomes repetitive after a while and it is no longer challenging after one semester unless you are willing to take initialtive.
column14: Things are pretty good at GE right now but the internship program will carry more weightage if there are chances for conversion to full time positions.

column5: GE Energy was a good place to work but not the best.
column12: There are many different branches and many different people that work in GE, so your ability to work on different things is endless. GE has great benefits and great training programs,
column13: I noticed there isn't really much room to move up in GE. Most of the managers and executives were brought in from other companies and were not promoted through the ranks. If you are happy with sitting in a cubicle all your life then GE is perfect for you.
column14: try to target the younger employees and keep them interested. When working around a bunch of old engineers it makes it hard to be excited to go into work and enjoy who you are working with.

column5: Great experience overall - a place where you can build a career on your own merit
column12: Strong common culture & values generally shared across the globe and the various GE businesses; Overall very good people; Flexibility in career opportunities. Incredible investment in training of employees.
column13: Sometimes too big and bureaucratic; communication is decent but messages can be a bit slow to trickle down to all levels

column5: Top pay for talent and company makes a profit regardless
column12: As long as you get your job done, no one bothers you. Loved my co-workers. I was able to work from home as necessary. Many benefits such as 20 sick days a year.
column13: Manager frequently said India engineers would work at half our salary. Had 3 (remote) mangers in a year so no decent review. RIF'd then then offered another position similar responsibilites at 50% previous wages. Lost 401k contribution because I wasn't vested at no fault of my own.
column14: Invest in your talent and retain them. Everyone I talk to has done a stint at GE and gladly left.

column12: Ge allows movement throughout the company easily. Moving to different locations is not hard to do. Lots of options throughtout the world.
column13: They make short term decisions that bite them in the @ss. Very quick to reduce headcount to meet a yearly number. Also global locations seem to be underperforming compared to US counterparts
column14: When making headcount decisions, use caution. These are people not numbers

column12: Big company with great opportunities for advancement, strong benefits and pay, and good management. Always a challenge if you want to take it. Great place to start right out of college. Company has excellent training programs.
column13: There is lots of competition for management positions, so need to really work hard to stand out. Can easily get engulfed in GE family and loose contact with outsider.

column12: Innovation, leadership, progressive, culture, vision, diversity, compensation, benefits, technologies, people and size. It's one of the world's best companies.
column13: There aren't any. GE is one the leading companies around the world in many different industries. The strive for perfection and achieve excellence.
column14: Extremely impresses with the company GE is today and proud to be a part of the future of the company. I would recommend working here to all my friends.

column12: Flexible hours good pay I really realy like doing this get to meet new people all the time and going to various locations
column13: A lot of detail work in photoshop, keeping up with all the files and then to have the customer only pic a few of the pictures
column14: keep up the hustle to try and get more clients and to keep said clients also invest more heavily on the equipment side

column12: Endless opportunities across multiple functions and working with (generally) pretty smart people across any business segment you go to
column13: Basic tasks and initiatives become monumental efforts given the size of the company and the perceived need for standardization across every possible process.
column14: More decentralization of decision making. Company was starting to move this direction as of when I was last there but, like all things at GE, it moved slowly.

column12: Exciting and motivational place to work. It has a wonderful team spirit with all of the aerospace engineers. Workshops to improve skills were offered on a continuing basis. I loved GE (Aircraft Engine Group), Evendale, OH. Further, women are advanced quickly.
column13: The only con for my family were the layoffs which affected my husband and of course the family.
column14: Keep treating people as viable entities as you do.

column12: Great people and culture. Top notch performance across the organization. Thoughtful on career path and presents real opportunities to move up
column13: As a large company, it can take longer to move up and can often involve living in a lot of different areas.
column14: Keep doing what you are doing. CEO is known to be one of the best in the industry and has always seemedto be a thoughtful leader.

column12: Good money, good benefits benefits, low expectations, This is a bunch of words because there is a twenty word minimum.
column13: Union runs the place, the work environment is extremely hostile. One of the work leaders makes the place a living hell. Another one does nothing and none of the employees will help to get them out because GE Lighting is union and there is pressure to lie to protect bad employees. Some employees tell lies to stir trouble and there are no repercussions.
column14: You need stronger less complacent supervisors. This mess requires extra effort and ingenuity to clean up and a bit of sneaky wouldn't hurt. Surveillance equipment is a good thing. Also, seniority should not be the sole criterion for jobs like work leader. Jerks get old too.

column12:
-GE has greatly reduced bureaucracy over the past 4 years
-New collaborative way of doing business
-Unlimited PTO for Senior Engineers
-Ability to promote yourself every 2 years by applying for other GE jobs
column13:
-Pay can be low compared to Oil and Gas jobs in Houston
-People change positions too often leaving voids
-Leadership organiztion restructures occur every 1 to 2 years
column14: -Drive a culture that reduces politics and focuses on action and work completed

column12: Great salary, benefits, management and overall atmosphere. I would highly recommend this company to my friends and family. Apply now!
column13: There are not many downsides to working at GE but one would be the long hours you are expected to work. Nothing to extreme.
column14: Monitor who your more loyal associates are that work harder, longer, better. Sometimes it feels like management doesn't pay attention to those important factors.

column5: Ive never worked for a better company
column7: Lead Agile Software Quality Assurance Analyst
column12: The feel of a startup without the stresses of financial limitations. Big on diversity, work/life balance, cutting edge technology- building the next gen apps and mobile technology for industry.
column13: I really cannot think of anything at this time, I love working at GE
column14: Research the tools you promote for building mobile technology to ensure they not only work together but work together for a mobile device.

column12: The challenges we get to work on, help solve some of the most difficult problems in the world. We get to solve problems at a global level and a large organization like GE provides the necessary scale to make it happen.
column13: The company recognizes individuals who can "manage" upward communication and are better at "influencing" and working the system. Expertise, execution and delivering over and above your goals and objectives is a significantly lesser factor in recognition and career advancement. Hopefully this gives you an indication what you need to succeed at GE and if you have the necessary traits as mentioned in the first sentence, you will be very successful at GE.
column14: Hopefully my comments in the 'Cons' section are self-explanatory and the management can interpret the advice.

column5: Worst company in the world to work for!
column12: Pay was good but money isn't everything! Enjoyed the work but not the company I worked for! I would not recommend going to work for this company to anyone!
column13: Worst run company I have ever seen. Very unethical from the top down. Cut throat management, they treat you like crap and believe me, you are only a clock number to them! If this company did not have such deep pockets and money to just throw away, they would have been out of business a long time ago! The best decision I ever made was to walk away for less money and get away from the toxic environment of GE!
column14: Learn how to be ethical and have some integrity! Treat people the way you would want to be treated. You should all go back to school and take a business ethics and management/leadership class! GE is the example of what NOT to be in the business world!

column12: Great work life balance, wonderful people. We're powering the world.
column13: collective focus is a mess. Lots of smart people but to many people trying to drive the boat. There is a "reset" at the start of every year meant to affect Q4, and it usually take the first 2 quarters to get everyone aligned; it is short sighted because there is no way to drive momentum or results that short term... but everyone wants to be a change maker. Everyone is busy but nothing is getting done...
column14: Start looking at a 2 to 3 year growth plan instead of constantly "pivoting"; just because it is a new year doesn't mean we should drop everything and shift. Keep people in their lanes and focused on smaller more impactful, measurable and achievable goals.

column12: Global, exposure, experience, top line employees, vast knowledge resources.
column13: Co-op programs are underpaid in some areas. Some areas are hugely understaffed. Brand management ideas are naive at best... it's only about sales, not understanding the consumer.
column14: Get more resources to marketing teams in some functional areas; get better at real marketing and not just sales. Have more processes and tools to address fast moving markets and business needs.

column5: Get out really talk to your customers and get rid of the senior execs who aren't cutting it.
column12: Great reputation, looks good on a resume.
column13: Incredibly political place to work, if you are not on the fast track, it is very hard to get noticed.
column14:
Talk to the people on the ground. I am in sales management, talking to customers everyday and its amazing the limited exposure I get to senior leaders in our business and the rarely ask or care about our customers or competition. Somebody else said it best, the company is too internally focused.

Company used to get rid of bad Senior Executive Leaders under Jack, but now they seem to hang around. Immelt doesn't seem able to make the tough personel calls.

column12: The leadership is by far the most impressive aspect of this company. Things get done quickly and correctly. It's a great place.
column13: There is not much I can say bad about this company. The only thing would be the hours are long.
column14: I would say to management to keep doing a great job. I am learning more that I could ever imagine at this position.

column12: Starting salary is good, the pension for older employees (which is no longer offered to new hires), starting vacation time and vacation growth, freedom to come and go as you please as long as your work gets done, freedom to take time off whenever you feel like.
column13: Salary grows at a snails pace, management does not know you exist, promotions don't appear to be given out on a performance basis but instead by nepotism, long hours, little reward, subjective performance evaluation system, senior management consistently makes decision that aren't transparent to anyone below them, constantly having to do useless hr activities, constantly have to take useless online training, constantly forces to do activities that reduce your productivity, engineer is done by a large committee (everyone feels they should be involved regardless of how small GE project is)
column14: Be more transparent, know when people are going above and beyond for you and compensate them accordingly, promote based on performance.

column12: Many smart people work here and are generally pleasant colleagues. If you are right out of school and can get into one of the management programs, it is a good place to start. If you are an experienced professional and need a job, then maybe this is a place to wait until the economy improves.
column13: GE is an extraordinarily bureaucratic company, despite the internal company line. It continually reorganizes (every year I've been here) so there really is never a steady-state. The company is investing in systems, but currently the info systems are absolutely dismal. It also off-shores a lot of employment to contractors in India, and many of these people have poor English language skills, and you will have to work with them.

column5: Program Manager/Sr Scientist at GE Security
column12: It was an excellent opportunity for me to work with strong product development teams to develop a new product line.
column13: The larger company mentality often stifles creativity in the commercial portions of the company.
column14: Try not to rush products to market, or start product development until the core technologies behind it are complete. As my former boss said often 'you can't put a timeline on innovation'.

column5: Severe issues in Platform team - Nepotism and Unprofessional conduct is common.
column12: GE as a company is good. They hired the worst possible Sybase rejects to lead the platform. If GE hires people with people skills this could be a good place to work.
column13:
People in manager positions have no clue what a platform is. 
Serious lack of people skills. 
There is widespread behavior bordering ethical misconduct. 
You will be *told* to work on weekends and not paid for it. If you don't there will repercussions.
column14:
Go beyond fancy numbers in ppt. Management is about people and not about a cherry picked numbers on a ppt slide. 
Address serious lack of integrity. 
Software is about human capital. Focus on employees who get the work done.

column12: Good pay, good people. Very nice benefits and a good team to help back up operations within the company.
column13: It's a bit cold in the the office sometimes. The thermostat must be broken. A few times I've thought about setting papers on fire to keep warm
column14: Keep on rocking. You guys are awesome and writing this review is giving me access to finally see the details I want about other jobs.

column12: Good management , challenging work, and supportive team. Flexible for internal job rotation. Good pay and good training facilities. !
column13: Not much to say about the cons, might be this is my first year in GE so I am still yet to find the cons
column14: Need better medical insurance.

column12: I enjoy the flexible schedule, and my boss is very hands off. GE offers great benefits, health, and retirement savings options.
column13: Some of the people at Headquarters tend not to respond to calls or emails within an appropriate time period, which is frustrating.
column14: Treat everyone as you would like to be treated. Answer calls and emails. Understand when things are urgent and important. Respect other people's time.

column12: Excellent job with a great team. Get to solve problems everyday. Introducing new hardware and processes and strategic planning.
column13: I will never be satisfied with the speed of Aviation. Simple changes can take months instead of days. Globalization has intellectual property and proprietary information challenges.
column14: Continue training and developing leaders. Stay with visual management and production standardization process. The growth initiatives drive focus for the value stream.

column12: This company is ethical. They offer plenty of career growth opportunities. The culture is supportive and positive in general.
column13: Less nimble in terms of responding to market needs because the company is so large and process oriented. Any necessary changes come slowly which impedes performance.
column14: Be more like a small company. Allow more control at local levels of business. Less bureaucracy would be a big help.

column12:
Smart people ...who enjoy working together
Committed to the industry and mission of the business
Giving back to their communities is a strong value
Culture with purpose and heart
column13: need to simplify more and take risk on people who can grow faster
column14:
Don't lose the great things about this business
Work on Simplifying and creating more roles that can contribute more
Unlock the collective intellect you have spent so much time hiring

column12:
Worked with great people - worked alongside with and learned from many colleagues who brought terrific experiences and skills. 
Excellent internal resources - deep knowledge base in almost any discipline of design and manufacturing somewhere in the organization.
column13: Big company - above average amount of bureaucracy - making change was often slow and challenging.
column14: Trust but verify - less bureaucracy to allow the leaders lead without unnecesary obstacles.

column12:
* Work with the best minds in the industry.
* People want to do the right thing.
* Opportunities to grow and develop.
* Opportunities to make a difference.
column13:
* Got into some trouble recently due to a lack of candor.
* Takes a while to learn how to navigate around in the company.
column14: Great products and great leaders in the businesses Keep up the work on opening up the environment and listening to all inputs.

column5: GE helps direct your career path
column12:
- Provided projects that added value to company
- Co-workers do not make you feel like an intern
- GE's culture is second to none
column13:
- No choice on position coming into internship
- Averaged around 50 hours a week during summer internship at GE
column14: Most managers have time to deal with interns but I know some managers didnt put any time into their relationship with their intern

column12: There are very few pros to working in TSG (a group that supports Aviation and Energy). The only potential pro is getting your foot in the door to quickly go elsewhere within GE
column13:
There are too many cons to completely list. The management has no idea what they are doing. They are so out of touch with the employees, it is borderline neglect. when anything goes wrong, TSG goes on a witch hunt. They want a name to go along with anything that happens. In a technical environment, things happen. Regardless of best intentions, that person will be attacked. 

If you have ambition to get promoted within TSG, it will only be if you tear someone else down. HR is not there as an advocate for the employee, but more to cover themselves in the event of a lawsuit.
column14: All Management needs to be removed and this organization disolved.

column5: I learned a lot about work and why things occur in the workplace
column12: GE is a great company to have on your resume and other companies love it. It is a huge fortune 500 company that offers a lot of opportunity. You learn important information about software that can be brought to other jobs
column13: The work there was a times very dull. I also felt that it was sometimes unprofessional in nature with dress and behavior code. I hope that in the future in another job I do not have that same experience.
column14: Make sure that interns are treated fairly. Often times I was very concerned with my position there and often felt that my boss would not let me do things that other interns were allowed to do.

column5: Invested in Technology, Customer focused and agressive in Schedule but Lean in operation which minimizes resources.
column12: Invested in Technology, challenging, interesting and exciting work. Customer focused.
column13: Too agressive in schedule with given resources. Not enough resources for load of work. Not very good pay compared to Industry standards.
column14: Provide more compensation/better salary to employees. Do not overload your staff but hire more people to do the job right.

column5: Lots to learn in a postive environment.
column12: There is a lot to learn. The people there for the most part are easy to get along with, easy to work with. The people are helpful and friendly.
column13: There is more bureaucracy and red tape than I have ever seen in my career. It is sometimes hard to get things done because of all the permission one needs to obtain.

column12: Made in USA or Germany, Electrical Equipment with Mechanical Tool Maintenance for Coal Mining Jobs.
column13:
I supposed that Elctrical So Many kind of type ( Ex: Power Souce has Electro Power Supply,,
High-Pressure Air-Supply souce etc. )
column14:
Usually need Parts Supplire must be Kept, and some case Urgent Repare case ( Keep the
case stocked in Any a warehouse within Spare Parts, it is the matter Very important.)

column5: A good place to begin career
column12: Diversity growth and opportunities for overall development. Emphasis on leadership and quality. Overall a good place to work
column13: huge corporation and visibility is a concern. Some businesses do not have clear path forward.Overall a good place to work
column14: Overall a good place to work with some improvements on training and mentor ship. train young talent and provide opportunities to diversify

column5: Good company if you have technical degree, but not good for other degrees
column12: Good pay, plenty of overtime, good people on the floor that you work with. The management is bad so it's very refreshing to have people that are down to earth and understand the struggles you go through, because they are going through the same thing.
column13: Poor management, too much overtime, a lot of the people in upper postitions are young, never worked the floor, and have no idea about the product lines they're in control of.
column14: Look within your organization for your talent before heading to outside prospects. A lot of us have degrees too, are looking to make careers here, and are not young students looking to add GE to their resume then leave.

column12: Company maintains the stability of its mature businesses while still investing in growth opportunities and changing to meet future challenges and opportunities.
column13: Too much focus on using quarterly financial metrics to grow in mature businesses rather than focusing on strategic opportunities that require investment and time.
column14: Push responsibility down to your regional decision makers and communicate your strategy/ vision and steps to achieve those goals with everyone below you.

column12: Work with very capable and intelligent people. Size of the company allows it to do things that other companies cannot afford to try
column13: Engineering sites are not in popular cities. Management sets up nearly impossible schedules and then cannot move out of the way
column14: Get buy-in from technical experts before setting up business critical schedules. We can etiher work or attend line of balance/status update meetings

column12: GE was a great place to start my career and learn quickly about technology. Always working on interesting technology and with top notch people.
column13: Limited possibility for career progression unless you enter a business unit that is doing very well.
column14: Work on retaining talent that you already have instead so there isn't so much turn over and retention of young professionals stays high.

column12: Always forward-thinking at the top-level. The company is working to become the world's digital-industrial giant
column13: Change is slow- moving in a very large company. Sometimes long hours. Management is now considering a change to variable compensation, which will better reward hard work.
column14: Keep on with the Digital Industrial push. Hire the best ... one good employee is worth five okay employees. And reward employees for good work.

column12: Mission driven company working in very diverse fields and quickly working to adapt the culture and management systems to the twenty first century
column13: It is a high pressure work environment and challenging expectations coupled with an intense focus on quarterly (or even shorter term) performance
column14: Keep pressing forward with the new strategy to make it a digital industrial company and reshape existing heavy steel industries with data and analytics

column12: It's a global company, if you want to develop your communication skill, it's a place to go. Generally people working there are nice.
column13: Things can go very slow in GE. It would be very frustrated, especially when you have to wait a few days for a simple answer, or when you could never get touched with somebody in the oversea manufacturing plant.
column14: Get people work faster.

column5: If anyone can do it, GE can.
column12: GE has phenomenal training programs/opportunities to develop it's employees. Employees are very passionate, smart and have great can-do attitudes.
column13: Depending on the business: they may be too many cooks in the kitchen and sometimes too many egos.
column14: Be more proactive in the current environment vs. reactive. GE is a big company and has the ability to do such great things and make big impacts.

column5: New benefits are not very good or competetive.
column12: Great co-workers, great training programs. You learn a lot.
column13: Long hours. Very political. No real leadership direction. New benefits package stinks.
column14: Listen to your workers. Some people have great ideas! Engage the team and value your workers. Listen to your customers. If you take care of those 2 things, the company will do great.

column12: Vast resources, diverse sources of income offer some protection during an economic downturn, strong development programs for young and diverse candidates
column13: Moved away from Welch's flat organizational model "nobody more than 6 levels away from the chairman" Leadership is insulated from customers and management is insulated from accountability vs. performance targets. Every organization has redundant functional leaders that are usually competing for the critical few knowledgeable resources that remain domestically. Short term results trump long term investment every time.
column14: Flatten organization, reduce the number of functional administrators that keep the leaders from getting/staying connected to the customers and staff. Stop managing to wall street and maybe the stock price will start to recover since they are the only blue chip that hasn't rebounded from 9/11

column5: Unless you are an IMLP yo uare out of luck
column12:
It's a big, pretty stable company
If you like it there and they like you, you may be able to move from one busines to another
column13:
They have an IMLP (Information Mgmt Leadership Program) program offered to college grads. It lasts 2 years and once these kids complete the program they are on the fast track to stardom at GE...to the detriment of everyone else. The result? Young people rising too fast and finding themselves in over their head with respect to their roles and responsibiities. 

This serves to demoralize the rest of the workforce...
column14: Look beyond the IMLP program as a way to promote talent from within the organization. This is the only way to get the legitimate, mature leadership you desparately need.

column5: I worked at GE for 13 years and always found them to be a very fair employer
column12:
1. Smart colleagues
2. Access to training
3. Opportunities to work in different industries
4. Resume' builder
column13:
1. Large company (sometimes impersonal) in the midst of difficult times
2. Benefits are under pressure (especially heath)
3. Have to be willing to move for advancement
column14: GE Capital needs to be pared back. We need to be a technology company again.

column12: Great name, not too much pressure. Lots of good people. Very little politics at the engineer level. At times some amazing resources can be brought to bear on a problem.
column13: Bureaucracy can be nearly impervious at times. Sometimes it may take months to get simple agreements signed.
column14: Contrary to popular belief, management should have some familiarity with the technology their team is working on.

column12: Office culture is usually good but can be dependent on site/business; market leader; ability to continue growing; training; gaining a good "toolkit"; continuous evaluation and ability to change jobs for those that are good performers; good people to work with and for
column13: Depending on the function, may need to be mobile to work your way up in the company. This is difficult if you want to stay in one location.

column12: GE is good at internal benefits for each employee. There are a multitude of training classes, learning opportunities, and adjacent growth opportunities.
column13: Matrix organization is very difficult to get used to and personally manage. Focus is heavily on the short term and finance drives the company operation. Very committed and aggressive teams but you have to be able to work and thrive in that environment.

column5: Good place to work very flexible
column12: Flexible schedule, good benefits including vacation and health etc. Has most things a competitive employer should have these days.
column13:
-little advancement at least in my organization 
-some managers were hired based on who they knew rather than ability, and it shows in the bottom line 
-little chance for creativity on new products as managers don't seem to understand the need to change
column14:
-allow money in the budget for innovation and growth (more than just the global R&D areas) as individual business have their own development and support teams
-cut management as the company is extremely top heavy
-require reviews for product managers based on how well their products perform on a variety of levels including overall sales, bugs etc.
-bring back the bottoms up review

column12: Great exposure to senior leadership with the opportunity to experience four different finance manager positions over a two year span.
column13: Very little work life balance and a lack of ideal locations to be based out of. Internal audit is encouraged following the program.
column14: Compensate talent based on market analysis and rethink Corporate Audit Staff as the sole method of developing the pipeline of talent.

column5: Cheap and greedy organization towards long term loyal employees
column12: Good company with good people, and interesting products that challenge myself.
column13: Cheap, and treat their long-term loyal employees like peasants. Management generates zero revenue, only looks at revenue metrics and their own gain, gets paid more and revenue generators (Real workers, somebody's gotta do the work) get pushed like modern day slaves to make ends meat. Don't expect a family with the salaries they pay unless you want to live poor.
column14: Spread the wealth to the people who have to do all REAL work for your salaries, and not the ones who do management's work (Again, management's work generates zero dollars). Defend our existence and actually do some real management of your staff to get them a livable compensation.

column12: Flexible, lots of growth opportunities if you are willing to relocate
column13: Work life balance, culture, hard to make changes, lots of red tape, leaders often promoted before they are ready- subordinates suffer...
column14: Promoting people has huge effects on the team that works for these leaders. I have experienced this directly. We need better processes to review a leaders skills and abilities before making them in charge of others careers.

column12: - It is a large company with opportunities to move around to a diverse set of technologies. - The benefits are fairly good. -Good resume builder. -GE Leaders of Tomorrow is a great way to network with fellow young employees. Travel benefits are good. - Flexible work arrangements are available to those with special needs.
column13: Pay is significantly below the industry average (in my opinion) for engineers with little to no bonuses. Work is generally focused on maximizing profit on existing technology rather than investing in innovation. Overtime pay is limited. Employees are encouraged to work casual overtime in office without compensation.
column14: Pay up. Look to companies like Google who employ perks that spur imagination and encourage group cohesiveness.

column12: It's a meritocracy. Colleagues are top-notch, and management has been carefully selected. I've never had a bad boss in this company.
column13: Engineers find it difficult to progress to roles of greater responsibility (i.e. business management). Salaries are low, and Erie is a notoriously boring town.
column14: Keep up the good work. The technology leadership team is top notch. Try to open doors for engineers to progress laterally across the business.

column12: Winning culture built on a foundation of performance, learning and integrity. A very candid and accountability rich environment. You'll learn performance management, collaboration, and a deep understanding of world-class business models and practices.
column13: Large environment requires go-getters to have significant capacity and tenacity to make a mark... it's doable but takes significant energy.
column14: Go with what you now. Continue the great tradition of performance and leadership.

column5: Good place to work, but expect manage your own career vs seeing a plan created for you
column12: management training opportunities, ability to change fields but not company, reasonable compensation, certain benefits are good (401k) but some are avg or below (healthcare)
column13: 24/7/365 job, accept it or look elsewhere, work/life balance is your issue to manager, not your boss's, incompetent managers tend to linger and may be promoted vs removed
column14: This about how to recognize and reward the pillars of the company: people who stay in their job for multiple years and perform at a high level, but are not really interested in advancing, relocating, or becoming 'Big Leaders'. Current plan is just turning them off and causing them to look outside the company. Risk to GE from this exodus is high.

column5: I love the company and the culture although progress is slow sometimes.
column12:
Some of the best reasons to work at GE are:
1. Leadership development
2. Size,scope & scale
3. Ability to solve big problems
4. Meritocracy - for the most part
column13:
Program graduates have a huge advantage over non-program folks
Pay is middle of the pack
Tendency to promote smart-people vs. Leaders
column14: Implement a 360 feedback process on all people leaders by their direct reports

column12: Promote/advancement is quick. The company prides themselves on cultivating new ideas and adding new blood with various roles. The work/life balance is good and the extra hours needed are made up for with the salary.
column13: Sometimes the GE politics can get out of control with things constantly changing on a monthly basis. Right when you get use to doing something they seem to change it.

column12: Incredible co-workers, high investment in employee development, countless opportunities.
column13:
Demanding - long hours, always tied to work, even weekends, holidays, and vacations.
Over-booked resources make it difficult to get answers and decisions since everyone is "too busy" to manage workload or attend meetings.
column14: Stop the glorification of "busy" within the culture and encourage employees to find balance. Happy employees produce the best results.

column5: Great place to work - very fulfilling career
column12: Work on the world's most important engineering challenges and with some of the smartest people in the business
column13: Need to constantly invest in yourself to remain on the cutting edge - it's not really a con, just something to be aware of. Lifelong learners with a passion to change the world will love it here
column14: Keep up the good work !

column12:
Great potential for upward mobility
Direct interaction with your manager on a day-to-day basis
Ability to work in 4 different locations in 2 years
Knowledge gained from courses taught throughout the program
column13:
Pay is below that of equivalent at other companies
Company is very stuck in the "GE way"
Difficult to make an impact from a corporate finance, back-office position
column14: Focus your recruitment on accounting majors since corporate finance is mainly accounting, not finance

column12: Opportunity to advance professionally and personally. Surrounded by knowledgeable colleagues and helpful experienced professionals.
column13: Easy to become complacent in structured "plug and play" role. Challenge to stay positive in an environment that is ancient and entitled.
column14:
Stay positive even when all else is negative. Listen to the tenured people and learn from their experience.
You are expected to work 24/7, or at minimum be available.

column12: The people I work with are really nice. I'm lucky to have a really good manager who tends to be hands-off, but is willing to fight for me, if I ever ask anything of him.
column13: The pay is average, career progression isn't that great. Most of the young engineers joining from the Leadership Programs are leaving after their tenure, and nothing is being done about it. It's a big company, so there are a lot of communication inconsistencies.
column14: Recognize your employees more for their contributions. There are employees who have been here for 10 years and have not gotten any title increases - they're basically stagnating in their career. Recognize that this is happening, and fix it. It's a wonder that they haven't left yet.

column5: Was once proud to tell people I worked for GE.... that ended a couple years ago
column12: If you are willing to relocate often and network with the right people, you can climb ladder.
column13: Poor senior level decision making as evidenced by exiting financial services at the trough, investing in oil and gas when oil prices were sinking, promoting renewable energy but investing heavily in French fossil fuel company. Slow paced, not a lot of urgency as ship was sinking. Teams are often pitted against each other, whether purposefully or b.c the org is so big no one know multiple teams are working on same projects, which is a waste of resources.
column14: Understand that the reason your brand is entrenched in the U.S. is because you were in people's homes and part of their lives for decades. By exiting consumer facing industries, your future success will be based on performance, not name recognition. And you have proved an inability to succeed on performance alone.

column12: I finished college and Ge is my first gig. Awesome people, culture plus team in my office. Can learn and have learned so much right out of school. Resources are there.
column13: Would like more detailed vision and knowing how what I m working on brings in money for the company. I am worried a bit currently about our vision but that’s only short term.

column12: Unlimited time off, but managers come up with their own rules and policies around this, so even though the company has this amazing perk, poor managers get in the way of it.
column13: The ownership for almost everything sits with the individual businesses, so if your management is part of the boys’ club, you can bet that they will always be protected and you won’t. Morale has been really bad since the structure of the company has been changing. It’s not a good place to be right now. All the people around you are either getting laid off or job searching. Everyone’s out for themselves. The no tolerance harassment policy is also a complete joke. The company doesn’t care. I truly, honesty feel that my manager could push me into a conference room, take advantage of me, and the company would look the other way.
column14: I don’t even know what to say. This has not been a positive experience for me.

column12: working at GE is nice because they are flexible (outside of a Corporate or high profile office). They allow for me to work days from home when necessary. GE offers a competitive benefits package.
column13: Working at GE encompasses very long hours and not a lot of personal thanks or monetary recognition for your hard work. They will get everything out of you and ask for even more - very demanding. As a woman who has been fortunate to be promoted up several times, it still feel like it's the old Boys GE.
column14: Senior Management needs to take the time to personally recognize people for doing great jobs and offer more financial incentives when projects are completed. Remember, a little monetary thanks can go a long way.

column5: Tough business but great culture and people
