column12: Energized, driven team of smart people who are driven to succeed. One of GE's best units from a culture and leadership perspective. It's a business that operates in a tough industry so you will be challenged but you will learn a ton.
column13: Very tough industry and competitors and the Company (GE) does not believe in/want us
column14: Keep communicating our challenges & opportunities

column12: Great place to start a career. GE demonstrates its passion to develop new leaders to guide the company and continues to display its strength in hard work and innovation.
column13: Management can sometimes be political causing much complaint within the organization
column14: Continue to teach and lead your teams. Look for ways in which you can allow your employees to develop while providing the necessary space for improvement

column12:
Big company if that is your thing
Exciting projects, good manager, 
Good intern socials and leadership program that offers a lot of potential
column13:
senior engineers are too senior...they are there purely for their seniority
and the company is too structured which discourages any innovation
column14: I really enjoyed working for GE, but it really gave me a impression that innovative idea will never find its rightful place in the company

column12:
- Learning Experience, ability to pick up the general understanding of the market
- Exposure to Management Tactics
- Great corporate culture and management team
column13:
- Fair Compensation, below peers in market
- Evaluation and promotion are subjective and not performance based
- Work/life balance could be better
column14: Junior employees have a high capacity to learn and a desire to succeed, they should be better incentivize to retain talent.

column12:
-Big company that provides infrastructure globally (water, power, healthcare, transportation, finance)
-Meritocracy: Best people rise
-Constant feedback: Provides regular feedback (often tough)
column13:
-Slow to change: lots of process
-Bureaucratic with senior roles going to central staffers rather than those driving business results 
-Risk averse
column14: Drive an entrepreneurial spirit, Reward people who follow-through on implementing their ideas rather than those who move every 2 years after making change

column5: Great place to be challenge and rewarded
column12:
- diverse team with great skills 
- fast paced working environment 
- fun team outings
- picnic day
- they pay for college courses
column13:
- company still learning the Houston way of business..... They will get there!
- often always seemed like we were working on the same problems
column14: Balance the staff with both experienced industry folks and new talent

column5: Great place to work ....must make friends
column12:
I enjoyed working with people from all over the globe, that being said was able to climb thru the ranks.
Pinch of a good ole boy company.
column13: When older employees retired , they took a wealth of knowledge and company could care less if younger group were up to speed. The push was faster ,cheaper product quality the last concern for some products....

column12: Building a a product (1.5 Megawatt Wind Turbine) that produces power w/o pollution, use of any fuel, does not contribute to global warming. Work with many wonderful and interesting people.
column13: A long drive from home (for me), the plant has been closed down.
column14: Many jobs for which a 4-year degree are required can be done equally well by many people who do not have a BA/BS.

column12: Great work/life balance and lots of opportunities for employees to get involved in projects as well as volunteer work.
column13: Has cyclical layoffs and employee morale drops for a year. Also, yearly performance reviews where you have no input on how your manager ranks you.
column14: Get rid of top-down employee performance reviews and start having real discussions with employees.

column12: great company, huge alot of ups and downs but overtime opportunity so sky is the limit with how much you want to make.
column13: No family time due to the amount of hours that are required by the workload, alot of communication issues between departments.
column14: I would like to see a resolution to the communication issues along with more appreciation from our customers who we have contracts with.

column12: Decent Pay and advancement opportunities. Highly diverse culture and plenty of avenues for career development
column13: Capital businesses are for sale. Not much more you can say after being told that you are for sale and will not be moving to the new purchasing company.
column14: Advice, advice, advice, advice, advice. No advice to give. Management is not being retained with sale either.. Will revise at a later date.

column12: Very good mobility. Great chances to move up or lateral for more experience. Coaching and continuing education are very accessible
column13: Medium to low salary for the skills applied. Very long hours (12 to 14 per day).
column14: Lighten the load so that people can see their families. The amount of hours required (and I mean Required by the Executives) is a bit much.

column12: Great place to learn about managing business. Very competitive environment and promotes self starters. Great mobility for those that want to change positions.
column13: Can be high pressure at times. If you are not assertive the job can be more challenging. You must be type A to succeed. Not for everyone.
column14: Keep up the competitive culture, it weeds out the weaklings and promotes a start-up mentality.

column12: lots of opportunities to work on new technologies and ability to move up in the company if you want to.
column13: lots of management change. Sometimes the management doesn't listen to their employees and force their ideas on you
column14: take a few minutes to listen to your direct reports. Your ideas are not necessarily the best. Make employees feel important to the company

column5: GE in KZ is not GE
column12:
- well known worldwide company, a leader in engineering
- very good career opportunities in a company with clear HR policies.
column13:
- unfortunately some of policies in KZ branch work not for a company, but for only a few people. And this leads to conflicts of interests, moral violence at a workplace.
- a knowledge is not at first place in KZ branch: you may be successful only if being ingratiating to these 2-3 corrupts.
- this strategy on giving regional branches more rights making them decision makers etc. is right, but without proper control I'am sure this is happening in almost every branch located in developing countries.
column14:
- more control on internal health of regional branches, including HR persons and their functions
- more anonymous surveys on aforesaid things, and surveys on a behavior of leaders of the branches
- more legal and financial audits, because violations of internal financial rules may arise as a consequence of a permissiveness.

column12: Good pay, good benefits, a possible great job
column13: There is a possibility on No incentives truly given to build pride or ownership in certain areas.
column14: Ensure or Train your new management personnel on how to lead and manage prior to giving them such a position. Putting someone in a position can cost the company on good employees leaving and seeking opportunity else where.

column12:
Surrounded by type A personalities
results-oriented work environment
they'll give you as much responsibility as you are willing to take on
all the benefits of working for a very large company
vacation is not tracked
column13:
no one to hold your hand
high expectations from day 1
difficult to maintain work life balance, corporate culture advocates long hours
All the drawbacks of working for a very large company
vacation is not tracked

column12: -located everywhere and ready to relocate you when you need to move. also a very stable company where you dont really have to worry about being laid off
column13: there are numerous cons to this company such as barely any diversity, horrible hours with no overpay, and no diversity
column14: pay overtime to engineers, need to hire a diverse work force, need to have more competitive pay, hire more people

column5: Global Operations - More Unfortunate Than Promising
column12:
Starting with the Inside Sales Team for Global Operations is a start into GE.
Lots of learning tools for all kinds of skills.
column13:
Poor selling of our services.
Poor communication with our customers, internal partners, business peers. 
Too many reporting tools and different ways to get information.
Too many business overlaps which cause more confusion.
Bad Data and marketing strategy are a bad mix. 
Lots of "collaborating" going on with little to no execution afterwards. 
Currently, Inside Sales is more like Sales Support.
column14: Get a better understanding of what your customer's want to accomplish by utilizing our services. Then strategize with them on what that should look like, keep regular meetings with them, establish and maintain an easy way to track success.

column12: There is an opportunity to learn something new everyday. If you are driven you can create opportunities for yourself and have great experiences. The people here are true experts and are more than willing to help.
column13: Since the business in this site is so old some of the old school mentality still lingers. You have to manage your own career, no one will do it for you.

column5: A great company to work for!
column12:
-Incredible opportunities for organic growth
-Forward looking/driving in the technology sector
-Most of the leadership is thoughtful and forward thinking
column13:
-Seems like you need to be in the right place at the right time to be recognized for advancement
-Leadership is not always as transparent as they should be
column14: Remember we are an industrial giant and leader in any industry we engage in; be resolute

column5: Great people , need to know how to navigate.
column12: Great leadership and training. GE Healthcare has many high impact projects to make a difference in the world. Great at execution.
column13: To grow solely on merit , takes lot of effort. Weak mid- level management and short term focused. Process heavy but willing to change if one stays persistent.
column14: Take care of the entrepreneurial talent within the company

column12: The people you work with here are top notch. The products you work on are critical to the entire world.
column13: We are having some financial difficulty right now that is causing uncertainty amoung some people. However, the company seems to be making the right decisions to move forward. Our new CEO is doing very well.
column14: Steady as she goes.

column12:
-Interesting Field, working with 4400 HP engines and comprehensive electronic systems.
-Training: Online, Instructor Led, Board Certification
-Benefits- Paid Paternal Leave, other perks, employee discounts
-Potential flexibility
-Salary plus overtime, paid holidays, flexibility, relocation benefits
column13:
-Glass ceiling- Limited ability for growth without relocating (depending on job location), 
-Customer Culture influences GE like a hand in a puppet, and fixed mindsets rarely change on the rail road, working with demotivated union employees.
-Employee's who have been static/stagnant in their careers or growth are disgruntled or have a know it all mindset, and makes for a difficult work environment at times.
-Low compensation for recent graduates and no cost of living differential. Example: LA vs. Nebraska has the same salary.
column14: Have greater transparency, continue to innovate and grow, make sure more seasoned team members are performing.

column5: Good place to work especially if your in the boys club
column12: Good company with good benefits and excellent training program and opportunities. The diversity of the productions and services help provide for added opportunities for the highly educated.
column13: boys club mentality and more emphasis on high education level rather than common or business acumen.
column14: Communicate better with the line employees so rumors don't affect moral so badly.

column12:
1. Excellent training.
2. Competitive environment.
3. Unlimited opportunities.
column13:
1. Opportunities usually mean transfer to eastern cities.
2. Some "old" divisions being sold or down-sized: lighting, appliances, plastics.
3. Presently Company is going through a rework back toward original strategies: engineering competency, excellent new product development and deemphasizing the financial element of the Company.
column14: Keep doing what you are doing.

column12: Working on solving some of the toughest problems in the world and developing products in those area... people I work with
column13: Requires a considerable amount of personal time beyond a typical 40hr wk to stay ahead at GE
column14: Need to re-evalaute the new healthcare system... very beuracratic and takes work time to resolve a lot of issues

column12: Lots of opportunity for job advancement; GE has offices in almost every major city; some of the best leaders come from here
column13: Some sites don't take care of their buildings; some managers are awesome but others don't seem to care about employee engagement
column14: Walk the talk - make employee engagement a priority in years other than when the GE Opinion Survey is distributed

column12: if you're smart and you fit in the company culture (which is gorgeous), sky's the limit!
column13: Poor work/life balance due to long working hours
column14: Acknowledge those who have been working well for the company for quite some time as they have a lot of historical knowledge which when it is lost can cause issues. Also it is less expensive then hiring external

column12: It is a great environment to grow your career. They really push for growth and development.
column13: Insurance is not the best. They don't have a path for hourly employees to move into salary.
column14: I have a wonderful manager. I wish more of management was invested not only in there careers but they should also provide opportunities for employees to grow within there current position.

column12: Great company to work, benefits and working environment. Fairly typical interview process, after passing a phone screening, it's a 3 on 1 panel interview.
column13: This is not the place for people who don't want to give 100% to the job. Internal competitiveness is strong.
column14: Keep paying and promoting for performance. That is the way to attract and keep the best people.

column5: Been here just a few months but it's a great culture.
column12: Great benefits - you are empowered and treated like an adult. They really try to create a work / home life balance.
column13: Cincy Global Operations is new so processes are a bit choppy in most departments. That is all I have experienced so far.
column14: I think your doing a great job!

column5: Good Company to work for for the long term
column12: Overall GE offers a competitive package for employees. There is a lot of room to move around if your willing to be mobile.
column13: GE is a very large slow moving company. There is a lot of frustration around process change and development. You are forced to chart your own path for career progression. Health benefits are average at best.

column12: worked with intelligent and passionate people
column13: Perhaps its common for service locations and branches to dislike headquarters in any company, but with GE there is so much red tape, so many mid level managers, so many people in the org chart between the revenue generator and the division head that it's stifles the work that can be accomplished
column14: trim down the org chart

column12: It's a large company with limitless opportunities. You have the capability and the power to truly redefine what you do, and find something that leverages both your skills and desires.
column13: For such a large company, I would think that the healthcare benefits would be better. Also, they're redefining who we are as a company which brings with it a lot of restructuring and layoffs.

column12: GE is like family even though it is a big company. Many businesses within GE allow you to post for many opportunities. Fast paced and great if you like Change.
column13: Big company so you have to take charge of your own career path. If you don't like change and transformation then the company isn't for you.

column12: The best sales organization in any industry. Well managed with a collaborative spirit. Many women in top positions. Plenty of opportunities to move into new roles.
column13: Because the company is so big it is very difficult to see a path to high leadership roles unless you start your career there early.

column12: Good company only if you desire to work for a large global company which decisions are made outside of your business unit. Training is awesome.
column13: Benefits have gotten less competitive over the years. As we move into an employee market, pay and benefits will become more of an issue.
column14: Block and tackle for your business units vs. being the obstacle. Walk the talk.

column12:
Leader in the renewable energy industry which can provide great experience. 
 Strong management teams and good overall culture.
column13: Can be slow moving and behind the ball in terms of industry changes. Compensation not great.
column14: Keep investing in the future of energy businesses and think about how to better compensate motivated and ambitious workers! Fossil fuels are going away, keep that long-term trend in mind.

column5: Challenging work but short-sighted upper management
column12: Challenging and stimulating work. Great lower management and talented colleagues in a collaborative work environment. Great salary and benefits.
column13: Short-sighted upper management. Lots of wasted resources with too many different projects, spreading resources thin. Tools and data bases too complex.
column14: Work on investing with long term mindset. Focus resources on most important projects.

column12: Challenging and interesting projects and smart people to work with; Good life and work balance; internationally renown and well respected company in the industry, good opportunity to learn new things especially for young professionals;
column13: Morale is low, very low; Constant drives to reduce cost, so travel constraints, and layoffs; Leadership is not making important and tough decisions swiftly; Opportunities get lost when no body dares to stand out, make the call and is willing to take the responsibility. From time to time re-org, like big-bang, back and forth.
column14: Two many senior professionals holding leadership roles who are mostly serving as messengers in between hands-on folks and key stakeholders; Need to assure employees of future of the company; reinstall faith and confidence in the company.

column12:
Best direct manager ever.
Great culture of personal ownership.
Flexible work arrangement.
Good vacation policy.
column13:
Large cost cutting measures and layoffs happen to often.
Executive management made poor choices and created to much manufacturing capability in USA.
Large overhead of corporate in Chicago that could be trimmed by locating in other lower cost cities.
column14: Management talks that people are most important but don't always think of them 1st when cutting costs.

column5: The best job i ever had.
column12: Amazing place to work, makes you feel great about what you do. The money is great. The benefits packages ensure you are well covered. There is alot of focus on recognition which is great for boosting employee morale. Bonuses are great.
column13: Heavy, Heavy Workload, fast paced...LONG DAYS.
column14: Understand that although we love our jobs, we love our family more.

column5: Entrepreneurial aspirations with a conglomerate wallet (and bureaucracy)
column12: Colleagues are phenomenal to work & socialize with. The business retains strong corporate/parent sponsorship despite continual challenges to deliver against expectations. Great opportunities for career development while executing in a difficult environment.
column13: The company continues to struggle for a coherent market identity due to it's legacy of acquisitions; after 5 years of integration attempts only recently have the silos started to melt and "GE" penetration taken effect. There is constant leadership turnover as the heritage managers start to fade and the GE-fed talent moves across the corporate umbrella.
column14: Dean Seavers is the most promising senior executive over the 5 years. The external focus revival is adequate, but deep seeded internal department barriers need to be removed.

column12: Good training, 6 month rotation, continous learning, classess, mentorship, young management, focus on training, core accounting skill, FP&A, project management etc
column13: Bureacracy, too accounting focused, bad managers from time to time, class material a bit outdated, a lot of rountine task/work
column14: FMP is a good leadership program, my only concern would be giving out more project based rotation, give out more exciting class assignment.

column12: Very good culture, and everyone is proud to work for General Electric Energy. Great benefits, and a flexible work life balance.
column13: If you don't get admitted into a leadership program, you will not be as respect when it comes to promotion.
column14: Generally the management is pretty good, occasionally you will have a bad apple. I would say just keep doing what your doing.

column12: The work was interesting and fulfilling, when there was enough of it. I gained a lot of experience with product testing and then reporting on my findings to management (sometimes many levels above my direct manager).
column13: Your experience can vary greatly with the luck of the draw with your manager and program. Sometimes there wasn't enough work to keep me busy.
column14: He's doing a good job.

column5: Finance types have run a once proud product company into the ground.
column12:
Reputation
Experienced professionals all around
Work with very smart people
Great place to learn
Great products in aviation, some other businesses
column13:
Metric driven--gaming the metrics more often than doing the right thing
Decisions based obsolete financial metrics and the stock price
Products that people want and value are secondary
Company hasn't invested in key facilities and product lines in decades
New health plan took away whatever advantage this had been in the past
column14:
Product, product, product.
GE has been a bank for too long and it hasn't served the company well. 
Reinvest in the people, technology, and hardware that made the company great in the past.
There are some early signs that Jeff Immelt has started to do this. I fear that it's too late.

column12: Good reputation, advancement, like the training programs and not cheap on conferences, and classes. company car, health and dental, good.
column13: they will keep you in the same place if you dont make your moves up the ladder, be sure to take advantage of opportunity
column14: listen to your employees to make sure they are fulfilling what you are trying to accomplish or it is all for nothing

column5: Tough, interesting work, with lots of opportunity for advancement and poor pay/benefits.
column12: GE recognizes talent/motivation, and does a great job of providing those individual's with opportunities to advance their careers and improve their skills.
column13: HR gave a presentation about how they aim to pay 5-20% below market value, but they make up for it with great benefits. Six months later, they tanked the benefits plans, which was basically a 5k pay cut for every non-executive in the company. Most of the people I know left for their spouses plan... If that was an option.
column14: There is a reason your top talent is leaving en masse. You need to decide if employees are a necessary evil, or a mutually beneficial resource.

column12: Good benefits, strong leadership (GE energy), Masoneilan not much comes to mind
column13:
not aware of any before I left the company (GE energy), they had just taken over Masoneilan, Masoneilan had many management issues, good old boy promotions, and "pet" managers on
speed dial to head of company
column14: Clean up Masoneilan management team, too much nepotism and "pet" managers in critical positions who are not really qualified

column5: Great company, great place to work.
column12: Opportunity to advance career, lots of mobility within company, good pay and good work life balance. Colleagues are helpful and there is a culture of cooperation (most times). Good training provided.
column13: Salaries are good but not great, medical benefits have been cut back and more burdensome on employee. Things move slowly on the work front, which can be frustrating at times.

column5: a personal assessment of working at GE
column12: good pay, good working environment, the people were nice and very professional, the facilities were well organized and clean, stable working hours
column13: The way they handled projects were very disorganized. Had the same work repeated by different engineers. Had engineers spending their time doing paperwork instead of managing the project.
column14: organize better. stabilize your work force and reduce personnel turnovers

column12: Huge focus on personal development. They take care of their employees. Not hard to find people who have been working here for 20+ years. Obvious commitment to integrity. People are typically nice and respectful
column13: Bureaucracy can be a problem for getting things done. You are part of a massive corporation. Not a very agile environment

column12:
GE has a great culture of sharing knowledge. 
You can reach out to any GE Employee across the globe and they are usually forthcoming and happy to help you.
column13: Since GE is a very large organization, there are well established processes in place which do often slowdown work. But we now have an Anti-Bureaucracy board which hopefully helps eliminate red tape.

column12: Competitive pay and flexible schedule; great office location; variety of engagements to work on; great tuition reimbursement and certification incentives
column13: lack of coordination with other teams and businesses; business strategy and process always changing leading to a lack of consistency
column14: I do not understand what management I should be giving advice to in this question. Management of the company or potential managers?

column12: Flexible and autonomous role. Ability to set your own schedule and priorities. No shortage of challenges to overcome and problems to solve. Never boring.
column13: Big, matrixed company with constant organizational change. Makes communication and accountability difficult. National/global initiatives rarely tailored to regional markets.
column14: Action simplification, particularly around HR events. Pay regional market rate for skilled labor.

column12: Seems to be stable,for now,not predictable.Decent pay and work hours are decent.Some room for advancement.Safety conscious and provides all equipment required.
column13: The opportunities for advancement is very limited,right timing required.Some employees are abrasive just need to block them out.
column14: Although some of the employees are the ones doing the work,it will be nice if management will actually know the processes,to prevent them from rolling over you.

column12: Flexible hours/vacation and encourages work/life balence (at least under exec level), some very good and innovative managers, a lot of very good coworkers, challenging the status quo is seen as good, lots of career paths are open, the company is growing and seems to be positioned for really good growth in the future
column13: Politics between businesses and management, selfish ambition in some employees

column12: Every engineer is talented and efficient. The experience of teamwork is excellent. Very good work environment, Very good management.
column13: Although the salary is relatively goof at first, salary increase is very slow. There is too much pressure for new graduates here.
column14: Mangers should pay more attention to the new ideas and creativities. Keep innovating and focusing on the customers. keep focusing on motivating employees.

column12: Can do alot of overtimes so you can make quite a lot of money. Generally a repeat process so it pretty easy.
column13: Is demanding in the area of time management. You have to have ability to stand for a long time in the lab.
column14: Get someone responsible for disposing lab waste products. Most of the time, they are left piled up in a container.

column12: GE is a good company that offeres 401k, health benefits with employee contributions. The employees that are the worker bees were amazing sons we treated each other like family. Sakary was good hit you certainly worked for it which is perfectly the norm in any large corporation.
column13: The management team had adgendas of their own. Good managers lead and I felt this was not so in the capacity in which I was employed. If you weren't in the circle of the management group you were not shown the respect. Do more with less.
column14: Treat the workers who are getting the job done with respect and acknowledge their hard work. Try to look beyond their own agenda for only them will the success of the entire organization flourish

column5: Join GE as a freshman in collage (internship) and become part of the leadership programs
column12:
Sky is the limit for those who keep nose to the grindstone.

Started off as an hourly production employee and believe I may make Senior pay band in my career here.

Culture is changing mostly for the good.
column13:
Lack of communications between the teams most of the time.

Middle and upper management are always changing.

column12: GE has great benefits including vacation, 401K, health ins. They offer challenging opportunity for management and travel.
column13: The culture does not work. As a manager, you cannot hold employees accountable to meet their deliverables and you are forced to meet the deadlines yourself. GE pushes with promises to get results from you and then cuts you right before the benefits would pay off.
column14: Let managers do their jobs. Stop letting inexperienced HR staff control performance. Staff does not need unlimited time off. If you did that on the assembly lines, you would not produce your product. If you have to give everyone a trophy for showing up to work - you are recruiting the wrong type of people.

column12: The company culture can influence everyone who works for.
column13: There are a lot of challenges. You need to deal with all kinds problems including technical, communication and your icon among your colleagues.
column14: 5 sigma is a good tool, but it only focuses on how to solve the problem, rather than which problem should be solved. I suggested management to use TOC instead.

column12: It is a very large facility where you are able to use your experience and training to good use and your efforts are appreciated by management. Plenty of advancement opportunities into other areas where you can learn more.
column13: It is a very large facility with a combative union environment. Most buildings very cold in the winter and hot in the summer, nothing major.

column12: Lots of training opportunities. The leadership programs are superb at getting top talent recognized and promoted. You can get involved in high profile projects fairly quickly if you're talented and persistent enough.
column13: Pay is "competitive", which means they pay only enough to keep you, but not as much as competitors. It's always a little weird when people hired after you, with no experience, are paid more than you with two years experience.
column14: There's a lot of senior management. Too many chiefs and not enough indians. I think the company is turning into a company of executives, with no actual people left to do things, like design and test. All that is outsourced now.

column12: There are great opportunities for future advancement in the company and accross the world. This company offers excellent benefits. There are plenty of challenges to engage the staff in interesting programs.
column13: It is a large company so you have to deal with the somewhat slow pace and bureaucracy.
column14: My advice to senior management would be to focus on major areas for improvement.

column5: Great name for the resume when you have to find a job that will actually pay
column12: GE is know for creating world class leaders, and they have grat programs for Six Sigma, and Lean Management. They have lots of benefits including great prices on second rate appliances. You get great recognition on your resume.
column13: If you are not in the right GE business you don't get the right programs. The do not pay well at all. Salary is almost always in the lower quartile unless executive band. Pay Pay Pay. They do not reward hard work and career bands are deceptively wide so a big move if in the same career band does not provide any benefit.
column14: Fairly compensate employees

column5: Great place to learn the ropes, but has all the general frustrations of a large conglomerate.
column12: Great cross-business exposure, ability to interact with many different industries. solid managerial atmosphere.
column13: very large organization with many partitions that often make it a frustrating place to work. However, therein also lie the benefits of having a large network and many opportunities around you.
column14: keep on keeping on.

column12: Who wouldn't want to work on locomotives? Opportunity to see all systems, work with engineering, manufacturing and field service. The job was always interesting. The technology is progressing rapidly. This job was seriously fun at times.
column13: Oppressive work environment, excessive demands, grueling schedules, understaffed. Weekends? Yeah right... Managers with no apparent qualifications promoted. "Diversity" hiring to the extreme. Recent foreign grads hired over much more qualified American workers. Zero appreciation for what you just did, what will you do for them tomorrow? (And it better be done TOMORROW!)
column14: Hire enough people, set realistic goals, let people have a life. Hire the best people regardless of any diversity quotas they may fill, and stop the H1B abuse.

column12: Bright people, casual work environment stimulates productivity. You are encouraged to utilize your existing skills and opportunities exist to learn new ones (if you can find the time!)
column13: Long hours, too many meetings and excessively complicated and non-intuitive workflows needed to accomplish simple tasks. Health benefits are inferior and are a disservice to all the hardworking employees. Cumbersome and ineffective performance evaluation process that really boils down to what your supervisor thinks,rather than any true objective metric.
column14: Institute a business-wide imperative to simplify processes and reduce non-productive time. This imperative should start at the top, e.g. no more 3-hour "all-hands" conferences. Provide avenues for employess to give feedback on their satisfaction, including quality of their benefits

column12: Experienced leadership. GE is a big global player in the energy space (its technology powers ~25% of global energy needs). Company invest in growing its ppl, ex. training, leadership programs.
column13: Schenectady NY is an awful location for young and single people. Sometimes too much of traditional conservative and bureaucratic company. Little diversity results homogeneous narrow minded culture.
column14: Better location will attract more diverse talent

column5: Great if part of GEHC proper, challenging as a recent acquisition.
column12: Talented people, great tools, competitive salary and solid development and training opportunities.
column13: Heavy and sometimes burdensome processes, different benefits and bonus plans for acquired P&Ls (be weary and ask)
column14: Ensure newly acquired P&Ls are staffed adequately to both fulfill requirements of GEHC processes and to do quality work in the process.

column5: Good company and department. Benefits are good.
column12: You will be recognized for good work and also for not so good work. You do need to perform to do well as General Electric.
column13: Fairly old school management style; focus on short term goals perhaps in spite of long term success. Systems could use some updating.

column12: Geographical flexibility - you can work all over the world within one division. Industry Selection - GE competes in the Financial, Healthcare, Power Generation, Aviation, Consumer Products Industries. Amazing benefits, relative job security, average salary for the role and experience
column13: Based on the role and level of experience, people report making higher salaries doing the same job at other companies.

column12: The employees are the best part of aha working at GE. GE offers ongoing training both technical and leadership. They are always looking for ways to innovate.
column13: Can be slow to move and get things done. Can sometimes have too many leaders/managers and not enough doers.
column14: Management should more fully understand what everyone does. Really invest in technology and digital both thx people and dollars.

column12: great coworkers and supervisors, They help you on whatever you need help in this industry no hard feelings to the fellow coworkers
column13: job is draining, doing the same thing everyday. gets tiring and boring when doing the same thing everyday with no cell phone on working site.
column14: Improve the job ability to be more fun and likable when working inside the machine operator room.

column12:
- Loads of smart people
- In general, good attitudes not a lot of pretention
- Flexible work arrangements for mid to senior level employees
- Relatively good benefits package
- Big company, lots of opportunities
column13:
- Heavy work loads, sometimes understaffed
- A lot of organizational changes...reorgs every couple of years, usually involving layoffs
column14: Create more lateral moves for employees when there are limited promotion opportunities.

column12: Great exciting environment with plenty of helpful people. Projects were useful and necessary and not busy work at all
column13: not a diverse environment at all. the same type of person works at the facilities. different management styles were in charge of the same project making it difficult to see a clear solution
column14: be more innovative in created solutions. use the available technology to you advantage.

column12: Good pay ,good people good union environment
column13: Management bs,to quick of turn over in middle ,lower manager's that don't have a clue in what's going on, but are going to change something just so they can have their name on it ,then move on to do it again
column14: Tap the experience of your work force

column5: Great Place to Work. Work life balance challenges
column12: I worked in the Retail Finance division of GE for 8 years. I had the pleasure of working with a group of smart, dedicated and fun people. GE's main focus is it's employees, which is demonstrated through the many training and Affinity programs offered.
column13: Work life balance is quite a challenge.

column5: Good place to work for but who knows about the future?
column12: This is a great company to work for due to its stellar reputation and benefits.
column13: Unfortunately due to company restructuring many jobs are leaving or atleast changing in scope and location.
column14: Do not fix what is not broken. There is no reason to so massively restructure a great company.

column12: Personable and even-handed management, looking out for their people when they can. Reasonable benefits. Lots of opportunity to move within the company. Challenging, meaningful technical work with top-notch colleagues, cooperative environment.
column13: Looking for aggressive youngsters, so the quiet capable are frequently overlooked. "Gig" work is becoming more common.
column14: Develop more efficient processes for moving good people to emergent needs.

column12: Challenging but flexible work schedule. If you're a self-starter and enjoys independence, and is also ambitious, then this is a good company.
column13: Big company, currently still transitioning in Power Services group. Lots of middle managers. Benefits are okay but not great.
column14: Don't take guys that have been in the company for 10+ years for granted. Should always consider life and work balance.

column12: Investment in training their employees. Lots of change all the time. Doesn't get boring! Culture is changing. Becoming more of a modern company.
column13: Not a lot of opportunity for raises. Outside of company experience valued above internal for wage decisions.
column14: Promote and give raises from within. Ge should catch up with the notion that in company experience is very valuable.

column5: Lot of opportunities to learn and grow
column12:
-Challenging Work
-Good Work Life Balance
-Strong ethics and integrity 
-Genuine Support for affinity groups.
-Good career growth opportunity for engineering.
column13:
-Matrix Organization
-Slow to change
-Drop in respect for technology talent 
-Extreme focus on bean counting and off late finance runs the company.
column14: Need lesser levels as new initiatives end up getting broken eventually at one of the lower levels despite company direction.

column12: They try harder the most companies to place employees elsewhere in the company during layoffs and take interest rehiring laid off employees first.
column13: No longer filled with brilliant technical staff like it was five years ago. What I especially do not like is they engage in unconstitutional hiring practices. They sign contracts with recruiters that prevent them from recruiting any GE employee no matter how long the employee has been there. Even if the recruiter has never worked with said employee. Product managers and technical product managers have limited leadership skills. In many companies that may not be terrible but at GE they are put in a position where it causes all sorts of problems.
column14: Work on leadership skills of TPMS and Product Owners.

column5: Old ways are the best ways
column12: PTO was great. VERY laid back, nothing was done in a rush. The people were great, never had any problems with anyone. Starting pay was good.
column13: Management flat refuses to embrace new ideas and technology. Raises were a joke, I averaged 0.7% a year over 3 years. Two types of managers, the old guard that is dug in on how they do things and the new hire college kids that have not a clue what is really happening. Managers move around every 2 years, no constancy.
column14: Just because they have a degree doesn't mean they make good engineers. And just because someone does not have a degree doesn't mean they can't contribute.

column12: Great local atmosphere - lots of activities, free snacks, good people
column13: Business is in flux constantly. C-Suite does little to communicate down and when they do, its in cryptic chunks.
column14: Talk real talk with the employees. We know the company is in shambles, but let the troops know what really is going on.

column12:
Compensation and benefits are above average. GE looks great on the resume.
It offers a great opportunity to college graduates and younger employees.
column13:
Communication from management is poor. Employees are pretty much kept in the dark about what the strategic direction is. Overall employee morale is low. 
GE is very quick to eliminate jobs, definitely too reactive. Training opportunities are rare. Everything is budget-driven. GE needs to learn to invest in the company, and to focus less on cutting costs.
column14: Be more considerate of employees, and remember that they have lives outside of the office. Focus on longer term objectives. Be willing to invest more money in process improvements and employee training.

column12: Good company to work for. Very nice colleagues. Nice Benefit package along with close location for commute. Enjoy my time there
column13: It is a well run company but the stock price isn't that great. I think it might be better if the economy was better.
column14: GE needs to get away from finance. Finance should focus on internal finance than external. Leave that to the banks.

column12: What a turn around from our days as Tyco. This company went thru many tough times as Tyco/Lucent, and as Lineage it shed many of it's bad habits.
column13: Very few down sides. The company is driven by the Finance dept., but this has not caused undo hardship to the daily operations, and has resulted in an extremely healthy financial position for Lineage.

column12: Easy to get a different experience without changing companies. Full pay for Graduate school. Older employees have hard-to-beat benefits: matching 401K, pension.
column13:
You have to work the system to get better than average salary.
Younger workers get the worst health plan available and poor pension.
column14: It's apparent that the strategy is to off-shore the Engineering staff.

column5: Great people that make up the company, but bureacratic processes.
column12:
- great businesses built for the future
- strong quality of co-workers
- constant acquisitions which provide personal growth opportunities
- good compensation for strong performers
- fantastic personal development opportunities both skill set and learning/training
column13:
- I work 10-12 hours a day with frequent weekend "catch-up"
- email is incessant... there are very few admins so you have to balance strategy with tactical
- the better you perform the more you get until you leave while poorer performers in the same job/band fly under the radar without much repercussion
column14: GE has become overly matrixed and bureaucratic - too many approvals, tie-offs across multiple lines of business and regions while not enough holding people accountable for delivering for our customers and shareholders.

column12:
-Big roles (Opportunities to lead massive implementations)
-Unique opportunities (how many companies can make a jet engine, turbine, etc?)
-Leadership development 
-Training opportunities
column13: GE is a very large company...this is both good and bad. Because it is so large there is a lot of red tape. Also there are limited salary increases.
column14: Treat your employees well. Give them competitive salaries.

column12: Great resources, diverse people, flexibility of work hours, locations, good training & leadership classes
column13: Highly bureaucratic, extreme focus on profit margin - struggle to get support for projects not tied directly to bottom line, lots of focus on cost-cutting - stifles creativity, changes to organization are not communicated well to those outside of upper management
column14: Be more open about organizational changes

column5: Corporate Cyber Security - Great roles and technology but poorly organized and biased management
column12: Good to work for such a large a diverse company. Company updates are interesting. Cyber security roles are challenging and some of the technology is good.
column13: Very buttoned down work environment. Corporate culture is ruthless! Not a fun place to work. Expectations are set too high. Very political work environment. Affirmative Action Plan for women in management is in full swing. Managers are so worried about clawing their way to the top, they step on employees and contractors whenever they can.
column14: Some changes in management have already been made through attrition and reassignments. Maybe someday they will all get on the same page. In the meantime, employees will suffer. The better leaders left for better jobs in other companies already, that says something about the opportunities and people wanting to stay there!!!

column5: It's a good company to work.
column12: Lots of opportunities. Networking is key to grow in the company. Delivery and organizational skills are recognized across the company. Very good relocation package.
column13: At times you may feel, you would need to come from one of the internal leadership program to grow if you are mid career.
column14:
Ensure everyone has opportunity to grow not just leadership
Program candidates.

column5: Great experience for college students wanting to get a taste of manufacturing.
column12: Great group of engineers to work with. Co-ops are compensated for over-time and treated as full-time salaried engineers and given challenging tasks.
column13: Very fast paced environment. With the role of a manufacturing engineer comes the required work during non-operating hours (weekends & holidays).
column14: Some tuition-reimbursement would be nice. Other than that, great program!

column5: A great place to work, but hard to climb in technology
column12: Great place to work with great people. Great work/life balance. There are some people who do their 40 hours and go home but there are those who chose to do like 70+ hours a week also
column13: It is hard to climb the corporate ladder in engineering.

column12: Pay is OK I guess
column13: It's hard to believe how much money this company makes when you see how poorly managed they are. I'm an hourly worker and you wouldn't believe how inept our lower and middle management is. We never have parts we need to do our jobs, this whole lean manufacturing was shoehorned into our facility a few years ago and it made productivity worse- not better. If Caterpillar gets their act together we could be in serious trouble.
column14: Stop worrying about your job and listen to the workers on the floor, they have a lot of good ideas. If you only "do what you're told" and not what's best for the business, we're all going to be looking for new jobs.

column12: Great people and a great work environment. The management team in my section was great. I couldn't ask for a better internship. It opened many new doors for me.
column13: Such a large company causes a lack of communication with upper management. There are not many chances to make these connections so when they are offered, be sure to take them.

column12: Many opportunities and upward mobility. Great benefits package including matching charitable contributions and tuition reimbursement. Global company with many divisions. Salaries are typically higher than the market. Commitment to quality. Processes in place to help guide the new employee. Excellent HR department.
column13: Very bureaucratic. Staggering work loads. Continuous reorganization and layoffs. Finance and paying vendors was a very long, complicated and frustrating process.

column12: GE is always trying to improve, not because regulators are forcing their hand to do as such, but because they are trying to build a strong company from the ground up. Lots of corporate initiatives that filter down to help create a focused, strong culture.
column13: Health benefits are much more expensive (high deductible plans) than when I started with the company.

column12: New exciting technologies in the IOT space and work with some of the cutting edge technologies
column13: Very chaotic environment with management going thru a change in direction multiple times in a year. Culture difference between local silicon valley talent vs GE's established management culture
column14: Get the strategy laid down at the top level and drive it all the way thru to fruition.

column12: High-caliber peer talent across the organization including top industry training and benefits. Benefits received from day one. Visible impact on a global scale across the industry with aggressive timelines, goals, and revenue targets.
column13: Very long hours (many weekends and late evenings), little work/life balance. No telecommuting work options. Only 2 weeks paid vacation allowed until year 5 with the company, however, vacation is oftentimes frowned upon being taken. Very aggressive and competitive company culture, which can be both a strength and weakness. Being a very large company GE offers much room for growth with a lot of hard work and dedication, however, it will take longer to move up the ladder than many smaller companies may offer in a shorter time frame.

column12: The work is interesting. There are always challenging new problems to solve, technology to develop, and other stuff engineers live for.
column13: GE benefits are bad and getting worse. Pension is gone. Vacation is gone. Medical insurance is poor with high deductible and out of pocket costs. The 60 year old plant in Salem is maintained barely well enough to keep rain off people's desks. No joke. The company treats the site like we are all factory workers, not engineering and technical.
column14: You are lucky anyone agrees to work in Salem, which is in an economically depressed area. In an area with a robust economy, the place would empty out.

column12: Competitive compensation. Large global corporation working on applying cutting edge technologies to real world products that power and propel the world.
column13: Quality of executive leadership has dropped significantly in past 5 years as senior leaders retire. Sadly, the replacements that come in often have little relevant experience or vision and primarily seem to be short timers with the goal of enriching themselves before they hop to the next business vs. working for the benefit of shareholders.
column14: Adopt a more rigorous process (and actually follow it) with respect to management selection and succession planning...it may not always be that the Harvard or Wharton MBA is the best fit for long term company value add.

column12: Professionalism, training, company growth. I would definitely recommend General Electric as a company with which to seek employment. Many businesses and markets from which to choose.
column13: Too many acquisitions. My experience overall has been very good. I would definitely recommend General Electric as a company with which to seek employment.
column14: Continue to empower employees and focus on their professional growth.

column12: Great company with good 'bones'
column13: Incredibly talented people are being discouraged to work on long term goals for a number of reasons,including the emphasis on where and how they work. Please treat your most important assets like grown-ups. The office is a great distraction, but it is not conducive to deep thought. Google got meditation rooms and message therapist. Goals are often unrealistic so when they are not met, then those doing the actual work in the group must be rated low ("C"). As a result, many engineers do not get pay increases but of course the managers still do and get their bonuses. The Six Sigma quality program was used to take cost out of the business instead of increase work quality. When the economy is bad the management uses it as an excuse to freeze pay and make layoffs instead of figuring out ways to sell more. Etc...

column12: New office amenities? Location? Ability to network and a sense that once you're part of the GE family, there will always be opportunity for you here, as long as you can tolerate all of the below.
column13: Lack of structure, guidance, and training. You are expected to be a mind reader and "on-call" at all times. They don't tell you during the interview that required OT involves weekends *and* holidays. In over 15 years in accounting and finance, this is the first organization that has required me to work on all major holidays. Work/life balance means we will allow you to recoup your time later, but family and friends are rarely able to wait for a week or two until you can recoup your time to take off and celebrate with them. Almost everyone in the Global Ops Center in downtown Cincinnati is new. This means that very few people really have a solid framework of information about the organization in order to make informed decisions or to inform others in their decisions. I quickly learned to not take other people at their word as most are quick to give the impression that their opinion is correct without considering that the siloed nature of information within this organization makes it nearly impossible for any one person to fundamentally know anything about which they speak if it isn't in reference to their microscopically specific responsibilities. The workspace is touted as a collaborative environment, and yet it does not lend itself well to collaboration among team members without finding a meeting space. Alternatively, there is not privacy or quiet space for thinking unless you grab a phone room. Perhaps workspaces within each group would allow for more active huddling. Functions within the same business are spread out over several different floors and spaces, where having everyone sit together in the same space would make more logical sense from a collaboration standpoint. Departments and functions feel very disjointed. "Change is the only constant" is a favorite phrase around the office, but the momentum of change that is occurring doesn't allow for people to adapt and become experts at anything before moving on to the next shiny system or tool meant to "streamline" processes...that no one has even had an opportunity to establish in the first place. "Not your grandpa's GE" is also another favorite phrase. While I admire progress and innovation, perhaps taking some notes from Grandpa's GE with regards to structure, guidelines and foundational organizational processes would have been beneficial instead of sending Grandpa to the nursing home and essentially writing him off. Bigger is not always better. They lure applicants in with attractive salaries only for them to find out that 60+ work weeks are the norm and the salary isn't that lucrative at all, once you do the math. Benefits are industry norm - nothing to write home about. Employees must pay for their own parking (GE discount).
column14: There is no glory is making your people sacrifice their personal lives to come into the office on holidays and weekends. In fact, it's shameful. Stop drinking the coolaid and realize that *you* have the power to set boundaries and guidelines that will improve the morale of your teams and ultimately the center as a whole. Until then, you will have difficulty retaining seasoned employees who have been elsewhere and know that this isn't "just how it is". Also, be up front with people when you interview them and let them know your work expectations. The general "are you OK with overtime" seems a bit misleading as anyone who has worked in accounting/finance knows that OT is fairly standard at period/quarter close and will answer yes. Instead, ask "Are you OK working weekends and holidays when they occur during period or quarter close?" If my interviewers and recruiters had been that forthright with the working expectations at the Global Ops Center, I never would have left my former employer that truly offered work/life balance and excellent benefits.

column14:

column5: "I'm really happy sitting in a cubicle all day" said No one ever
column12:
Benefits are ok, pay is great (at least at Corporate HQ where I work) I get 4 weeks vacation per year, 50% 401k match up to 8% of salary, health insurance is mediocre at best, however I am one of the lucky ones and I was grandfathered into the defined benefit pension plan. 

Pay is typically above market..I will even dare to say that most people I work with are grossly overpaid. Most jobs here are low stress in the sense that you can royally screw up and suffer absolutely zero consequences whatsoever. Almost impossible to get fired from this place. There is a guy here that regularly takes naps, watches movies at his desk, takes 2 hour lunchbreaks and he got promoted and now makes $130k per year.

There really is a lot of opportunity here, but like many other places networking is key!

Sometimes when I tell people I work at GE they automatically think I'm smart.
column13:
Working here feels like Groundhog day (the Bill Murray movie)..not necessarily a bad thing, just not good either. Each day is the same as the last. A very mediocre existence. 

Now I'm no doctor, but sitting in a cubicle 10+ hours a day probably isn't good for your physical health or mental well being..but this problem is not exclusive to GE. Working here results in such a dormant lifestyle--my physical movement on the job is limited to walking to the mens room to drain the snake. This lack of physical mobility explains why some of my coworkers are the approximate size of a water-buffalo.

What is with people taking themselves so seriously here? I work at Corporate HQ and everyone seems so pissed off all the time! This guy sitting next to me thinks he is the cats pajamas.
column14:
I have ridden the elevator up with Jeff Immelt several times. He doesn't look so good lately...I would feel bad for him if he didn't make 400 times my salary.

Who am I to give advice? But if you insist here it is:

Sleep more, take more walks, eat healthier, laugh more, be grateful, do good things and expect nothing in return

column12: There are many hard-working people on the teams. There is ample opportunity to travel to some interesting locations in many positions, since they are truly an international business. Because the work load it is often so challenging, it gives an individual opportunities for personal growth, so long as one can keep it together mentally without feeling defeated.
column13:
There are many disconnects between employees and management, as well as between groups/ departments. 

As an engineering project manager, we were often placed in a failure situation without any real opportunity to succeed. For example, business reps and project managers would aggressively court customers (they are incentivized by bonuses), promising highly unrealistic delivery dates and prices, and once a deal is signed they would simply throw it over the fence for engineering to "figure it out". Many projects start in this way, far over budget and behind schedule from the start. It is almost as if projects are planned to fail from the start, but just by a little bit. In this manner, they are able to squeeze every ounce of energy and motivation from the teams, knowing that if the team fails to mitigate the problems sufficiently that they will be held accountable and fired. Along these lines, the customer is often delivered a 90% mature product, with known flaws, and then later pressured by the commercial reps and legal teams into signing maintenance contracts or additional services to fix these problems that are usually well known by GE

Regarding management and executive leaders, there are some very strong people. However, because the culture is such that firing, lay-offs (where they immediately re-post the position), and disciplinary actions such as the so-called Performance Improvement Plan, are so common many managers are compelled to protect themselves rather than help their subordinates or others. Another issue is new managers being brought in to GE that are so out of touch with the organization, product line, and culture, but they must either blindly discipline or fire people, or risk suffering that fate themselves. I have seen a few very good long term employees (15+ years) get pushed out the door in this way. 

In short, it is a very rough culture to be a part of. In 4 years working at GE Transportation in Melbourne I never felt comfortable at work. I was always concerned about becoming the next scapegoat or taking the fall for something unknown or completely out of my control.
column14:
Accept that your employees are your most valuable asset, not hardware. Listen to input from employees at all levels. Understand that the complexity or workload of a project or task does not always correlate to how much profit it makes the company. 

Respect your customers and be honest with them. Do not cut corners for the sake of making more profit. Do not make unrealistic commitments to customers just to get deals signed.

column5: GE could be so much better
column12:
I've worked with various GE business for 25+ years and have had amazing opportunities, successes, and career highlights. I've also been incredibly lucky. 

Overall GE has great people. There really are no slackers, although you will of course come across sociopaths here and there, especially those on the fast track. Try to avoid them. Enjoyment of one's work at GE (or anywhere) can very much depend on the local team dynamic and the skill of the local leader to nurture and energize the team.

Vacation policies have improved, with Senior Professional Band and above now on permissive leave programs where one is simply allowed (with manager approval) to take the time off they need. Note that this works well when the employee is comfortable taking time off and the manager agrees with the amount of time off that the employee wants, but I fear that many younger employees may be afraid to take time off if they think it might make them look less dedicated than their peers. If you have any concerns, my suggestion is to find a mentor to coach you in this. Folks that have been around a while are well-calibrated to how much time off is reasonable.
column13:
Surviving a career at GE involves dodging a lot of bullets. While this has become somewhat normal in corporate America, GE was among the first to perfect the art of shedding large masses of people. GE makes proud claims of being a meritocracy, but most job loss events are unrelated to performance. If you are in a business that is doing well, you MIGHT be okay but even then there are too-frequent seismic shifts. Several times in my career I created amazing teams with clear purpose, uptake, and customer impact, but constant change always seemed to disrupt forward momentum short of the potential. Of all the people I've worked with, I would say that ~80% were pushed out for one reason or another. Very few make it to natural retirement. GE still CAN be a good place to spend a few years, but is probably best viewed as a launch pad. Finally, while salaries are fine, GE's healthcare benefits are pretty bad, and retirement healthcare benefits are simply not affordable (but most won't retire from GE anyway).

Note that as of this review (August 2017) GE is in the midst of significant turmoil due to: (1) financial under-performance; (2) activist investor pressure; and (3) change in CEO. It may take a couple of years for the new CEO to get things back on track, and I suspect the process will involve substantial change.
column14: GE has always had a bit of an arrogance about its management leadership. I believe this is a blind spot. Also, there is way too much in-fighting and internal politics, to such an extent that important decisions are made parochially and often not in the best interests of the company.

column5: World's most highly regarded company, loathed by its employees
column12:
Competitive Hiring Salary

Employee Driven Annual Review Process, called EMS internally. Basically each employee is required to do an internal resume of their qualifications, experience, accomplishments for the year, and your perceived strengths and weaknesses. Then the EMS is reviewed by your manager and your manager's manager. Your manager then does a counter-point to your listed accomplishments (or if you're well aware of your strengths and faults your manager will just agree with you), then you sit down privately with your manager to discuss views. It really give the employee a chance to trumpet themselves to management, but it is really tough when you're fairly humble.

Regular raises, about every 18 month for most employees, every 12 months for the "Top Talent" in the company.

Great Benefits, the usual health, dental, vision, 401k, and vacation, plus discount programs for company products (what does GE not make, honestly) and partners.

Vast internal job opportunities, with so many divisions and locations in GE, there is a lot of potential places to go within the company.

Ambitious growth of the company, that so far has been sustained for a few years now. Sustained double-digit revenue growth year over year is phenomenal for any company.

Recent addition of CTO position over Engineering. Having an Engineer administrating the technical aspects of the company is the right thing to do. Having an advocate for the technical people in the company is a great thing. Too bad this is a recent development. 

At least in the groups I've worked in, my managers have been very flexible with work hours and time off.

Strong emphasis on Integrity, making sure things are done above-board.

It's nice getting instant, positive recognition from people when you say who you work for.
column13:
Re-org of the month club. The upper management of the company can't seem to make up their mind about how the company structure should look. In the time I've worked at GE there has been a re-org on average twice a year. GE is one of the world's oldest companies, and one of the 5 largest, yet for some reason no one seems to agree on how we should look, internally or externally.

"Roof-top consolidation" and Outsourcing. I'm not sure what the problem is with having lots of small facilities, but management hates it like the plague, so they keep cutting facilities. They seem to either consider people to be disposable, or somehow expect their whole workforce to be so loyal that they'll move anywhere from 50 to 2000 miles to keep their jobs. Or they instead will just remove the facility entirely and move it to where labor is cheap, not seeming to care how long it will take to recoup the investment to move the manufacturing, nor the loss of good-will and respect with their customers and employees.

Lean workforce and getting leaner. Every time I think we're a skeleton crew, they find more flesh to remove. Whether through attrition or layoffs, each time people go, they're not replaced, but somehow we're supposed to get just as much done.

Far more outside managers hired than people promoted within. This is actually double-edged, because sometimes outside people are needed to break the status quo, but we need to be weeding out the incompetence, not bringing in fresh supplies of it.

We at least get regular raises, which is better than some companies, but with the 18 month frequency for most employees, the raises don't keep up with inflation. The only way to get a real pay raise is to change jobs.

Minimal upward mobility. Maybe its just my division, but with so many managers being hired from outside, it leaves no place to go up where I am. I expect I'll have to find a different part of the company to move up to the next rung.
column14:
#1. Stop with the re-orgs, just hold where you are and make it work. There is no magic bullet.

#2. The customer should be #1 and your employees #2, right now it seems like we're at the bottom of the list behind everyone else.

#3. Hire from within where possible but PLEASE fatten up the workforce, we can't do our jobs with no man power.

#4 Compensate your employees competitively, or they may all leave you, and all the tribal knowledge and IP along with them.

column12:
In working at any of the GE business you will get exposure to brilliant people that are very knowledgeable about that specific industry (and I am only speaking about the “real products” side of the house (Aviation, Energy, Industrial, Transportation, etc)… GE Capital is another story). 

Benefits - Healthcare benefits are great. Even though you make contributions depending on the plan chosen, these are minimal when put into the context of healthcare costs today. They also offer FSAs, 401K matching (50% up to 7% contribution) and discounts at major retailers and service companies.

Career Growth - GE offers a wide array of opportunities. With the right amount of networking and connections you may be able to land the specific role you might be looking for. Depending upon the function you might get more/less management visibility. At the end of the day any GE experience will look great on your resume and have potential employers drooling over your "great" business management experience/exposure.

Culture - GE lives and breathes integrity. I work in finance and can honestly say that in 8yrs I never saw an integrity violation. Not to say there were any attempts at it but they were always identified and dealt with.
column13:
Culture – The Company is engineering driven. If you are not an engineer you are considered a “backroom function”. You do not have an equal sit at the table when it comes to big decisions unless you are with a group of your own (i.e. Finance with Finance, Sales with Sales, etc…). It’s a very intense environment where nothing really gets accomplished. Informatin systems are just as legacy as the business mentality. In an HQ role you will probably push PowerPoint presentations back and forth for 6 months not really influencing the underlying information (it’s usually the same data with different cuts) but definitely making sure you appear to do so. We used to call this sort of science… “the art of chartology”. The Energy business is very bureocratic, slow, un-innovative and there is a huge disconnect between the HQ ivory tower and what really goes on in the field.

GE promotes the fact that you “own your career”… and you do. If you want to progress within the company ranks it comes down to how well you are able to build and use your network. “What about working hard and delivering?” you may ask. To that I would say “Never mind that! Focus on building your network, developing your delegation skills, having an elevator speech and identifying the right people to hang around… if there is time left crunch some numbers and send some emails” 

Business are reorganized on an annual basis. The main reason usually is to hide nasty losses and performance under the rug of a better performing unit.

Growth/Promotions – 95% of the elements needed for promotion are the standard ones when it comes to big bureaucratic organizations. Some of these elements are making sure you save “face”, be a master chartologist, know the right people (and kiss the right ass) and appearing to be a “doer” when you think you already are just to name a few. Salary increases are not significant (1-3% every 18mths) unless you change jobs and negotiate your pay in a stellar way. 

GE summarizes the qualities of a great leader into what they call the “4 Es”. Energy, Energize, Execution and Edge. In theory they look great but in practice they are a disaster. Most of the managers think that practicing Energy/Energize is intimidating the teams to do what needs to get done. When it comes to having “edge” its very well known that it translates to “being an ass”. Don’t take me wrong, I have seen people practice all of them flawlessly and be excellent leaders… but it’s by no means the norm around here.
column14:
Drive more innovation (put your money where your mouth is). Streamline new product introduction processes by listening more to the people down in the ground. Re-evaluate your promotion practices remembering that you are setting the tone for the rest of the organization. Learn to reward your middle management (not necessarily has to be with money…) after all they are the ones doing the work for you. Be honest with your workforce… you won’t appear to be weak at all and will really connect with the masses. 

FOCUS… you can’t do everything all the time. Basics teachings of business school “Resources are limited/scarce. You need to prioritize in order to maximize their usage” (btw… that goes for people as well)

I love the fitness center, extra events the company does like global community day (you volunteer for a day instead of working), family fun day where they bring in bounce house, face painters, things like that. GE gives out freebies like LED bulbs and t-shirts frequently. You can still get appliance discounts even though appliances was sold off. There is no more employee buying discount on top of the friends and family pricing however. GE also has a great rewards program where you can nominate your hard working co-workers for gifts cards or cash.
column13:
HR made some bad decisions recently. They froze all salaries for senior level employees for a minimum of 3 years (could be longer) to implement a bonus program. They did not give you an option to opt out. The biggest issue is the goals to get a bonus are extremely difficult and conflicting. They've also decide "co-location" is important. The problem is they didn't co locate people with who they really work closely with everyday. They also put folks from real offices (walls, doors, windows) into cubicles that are loud and distracting. It's a global company, so you are working with people all around the world. You can't hear them on your conference calls with this awful setup. 

There is no such thing as work-life balance. I've seems multiple people moved to new positions and the old positions now is responsible for two full time jobs. I was actually given three.

Supply chain and product management get blamed any time something goes wrong even if it's not their fault. Top management will talk about what great teams we have in meetings of 300+ people when referring to sales, but in the same breath tell them all how bad supply chain is. Because the executive treat the team like this, all the folks working for them do the same. It's never ending and disheartening. The supply team is full of hard workers who make miracles happen everyday, but are rarely recognized for those efforts.
column14: Bring back yearly salary increases. If you want to add a bonus, no problem. Do it on top of normal compensation. Focus on retaining your top talent. Right now you are alienating them and they will leave. Learn to listen. Your team knows what is best and is smart. Do what they ask when it comes to things like office location. Stop making decisions to help one goal metric that completely screws up another. Stop planning only for this quarter, plan for the entire year.

Where to even begin. Despite operating tax free for many years and amassing billions in profits, they shrink the wages of the future employees with a pay scale that lowers the average wage by almost $5/hr. 

It is also very clearly anti workers rights and does everything it can to union bust any organization attempts, so far as to allow certain "special" employees extra special rights to walk around the plant during work hours spreading lies about how terrible workers rights are and if you were to organize they will close the plant. 

It is the epitome of self service, in the company itself and the profits they refuse to share or the self serving legacy workers who seek to keep new employees down while they enjoy their cushy gig. A job that can never be replaced for them now, as no one else will pay these people 30/hr to sit around talking. 

If you believe in being a company man this is your place, though sadly with the lack of effort from the legacy workforce to preserve good paying jobs for the future generation your booty licking is now valued 25% less per hour. Same work though, you'll suffer the injuries just as hard, but now you don't get the profit share or the pension or the stocks or the trucks or the boats or vacations or 40 hour work weeks. Have at it!
column14: Treat your employees like people. Stop standing in the way of progress. Allow workers the right to organize for their efforts. Stop destroying communities like Erie. You don't need it all, you do very little. Management exist to help the people who actually do something. You are not worth your weight, be humble and take care of those who prop you up. Find a new company GE is sinking :p
