column5: A company with a great mission and essential to our world, but sadly with sometime poor local sites
column12:
GE does the most important work in this world and gets very little credit and accolade for what it can and does achieve. You have electricity when you flick the switch, you have GE to thank for that. Greener energy? Those big windmill, guess who? GE that is who!

A lot of talented and smart engineers in there. A lot of people taking great pride in tackling the challenges out there.
column13: No leadership and no career path... at least for the offices based in Scotland central belt. You would think with such a large group, opportunities would be abound. Sadly, no. Lots of silos, lots of in-fighting about budgets. Very rigid structures and frustrating "managers" to deal with. Some say it is because they are badly treated and therefore it trickles down. Well over the years, I have met and kept in touch with various GE folks (some managers themselves) around the world and the barriers I have experienced seem pretty localised. So much so that if you mention the name of the site I am based from, the reply from employees based elsewhere might often be: "oh, I feel sorry for you".
column14: Pay us what we are worth and grow everyone, not just the folks who like you and you happen to like or have lunch with. In other words, do actually reward on merit.

column5: Mature processes, trained leaders, unfortunate business situation (negative cashflow) impacting employees
column12:
GE comes from a legacy of being strong with their employee development, which can be felt already in the way how they recruit and the professional behaviour of their recruiters, HR people vs. other kind of newish tech companies where inexperienced youngsters recruit senior leaders. 
Also the have a great process maturity as they build real things that need to work and can not be test on their customers (think about what you might learned in business school about six sigma or how to manage finances... GE might invented and matured some of it for the rest of the business world in their long legacy)
Managers are not just people that sold something big and being rewarded with team afterwards. They are being tested and tried on leading teams and people before they actually do.
column13:
GE is still a very american company in the core. There can be a feeling of sitting on an outpost even if you sit in the heart of Europe with large business and resources around you.
The entire company was hit hard in recent years due to their failed investment into Alstom (power business). The ripple off effect is felt in all other business units, with hard cuts and head count reductions even for considered save and needed functions.
column14: Return to your focus on people. It is people that create a culture and GE had a lot of the strength coming from a commited employee base. Some of that was damaged in recent years under heavy cost cutting. If you want to succeed as an organization that attracts talents, esp the younger generation you need to be able to show that people are valued and not just treated as a resource.

column5: Best place to learn and build friendship
column12: Best leadership development programs for college graduates - FMP, ITLP, Corporate Audit Staff. Help to accelerate learning and career development. Great people around the company, with shared culture and discipline. Everyone focused on the work and like to go above and beyond. Integrity and compliance is given and reduces the frustrating company politics. Although many have left in the recent years, people continue to maintain regular contact and reminisce about the time in GE which demonstrates the impact of the company on people's lives.
column13: Depending on the P&L structure, regional teams with limited decision power. Slow to respond to market needs and customer feedback. Communication chain and matrix too complex to get things done.
column14: Drive LEAN across the organization, especially in business processes. Ensure sales and other commercial team members have the right amount of voice internally.

column12:
At Hungarian Budapest-based shared service center: 
Total flexible working hours, great team where you are really part of it, super-extra benefits: free coffee, tea, milk, free fruits, great working conditions, high-class office building, best cafeteria system (fringe benefits) with lots of options, family-friendly environment (baby-rooms), tons of company events, very active company life. 
Very great training opportunities, chances to take extra (even regional or global) projects besides your daily job.
They do everything to feel good, they provide everything they can in a very wide spectrum to sacrify your life to them...

column12:
- The people you work with are brilliant and highly qualified. There's so many true leaders amongst you
- Culture treats everyone like adults; work from home/anywhere all you want; expenses are simple, leave is auto-approved and encouraged by policies. 
- Travel domestic/internationally for work and training
- Great salary and benefits
- Dynamic and exciting workplace
- Leading edge technology
- Brand opens doors
- Ethical values and protection of whistle-blowers/compliance concerns - proud to represent the band. 
- Opportunity to create the role you want it to be and wear many hats.
column13:
- Slow to respond to market demands and change offering
- High pressure - quarter to quarter no matter what role you're in; hard to focus on strategic outcomes. 
- Risk-adverse and inflexible to everything. If it's not standard, GE says no until pushed to the brink of losing sales (and ends up losing). 
- Insecure employment; always on the cusp of being sold off, closed down or redundant. 
- Always bare-bones on human resources.
column14: I've shared this with my leaders before but GE needs to be much faster and more flexible with products, legal and finance solutions. GE is getting worked by competitors willing to create solutions for customers to get the deal done. GE allows lawyers and finance to determine sales outcomes.

column13: It is a company either in transition or on its way to be broken down and sold. Our whole AR department was sold (transfered) to a bottom- feeder BPM (outsourcing) company called Genpact or Headstrong. Through this employee transfer, GE got rid of hardworking employees who for over 40 years have collected and added to its bottomline. They did this in order to cut costs. Genpact, the bottom- feeder that it is, it is getting rid of us after only one year as they are not used to paying high salaries. They mainly function in 2nd and 3rd world countries and pay dismal salaries, with negligible benefits. They're not used to paying decent North American salaries. We are in constant contact with Genpact employees in India, as the company is Indian-owned and let's just say common- sense is not their forté. Their way of thinking is very one-track and don't see around the problem. Is that who you want to work for?
column14: Value your employees. Without us you are nothing. The bottom line isn't everything.

column5: Great company going through hard times.
column12:
GE always care for there employees even in hard times. Flexible working hours.

Companies believes, culture and values represent digital transformation. They have build a framework for working style which they call Fastworks which is based on lean startup principles. lot of focus on simplification and customer first mindset.

following are company's believes:
Customers determine our success (Customer focused priorities, urgent customer needs)

Stay Lean to go fast (Lean Start-up/Fastworks/MVP/Build Measure Learn, service of speed and teamwork, flexible and responsive to the market., help streamlined a process and remove waste)

Learn and adapt to win (open to learning and relentless improvement, fail fast to learn, remain competitive)

Empower and inspire each other (Every one is a Leader, Encourages everyone to share his/ her opinion or viewpoint to improve the process. 

Deliver results in an uncertain world (act with urgency and play to win. handle changing priorities and deliver results faster.)
column13: GE is going through hard times financially so not much opportunities to grow. We have many restrictions on anything that cost money i.e. travel for business, training,. too many processes and required approvals o get something done.
column14:
As a leader we have responsibility to coach people around GE believes and values which are missing in day to day work. I still see bureaucracy and people working in silos and only caring about there function. We talk a lot about DT transformation but is it really happening?
 
We can do a lot more to align our people, processes and policies with new GE believes.

column12: It is a gigantic solid company which is interested in both, satisfied clients and satisfying employees. GE will try for you to be healty and happy inside and outside the office. I offers varios programs to the employees to mantain a good helth, offers some basical medication to all employees to prevent contagious viruses to affect the work of everyone. As in every company, you are supposed to do your work and if you don´t do that someone will be afected besides you or you can even affect much more preople.
column13: Your advance in your professional life will be slow, as it would be in any average company. Because GE is not fireing people avery day, you will take a while to go up in the herarchy and get more responsibilities and increase your salary. If you are looking for a little above average job in a solid company your will be fine in here. This way you could raise or mantain a family with a good level of confidence that your job is going good. But if you are looking for something extraordinary were you could risk a little bit more and get better experiences, try somewere else.

column12:
I joined GE as fresher, I still remember my first day, felt very proud to be part of this Huge Organisation with such a reputation, Even though I am not working here any more but still wanted to share my experiences with you :

Work Life balance : I worked for Appliances & Lighting division and Work Life balance is the best feature.

Compensation : Its almost like an Government organisation and will give a standard hike yearly of 10 % at an average.

you can easily find many people working for more than 10 years and am sure they will continue till retirement.

Excellent work culture surrounded by highly talented helping people.

Perfect company for ladies and for those ppl who wanted to have a cool life with out much expectations.
column13:
Learning curve is very low.
Legacy system with lot of complex technologies.
Most of the tools used are customized ones working on those technologies wont help to get a job in the outside market but there are lot more things we can learn here for a successful career.
no need to comment on managers bcoz they are 'manage'rs but since I came out and got chance to work with other managers, I feel Managers here are far better in many aspects.
column14: This is my first company and I always love this company :)

column12: An organization of large scale and scope, that can bring considerable resources to bear when it is serious about going after any one market or solving a particular problem. When the organization gets behind an idea and solution it is able to be very innovative. Generally offers a good work life balance. Also offers opportunities to really learn and develop your leadership abilities.
column13: At times is not agile enough, takes too long to make basic decisions, especially by the management. The management can be risk adverse to the point of undermining itself and future growth and opportunities. The organization also can behave like a relic of the past and be too top down driven and this negatively affects the individual initiative/ownership and common sense of employees. Also there is sometimes too much focus of growing margins/profitability through bottom line growth/cost cutting at the expense of sacrificing top line growth. Their is a need to better understand the law of diminishing returns in the organization in regards to cost cutting measures and more focus needs to be put on customer satisfaction.
column14: The levels of management have grown to fat and seems the solution to many problems is to add more management when the reverse is needed, more resources need to be allocated to getting best in class contributors for marketing and engineering.

column12:
Great history, great future.
GE works hard to remain vital to the key underlying needs of this ever changing world. The vision is inspiring and well articulated. Immelt is not frightened to fundamentally change/exit segments once at the core of the business which are no longer aligned to the evolving vision.
column13: GE is a 'performance machine'. Driven by the quarter, at the operating level fear can prevail. "You may miss one quarter, but you don't miss two". This can lead to a macho style of management at a unit level, particularly under the recently defunct appraisal system. It's great to see the leadership recognise that as a blunt tool and are working to change it. Time and feedback on Glassdoor will tell.
column14:
In my experience in GE at a working level there is a GE 'type'. Let's say Blue personality types - e.g. like their spreadsheets and every thing has to be demonstrably logical. Many mid-level managers/ E-bands are Blue/Red, as above but with zero tolerance. Overly competitive and can have lower Emotional Intelligence. In my view GE would be a better company if there was room for the yellow creative/imaginative types - you need them but their not very welcome by the Blue/Reds.
If you are a Green - foorget it!

column12:
The variety of work and pace of change will arm anyone with a formidable set of transferable skills and an ability to adapt in new environments that is rare in any other business.

I was exposed to and learned from some amazing leaders and fantastic colleagues, who made every day a learning day. Some incredibly smart and humble people who always felt they were contributing to a bigger purpose than simply the bottom line. None of us forgot how important that was either.
column13: Fundamentally, GE is a risk averse organisation and has a system designed to avoid mistakes that would expose the company to litigation. The matrix structure, peer buy-in and multiple process sign offs really do hone your influencing and negotiating skills, but slow down the pace of business and can damage the ability to respond to market opportunities and risks.
column14: In the VUCA times we live in, with the pace and extent of industrial disruption we see every day, the Cons need to be rigorously and robustly addressed. If you've spent a decade or more training your EB+ leaders to run businesses, let them run those businesses in a more entrepreneurial way. More mistakes will get made for sure, but the scale of the wins you'll get will far outweigh the losses.

column12:

Offers Professional development
Large company lots opportunities to transfer to other business segments

column13:
Coming from an acquired company you are treated as if you are ignorant and a second class worker because you were not hired by GE and don’t know the GE way. 

Matrix system has some good aspects but it also creates tunnel vision and employees & managers don’t seem to know what goes on outside their matrix. Employees only see what they do and don't realize how their job functions influence other jobs in different departments. GE is extremely top heavy with upper management making it take forever to get something approved because you have to run it by 20 upper managers first.

Benefits are very poor – coming from a smaller company our overall benefits package was better and cost less for both employer and employees.
column14:
Trust your management teams. You hired talented upper management and pay them good money to do a job, so let them do it without having to get 15 other regional and global manager’s approval first.

Respect your employees and stop reducing what benefits are offered to employees with higher deductibles and more out of pocket expenses. I realize GE likes to increase their profit margins and pay the CEO & VP higher bonuses but now your greed is taking advantage of the ones who make the GE systems work. A CEO & VP’s can have all the great ideas in the world but without the worker bees your ideas will never be put into action.

On top of that after a while even if having the chance of rotating in different position the way of working for this company is similar across the different platform and if what you want is to experience different reality is not really going to be the case.
column14: Try to be more open minded to the external world being not only focused on internal issues. Sometimes great ideas can comes from the outside rather than the inside. My feel is that GE sometimes is a bit his own world with his own way of doing things and managing businesses.

column5: GE banks its success on its logo
column12:
- Looks good on a resume, as many people have said
- Flexible work hours
- Interesting portfolio of products and services
column13:
- Constant reorganizations, department name changes, and employee title changes confuse customers and employees alike
- Multi-layered bureaucracy makes the most simple tasks and exercise in frustration
- Most employee titles are fluffed up to the point where everyone thinks they are a "big shot"
- Fragmented order process confuses customers; there are so many people involved in a simple job that it feels like there is no central contact
- Everyone is always "busy" with endless required paperwork, but nothing seems to really get done. Things move at a snail's pace
- Employees who have worked only at GE for their entire lives are spoiled - they think they're busy but would not survive in a small company where everyone wears multiple hats and performs multiple functions. 
- GE product and service prices are bloated, not because of the quality of their product or services, but to support an overwhelming administrative and management hierarchy that costs billions of dollars to support


Overall, it often feels like GE is surviving on its legendary status and well-known name and logo. It is the type of company where the smart people learn what not to do when running a business, then go to a smaller company or start their own to perform things more efficiently and for a better price. They still make decent products, but this company is going to be eclipsed by other companies that are more innovative and less bloated.

column13:
Politics. It is everywhere but I think this should be minimized. 
There are people who are not technically sound and just because of experience are sitting above. They should become LEAN.
Management needs to become a bit hands on rather than being just listeners. That will definitely help.
column14:
Improve the recruitment process. Don`t consider lower pays and experience. People with right set of attitude should be hired. 
The recent focus on software particularly is nice. At the same time, there are many similar kind of projects being run. They should really get the architects and the teams together to have a similar kind of tech stack. And rather than being in silos teams should feel free to collaborate. I saw there are very few teams doing so but even then not so actively.

column12:
- You get to work with extremely smart, visionary & inspiring leaders
- Various training opportunities for technical or soft skill advancement, local & oversea (you will need to communicate ahead to your hiring manager)
- Great career exposure and you get to work across multi regions, stakeholders, subject matter expert from all over the world (don't be shy to ask for new roles, new opportunities). The culture within GE is, if you don't ask for it, nothing will happen. Prove your value, be a good negotiator and you will be fine
column13:
- Pay is below the market for local hire talent. Low base for fresh graduate (probably due to large pool of applicants from top ranking universities and the HR can demand lower salary for fresh graduate)
- Annual increment can be pathetic, ranges from 2-5%
- Too many mid level managers don't perform but still stay within the company
column14:
1. It will be very motivating for HR team to do benchmark and salary adjustment before employees demand for it or employees move on to the new opportunities outside.
2. Perform a fair 360 degree review for management level. There are many managers who are complacent and not doing much while some are working really hard.

column12: Good top management - the quality of leadership is excellent. The training received by top management at global training centres ensures consistently good people guiding the company. The research & development centre in India is one of a kind since such centres are quite few and far between in India as compared to the rest of the world. So for someone who is not too keen on cutting edge research and is looking for a fairly challenging job without core software development, it is a good fit. The work life balance, team spirit & benefits (not compensation which is very poor) are great!
column13: The centre especially focusing on research is touted as being on par with the centres in rest of the world - US for example. But this is far from true since most of the cutting edge work is executed in the US and only small bite sized work chunks manage to reach India. The quality of people is not as good either - there is a heavy compromise, due to abundant availability of Masters candidates - while PhD is a must in the US thereby ensuring greater quality of research output. Also, restrictions on offshoring work from US due to defence/security concerns prevent great work coming this way! The biggest downside is the terrible pay, where quite well qualified candidates are paid even lesser than freshly graduated software engineers elsewhere!
column14: Focus on maintaining standards across the world's different centres. Increase the compensation levels. More opportunities to travel to conferences worldwide. Treat Indian employees on par with the best across the world

column13:
Too many intranet sites, workflows and approvals for frequently used tasks.
It would take more than an year for a new joiner to get accustomed to the critical processes involved which could affect appraisals.
If asked to join a Performance Improvement Plan then its better to resign.
column14:
You have got so many standards and policies but you don't have a strict guideline to enforce a "Performance Improvement Plan". Like when should an employee be put under PIP, should differ for each role. What type of a PIP should be selected and who should review the PIP. You cannot remove an employee from a project due to breach of compliance and give him a project which is beyond his skill set and terminate him for not executing the project. One should be terminated for breach of compliance if it is really a breach. 
You cannot serve a termination letter to an employee and then provide a service certificate which states that the employee has resigned as per database records. 
How can your system send "Undeliverable Email As ID does not exist" for a Vice-Presidents mail ID who is in service till this day. The funny part is some times you do get a "Read Receipt" for the same email ID.

column5: GE Challenging, Educational place to work
column12: I've worked for GE for 10 years and I've been very satisified with my job. The salary is very good, the benefits have been great although they have recently changed. It's challenging and you learn a lot about business and industry. It's especially great for college graduates who can get into one of the leadership programs because they get exposure to many different businesses and leadership. I've always been supported in taking time off when necessary for my family. I believe that most management at GE tries to help employees have a good work/life balance.
column13: It's demanding. GE employees work hard...most more than the standard 40 hour week. There can be a lot of pressure to perform but hard workers are rewarded. It can be hard for newcomers to adapt to some of the processes and terminology used internally. Not a company for thin skinned people who can handle constructive criticism and demanding expectations.
column14: Keep morale up especially in these tough times. Employees are taking on more and more responsibilites outside their expected job scope and it can be a tough pace to keep up.

column12: Bar none the foremost leadership development organization in the world. If you are seeking to develop into a respected well rounded general manager this is the Harvard Business School for that. The GE culture is ideally suited for results driven, high achieving professionals. The diversity of experiences and challenges you are exposed to along with the highly-involved grooming provided by seasoned veterans and the the formal GE management training ensure a polished, sharp future business executive.
column13:
Rigid and out-dated compensation structures:

During the Welch era lucrative stock options and generous bonuses were common; that's no longer the case. Which has led to the overall compensation model for GE to be un-impressive in the past decade. 

Employer Brand equity not the same for the younger generation:

- Not in touch with "What Really Matters" for the younger generation
- This has led to retention issues particularly with the younger demo with 3-5 years of GE experience. People are not looking at building a 30 year career with GE, job security is ni longer a primary motivator 

Work/Life Balance

- Non-existent, ideal for some hard charging types but not for everyone

column5: A Tale of Two Companies - Welch and Immelt
column12:
- a wide variety of industry opportunities, in a wide variety of roles
- you are in charge of your own career (up through senior professional band)
- you get to work with and network with outstanding people, experts in pretty much every speciality are always less than the proverbial "six degrees of separation" away from you.
column13:
- glass ceiling, promotion to E-band (executive) band based on political approval, not competency or performance
- company now has way too much adherence to corporate ideology (e.g. diversity, healthymagination, ecomagination), this trumps sound business results-based performance management
- way too much bureaucracy, too much time wasted on corporate standarization
column14:
- go back to basics - reread and apply all the Jack Welch books, the company has seriously stumbled and lost its edge since Mr. Welch retired in 2001.
- bring back Welch's famous WORK-OUT process (to force management to eliminate non-value-add administrative overhead)
- cut the fat, cut the bureaucracy, give P&L leaders free reign to maximize the profitability and cash flow of their businesses...get rid of all the unnecessary, government-style standardization
- apply Lean principles to management and various administrative processes (e.g. customer order entry, IT support, HR processes) which are very slow and bring down the performance of the whole organization. GE is great at doing Lean and Six Sigma on the shop floor, but terrible at doing this in the offices - the latter is where most of the waste occurs.

column5: Good company, tough times... evolution needed
column12: Innovation, diversity, meritocracy (usually), integrity, broad range of professional opportunities, good leadership development (although not as good as it used to be), some really good people and leaders.
column13:
*Right now it's too unstable, but hopefully will reset/recover soon, I trust Flannery's intention and abilities to fix it*
Complex matrix org structure, sometimes overly competitive "internally" (when competition is truly outside), not the best compensation/salaries.
column14:
1) Implement changes ASAP, and lets have a fresh start, not extending uncertainty longer than needed. It's time to evolve, but employees and leaders cannot optimally focus and make good decisions when operating in "survival mode".
2) Beware about some "great storytellers" in some top leadership positions, who lack optimal depth/judgement... They speak so well and so incredibly confidently that it seem they have great plans/results, when that's not really the case. Those are the wrong type of "strong leaders", very dangerous since people don't see they're being led to the cliff until it's too late (not referring to Flannery by the way, I actually think he's really good, having been in several meetings with him)

column12: Good Salary and bonus system
column13: Lack of Direction from top

column12: GE offers great work life balance. The leadership team is miles ahead in terms of everything they do when compared to most other organization. Employees have an identity beyond being stamped as just a "resource". There are several programs to fund employees and families health and well being. Several events, outings appreciation methods etc. No login logout or any forms of employee tracking. All is well as long as your work is done, no one else is bothered about anything else. Freedom to express and give opinion. Presence of councils like Ombuspersons and Prevention of harrassment - these are very powerful and protect the employee from retaliation from manager
column13: Absolutely very minimal onsite opportunities. Pay is less when compared to other pay masters. Its mostly a trade off between whether one needs a very high salary or a good work life balance. Otherwise cant think of several negatives because i have experienced the terrible work culture in services companies
column14: Try to pay more competitively. People leave GE only because of pay or lack of onsite opportunities

column12: Good campus, Good technical work
column13: Limited vertical growth, Limited appreciation for expertise

column12:
1. The development teams are intelligent and helpful. 
2. IT team moves fast to procure you equipment 
3. Compliance team is very strong and effective.
4. Flexible timings
5. Nice looking campus
column13:
1. Policies depend on your manager. Some ppl I know got a sabbatical while it is not in policy. Genuine ppl in need did not, again because it is not in policy. 
2. Micromanagement happens from higher levels. 3-4 levels below the CEO is tracking every scrum team's burndown on a daily basis.
3. You are expected to be available all through the day. There are always calls with US. So there is no work-life balance.
4. Low pay to existing employees while they are paying a lot to the new joinees including a joining bonus (which is not a standard).
5. Very volatile management and each new manager brings in their short lived initiative and stresses out the working population.
6. In some projects, priorities change every single day. Commercial team, Product management and engineering are never in sync. So the development team is always stressed out.
7. Pretends to be a environment friendly company. Employees who take car lease get more benefits than the employees who take the bus. Bus fare are very high and routes are not good.
8. Sourcing team/policies are horrible. To get anything for the lab, even the smallest connectors will take you almost a month.
column14: Trust your employees or don't hire them. Micromanaging never helped any company succeed. Care more for your existing employees and bring their pay to market standards, else you will only be stuck with new joiners and no one with domain expertise to help push out the product.

column12: GE is a company that gives you challenges every single day, you never have a dull moment, if you're passionate and committed to whatever you do, GE is an amazing company for you to do it. It offers every possibility to grow your career inside the company both professionally and personally with a wide variety of courses and training. GE is a company with a great focus on diversity and innovation, they take really good care of their employees with activities and initiatives that cater to their interests... whatever you like to do or fancy trying your hand at, you can find an affinity group at GE. The company's culture and values play a key role on everything that happens within it, showing at all times that the company has a backbone and it sticks to its beliefs, standing by their culture at all times.
column13: It is a very demanding company; as everything you do has a real impact, even if it's the smallest task, the level of responsibility of all employees is really high.

column12: Work with great people, lots of variety and opportunity for advancement. Great matrix organization with ability to interact with top level management on regular basis. Benefits are good and management awards are a plus. Review process is lengthy but can be great if you have a great manager that is a mentor as well. Opportunties for community outreach are also outstanding.
column13: Work / life balance can be very unbalanced. The general culture within GE is to work longer hours. This can be hard for some. When you have a less than desireable manager, reviews can be difficult because you won't always get the mentoring you might need to achieve stretch goals. With that said, there are numerous ways to find mentoring elsewhere in the company.
column14: Find a way to make work / life more balanced. At times it feels like the company has become too lean. Keep up the great work with management awards - employees truely appreciate it.

column12: good to work on with bigger teams and other BUs always ready to support
column13: processes slow down the work, not agile and nimble enough

column5: Good money but you will have to work for it
column12:
Brand Name looks good on a cv. Other companies know that if you were at GE you were competent in your job. GE also has a mandatory fire 20% yearly of the workforce rule therefore if you last longer than a year other companies know you are good at what you do. 

The pressure is high depending on the role and current market status. As of late 2008 the lending business would be tough because of the number of losses that GE has to write down globally. This means that the expectations on you will be even higher to perform
column13: High pressure and long hours. GE also does not really train you for a position. They calim they will train you but in actuality the do not. Typically they through you in the position and initially make a bunch of mistakes. the advantage is that you learn quickly because of the pressure you are under. This will result in you have completed a lot of different jobs at a senior level whereas you peers in other organization would not get the same exposer. Get used to sleepless night though because the pressure will be on the whole time through your tenure at GE
column14: Need to give promotions based on qualification not on numbers of years at GE

column12: First in class leadership team and impressive corporate culture with full of respect, open communication, focus on ethics and compliance.
column13: Too much bureaucracy and levels of management. Most of decisions are still taken in US despite efforts of localisation, which is waste of time, costly and people cannot feel empowered.
column14: Still there is a lot to fix in terms of base cost. I saw this from remote location, where decision despite a lot of effort are made from US and related to local market. For me the ultimate proof is that still most of EB/SEB/Officer new positions are placed in US. There is still room for plenty restructuring including merging back office functions for similar segments in Energy. There is duplication of and multiplications of management layers, where many people want to proof that they are busy. Same review is taken first at local level, than European, then Global/US - waste of time and resources. Let's make structure more flat, trust and empower people more on the ground outside US.

column5: All good things come to an end
column12: A culture that enables you to be what you want to be and go as far as your skills/ambition can take you. GE has given me diverse experiences across the globe, in multiple businesses and industries. In the end I was part of the Capital team which led to my departure and whilst I was ready for a new challenge, I'm very grateful for the platform GE gave me.
column13: At a point, there are only so many places available above you in to which a promotion is possible - in the Finance world, CAS graduates often take priority and so opportunity can become limited. Sometimes too many chiefs, and despite the desired culture shift, many hoops (and associated work) to go through to get things done.
column14: Continue to push the start-up culture ... be positive and go for growth vs. continual cost out (but respecting that that also needs to be done).

People could grow better if, in some position, medium management will use more opening applying policies. This way will grow businees chances too.

column14: Generally speaking policies related to employees are really good under almost any point of view. It is true that business cases, over all in large scale, need to take care about risks but sometime there's a need to consider medium long terms effects (hear more from people on field) not only the monthly or yearly cut-off, especially in crisis times as are running today.

column12: GE carries a internationally recognized brand name and is a great employer to add to any resume.
column13:
What I experienced from the multiple years I was at GE was employees being over worked and mistreated. The stress level everyone had was very high and the sad thing is that GE created a good amount of stress for their employees for no real reason. The complexity of having a simple drawing released to give to a customer who is waiting on it is baffling and to make a revision to that same drawing is like having your teeth pulled. The high level of bureaucracy is actually a hamper to productive work that forces keeps most employees from making the improvements they need.

Additionally, GE focuses more on the negatives than the positives created. You might have done significant overtime on a certain issue or project but will have a specially created team dock you if you have a single miss on a drawing you release. Imagine how much pressure you have to release each document you create flawlessly each time because if you don't it will be tracked and recorded against you at the end of the year. Even worse is most times you create several hundred documents a year and the fact GE does not change their way of thinking on employee treatment is mind blowing.
column14: The HR I encountered at GE was horrifying. When your HR can proactively prevent you from having any advancement in a company you know it is time to find greener pastures.

column12: International, lot of investment in New techno
column13: People are moved, only number
column14: Interest on technic not only planning

column12: Flexible schedule, employee benefits, etc
column13: No career progression. Limited resources for employees due to cost reduction.

column12: Nice policies, Work From Home,
column13: Less hike, not a challenging work.

column12: Good to me working in ge
column13: Politics is there every time

column5: Prepare to sacrifice your personal life.
column12: Pay and benefits are great right out of school, opportunity for raise after every program rotation, mentoring and review feedback great, knowledge sharing very important across the businesses
column13:
Healthcare policy - now basically like car insurance with the lowest deductible over $500 (they make up for it by shoving healthy living down your throat to avoid getting sick)

NO Work-life balance in finance... for at least the first 5-10 years. Prepare to be single until you are 30. 12-hour days are not uncommon at all for FMPs and FP&A analysts. They claim to support family life, but the pressure to be in the office crazy hours and/or to be on your laptop at home makes getting away from work nearly impossible. I've heard people get divorced over the phone in the next office, people cancel family vacations at the last minute, people who's elementary kids have been at a different school every other grade.

Relocation is required throughout the program, and afterwards most analysts are promoted every 1.5 - 2 years and often have to move. So even if you do manage to have a personal life, it better be a mobile one.
column14: Provide a more stable environment for the finance folks who do not want to uproot their life every few months. Push for better work-life balance.

column5: Company becoming terrible place to work, best experience become worst
column12: GE was wonderful company when I joined and heaps of learning, leadership was awesome and working environment was absolutely marvelous.
column13:
In the last 1 and 1/2 year GE has become a terrible place to work, so much close approach for employee, massive cost cut organization wide, firing people on regular basis, so bureaucratic approach, less opportunities and no growth values. 

Since GE has sold its finance business, they have started become pain, I did not want to say but really a third class company from a first class company. 

I was not expecting that GE will fall like this. Seriously not worth to even consider working for GE.
column14:
Please do something good for your employee and make yourself proud. Don't play with people and give pain by so much cost cuts and demotion of people. If you are thinking you are leading a company in leadership industry then prove it. GE leader is bottom of the well and so disappointing to see how GE is progressing. I doubt with this mindset and approach you will have good working people staying with you.

A small mistake can lead to big disaster and I am feeling GE going towards it. Please do something good for your people and respect them.

column12: International environment, diversative teams, good offices
column13: So many times HC reduction

column5: Lots! - experience, challenges, opportunities, procedures, rules, employees.....
column12: GE makes opportunities available for employees to take if they want. There are online courses, company subscriptions to business and management books and videos (all of which can be taken advantage of without needing the consent or knowledge of your manager),, and volunteering opportunities to give something back to the community as well as the more formal leadership programs. There are many opportunities for a person to improve their soft skills free of charge.
column13: It's a large company with many rules and procedures and its unlikely you will be able to make a decision. Add several months to your expected decision turnaround time!
column14: Trust your local managers to make decisions for their business. Give guidelines if necessary. And if you don't trust them, get new managers. Don't keep all the decision making to yourself because you are making yourself into a bottleneck, and surely you don't want the pressure of doing it all?

column12: Leadership encourages innovation, process improvement, and empowers employees to lead. The open office promotes collaboration and IT collaboration tools further support the ability of remote teams to stay connected. Leadership is focused on long-term solutions and supports employees to be able to do their work and achieve goals.
column13: Analysis and reporting tools are lagging behind strategic vision, but working on improvements. Not all businesses are aligned with the strategic vision and understand the value of Global Operations organization (understandably - this is a big shift in mindset and culture change).
column14: Continue encouraging employees to bring ideas and new ways of thinking. Take the time to understand what your team(s) do and ask the important questions about their pain points and suggestions on how to improve. Take action and live the GE Beliefs. Hold frequent touch-points with your team and share important initiatives from senior leadership, so that team members do not feel out of touch.

column12: There is no pros in GE
column13: No Work life balance and poor management

column5: Great company to work for, always ahead of the game. Best thing that ever happend ot me.
column12:
Great work life balance. Always thinks ahead of the time. Invests in future and breakthrough technologies to keep its businesses and people best prepared for the future. Provides aome of the best learning oportunities. 
Demands best peformance, not aplace for just earning your living. If you love to compete and win, this is the place, otherwise you will not survive for long. The company is brutal when it comes to cutting slack.
column13: Size of the company is sometimes a disadvantage but usually an advantage. Those who join GE later in their career do not get the same level of attention/support compared to the candidates coming from its MT programme, even if you are the best, expect to be counted 2nd best.
column14: Look beyond your program gradutes for promoting best talent. That's becoming one of the major discontent of people.

column12: GE gives you the opportunity to fulfill all your career goals and recognises and rewards hard work. There is a wealth of on-line resources to help you do your job but not alot of on the job training. The organisation is constantly changing and you have to be flexible - this is something I enjoy as there are always challenges.
column13: There is no work/life balance this is a message that is fed from the top. Deadlines are extremely tight and have to be met often resulting in 50 plus hour weeks and weekend work. The organisation is very short termist and it is often hard to see the longer term strategy. Compensation packages tend to be at market rate on entry but fail to keep pace with competitors after a couple of years in the job.
column14: Nothing comes to mind at this moment.

column5: A good company for your retirement
column12: They don't have competitive salary, but acceptable. The other benefits are stock + pension plan. You have to spend many years working here to get good pay by increasing salary 3% per year. Many legacy products are still under development and maintenance, so most likely you will use some technics out-of-update.
column13: Good company culture, work-life balance is much depending on your profession behavior. Too many issues are there all the time, you adjust work-life balance if nobody pushing you.
column14: The employee quality is getting worst and worst due to less competitive env. Employees having competitive skills most likely go for a higher salary, the others working there are most 40+ to 60 years old. Too many managers, technical leaders ,etc, many of these peoples are not worthy of their paid, especially looking at what they are contributing. Overall it is a good place to stay for your retirement.

column5: I was doing work in steam turbine department
column12: The culture is very friendly in GE INDIA
column13: Nothing to say about this

column5: Welch was a tough act to follow, but c'mon !
column12: Under Welch GE was a true meritocracy and you got the chance to stretch and grow. Impact and values determined mattered the most. I truly admired most all of my direct managers and valued their mentoring. It helped make me a confident, competent senior manager.
column13: Under Immelt, the selection of world class senior managers deteriorated significantly. Jeff just lacks the capability to evaluate and select great senior managers. Also, career growth opportunities to move between business have become stagnant. This was at one time a source of great competitive edge for GE.
column14: I would advise the board to think hard about a new CEO after 8 years of underperformance. I would advice Immelt to select better people and not just his old buddies.

column5: The best place to work in bangalore
column12: The campus is great and the facilities provided to employees are the best in class. The people you work with are brilliant. There's a lot of learning and equal amount accountability. The organization emphasizes a lot on leadership and continuous development. All systems are in place and employee safety are of high. Some of the best things i like about GE is the volvo bus, superb gym & sports center, 5 different food vendors for lunch, beautiful campus and
column13: I hear dissatisfaction on salaries. The company can do better on that, for the high standards it maintains in the other departments. There's little opportunity for travelling around the world and all the jobs should get done at the desk. This is must need for people who want to travel.
column14: Pay better and don't be too absorbed on goal completion alone.

column5: GE is a great location for personal growth.
column12: The are plenty of opportunities for growth depending on what career direction you want to go to. The company is so vast there you can do anything and everything that you would like as long as you know the direction of your career.
column13:
Because of it's Pros, there is a high turnover rate for management positions so it's difficult for people with long term goals in their current position to get a steady feedback and growth due to the management changes. 
Although GE is so vast, each individual division, department, site operates as it's own entity so lot of tools, knowledge, are not shared or common.
column14:
Focus on technology and the people.
GE is a great company, but the health benefits is a huge disappointment. Went from all co-ops to higher premiums and higher deductibles.

column12:
-Very good culture & ethical
-Good Campus with lot of facilities
-work life balance ( but few exceptions are there)
-vast learning opportunities to enhance technical & leadership skills
- People in senior technical roles are really great
-Performance really matters
-Global Exposure
-Truly Engg environment
- 'GE' tag benefits in higher study (MS/MBA).....
- Job switch is easy and one gets good compensation....(many people work for 2-3 years & finally land in good job offer from competitors/ similar domain)
column13:
-Pay scale is low
-Seems FEW people are in leadership positions by mistake. (probably they were in GE at right time), 
-To get good rating, project execution is not enough (probably 60-70% contribution in overall rating).
-Not a good place for B tech candidates who really want to continue in Technical Career Path since limited options are available for higher study while working, that is from local College, from where they never recruit.

column12: I learned so much from my time at GE. I made great connections, and was able to further my experience and learning. Education offered is fantastic. I would never have learned about Six Sigma in another company. They are also very involved in their local communities, I had the opportunity to volunteer for many projects and become a leader in volunteer activities.
column13: Pay was not that great, they are rather on the cheap side. Also, if you are a really good worker bee/indian rather than pegged as "leader material", you'll find you get stuck in your position even when you ask for more responsibility and to move up.
column14: Take a good look at your worker bees, they are better than you are giving them credit for. You should also pay better, it's one of the reasons I left.

column12:
GE has been focusing during the last couple years on developing world class leaders, to develop a people's driven company, investing in coaching and motivating the workers. This creates a great environment to work, as it motivates to go the extra mile and deliver results. You are also awarded and recongnized for your efforts.
As long as you get the right management. 
Great work-life balance.
column13:
Unfortunately, the above statement is still work in progress. So you may find some more old school type of leaders who's mentality is not yet focused on developing the work force.
The salary is not the best in the market, but is fair.
Continuous change in strategy.
column14:
The work force drives the company. If people are motivated, well paid and with a good work-life balance the business will excel.
We are getting there, we just need to make sure all management is aligned with this goal.

column12: GE is renowned for the high quality of personnel that you work with day to day. This reputation is well-deserved. I've worked with best-in-class people, who work well as a team to elevate the work product of the entire organization.
column13: GE is a good place to work at with various job opportunities within the company. Working in a water filtration plant is quite interesting; the process of creating filters is very important to our environment where it benefits every country and culture. It is a diverse community with respectable and friendly co-workers. The job positions at this company to perform are generally easy to understand. The company provides a work-safe environment. You learn why and how important filters are to our environment and health.
column14: Great place to gain a multitude of experience. Knowledgeable, process improvement driven environment...honored to have the opportunity of growing with such great minds.

column5: Great for job satisfaction and career oportunitities, but Immelt is screwing up.
column12: My role gives me a lot of satisfaction. Allowed to focus on the important few priorities without been rated negatively when the others are neglected. Being a multinational there are great opportunities to relocate around the world and the top performers are not discouraged from doing so. Even though you are worked hard, there is generally an air of positivity and good nature within the teams.
column13: A lot of uncertainty and lack of job security within some of the business units given Immelt's portfolio management work. Seemingly every week something is sold or trying to be sold. Lack of appetite for giving managers enough people to get stuff done means you are worked hard. Work/Life balance is heavily favored towards work.
column14: Talk straight

column12: A large company, growth opportunities, ability to transfer, long runway for career, they take a long time to allow you to come up to speed and show how good you are.
column13: Very political, and long tenured people are kept whether they are capable or not; GE takes care of the people who stay around. You can get away with very inappropriate behavior if you are viewed as adding unique value. regional office spends excessively while satellite locations are squeezed mercilessly.
column14: Read the cons. Managing on a quarter to quarter basis hasn't helped the stock price for 9 years, so why not try something else, like strategic planning? There were reasons no one wanted to buy C&I when it was up for sale a few years ago, and I must guess one was no long range development plan.

column5: Great Company to work for, but don't want to hire contract employees full time
column12:
Amazing people
Great leadership
Really seems to care about employess
Lots of team building and fun employee events.
Awesome communicate on company plan and direction from top management.
column13:
Have a large workforce of under paid contract employees that are replaced with someone else after their contract is up (max length is 1.5 years). 
Need to really update some of the systems used
Need better communication between departments and job functions in areas that over lap.
column14: Spend money to not only invest in systems but people as well. Understand that it takes time to learn how to do a job and then to start to effectively do it. With this system, you always have someone who is new and doesn't fully understand how things work or what is going on, and it leaves your workforce less efficent.

column12: At GE you learn to lead. Those who think they know already what it means to lead, get forced to learn how they should really do it ; and those that don't know the leader in them get a chance to awaken their leadership side. It is all about the way GE manages you with it's overall development agenda, on the job and through training. Amazing opportunity at any career stage.
column13: You need to take control of your destiny in this company ; come to work willing to change and improve - and do it. If you don't drive performance, and show you do so, or if you depend on instructions from your boss, you're in for trouble or on your way out.
column14: Need a new corporate improvement agenda to rally the troops across the board ; or reinvigorate six sigma and lean.

column12:
Well Pros is that GE was once a pioneer , Wipro employees invaded them like bed bugs , and all that is left of GE is its skeleton . But Still strong enough to withstand.
Its share prices are all time low. Company which divested a lot of money towards 
Research and Development with no Business Development in new emerging areas. A failed mammoth. Lead by some Pseudo Educated management's poor 
foresight , with one of the most racially discriminating lobby's whose favorite pass time being fighting against one another, In India their HR team start weaving Sweaters from Winter Till it Comes Again. Irresponsible administrations. Even can't transfer PF from their Trust to a PF account , you need to wait till 60 years to get a reply back from the HR. Thank god I am no more associated with GE.
column13: No Cons I have put it Pros.
column14: Keep doing what you Do . Keep it up . You please stay with In GE, otherwise the companies around will be contaminated with your retardedness.

column12: I do not have any
column13: No future in this company

column5: Actively trying new things in a large old company should be applauded
column12: GE will take small companies and try to balance the introduction of their systems with allowing the entrepreneur spirit to continue to flourish. A difficult balance, but well worth it as a small company grows into a larger one.
column13: The cost discrepancies between different product groups makes for a challenge to work across division boundaries. The review cost structure of 100MW systems cannot be the same as the review process requirements for the 0.5MW system. The “tollgates” need to be better matched to the actual risk proposition, or the small company needs to be left outside the fold.
column14: We need to continue to monitor and adjust the way small entities are swallowed into the larger GE and it's systems. Synergy is only possible if the smaller group continues to thrive.

column12:
Some of the best leaders in the world. 
Can run any type of business using the same core operating rhythms and metrics.
Learn to apply best practices to any business scenario.
Learn how to think and evaluate the space around you.
Huge but if you pay attention you never loose track of how you fit into the bigger picture.
Tough but usually fair.
column13:
As a mid career hire you will spend a lot of time trying to keep up with younger GE bred (typically Finance) internal program graduates. Best time to join GE is (i) either fresh out (ii) seasoned executive whom can come in at a high level (typically with an acquisition)

You will be kept on your toes with reorganizations, acquisitions and restructures. 

Immense amount of effort to manage internal customers and processes.
column14: Don't listen to the street too much (they have no clue)

column12:
Big Name. The entire World knows the name GE and therefore a great place for anyone fresh graduate to start work. Looks good on the CV
Benefits such as employee discount and shares
Employees can move to different department in the compnay e.g. Aviation, healthcare, corporate
column13:
A big company therefore it can take time to move up the ladder.
Salary after the end of graduate scheme is not good. 
over loaded with work can sometimes result in lack of learning and technical growth.
column14: Graduate engineers should be used as future leaders. During the 2 year scheme they should learn the ins and outs of the company projects, from tenduring, to configuration, planning, commissioning and closing. They should shadow current engineers and learn from them, and not just sit and do paperwork. Learning should never stop and they should be checked monthly on progress.

column12: Great pay for salaried positions (perhaps several overpaid people). A good work life balance for the most part.
column13: Everything! This is by far the worst company I have ever worked for. Working for GE was not my choice. It's an unfortunate result of an acquisition of the company I loved working for. We had always dealt with GE as a customer prior to them taking over and we frequently joked that such a large company couldn't really be that messed up. Constant payment errors were the norm - both under and over payments and issues would go months if not years before getting resolved. Now that we are GE I see why. For the most part no one who works there has a clue what they are doing. Those who are intelligent and are good at their jobs move to new positions or leave the company completely. Can't say I blame them. I used to want to be an account until I worked here. I fell like I get dumber and dumber everyday that I am there. Their systems are confusing and completely inaccurate and I wouldn't believe a single number on their financial statements.
column14: Figure out what the heck you are doing! Stop changing structures every few months creating more and more confusion to the point that the only people who even vaguely understand it are those that have worked their whole lives at GE.

column12: Very professional company with a high level of integrity and many development opportunities. Due to the size and structured talent development approach there are many opportunities to develop and have a long-term career. Anybody willing to invest the time and effort should be able find enough challenging assignments along the way. I've been here 9 years and i'm still learning.
column13: You have to be able to deal with the required flexibility that comes with a large multi-national: e.g. new businesses can be bought but also spun-off year-round. You will see many changes along the way which will require and open mindset to deal with. If you don't embrace change then GE might not be the right employer for you.
column14: Put more emphasis on developing your longer-term employees. Make sure you value the in-house expertise and skill-set built up over the years.

column12: They are very conscious that their employees need to be able to have flexible schedules from time to time. Also, Diversity is very important to the company as well as self improvement. At GE, no matter what particular GE company you work for, you always feel part of the big GE family and you have activities with other employees from other GE companies every now and then (i.e. GE Women's network, Healthahead, etc.)
column13: Very bad communication ethic inside the company. News travels slowly through non official mediums and people tend to feel confused. GE ranks their employees but you never know where you stand...
column14: Management should always know what is going on and share the news as soon as possible with the rest of the team (i.e. arrival of a new employee, leave of an employee... not weeks or months later).

column12: Average company . Few managers are so bad and take things personally
column13: Not so flexible limited wfh available
column14: Good

column12:
- If you enjoy making a difference, this is the company to work for.
- Great learning culture. You should never stop learning because when you do, it's probably time for you to start looking for another role. That's what makes people in this company so great to work with.
- Huge conglomerate, can't find any other company that has business units large enough to be a stand-alone company and switching from one to another is not frowned upon. 
- Strong corporate culture, GE is the same everywhere you go, heck they have their own fonts, branding etc.
column13:
- Like any large company, you'd find pockets of people who don't embody the GE values, can be frustrating to work with them
- Can be slow and bureaucratic at times
- Don't expect all warm and fuzz, people here mean business

column12:
good culture
infrastructure
food n

Strong global company
Great pay
Processes well defined
Work environment is hit or miss, can be either the best or worst place to work depending 
on the business you work in
column13:
Constantly acquiring companies during my 13 years with GE, creates confusion and disarray 
with customers and internal people
Sometimes management seems more interested in acquisition rather than organic growth and innovation from within 
Can be severe work/life imbalances..again this depends on business you are working in
column14: Understand and become more knowledgeable in your business so that you van make more informed decisions. In my opinion, in some respects GE management has lost control over some key business units. This is because they often don't understand the business or their customers to the degree required to be successful, instead choosing the easy path of milking revenue streams from previously acquired successful businesses.

column12:
Big company - has money to get things done if they choose to
Very good technical career path (goes VERY high) and good communications around world within this - there's always someone you can talk to about technical problems.
Good local management (GE Druck, Groby, Leicester, UK)
Interesting technology, very good engineering expertise here
column13:
American corporate culture sometimes very hard to put up with as a Brit - way too much bulls**t
Executive management often only in jobs while bouncing up the ladder - means they don't get to clean up the mess of their decisions if they are only in role for 18 months
column14:
Get some commitment from executives - make them stay in role longer!
Understand that not all your global employees are from the Good Old US of A

column12: I've managed to stay there for 3 months, while not doing anything, so if you want to go on a vacation, work for them. But be careful, others can get a workload that couldn't be finished by a single person.
column13:
"Customers determine our success" - yes, but they could have a guess on how to be successful as well
"Stay Lean to Go Fast" - but they rather prefer to look busy instead
"Learn and Adapt to win" - they couldn't even learn from their own mistakes.
"Empower and Inspire Each Other" - yeah, this could work, but not in Hungary
"Deliver Results in an Uncertain World" - if employee turnover is a result, then GE rocks!

To sum up, GE SSC is a big playground for big children. They hire puffer workload to hang around, until they find some work for them. The whole system is ridiculous, so no wonder they make a joke out of themselves in front of the whole Hungarian SSC sector.
column14: You thought that building up a new SSC only takes 3 years, you have to admit that you were wrong, and after that, you can start stabilizing the hub.

column12: The potential to advance is there if one is willing to work for it. They train for the job, and the pay is awesome, as well as the benefits and extras. They are supportive in and out of the job. It is a challenging job, but not so challenging that one cannot learn to do it. It is a very friendly and fun atmosphere. Probably the best job I have ever had.
column13: The only downside I have found is that they don't coordinate to have the same technician on the job. I have ended up starting half way through someone else's job and it does get confusing.
column14: That they should communicate more with the coordinator and have the technician that starts the job... stay there throughout the entire job.

column5: Ability to pursue many different career opportunities, but at a cost
column12:
values, integrity program is real, process and systems - really tries to "get it right" even if it takes time
Fantastic tradition of talent - great VPs in our division (O&G)
column13:
bureaucracy - there are models folks follow which while required to manage such a large company, limit individuality.
CEO has had too many different initiatives in last 10 yrs poor investments and some very expensive acquistions that have not panned out - look at stock price 1/3 of level in 2000...almost all comparable industrial companies have exceeded their 2000 peak by now
column14: look for richness of experiences in talent vs. just administering the processes or powerpoint skills. Conduct more "360's" so you can see how folks are performing for their customers, peers and employees.

column12:
Career development opportunities are limitless
Truly a place where working hard gets results
Everyone is able to have a voice - you speak up, people listen
The company feels safe - in the economic turmoil that is important
Investment in you as a person is good, what is available to you is not limited by your position
Communication is good, there are so many different ways to hear what is going on
column13: Sometimes it doesn't seem like performance management is tough enough - some people seem to get away with things for too long
column14:
Keep going, keep listening, keep taking notice of what people are saying 
Keep meritocracy in your minds at all times - that is what has made GE successful for so long
Never forget that it's the employees who make the place great

column5: Average work but good work-life balance
column12:
- lot of freedom to choose when and how one will accomplish the work. 
- adequate time for self-learning 
- beautiful campus
- work-life balance
column13:
- limited avenues for working on projects which are technically challenging and have huge impact
- technical ability is not recognised sufficiently enough. Management is more interested in keeping the show going in terms of getting some work moving.
- not a great place for folks who are more technology centric and less focussed on moving ahead in the career ladder through networking
- candid talk not encouraged. 
- quality of colleagues is not top-notch
column14: Do honest and critical analysis of the impact of the organisation in Bangalore. Do not tom--tom ordinary work as something extra-ordinary. Make people feel valued for their technical ability.

column5: Unlimited growth and challenges offered at GE.
column12: Since the beginning of my career I’m faced with challenging work assignments which have accelerated the growth of my existing skill sets and have added new skills to my toolkit. At times I find myself outside of my comfort zone because of these new experiences. GE’s culture supports an atmosphere of collaboration. I’m able to turn to my colleagues for their expertise and guidance when faced with a new task I’m not quite sure how to tackle. In addition to learning from my peers and management; GE also offers an abundance of training.
column13: At times bureaucracy and the amount of work procedures we must follow can slow us down. We should strive to be more nimble and efficient.

column12: GE is a great organization for career development, especially for beginner professionals, GE is focus in short term results, but GE is capable to keep on track the long terms as defined in strategic plan. Even having a dynamic and daring profile, GE promotes a great environmental for working. Ethics, Compliance, Customers, Employees and Results are the main worries and beliefs of GE.
column13: In order to keep the short term results, GE changes all time the organization as market demand, sometimes these changes are so fast making impossible to gather the results of the previous change and its can demotivate the employees.
column14: Sometimes it is acceptable the second flop, sometimes it is necessary to learn with failure in order to implement the improvements before change everything.

column5: Great place to learn and build your career. Superb networking and highly flexible work environment!
column12:
- Tremendous opportunities and excellent career progression
- Talented people and management
- Positive environment with great leadership
- Good work life balance
- Focus on All round development through both Technical and Soft-Skills trainings
- Quality work, high rewards and recognition
column13: GE is a large organization with more than 300,000 employees. It is easy to get lost among so many employees however hard-work and superior talent is very well recognized and promoted in GE's rewarding environment.
column14: Send a quarterly report to all GE employees with the keynote achievements from different businesses of GE. This will keep employees engaged in GE's various business practices and also motivate to individuals to perform better.

column12: Rapidly growing center in Budapest comes with many opportunities - as long as you are brave enough to take them. Opportunities for cross function training and moves between teams. The organization is really flat - you can meet / work with senior managers and get insights from them. Flexible working time and trust that you do your work. Great networks and events organized by GE.
column13: You have to work a lot.- so work life balance is difficult to manage- you can make it, but it requires a lot of maturity and organization. Overtime is not paid
column14: Pay more attention to the workload in your team. Make sure that you talk to your people - very often you don't know them enough.

column12: It is a job for freshers and, not for experienced professionals. The workspace is encouraging and you can try balancing time between work, home and the gym. There are busses to shuttle all alike, but some places are not serviced. Leaders are generally good, but not your leader and there is zero oversight. Stay alert and survival is for the fittest.
column13: Politics in this workspace is too high for comfort and the greatest politician will be your own leader. Without oversight, your leader is in total control and as a contract person you have no redress or recourse. Schedule is erratic, because retention of talent is a problem. Team Leaders work in the GSOC, where there is no time to learn properly or expectations are too high. Age is another problem; the Leader dislikes her contract labor to be senior in age to her. Pay is not as stated, but much less. Favoritism is yet another major issue.
column14: Best is not to recommend such contracts, if you can, and sustain the talent pool.

column5: Getting tired of constant meaningless changes
column12: Very good company culture ; focus on integrity in all levels; fun place to meet people from different countries;
column13:
Confusing organisational structure : you never know who will be a person to go. I had to shootout my issues and questions to the air hoping somebody will answer and help
Huge workload
Polishing up results - creative reporting
Quarter after quarter - as if there is nothing beyond current quarter
column14: the pace of changing should be slowed down- t least in areas where its not necessary. I have a feeling that there is a drive to change constantly- even things that function well. Also, processes and tools get changed even before the previous one matured and had a chance to be adapted .

column5: Great place to work, learn, and move on
column12: Lots of really smart people willing to work hard and help others. Very good at teaching industry specific issues. Pay is ok relative to market. Benefits (health insurance) have recently become much more expensive for the employees.
column13: Leadership still focused mostly on short term goals, no matter the industry dynamics. Big promotions are often reserved for employees hired into one of the management training programs out of college. Still too much "head quarters first" perspective from management.
column14: Sometimes, you have to weather the current storm for future growth. Comp plans too often reward average teams in the best markets instead of the best teams that happen to be in challenging markets.

column12:
Benefits 
Day goes in quickly, when left alone to do the work.
column13:
Pay lack of bonuses on the shop floor or incentives, all managers get the bonuses, factory workers are the under dogs. 
Yearly pay rise of 1.6% not very fair to the amount of growth profits accumulated over the years
R&R's not given out fairly and/or none at all to factory workers; engineers and interns get them, even thought it isn't their idea in the first place, it's there job when they are in doing some work and not playing squash or golf.
Policies changes and never updating workers
communication lack off all jargon and no straight direct answers
No Job opportunities, who you know not what you know gets the position
Managers lack of "know how" the factory floor operates
Dead lines and stock run outs at the same time
Managers lack of listening to the one's who know what they are talking about, and responding in a timely manner
Customers and Quality are my only and 1st priority, not a belief in a flawed self centered system.
column14: Sort out the cons, the pros are very little.

column12: Immense resources for employees if they get nominated to go through certain leadership training. Company is large so there are opportunities.
column13: Health Care package is below standard. Senior Management might not know what your shop actually does and limits decisions. If you didn't go through a GE Leadership program, you get lost if you came from the outside. Honestly can't say I see what Immelt does to impact the company other than talk to share holders. Some business units are still run like we are in the 1940's for manufacturing. No innovation in these business units.
column14: Back your middle level managers decisions as well as those on the shop floor every day. Challenge employees but trust that they know what they are doing.

column12: The most senior leadership (Immelt & direct reports) have great vision and this company definitely has the resources necessary to be successful and do great things. There are a lot of great people in this company that really care about what's best for the company and it's stakeholder. Unfortunately these people are rarely heard.
column13: I have never seen a company were so many people act only in their own career interests and not in the interest of the company. The default answer to everything is 'NO' because people need to put their own credibility behind saying yes. As a result this company is the consummate underachiever. Also, for a company touted as having the best leadership, I have not seen this other than at the very top. I can't believe the number of really poor leaders in senior positions that are allowed to hang around poisoning any ounce of entrepreneurship within the ranks. Shameful.
column14: Get the straight goods. Read beyond what people are telling you to their true motivations. Be open minded and objective.

column5: Good place for an internship but for a long-term career I am not sure
column12: GE provides good training and job responsibilty for day one. Work atmosphere is very good and most people pulling on the same the string.
column13: The company is too bureaucratic and therefore has long response time and little recognition from higher management for work. Furthermore, the company is so large that you are just one of many gear wheels and can be easily replaced, which can feel a bit daunting at some stages. Poor work environment, unless you fancy to work in a container next to a power plan, above a workshop or in a warehouse.
column14: more recogniztion for work done by people at lower levels of management

column5: Not the best organization to start your career.
