column12:
-Very good work life balance
-Very supportive US counter-parts
-Very good culture among colleagues.
column13:
-Among the worst management & most of risen to leadership roles due to chance & not really dude to abilities.
-Leadership drowned in politics who will patronage employees of their preference. This leads to unfair appraisals & promotions. Even who gets better work & who does not is completely dependent on the leadership
-Lots of freshers are hired from the best colleges in India only to do work which does no justice to their abilities
-Salaries are not the best unless you are close to your managers
column14:
-Being a technical org, the top most leadership in India should make sure all managers are technically well qualified. There have been many cases where managers do not understand anything about the work the employees are doing either because they do not have enough exposure or do not have the inclination to keep themselves up to date with stuff
-The US leadership is great but their Indian counterparts are way short of the mark.

column5: Big challenge and learning on strategy and prioritization
column12: Great products and services. Innovation and investment on research are outstanding. Highly qualified employees. Ethical environment. Thomas Edson is the founder of the company which inspire and guide the people through the decades. Flat hierarchy. Fast on merge and acquisitions.
column13: Too big to be understood and managed as one company. Several systems and environments that do not connected to each other. Back office transactions are done very poorly and takes forever to be acomplished. Lack of integration and sinergy among the businesses. Geographies work too long for internal demand and presentations instad of having customer, out-side in focus.
column14: Say no with arguments to higher levels in order to work for customer and sales increase.

column12:
Interesting technology.
Always something to learn
column13:
I am surprised so many people on this site are satisfied with GE. The employee experience for myself and virtually every other colleague I speak with is one of disappointment. This is reinforced by a high turnover of personel. The reputation for training GE has does not take place in my business unit, the quality at times is embarrasing. The disconnect between employees and leaders is vast. There is no support, teamwork, or cooperation. It is standard for emails not to be responded to. When we are the face of GE to the Customer we need support at times, it is not there. The was actually an article on the GE intranet last week called "Culture Shock" where it talked about the "exodus"of people. This too was reinforced by the internal GEOS (GE Opinion Survey) which confirms my comments. The culture in my business unit is subpar, period.

I am looking internally to get out of the unit I am in, otherwise life is too short to work here.
column14: Listen to Customers, listen to Employees

column5: GE is cheap about most things and it shows
column12: Honestly, I only liked my team, and you can't really interview for that going in
column13:
Aggressive Silo'ing. Their goal is horizontal alignment which gives them operational visibility, but it makes getting work done very difficult. It increases the time of "Work in progress"

They're actually falling back on the previous. I think they're aware that it doesn't work. But that's con number 2. They change organizational structure and ideology too often. Then, there's no investment or execution on those organizational changes.

They make you pay back their piddly relocation package before 24 months. I'm pretty sure industry standard is 12 months. 

If you're coming from a 2-300 person company, they may be offering you marginally more than what you make. You'll find that the brand of GE is the only thing of worth at the company. You'll also find that you can use that brand to obtain significantly more money else where after a short period of time.
column14: Management is actually very sharp. People may try to act like they could run a 122 billion dollar company better, but I doubt it. Still, something gets lost in translation from the top. Execution falters and to me it stems from being unwilling to invest in your workforce.

column12: GE is a well-known and solid company. For the most part, there is decent job security. Pay is about the industry average in my field. Management had good technical knowledge and led the group well.
column13: From talking to many of my co-workers, it seems there is not much financial incentive to doing a good job, as the bonus structure is very flat. Also, the work I did was not terribly exciting, nor were there lots of other exciting opportunities at my location.
column14: The upper level management does a great job of allowing new employees to be properly trained, but I think there is still a little too much bureaucracy in this organization.

column5: The Company appreciates its Employees by meeting their needs through a well established employee relations unit
column12: Company Values are based on the Employee motivation, have a great comp & Ben scheme- ie. Great medical cover, access to international training & development tools, free staff lunches and participation in to corporate events that increase ones Network base
column13:
Bureaucracy in terms of processes hence creating delays 
Favoritism based on ones ethnic background 
High turnover based on pressures from sales
column14:
Ensure that all staff are aware of the goals and objectives and clear forecasts so that staff are not under pressure due to sales 
Creating policies on Organization culture to ensure unity and promotions based on performance rather than ethnic background

column12:
1. Challenging work using latest technologies and real time environment/data.
2. No variable component, only fixed pay.
3. Flexible benefits are good.
4. Till staff engineer level coding to be done.
column13:
1. Growth opportunities are slow.
2. All resources are in control of Managers, so they do micro management & sometime even threaten their employees. Team Leads have no control over team vacation, salary,......
3. My manager used to openly talk about how he made resources cry. Many resources complained to his manager but no serious action taken.
column14: Take feedback of managers even from team members not in a group but as anonymous survey. Currently it's taken in group session, resources are scared to tell what they are going through.

column12: Flexible work arrangement, competitive salary, nice and educated people
column13: Managers do not have solid soft skills, most of them are engineers trying to lead another people. Lack of vision, and mission. Meritocracy does not work, it seems sometimes Exposure and Image are much more important than a solid and sustainable performance
column14:
Educate your managers, specially top level ones, to have a long term vision, and take that into account when promoting and supporting your individual contributors career and growth plans.
Exposure and Image are nice, but they will not solve the real issues most of the time. If you continue underestimating most of the people who do the hard work, you will banish them without even notice it

column5: Great place to grow a career
column12:
It is a company that strives to maintain a very high standard of integrity
Huge investment in developing people
You get to work with a lot of smart and very nice people (the occasional jerk, as anywhere)
It is a Meritocracy - rewards, recognition, promotion are based on what you accomplish and how you behave
Great diversity of businesses, products and markets
Constant change - never gets dull!
Community minder - supports volunteerism, United Way, environmental and social issues
column13:
Complex organization structure
Some bureaucracy
Short term focus tends to predominate in business units
column14: Build the talent pipeline for the future - don't let short term results get in the way of building for the future

column12: Great company to work for career development, cross cultural opportunities, clearly defined roles, team spirit across different functions. The company is progressively innovative providing unparalleled opportunity to continuously unlock one's skills and discover true-self.
column13: I am not aware of any demerit worth of significant mention with being an employee in GE. However, with the power of hindsight there could always be better ways to do things. I am always pushing myself to discover better ways to do things since GE has provided that platform for every employee.
column14: Keep up the good work especially the open door policy and the will to always challenge the convection, which has driven the company this far.

column12:
You get the benefits of working for a truly global company. Lots of cross functional and cross national collaboration and insights into international markets. If you are open to new opportunities you will always find what you like. Also GE is very strong at promoting company culture.
I love the fact that GE is able to do something like globally rebranding such a giant organization.
column13: Can be burocratic and slow in corporate decision making, though GE makes conscious efforts to speed up through Fastworks initiative.
column14: Local management makes conscious efforts to help individuals feel content about their job however could focus more on employee advancement in frame of listening more on a personal level.

column5: Highly professional and compliant company, little focus on the customer
column12: GE offers a fast paced, rapidly changing professional environment where employees with self drive and self direction can thrive. Compliance is not just a rule to abide by, it is part of the culture and a huge asset compared to competitors. Employees are treated fairly, although the company fails to lags the market in terms of salary levels.
column13: The company´s focus is too much on the short term results. If fails to apply long term strategic plans. It operates in industries with high barriers to entry and high margins, and therefore does not place the customer needs front and center. There is a bit of a silo culture in some functional areas that do not realize their role is to support sales. Decisions are not made in the country, this does not allow flexibility or adaptability.
column14: Refocus strategies based on customer needs. Move away from the industrial mindset to a services mindset. Short term execution is important but long term strategy requires allocating resources to areas with no immediate returns.

column12: GE is undoubtedly the biggest conglomerate within the US. Therefore, the transitional placement within the company is endless. You can be an engineer, a financial analyst, etc.
column13: Like a double edged sword, while GE provides some of the best education for its employees, it sticks to only that. Most of the employees at GE can be seen to only be working strictly for GE for the rest of their lives, simply because it is difficult to transition to other companies outside of GE. (i.e. GE's FMP program is a replacement for business school)
column14: The hierarchy of GE is enormous, and it is very difficult to get to interact with the upper management at GE.

column5: Good place to learn and grow in the right position, lots of talent, but lots of competition!
column12:
- Multi-cultural environment with good diversity.
- Good training grounds for professional growth.
- Being able to develop and share best-practices across the business.
- Working with cross-functional teams and matrix management.
- Overall communications from the top including vision and direction were effective.
column13:
- Benefits were slightly better than average, however not as good as GE 'Core' benefits.
- None or very little bonus due to lack of profitability not due to performance! Work very hard and perform well, yet no bonus!
column14: Focus more on products, product-mix, giving the customer what they want when they want it. Work more 'in-the-business' than 'on-the-business'.

column5: Bureaucratic...No clear path of career development...Very qualitative review process...Limited career growth
column12: The brand name helps in the resume
column13:
There is just way too much waste. There are too many managers to manage very few people. Even being an individual contributor, you will feel the politics being played. I might be useful to do a lean project to reduce the waste in the number of managers. 

Although they have a so called career ladder, it is near to impossible to go up being in your own division. For example there is only 1 principal engineer for over 300 engineers. The only way I see to go up is to move laterally across GE businesses. 

The review process is very fuzzy. There is no clear way of understanding how are being reviewed, or may be I haven't learned to play the review game yet. 

There is really not any innovation going on in the software division in "Smart Grid", although it is called NPI. If you keep working for long in such a domain, you could end up far behind the rest of the software community and might not add any value to the resume
column14: I would just like to see employees rated more fairly

column12: The best company i had ever work with, great leaders, very competitive, you learn by doing, a total support for a professional career growth, great culture and values, great environment.
column13: Not totally a Con but it is true that the company is very competitive and moves fast, so it is sometimes difficult to maintain a good work/life balance, what i can say is that if you are committed the company responds in consequence.
column14: My manager once told me "I don't receive more salary because I am more special than others, I receive it because I have more responsibilities and I have to act in consequence and take care of my team".

column5: No Development , Lack of Professionalism, Too many Managers and Not Many Engineers
column12: To have GE on your CV if you are a young engineer, an dto get some travelling of you are lucky and your manager doesnt get it first!
column13: No Development Plan for young Engineers, Lack of Professionalism from your Line Managers, No Development and No Good pay . Stay in GE for a year not more, its very unpleasant and unprofessional environment to progress as a young engineer! Never Again!
column14:
My line manager blocked my transfer to other departments 6 times! The HR does nt do absolutely anything! There is no grievelance procedure.
I have applied to transfer to other department within GE 6 times and my manager blocked me even though I had very good reason. I got involved the HR, line managers, Obdusman, Union in order to be able to transfer to another department to develop and my managers and HR blocked me 6 times!After that , my manager made my life so miserable! calling on the phone other managers while I was sitting net to him to let them know that I suck as an engineer! He gave me no job to do! He ignored me ! And he made me want to leave!

column5: Complete lost all drive to excellence
column12: Good salary in good business environment
column13:
Driven by short term incentives with little technical sensitivity by finance jugglers.
A once great high tech company has completely lost its drive to excellency and is preparing to marginalize a once admired brand. 
Loosing tech know how and running the company on a shoe string for years is not sustainable and will not succeed.
Do "America first" is a bad idea if you are running a global company.
If it is "fix it , sell it or close it" you need to have deliver on all three not only 2 and 3. 
The destructive energy that the company reveals is not matched by anything positive.
column14:
ask yourself : How do i want to make all that margin in 3 years or in 10 years?
Where has the money gone that was flooding the company 3 years ago. Are you still in control ? 
When is the current management taking responsibility for the horrible performance adn when do they stop blaming the "old guys".

column5: Employees freindly Great culture and work life balance..
column12: Good work life balance especially work from home was nice. We can have a mild mindset in office there would be no tension and pressure.top managers were friendly no commnading its requesting from employees was good.
column13: Its taking too long time and procedure to resolve any HR related and process related issues thats it...
column14: Not only in GE for all managers in all concern. Be friendly to your employees and get work done as it is in same way...If you leave your employees in cool mindset you will get work done before the SLA. I have learn this from my manager in my process in GE....

column12:
- constantly intellectually challenged
- opportunity to work with some amazingly intelligent and driven individuals
- culture of company overall is very inclusive
- support of work/life balance is satisfactory
column13:
- expectations for above and beyond performance are the standard
- must be able to prioritize as projects and issues are assigned to competent individuals continuosly
- healthcare benefits have become less than satisfactory as of January 1, 2010
column14: Some corporate initives rolled down from the top are unnecesary and seem to be designed so a senior GE executive can check off a box. Senior management of subsidiaries needs to learn how to push back in connection with at least some of these bureaucratic initiatives.

column5: Not a company for Gen Ys (Stay away from Water & Process Technologies)
column12:
- Good Engineering/technical personnel
- Good training ground and research support in various parts of the world.
- Thinks Big or Bust on most projects
column13:
- Highly beauracratic ( It takes 6 months to add a vendor to the vendor system) 
- "Sucking up culture" ( Manager needs to hear only positive things and not bad things) 
- The management is full of White Male Gen X folks who don't understand Gen Y at all (majority > 45 years) 
- The ombudsperson system is flawed (Multiple people have been given "neutral feedback" on their problems that were filed anonymously and later they were given poor ratings) 
- Rank and Yank system is still very prevalent even in 2015 (The HR said rank and yank is non-existent, but still PIP are served out to employees when their ranking is low and they are kicked out without compensation. HR lies like its nobody's business and management has no concern for shareholder wealth creation)
column14: Kick out the deadweight fast, remove the performance management system, Improve diversity by hiring more women into Engineering/Technology Management roles because right now its alpha male and full of Gen X.

column12:
1. Great people, positive & friendly, for me the biggest strength of the company
2. Dynamic, one of the fastest pivoting companies in the world with respect to its size
3. Finance is not treated as accounting or figures department, Finance is a strong if not the strongest function in the management
4. The integrity is the biggest strength in culture, I strongly believe in values of equality & compliance of the company
column13:
1. Working hours are more than regular in a working day in general for Finance
2. The pro of fast pivoting can be dangerous for the job security depending on your country / business etc.
column14: Value your employees, this is your biggest asset

column5: Why you should work with GE
column12: A great place to learn, on job. Good options for work life balance. Fair appraisal system.Promotional opportunities are global, if you are willing to take risk.A technology and innovation oriented company, one of the best in the world. Reasonable salary.
column13: It is still US centric. At times has inertia to change, called Govt of GE! Gets too bogged down by compliance.
column14: Realistic vision. Patience.Build for a long term play in India.Improve market intelligence, govt relations and customer interaction. Connect researchers with markets, customers and consumers.They need to understand that in India COST is all that matters. All players have matching technology, anyway.

column12:
There are several great things about working at GE:
First, you feel like you're making an impact on the world outside, working on projects that change people's life.
Next, I had the chance to work with really, really top notch experts in their area, and it is amazing what you learn there.
Finally, it is a company that relies on very strong values and make no compromise with compliance.
column13:
The size of it make it hard to move. When you have new ideas, when you need to be flexible, it is hard. Harder also when those ideas don't come from US people...
Finally, salary and benefits are way behind competition.

column12: Overall, GE had a good work atmosphere. People were willing to help you understand something that was handed off to you without much prior knowledge. There were great opportunities for promotion (or at least lateral movements in the org-chart that came with higher pay) and branching to new fields of work.
column13: Because GE is a large corporation with many separate departments, the red tape involved with implementing process improvements can be cumbersome.
column14: Offer clear and direct leadership especially pertaining to development project priorities. Limited time and money must be properly allocated and it is important to plan for the longterm how each program will progress throughout the year.

column5: On the good side for such a large corporation
column12:
Career mobility - both functional and domain
Increasingly international outlook
Modern ways of working - not tied to your desk or need to be in the office
Truly embraces diversity in all aspects
column13:
Sometimes too US centric
Company politics as a you move up - not particularly worse or better than any other corporation of that size
Personal network will make or break your chances to move up in the long run
column14:
Continue the drive to simplify 
Go one step further in terms of inclusiveness by giving a real chance for top management positions for this who do not come from internal management fast track programs (XLP, CAS etc...)

column12: Real engineering work!!! The work is interesting, challenging and rewarding. The trains pass by the building for tests and you see your work directly! High level of skill and great co-workers!
column13: Everyone is WAY TO QUIET and to themselves. Zero communication. HR is disorganised, disinterested and not knowledgeable of HR procedures. IT is a pain to deal with. Engineering is behind on current software.
column14: Rack and stacking people before the employee appraisals? How does that work?! Better communication throughout the company and different teams would be nice. Fix your HR, they are horrible! Treat contractors like people!

column12: Strong company with very talented people. Good pay, benefits are ok, use to be better. Opportunity for growth is high as long as you apply yourself. Management is supportive.
column13: People will always ask if you know "so and so" who works in "name any GE division that is not your own"...We are one of the biggest companies. Very high probability that we don't know them.
column14: Benefits were great. One of the best parts about GE prior to 2010. New deductibles really are a pain point. Even with the best plan, you still have to pay $2K. Times are tough and we understand, but had to provide some feedback here.

column5: Great program that doesnt prepare you for the roll you will take at the end
column12: Great management and business training, excellent way to meet a large group of highly motivated, talented people who will likely have interesting and fast moving careers (they just might not be at GE), incredible way to gain business experience by working for different support areas and businesses while living in a number of different cities.
column13: program does not prepare you for off program roles, slow moving company culture, some rotations are better than others, high turnover
column14: Decide if this is how you recruit for IT positions or recruit for IT leadership positions.

column5: Good place to work for politicians
column12:
Numerous opportunities come up very frequently
Interesting projects happen from time to time
In general, people are really good at what they do
column13:
Extremely political environment - doesn't matter from which corporation you are coming from, GE will be a more politically-charged place to deal with. Very commonly you will hear employees complaining that "Here we are more valued by other opinions than by what we deliver".
This environment can be very stressful at times, and promote a lot of conflict between peers.
column14: Watch out for the bad apples. Although GE culture promotes the structuring and promotion of stellar projects, it doesn't promote the delivery of these projects.

column5: Company on the right path for future growth
column12:
- Company is going under transformation towards digital.
- Management lead by example. They are serious with what they say and walk the talk. 
- Great place to start a career to build leadership.
column13:
- Lack of visibility if you are not in a leadership development program.
- You will have to navigate the career and determine your next best role.
column14:
- Need to be more aggressive in cost-cutting, too much inefficiencies in the business
- Need to communicate the branding better to the street. People are still viewing us as traditional industrial company, we should start getting higher PE valuation for our digital work.

column12: GE has the capacity and the people to solve some of the worlds biggest problems. It works to support development and careers of its people. It's constantly changing and improving with a focus of helping its customers. Finally I think it rewards it's people fairly.
column13: If you don't like commercially focused companies then GE will not be for you. It's a very positive environment so if you are a glass half empty type of person you might feel uncomfortable. If you are a person that needs boundaries to be drawn for you then You may struggle.
column14: Keep focusing on the customer and the big problems...

column5: Great company; holding its own in the market
column12: I like the fact that they're located all over the world & can therefore appreciate having international colleagues & cultural exchanges. Also, for the most part, they're very conscious of employee/leadership development.
column13: Things change constantly, without the proper thorough follow through with & for employees. Hard to evolve professionally at times, as well, due to politics. At times, it appears as if everyone's out for themselves.
column14: Don't keep supposed leaders, simply because you "have no one else". Try to get to the heart of the matter & weed out the bad managers: listen to their (bad managers) subordinates & take action.

column12: Great leaders who drive real tangible change to keep the organization nimble and agile despite the staggering size of this corporation. It is almost a mini-universe in itself given the broad range of businesses the company operates. The fact that each of these businesses are among the top 3 in the world in their business segment shows how well the company is run.
column13: Challenges stemming out of sheer size of the corporation - duplication of effort, silo'ed operations, communication gaps.
column14: Do keep driving the simplification agenda - but keep your eyes and ears open. It is very easy to go to far with cost cutting.

column5: GE is a good place to work after college.
column12:
GE has a good name. 
Big Company with over 300,000 employees
Diverse businesses: Capital, Energy, Healthcare, Transportation and many more. 
Many locations: Connecticut, Ohio, Georgia, and many overseas.
column13:
Their leadership programs are not as flexible as other companies. 
You have to stay within one of their business. For example, if you're with Healthcare unit, then you will need to stay with healthcare for 2 years. You can not choose Energy for other rotation.
column14: Offer more flexibility. Give new hires and interns more opportunity and time to show their talents. Listen to what others have to say instead of just denying them.

column5: Fast paced workplace with unique opportunities and a focus on technology and innovation
column12:
Huge community of coworks that you can ask questions, share ideas and gain data/information. 
Strong focus on cross functional team work to achieve objectives.
column13:
Organization has become functional so at times people operate in silos only willing to do there particualR function and nothing more. 
Leadership could is not always forthcoming with performance feedback. Due to very fast pace environment we do not make the time to celebrate individual or group "wins"
column14: More focus on performance feedback, individual growth and succession planning. Finally, ensuring the time and effort is taken to recognize performance and celebrate wins

column12: Worldwide company, muti-business , good working environment, good benefits like company car, private pension, health insurance, frequent personal training. Good bonus linked with achieved goals.
column13: In Brazil, too much dependence of USA conditions and regulations, rules and demands.. Lack of agility in making some decisions due the distance and misknowledge of our current situation. Resistance in investing here due lack of trust in our economy and our complicated work relationships.
column14: Be aware of everything that is happenning in all companies areas, try to learn about other areas, invest in networking, best use all the available resources offered by the company, frequent search of new opportunities (COS).

column12: Great company, culture, opportunities, improvement and continuous growth, training, global reach, locations and work environment, great senior leaders, history and solid performances, EHS, digital and forward looking mindset.
column13: Salary, speed, sometimes hard to navigate as it's a massive global company, internal processes are sometimes slow or old, very complex environment in terms of the different verticals industrials + digital + capital/financial
column14: It's hard to advice a management in such a huge company, i think the distance between junior and senior is still too big, many of the infrastructures needs a refresh/upgrade, a lot we can do on brand awareness, digital, new media and social

column5: GE are not perfect but they are always trying to be better.
column12: GE pay above market salary and benefits, offer flexible working arrangements and up to 8 weeks of annual leave per year (5 weeks paid and 3 weeks unpaid). Employees are well looked after in great work facilities. Constant change results in lots of challenge and opportunity for new ideas.
column13: Change fatigue! Death by email. Career path is not always clearly defined in some divisions.
column14: Be brave! Make the tough decisions! Consider small, thoughtful gestures to support your staff on an on-going basis rather than assuming no news is good news.

column12: Very well established company with good internal processes. Managers treat people in a very human way, everyone is extremely friendly and helpful, great atmosphere to work in. Flexible work schedule and opportunities for growth. Extremely welcoming for first time job seekers, great coaching / teaching culture. Pays fair wages and good flexible benefits.
column13: The business is in decline, lot of pressure on saving money, sub-businesses get constantly re-organized. Lot of corporate silliness coming down from the higher management. Much 'pretend innovation' with effectively little change in overall outcomes. Getting into executive band is a brawl with occasional bloodshed, many of the execs have been in the company for way too long.
column14: Due to the size of the company senior executives are super disconnected from the actual operations and make decisions based on their executives' input that is often not honest/accurate. It would be high time to drain the swamp within the executive management - so much promised by so many, so little delivered..

column12: Work-life balance, good managment, comfortable office work, flexible working hours, u can find a work which u want to do, not oly from ur assesment leader
column13: No interesting work inside in intern position, nobody just want to give u real projects to work with. Only exel analysis or such kind of "Dirt work"
column14: I think u need to pay mare attention to low position, company hire a lot of interns and some managers just dont know how use them in correct way, just give them work which interns dont want to do, and its form a missmatch between what u expect after interview and reality at work.

column5: Worst company I have worked in in 25 years
column12:
Compensation was good
Vast resources
Interesting products
Looks good on CV
Some divisions treated well
column13:
Very political; as others have mentioned
Run by the HR department; who don't seem to like Humans.
Always short on enough resources to do the job properly and bleed the remaining team dry
Very stressful environment - 6 people off with stress out of 30 people in two years
Don't look after staff, treat them as commodities - staff not treated like humans
No reward for long hard hours
Unequal treatment of staff depending where you work
Told what to put in your staff's EMS (Appraisal)
Appraisal system just seems to be used to get shot of people who are deemed not to comply.
Management don't want to listen to ideas outside their own.
Poor life / work balance
Encouraged to be like a GE robot.
Full of all the write PR words but just don't live by them
column14:
Treat people well and with dignity and you will get more from them.
Listen to staff, they have a voice and most often know better at what's going on and how best to improve matters.
Don't destroy people's free will and ideas - let them flourish.
Ensure all divisions in GE are treated and managed the same.

column12: One of the worlds truly great companies to work for. If you're willing to go the extra mile, there are hardly any limits. It's providing excellent opportunities to advance and you get a chance to work with some of the best people (to any highly competitive standard)
column13:
Change is a constant, which is fine. But sometimes things change too quickly or for no obvious reason.
The company has become too complex: workflows, centers of excellence for (too) many specialist areas, approval over approval over approval
column14: De-complex the company. Let individual leaders, close to the customers make the decisions they need to be successful in their market place.

column5: The work experience with GE is simply amazing. I learned a lot working with GE.
column12:
1.To work with GE is a dream of many aspirants.
2.GE provides Learing and progressive work environment 
3.They provode lucrative facilities to their employees 
4.The higher management is supportive.
column13: As such there are no challenges to be faced when a team works with proper management nad planning.Further GE believes in customer satisfaction and delivery. To achieve these two goals, the team has to work rigorously no matter what kind of challenge needs to be faced,we wll definitely face and overcome that.
column14: Look around you, examine who is doing what and act accordingly.

column12: A culture rooted on integrity that keeps the balance and order to every day activity. Providing a safe environment to try new things, fail and learn.
column13: Change is the only constant, you must be efficient on what you do, with high emotional intelligence and resilient to take up on the many challenges and changes the company presents
column14: Strong strategies and leaders are required to keep focus on what is the core activity and value, to avoid losing attention and people productivity. We must feel, in spite the bad weather, we know what we are doing, as if we are navigating in calm waters.

column12:
- Great work atmosphere.. 
- Good company culture
- Excellent work life balance
- Generally very support management who is smart
column13:
- Sometimes there is a lot of work which one has to work through
- there is a quarterly pressure, expectation to make the numbers
- Some businesses can be driven by short term goals rather than more strategic goals
column14: I believe that over the next decade or so, talent retention will be critical to any company's survival. GE does an excellent job of attracting great candidates. If GE is able to retain a majority of these high flyers, GE will do very well as a company.

column12:
GE has a wide range of businesses with a diverse portfolio of products and service.
GE has a strong global presence.
GE is a highly respected company.
Past GE stock performance was a major advantage for employees but that has changed in the last several years.
column13: GE has terrible compensation plans, if any, for junior level and mid level employees. No bonuses were paid in my business. GE's stock price.
column14: Improve yearly employee review process and make available bonuses and other forms of compensation and recognition. Short term returns (job cuts, RIF, reducing facilities maintenance ...) in my business was choking out long term growth and limiting capabilities.

column5: Great company but demanding--are you ready for the long days?
column12: GE has an incredible employee base--bright, hard working, motiviated. The comapny is professional, image focused by supporting the right brands/solutions.
column13: Highly competitive. Little work - life balance despite them trying to promote one.
column14: Disappointed in the support my direct and skip level leader have given me in "finding my next role". The party line is we will support you finding your next role if you deliver..and after delivering for many years and being rated top talent amost each of those years....not seeing, feeling, or hearing the support to find my next role. Very disappointed in this.

column12:
The culture is surprisingly very good and quite open. You can go to anyone in the organization and ask for help or information and they will usually be ready to help.
A lot of people grow here from junior positions and the potential for growth is almost allways there (both internally and externally). 
There was many things you could learn here. And as a global company, the general processes are quite well managed and the company has resources to use new technologies.
I would recommend this for starting your carreer.
column13:
In some things it it huge corporation. Your local CEO has about six levels above him (plus vertical leaders etc.) and these people are rotating time to time so expect changes in management every few years and decisions from above that do not seem to make sense from local perspective.
The compensations are not that good, but as long as you are learning things that you can later sell elsewhere, why not :)

column5: good place to work if you like flexibility, less so - if you hate change
column12: great people, good work life balance, flexibility, good training if you're lucky to be put forward for the Crotonville leadership training
column13: it's an American firm, with lots of decision cascaded from the US, silos, decisions made always against the 'cycle' in terms of market trends and investment cycles.
column14: Be more aware of what people on the ground think, less politics, more action, aim to keep people motivated when the going gets tough. Constant chance in organisation is destructive. sadly GE always rhymes with change.

column12: They are not afraid to take chances or to challenge good people i.e. if a highly regarded employee is interested in moving into a new industry or function but don't have relevant experience they are willing to give them a chance to prove themselves.
column13: As with many large organisations the matrix management can be complicated and at times be overly bureaucratic. Its often a case of not what process you know but who you know in order to make things happen.
column14: Giving staff more of mandate and allowing greater autonomy would improve morale and also make things happen quicker and faster.

column12:
Tons of opportunity for those willing to make serious a serious commitment to the company and to their career. 

Many locations and different industries allows for continual new experiences.
column13:
Extreme amount of time preparing powerpoint presentations for majority of all internal meetings. 

High value within management placed upon those who develop internally through leadership programs such as FMP and CAS which makes it difficult for experienced hires to gain traction within the company. 

Limited ability to move from controllership roles into core finance.
column14:
Create cross functional and cross business employee reviews (session C) to facilitate movement of talent. 

Create more transparency into career movement opportunities.

column5: Great place to start your career, learn from their management best practices, but be ready to put in long hard hours
column12:
- Great in terms of recognition and normative rewards
- Easy access to multi-functional learning tools
- Great brand name that is globally recognized
column13:
- Pays salary below industry averages
- Benefits package is also lacking
- Lots of long hard work hours due to scattered global teams in different time zones
column14: Focus on being more selective of the quality of people you recruit, pay commensurately higher for quality personnel. Additionally focus on mitigating the effects of constant change down to the grass root levels.

column5: Best Class Company to Work with Great Leaders, Game Changers
column12: International Exposure, Globally Organized, Top Priority at EHS & Integrity, Customer Oriented, Respect all Cultures, A Company for Continuous Learning& Self Improvement, Localized Culture Driven
column13: Too bureucratic, Slow in Customer Survey Returns, Behind in Technological Improvements in Comparision to Competitors, Too Much Presentations Less Touchbase, Viewing the Business Only From Inside When Working for GE, Too Many E-mails in day to day work, Bounded with Procedures
column14: More touchbase to employees, View business insides,outsides from various perspectives, Less presentations more Simplified Procedures, Focus on TX business, Hiring great shiny younger generation is essential for future build up.

column5: Great company for making great things happen
column12: Challenges, volume and scope of roles is great, pushes you to change, be sharp and focused...leading edge... Inspiring colleagues and some exceptional leaders...executional excellence... Great minds... Excellent growth and development opportunities
column13: Change is constant, competitive, high expectations, forces you to really face your weaknesses and improve, if you don't drive achievements others won't do it for you... Processes, tools... Still authority focused...
column14: Speed up, delegate and empower regions and let regional leaders decide, be more present on the market to build the brand... Re-think inclusiveness culture as it's in the way of challenging status quo... Simplify... Simplify... Simplify

column12: Gives you the pros of a global company. It's huge, very diverse, and if you are interested in working with all levels and cultures, you have it. Also has the variety of products/businesses, so you can get a sneak peak in very different areas.
column13: Being huge and global has its disadvantages. Making decisions sometimes takes too long. Recent changes in management causes confusion and uncertainty inside and outside of the company. Not sure where it's headed.
column14: Layoffs are sometimes necessary. But it would be nice to see the logic behind... performance before location - as an example...

column5: great expertise centre, fun innovative place but sometimes more consideration to employees needed
column12: if you enjoy doing innovative things, it is a great place to be- new business ideas, innovative technology, progressive thinking, often elite teams
column13: It often happens that GE starts recruitment and kills it in the middle of the process. if you apply internally, you may harm your relations with the current manager. Staffing decisions are sometimes made without sufficient consideration for skills, fit into the position and emploeees career plans
column14: create and support clear career paths, give equal chances to people, irrespective of their origin and gender, consider employees ambitious and plans

column12: Great workplace environment, tons of opportunities within the company, matrixed organization allows you to interact with several different areas and levels of management. Overall, the company is great.
column13: Difficult to move issues forward, the decisions, even little ones, need to be approved by several people, what makes the processes very slow. HR is the slowest of all, and they are always ready to let an employee go to cover their backs for some mistake they've made.
column14: Use Fastworks as an actual framework to move the decisions faster, and not only a cute policy. HR should be the first in line.

column12: Great to be able to train myself for free to the new GE Digital & Industrial transformation ! Being able to be a leader in GE for transforming our way to communicate, work, and produce Predix solutions to internal and external customers is a great adventure.
column13: We work in a VUCA world, meaning we are confronting volatility, uncertainty, complexity and ambiguity. But this is a great challenge, and a new way of thinking & mindset
column14: make sure not to communicate about future solutions as if they were already available, clearly state was we propose and what we will propose

column5: Very caring company with great prospects!
column12:
Working for GE is like working with your family.
. Value their employees opinion
. Incentives, including; employee of the month, free lunches, prizes (chocolates, wine etc)
. Close working relationships
. Progression opportunities
. Private Healthcare
. Generous Pension
. Company cars (career band dependent)
. Core beliefs for all GE business worldwide
. Monthly conference calls to track figures
. Monthly 1 to 1s
. Biweekly team meetings
column13:
. Training isn't always given promptly
. Some managers seem to have favourites which is noticeable throughout the team
. Bonus' and money incentives aren't provided to all employees
column14: Ensure all members of the teams are given equal respect and opportunities.

column12: GE is offering a wide variety of Leadership programs that accelerate your career through exploring different businesses in different locations globally and get the right exposure that enhance your skill set and accelerate your career within GE
column13:
As any other multinational , the company get affected with the economic situation globally and accordingly the businesses get impacted negatively.
Very complicated organization structure that takes sometime to understand it and digest the way GE works.
column14: Keep an eye on the talented employees in the company in remote areas with no senior management presence not to only focus on the main regional Hubs.

column12: Great Insurance, flexible hours, great people, keeping us in the know - as much as possible.
column13: The work keeps getting piled on. We are all busting our butts to keep up and there is no relief in site. What stinks is hourly people are working just as hard as salaried people to keep this company afloat, but when it comes time for bonuses - hourly people do not receive bonuses. Somehow that just does not seem right.
column14: It's tough right now, but I think you guys are doing a great job trying to turn us around.

column12:
Ample opportunities given to employees to showcase their leadership abilities.
Good work life balance.
Employee health and family concerns are given huge importance.
Huge emphasis on Six sigma.
column13:
Software division is not at par with the engineering division.
As it is a huge company, people tend to get lost somewhere in the middle, so HR should have more interactions regularly.
As huge emphasis is given on Six Sigma, sometimes projects are completed in a haste for the sake of achieving six sigma goals
column14: Keep up the good work, but more one on one interactions to understand the need of each employee is needed.

column5: Not what it used to be for HR professionals... beware
column12:
Smart people
Variety of experiences
Job security
Location... presence in many different locations
column13:
Tactical, execution oriented... consumed with executing on GE Corporates initiatives
Poor financial perks... stock isn't worth anything, increases are minimal
Lots of relocations and you lose significant money each time (promotional increases lag loss on real estate)
Top, significant HR jobs all occupied by males... and most are from outside the US working in the US
Poor work life balance... they are flexible but the reality is that the company is so cost focused there is always more work than any one person can handle
HR processes are centralized leaving very little room to actually develop anything significant
Bureaucratic... slow moving ... risk adverse
column14: Catch up with the times... what made you successful in the past isn't going to keep you successful in the future. You are losing good talent at an alarming rate. GE is no longer the sought after employer like it was with HR Master's degree students.

column12: Extremely customer and process oriented. Safety first. Take care of employees. Dynamic business: the employee has true opportunities to take accountability and to promote according to meritocracy.
column13:
Firefighting (lack of an structured long term vision).
Very difficult to get an international career as an expat despite your capabilities.
Yearly feedback too much based on perceptions of the current management team so promotions into management positions depend on a ver close environment wheren relationships play a key role. Not always meritocracy is the basis of promotion in the local environment.
column14: Year feedback cause frustration on some employees due to they are very subjective

column12: Very good company to work for! One of the best out there! Company culture is awesome, good benefits. Opportunity to grow. I have suffered a low key bullying that didn't turn out to be a serious issue and once reported it was acted upon quickly and justice were made. They really take serious on this sort of harassment.
column13: I don't have any downsize in my experience at General Electric Intelligent platforms. Overall it worked well for me. I have had one of a kind experience overall. Better place I have ever worked in UK.
column14: Train successors well.

column5: Great place to work! Highly recommend it.
column12:
Seasoned management. Great people. Walks the talk. Exposed and enacted values align very well. 
Great culture. Very good benefits. Overall, great company to work for.
column13: Great benefits overall. However, healthcare benefits are not the best. New employees currently get only 2 weeks vacation. However, this is changing from 2012 onwards. It us going to be 3 weeks from 2012 onwards.
column14: Need to be little bit more aggressive in entering new markets. GE should continue to innovative to stay ahead of the competition. I would like see some more breakthroughs from GE.

column5: Not bad if you want to play the political game
column12:
Stable company
Great name recognition for your resume
Ability to move around once you get your foot in the door
column13:
Poor health care benefits....very costly
Very political environment, you have to be careful whose toes you step on
It's all about networking and making sure you are in good with the people who can help you in the long run
HR is totally clueless and won't help so be careful what you share with them because they will definitely use it against you
column14: Let the managers who know what is going on make some decisions. More oversight on who you put in Human Resources. It's a shame when you are too fearful to come forward about things that are unethical or unfair because you know the HR Department will give you a black mark and make sure you are targeted in the future, which includes preventing you to move up the ladder or to other areas.

column5: An exeptional place to start work...
column12: Great ethos, a definate work hard play hard culture. The benchmark in setting a simple and well articulated strategy. The place was an absolute meritocrasy and the Financaial Management Program is possibly the best graduate training program in the world. Embrassed innovation and technology early and has reaped rewards.
column13: Face time culture, brutal yearly review, Needs to find itself aftewr Welch years. GE hides is light internationally sometimes and has lost that "innovator" halo affect it once had
column14: Be less focused on hitting your numbers and more on the company culture

column5: Great place to be challenged professionally.
column12: Ge is a fantastic company to develop your leadership. It is strongly transparent and compliance. The customersecond are really the focus.
column13: I can't say if it is general. But the benefits promised at the beginning of hiring process is not entirely supplied when you are in.Maybe due the nature of business, there is not a focus on priorities. Everything is priority and it changes all the time. Lack of responsibility role definition.
column14: It should be take care of the career plan of some employees in order to avoid regrettable losses.

column12:
* It's easy to move around within the company as long as you're in good standing (the vast majority of engineers are).
* The company is amazingly open: every week Larry Page and Sergey Brin host what's called TGIF where food, beer, wine, etc. is served, a new project is presented, and afterward there's an open forum to ask the executives anything you want. It's truly fair game to ask anything, no matter how controversial, and frequently the executives will be responsive.
* No, nobody cares if you use an iPhone, Facebook, shop with Amazon, stream using Spotify, or refuse to use Google+. The company is amazingly open and flexible.
column13:
* The quality of the engineers is possibly dropping, but possibly not. It's hard to get real metrics, because as the absolute number of people grows, naturally the number of bad apples grows; as a percentage it's supposedly the same as it ever was, but with larger numbers of poorer quality engineers it just _feels_ like things might be changing for the worse.
* Also with growth means more internal-confidential data leaks (again, because of the raw numbers of people) -- product announcements being ruined, etc. That means the company has to be tighter-lipped internally to avoid leaks, which makes things less open. It's still an amazingly open place, but less so than it was even a couple years ago. The good thing is they recognize it and actively look to improve things because they know how important it is to keep the good culture.
column14: Keep the focus on the user. Everything else will follow.It's still an amazingly open place, but less so than it was even a couple years ago. The good thing is they recognize it and actively look to improve things because they know how important it is to keep the good culture.

column5: GE My 15 yrs..A Great company to work with in spite all odds
column12: Great company to work with , Ethical company , offers opportunity to travel all over the world. You enjoy your work . Time flexibility and employees are treated with respect. pay on time .No short cuts.. when it comes to EHS rule is simple and straight.. employee safety is key . flexible working hours.
column13: There is no shortage of benefits if you are in E Band or above however below this is pathetic like in GE if you join fresh next 15-25 years till you are EB you will not see a Business class seat in plane. will travel in economy class .. not a good pay package meeting GE name and profit it makes...job security is not there. Each cost cutting is for below EB employees..As no one will bring a cost cutting idea for E Band. When i joined in 2001 it was a better place to work each year some or other benefit has disappeared.
column14: Changing your hiring process.. right now its linked to hiring managers nationality or his manger.. so a Egyptian will hire only Egyptian .. second since now organisation is flat so we need people with experience .. you can not shift communication gays to do Sourcing or facility manager to do Global logistics.. all this biased and wrong hiring need to change.other is Medical benefit in MEA .. GE is below par with regional companies..HR is paid to cut cost for lower band employees and keep EB happy . no cut for EB..

column12: Large blue chip company, huge legacy and learning potential
column13: over-reaching in the past and a bad reading of the markets are leading to the current spasms - reduction in force, selling off businesses
column14: as the company that invented the "lightbulb" moment of innovation we are at risk of losing that by focusing on short term cash, cash, cash. Yes its understood its what's needed for the business right now, but give some hope at the end of the tunnel that we are still innovating - so that the company can have more flashes of inspiration...

column5: OK, mediocre, luke-warm, average place to work
column12: big knowledge base on their beloved business processes, might be rewarded if you make work your life and make the right connections I'm told, can really learn a lot about big business if you want
column13: lots of corporate 'overhead' meaning they always have some new complex process or initiative that you'll need to learn and use while you could be getting real work done and then they go and change it next year, describing the company as bureaucratic is overly generous, spending way too much time on things like getting a computer fixed because that's 'how GE does it'
column14: Where to start? The company's lost 60+% of its value since Immelt took over and it's not just because of the economy. Over-leveraged deals, bad assets, employees who feel taken for granted, overly complicated business practices, processes that stifle innovation and creativity, etc. are just the reasons that immediately come to mind.

column5: GE-Just a Big Name---Worst Experience Ever-RUN!
column12:
GE has a reputation for being able to get talented people (the draw is the name)
People are nice to work with
Benefits ok compared to other places
column13:
False promises-promote work/life balance to get you in the door
Lack of professionalism and expertise of Senior Leadership
Low Salaries compared to competitors---no incentives---no bonuses
Unethical, cut-throat, throw you "under-the-bus" culture
Insensitive to employees needs and recommendations for improvement
Promote people without backgrounds to positions and then pay for them to get the qualifications later
Typically work 10 to 12 hr days and weekends
Lack of employee recognition and use of Awards Recognition program
Lack of career growth opportunities
Favoritism 
Unfair pay with women
Big salary discrepancies
HR is a joke---lack of concern for employees--HR reps rotate frequently and promoted often
High turn-over
Company lacks innovation
Company is behind the times in comparison with competitors
Lack of training opportunities for employees- only for the "chosen"
column14:
Take accountability for loss of good talent (hold HR and Senior Management responsible for loss)
Listen to employees
Stop making false promises to get employees in the door
Hire competent Senior Leadership
Create a program centered around employee retention and create growth opportunities to keep employees long-term
Honesty is the best policy

column12:
It is true that GE offers world class training and development to build your skills and career. I have worked in the past at other Fortune 500 companies and in comparison, every GE training session has been a valuable learning. 
Working with bright people across the globe. Strong collaboration to not only help you succeed but solve problems.
column13: Highly matrix, complex making it challenging to change things such as processes or getting simple things done.

1. Provides trainings necessary for the individuals

column5: GE as a company to work for

column12: Somewhat flexible working hours (depends on teamleader). I liked that I had a lot of foreign colleauges, so the atmosphere is really multinational and I could use my English.

column5: The best company to work. your life changes
column12: Continuously learning, truly democratic, completely process driven, highest level of integrity, full freedom, good work culture, good work life balance
column13: Lot of conflict between cross functional team and lot of beurocasy in company. The acquired companies are not completely merged with parent company so people still behave like they work for different companies. Only original GE people gets advantages
column14: Don't judge people based on their religion or community. Give equal chance to other people also who may have not spend long tenure with GE but still have the capablity

column12: Good company to work for. Challenging environment. Excellence in Finance. Young people looking for improvements everywhere. Possibility to work with different businesses in the same company.
column13: Balance between personal and professional life, overtime is high. Too much bureaucracy in processes those should be more simple.
column14: It´s hard to manage a big company like GE, I just think the process of M&A could be done better. There are some technologies and processes from the companies bought by GE those are better than the ones GE uses, most of them are taken for granted.

column12: Carrer development, benefits, constant information sharing (all the information about company are available), leadership programs, lots of kind of bussiness available to work on (renewable energy, healthcare, current, etc), affinity groups (GLBTA, African, Veterans, etc).
column13: No work limit, difficulty to have a good work load (very often it is possible to see employees overloaded), leaders not prepared (i believe this is a personal opinion, once, I came from Alstom and even after the acquisition my leaders remained the same).
column14: Evaluate the leaders constantly and be closer to the workers to understand the real needs

column12: Large business with opportunities for both lateral and vertical movement. Though the company is large, teams are organized into manageable sizes and cross-functional communication is usually easy.
column13: Sometimes subject to the bureaucracy typically associated with a large company. Communication is often slow (both from management to employees and laterally across businesses). Leveraging of resources across divisions is not fully utilized.
column14: Ensure that individuals and resources are utilized to their full potential. Use experts across businesses and P&L's when necessary, and allow skilled employees to work on multiple projects.

column12: A broad range of businesses provided flexibility for movement between roles. The senior leaders of the company are also world class.
column13: Promotions and success in the company to senior levels can be highly dependent upon flexibility (e.g. moving more for different jobs increases your likelihood to be promoted).
column14: The leadership teams can continue to work on their global expansion plan and building a brand around the world. GE is very well known in the US, but does not have a strong reputation in Europe or other places around the globe.

column12: Excellent coaching from the reporting managers and other senior members of the team, high level of autonomy given to the employees even if you are starting at GE.
column13: There are not really any cons that could be mentioned but maybe the culture doesnt suit some people which makes it a disadvantage for them
column14: none that I can think of. senior appointments are made mostly based on meritocracy (as far as I analyse it) so there is a very good reason why people are where they are. decisions and strategies have always been good so far

column5: 125 year history means zilch in the current environment
column12: The culture, people, global scale and opportunities (albeit reducing) are some of the best reasons to work at General Electric.
column13: The fatigue associated with 3+ years of huge change and uncertainty about the business and individuals' roles make up a big part of the downside of working at GE (but also can lead to new opportunities for those who persevere).
column14: Get to where you're going with the Company as soon as possible. Continue to deliver transparency, support and respect to those impacted by change.

column5: GE is a great company to build management, quality and leadership abilities
column12:
I was very proud to work with this company. The best part of C&I was intelligent, savvy, talented people in global environment that you felt excited to work with every day. We always had new challenges to tackle so it was never boring. Change was part of the culture and not something to fear - it was something to capitalize on. Excellent processes and tools were available to complete job and function responsibilities. We had fire fighting just as everyone does but there was also time and rewards to taking the time to blow up processes and streamline everyday responsibiities using six sigma. There was good balance between team and individual goals and objectives.

Fantastic support was provided from GE Corporate on management training, online tools, and knowledge sharing. Even with so much change in acquisitions and divestitures, the GE umbrella felt stable and highly respected.

Feedback was part of the culture and performance appraisals were completed on time and were reviewed by top management. Session C data was proactively used to develop people and effectively utilize internal pipelines of talent. Managers and executives were very open to questions and assisting in grooming the next leaders. Opportunities were usually available for those who actively pursued them.
column13:
Learning the big GE world is a challenge and occasionally overwhelming to handle everything coming at you. Work/life balance was sometimes nonexistent but always seemed to work out well in the end. Pay was competitive but you must stay on the fast track for promotions to really drive salary up, otherwise the merit increases kept you whole but you never really got ahead with compression happening more than what we would have liked. 

Losing other GE businesses was hard because even though you understand the corporate strategy behind selling off the pieces, the people leaving felt like family.
column14:
Understanding the global marketplace with global commitments, remember that GE is a US legacy as truly part of our country's DNA and that history made GE as great as it is. First priority should be US focused growth and development.

Always appreciate your Highly Valued people who are your anchors and will be consistently, efficiently contributing day after day. These folks sometimes get lost in the shuffle of effectively managing your Least Effective individuals and building (and eventually losing) your Top Talent.

column5: If not hired into a program, tough to advance
column12:
Diverse company, lots of businesses within to interact with.
Having "GE" on the resume looks good to outside parties or in conversation.
column13:
Changed to a horrible healthcase plan the year after no raises were given.
Almost all internal postings at the midrange to higher levels prefer some GE program, this limits opportunities to those who just came to the company for a standard job.
Corporate politics.
Promotions seem to be given to people that do more talking than working.
Most management heads admit they leave hard working employees in the same position, rather than promote.
Annual evaluation process is long and repetitive, once it is done there is no further feedback given to employees on how all the information is used or processed
column14:
Reduce the work that goes into the annual review process and focus more on real action items. 
Upper management needs to have more visibility into what the employees are actually doing.

column12:
Core value - integrity...everything flows from there.
Stable and profitable, lots of opportunity to learn about business, marketing, finance. 
Lots of opportunity to learn and grow if you seek out the opportunity. Lots of networking opportunities.
column13:
It's a big company - change can sometimes be slow. Sometimes it seems like there are more reviewers and approvers than people creating and servicing a product. - keeps us safe I suppose.
Pockets of innovation, but most new growth comes from acquisition.
column14: Connect everyone with the customer, fully adopt lean software development

column5: Company needs makeover from the top down.
column12: Great people and access to global markets. Good learning ground for young talent. Customers want to believe. Employees still care about the company.
column13: No longer a meritocracy. Everyone is in survival mode. Leaders are insulated from their people. Lack of common vision and strategy buy in. Loyaly is not a core value. No one ever retires from the company. Losing competitive edge and eroding core values. Too focused on trying to influence government policy vs making real profit growth for shareholders.
column14: Changes are needed at the BOD level as well as with senior leadership. Focus on generating new margin dollars vs simply expanding margin %. Re-engage leaders to develop strategy and re-create change acceleration culture. Collapse the inner circle and break up the larger divisions. More P&ls are good for innovation and growth. Return to meritocracy

column5: I am very fortunate to have had so many great opportunities within a short amount of time.
column12:
- Great place to learn and develop, especially as an early career professional
- Many resources are available to develop
- Team members are extremely bright, inspiring, and willing to share knowledge
- Easy to network with people from other parts and businesses of GE
column13:
- tough to be agile when so large
- harder to move up because there are many layers
- depending on your role and/or business, can start to feel very stagnant in career path
- salary is lower than competitors

column12:
1. nice campus
2. good gym and play room
3. good transportation service
4. good canteen (multiple options available)
5. Brand Name
column13:
1. less salary
2. older technology
3. bad management
4. unrealistic deadlines 
5. tools so old they makes you feel like that you belong to stone age.
6. less coding ,most of time gets consumed in following the process.
7. due to flexi hours, people stay more .work which could get finished by 6 ,will get finished at 
10 ,12 or 3'o clock in the night.
8. Hike depends on what people think of you ,and not on how much you have worked .
9. Too much politics .
10. Too much work pressure sometimes .


if you are comfortable in working in "notepad" and using "printf" for debugging .Then this is THE company for you , because its their bread and butter.
column14: Introduce better tool, to make employee life better .

column12: Pay and benefits are very competitive for engineers. Safety is priority number one on manufacturing and other activities. Owns and develops technology, even has an (albeit small) R&D department. Core business is profitable and with very high grow potential. Very high capex in the last decade.
column13: Expect to work long and hard. Working environment can be challenging and demanding. Aggressive feedback (yelling, name calling, etc) from management at every level not uncommon. Competition from all over the world can challenge the profitability.
column14: Keep on working on improving culture and environment.

column12:
Good Pay
Good Management 
Supportive environment
Various programs
Leader Roundtables to keep you update
column13:
Matrix management, culture difference and many people ignore that.
Small task can die within loops
HR are often not aware off some key things
column14: Please keep the benefit up, political within the regions should be avoided for more productivity. GE have genious people working for them its just to align them to be on the right track. But over all love and honored to be part of GE and will stay this forever in my experience as memorable experience. Thanks GE.

column12:
- Good environment to work - People are usually friendly and always want to help when its needed
- Excellent Leadership programs - Several programs to help accelerate career
- Well defined career path - You can see where you can go and how long it will take
column13:
-Because of the size of the company, bureaucracy is consistent, even after several attempts to make it simpler.
- Constant changes on leadership and acquisitions make the structure of reporting really difficult
column14: Give importance to people that execute and deliver, not to people that do good power point presentations.

column5: u can work here if u dont get any other place
column12: positive points are flexible working hours and weekends off. generally u dont have to work more than 9 hours in a day. reasonably competitive pay compared to other IT companies. reasonably good canteen facilities, subsidized food and transportation.
column13: poor job security, bottom 10 - 20% or so are axed every year. american policies are not sensitive to indian culture. priority of procedure and policies over people. people are treated more as 'labour' rather than 'talent'. is not able to attract highly qualified people from top schools nor is it able to create an encouraging atmosphere for the highly qualified people it does manage to attract. too much peer competition and evaluation is not able to create atmosphere of collaboration and teamwork. american policy provides too much encouragement to women who may otherwise be incompetent or not so deserving. funny work culture and mind games. incompetent HR.
column14: mediocracy breeds mediocracy. thomas edison definitely was a great inventor but the company is definitely not following in his footsteps. instead of chanting about innovation, make it happen!

column5: Great learning experience in some things, boring in others
column12: It looks great on your resume, and the company is really a great place to work, but you should know what you want or you might end up working on things you don't like.
column13: Not much to do, if you're looking to be a software developer you won't have too many opportunities to program and code
column14: Give the interns more work! For me it was sometimes like a vacation, I would have liked to do more things and to do more things related to my major

column5: Relaxed atmosphere but poor management (industrial Solutions)
column12: A company for women. Flexible on working hours. Lots of opportunities in different countries. Stable environment, not stressful. Compensation and benefits are average. Atmosphere is relaxed. Innovation is not promoted, but it is supported if you are willing to do better, there is plenty of space to be creative and to perform.
column13: A lot of slackers in the organization, no common targets, customer is the last, ineffective management. People with real potential will not get higher, management is awarding seniority over performance. A lot of leaders have seen just Ge in their working life, resulting in an environment poor of ideas. There is never a responsible if things are going wrong. Leaders are working less than teammates, using home office for unofficial holidays
column14: More Simplification and less slackers. Clear goals and feddback on results

column12: GE is a Top company in many fields, it is very respectful with people, it has a lot of values and opportunities for the people. GE is one of the most inclusive and open work environments you can find in a good company in the United States.
column13: Sometimes the management ideals are not the same from country to country, the tropicalized ideals tends to happen.
column14: GE Management should take more involvement about the offshore engineering centers outside of USA, many things tends to happen that are difficult to escalate to USA.

column5: Awsome company with great opportunities to train yourself
column12:
1. Good working environment
2. Freedom of expression
3. Career Opportunities
4. Visionary executive leadership
column13:
1. Little differentiation in the role model and solid contributions
2. Too much process focused on several trivial things makes progress extremely slow
3. Compensation on the lower side but benefits and exposure do compensate to some extent
column14: Try going back to Jack's era and apply some of the performance management techniques. The company needs a serious look at differentiating Role model vs Solid contributions. Remove the fat which has built over a period of time.

column5: positive and constantly being pushed to better myself.
column12: Training g courses and learning programs constantly pushed on employees enable professional growth. Most are relevant and really do help
column13: getting so big you no longer speak to anybody -- "workflow" procedures dictate all purchasing, decision making activities, contracts. Very cumbersome and time delaying to accounts
column14: allow us folks at customer level to interact with customer and make our decisions with accounts. Rather than "I have to get to you" meaning, I need somebody else's approval before I can authorize anything

column5: Global Corporate Giant with Advantages and Disadvantages
column12: Lots of exposure if you want it. Many resources to help you grow. Learning, HR. Support and giving the opportunity to move around the world and meet some great people. GE could be a country by itself.
column13: Constantly changing corporate environment. You need to understand this to be able to move with the company and grow with it.
column14: More visibility to what the company is doing. Different parts of the business need to do things alike more. they look at things differently and do some things differently

column12: great company, treat interns as normal employees, challenging work everyday, push you learn how to be efficient and minimize errors in a high pressure environment
column13: sometimes may need to work a bit too much, work late especially during quarterly closing, not so much activities within the company as everybody has tons of work to do
column14: if you are a workaholic or love working under pressure, this would be the best choice, wage is pretty competitive, but from the balance of life point of view, may not have too much leisure time

column12:
The always steep learning curve. I enjoy taking new and challenging assignments in this company.
This company also offers flexibility of switching to different jobs within the company.
People are very nice to each other.
column13:
GE is a bit too big and sometimes not as competent as smaller companies in decision making.
GE is
column14: Run like small companies. Currently too much efforts spent in internal pitch prep and management review. Should spend more time externally with clients and suppliers.

column12: Ge provides an excellent atmosphere to grow your career and learn best practices. The training is second to none and I would recommend the company to anyone.
